oṁ āḥ hūṁ
slob mas kyang*/ a ho ma hA su khaM/ zhes brjod cing myang ngo*/ /
The disciples should say a ho mahā sukhaṃ and taste it.

de ltar byang sems mgrin pa'i lam brgyud/ rtsa gnas thams cad du son cing khyab pas bde ba chen po'i ye shes bskyong ba'i mos pa dang*/ ngag gi dri ma dag / gsang ba'i dbang thob/ lam rang lus thabs ldan bsgom pa la dbang*/ 'bras bu gsung rdo rje longs sku 'grub pa'i nus pa khyad par can bzhag pa'i mos pa mdzod/

Consider that in this way, the bodhichitta passes through your throat. It reaches all the stationary channels and fills them, giving rise to the wisdom of great bliss. The impurities of your speech are purified. You receive the secret empowerment. You are empowered to practice the path of skillful means, relying on your own body, and the extraordinary potential to accomplish the result, vajra speech, the body of perfect enjoyment, is established within you.
yang*/ bla ma'i thugs ka nas ye shes kyi rig ma gzugs dang lang tshon phun sum tshogs pa zhig byung nas/ khyed rang rnams la phyag rgya'i dngos grub kyi don du gtad pa'i mos pa mdzod/
Again, Consider that from the teacher’s heart center a wisdom consort, of perfect form and youthfulness, appears and confers on you the accomplishment of mudrā.
dga' ster gnas ste lha mo ni/ / sna tshogs gzugs can yid 'ong ma/ / khyer cig khyer cig sems dpa' che/ / khyer la mchod pa rtag tu gyis/ / zhes rig ma'i gzugs brnyan gtad/

The goddess who bestows joy, who bestows the state [of great bliss], The lady of beauty in different forms— Take her, take her, great hero, Take her and always venerate her. With this, show the image of the consort.

khyed rang rnams rdo rje 'chang chen por gsal ba la/ da lta gtad pa'i rig pa de nyid yum rdo rje snyems ma'i ngo bor gnas pa/ mkha' gsang byin gyis brlabs pa la sogs pa 'du shes gsum gyi sgo nas rjes su chags pa'i sbyor bas snyoms par zhugs pas/ byang sems gnas bzhir babs pa ste yas babs dang*/ ldog pa'i rim pas mas brtan gyi dga' bzhi nyams su myong bas rang rig bde stong brjod bral la mnyam par bzhag /

Visualizing yourselves as Vajradhara, enter into union with this consort that I am now showing you, who is by nature Vajragarvā, maintaining the three perceptions beginning with blessing the secret space.[16] As a result, the bodhichitta flows into the four centers, {70} and you experience the four joys in descending and ascending order. Through this, remain in meditative equipoise in natural awareness, the inexpressible bliss-emptiness.
des shes rab ye shes kyi dbang thob/ yid kyi dri ma dag / lam gzhan lus shes rab pho nya'i lam bsgom pa la dbang*/ 'bras bu thugs rdo rje chos kyi sku 'grub pa'i nus pa bzhag pa'i mos pa mdzod/

Consider that with this you receive the wisdom empowerment. The impurities of the mind are purified. You are empowered to practice the path of the wisdom consort, relying on another’s body, and the potential to accomplish the result, the vajra mind, the body of truth, is established within you.

de ltar dbang gsum pa'i skabs su nyams su myong ba dpe'i ye shes de nyid/ don gyi gnas lugs rig pa rang bzhin gyi ngo bo 'dus ma byas pa 'khor 'das thams cad kyi srog tu gnas pa de rang ngo tshul bzhin shes pas glo bur bag chags kyi dri ma sangs te/ bral 'bras mngon du byed pa ste/ sangs rgyas thams cad kyi chos kyi sku rang rig gcer mthong du ngo sprad pa'i mos pas lus gnad lta stangs sems dus gsum rnam rtog gi spro bsdus ma bslad par rang rig bde stong ma bcos pa'i ngang du mnyam par 'jog par zhu/

The illustrative wisdom experienced in this way during the third empowerment is the nature of awareness, the ultimate way things are. Its essence is uncompounded; it is present as the vital force of the whole of samsara and nirvana. Recognizing it correctly as one’s own nature purifies the stains of adventitious habitual tendencies and leads to realization of the resultant divestment.[17] Considering that you have been introduced to your own awareness, seen nakedly, the truth body of all the buddhas, please settle in meditative equipoise, adopting the correct physical posture and the right gaze, with your minds in the uncontrived state of awareness, bliss-emptiness, untainted by the proliferation and dissolution of conceptual thoughts related to the past, present, and future.
ye shes 'di ni ches phra zhing*/ / rdo rje nam mkha'i dkyil lta bu/ / rdul bral mthar phyin zhi ba nyid/ / khyod kyi pha ni khyod nyid do/ /
This primordial wisdom is extremely subtle, Adamantine, like the midst of space, Free of defilement, ultimate, the state of peace; You are your own father.[18]

des sgo gsum gyi dri ma dag / dbang bzhi pa thob/ lam phyag rgya chen po bsgom pa la dbang*/ 'bras bu ye shes rdo rje ngo bo nyid sku thob pa'i nus pa khyad par can bzhag pa'i mos pa mdzod/ mthar slar yang mos gdung drag po mdzad pa'i rkyen gyis/ rtsa ba'i bla ma rdo rje 'chang chen po de nyid dgyes zhing brtse ba'i nyams kyis bde ba chen po'i rang bzhin 'od kyi phung por zhu/ khyed rang rnams kyi dbu gtsug nas sib kyis thim pas bla ma'i thugs dang rang sems dbyer med rtsa bral lhun grub chen po'i ngang du bzhag ste/ bla ma'i sku gsung thugs kyi byin rlabs zhugs pa'i mos pa mdzod/ rol mos byin dbab/

Consider that with this the impurities of your body, speech, and mind are purified. You have received the fourth empowerment. You are empowered to practice the path of the Great Seal, and the extraordinary potential to attain the result, adamantine primordial wisdom, the body of the essential nature, is established within you. Finally, consider that as a result of your fervent devotion, the root teacher, the great Vajradhara, looking pleased and loving, melts into a mass of light, the nature of great bliss. It dissolves through the crown of your head, and you settle in the baseless state of the great spontaneous presence, the teacher’s mind and your mind inseparable. Consider that the blessings of the teacher’s body, speech, and mind have entered you. Play music to accompany the descent of blessings.

de nas 'jug sgo'i spyi dbang gi rim pa legs par grub pa yin/ da grub thob brgyad cu rtsa bzhi'i byin rlabs rnams chabs cig tu sgrub par byed pa la thugs mos 'di bzhin du mdzod/ de'ang snang gzhi mdun gyi maN+Dal 'di nyid dag pa ye shes kyi zhing khams rgya khyon tshad med pa phyi rol srung ba'i 'khor lo gzhom du med pas yongs su bskor ba'i snying po/ dur khrod rol pa'i gzhal med khang bkod pas khyad par 'phags pa lha rdzas kyi nyer spyod mtha' klas pas brgyan pa'i nang du lte bar seng khri pad+ma nyi zla'i gdan la rtsa ba'i bla ma rdo rje 'chang gi rnam par bzhugs pa/ de'i mdun nas brtsams te g.yas bskor du rim pa bzhin/ grub pa'i dbang phyug brgyad bzhugs pa ni/

The stages of the general entrance empowerment have now been properly completed. Next, to receive the blessings of the eighty-four siddhas all together, consider the following. {71} The support for the visualization, the mandala in front, is a vast, boundless pure wisdom buddha field, surrounded outside by an impenetrable protection circle. At its heart is the measureless palace of a manifested charnel ground, extraordinary in its layout, decorated with infinite divine offerings. Inside it, in the center, is a seat consisting of a lion throne, lotus, sun, and moon, on which is your root teacher, Vajradhara. Starting from in front of him, and in successive order clockwise, are eight lords of the siddhas:

ri dwags kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i 'phags pa'i gdan la/ grub pa'i slob dpon chen po lU yi pa/ rgya gar gyi A tsar+Ya nus ldan gyi cha byad sku mdog sngo skya cung zad skem pa'i tshul can/ ral pa'i thor tshugs cung zad dang bcas shing ras kyi smad dkris gsol ba/ sku'i mdun phyogs su nya'i rgyu lto spungs pa las phyag gis blangs te gsol ba'i tshul can zhabs phyed skyil gyis bzhugs pa/

On an antelope-skin[19] seat is the great accomplished master Lūyipa, dressed in the attire of a powerful Indian āchārya. His body is light blue in color, and he has a slightly emaciated appearance. His hair is partly tied in a topknot, and he is wearing a cotton dhoti. In front of him is a meal of heaped-up fish entrails, which he appears to be taking with his hand and eating. He is seated with his legs half-crossed.
rin po che'i khri la grub chen lI la pa mi bdag gi cha byad dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs chags pa/ dar gyi na bza' dang rin po che'i dbu rgyan mgul rgyan la sogs pa rgyan thams cad kyis spras pa/
On a jeweled throne is the great siddha Līlapa, dressed in royal attire, his complexion white tinged with red. He is adorned with silken garments and all the ornaments—crown, necklace, and so forth.

kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i phags pa'i gdan la rje btsun rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug chen po'i rwa pa'am bi rU pa sku mdog smug nag sbom zhing thung la gsus khyim che ba/ dbu skra co bregs la me tog gi 'phreng bas brgyan pa/ spyan lta stangs 'phur tshugs su gzigs pa/ phyag g.yas sdigs mdzub nam mkhar gdeng pa/ phyag g.yon pa men gyi rwa zhal bdud rtsi'i gang ba/ sha na'i gos kyi 'doms dkris gru gsum can zhabs rol pa'i stabs kyis bzhugs shing*/ g.yon gyi phyogs nas mkha' 'gro zhing gi rnal 'byor ma mi mo'i tshul can gyis bdud rtsi'i bum pa 'dzin pas mchod pa/

On an antelope-skin seat is the revered great lord of yogins, Birvapa or Virūpa. He is dark brown, short and fat, with a large belly. His shortish, curly hair is decorated with a garland of flowers. He is looking with his eyes gazing fixedly. His right hand is raised to the sky in the threatening gesture; his left hand holds a decorative horn cup filled with nectar. He is wearing a triangular hemp skirt and sitting with his legs in the posture of royal ease. To his left is a yoginī from the ḍākinīs’ realm, appearing as a maiden, holding a vase of nectar and offering it to him.

Dom+b+hi he ru ka sku mdog dkar dmar rus pa'i rgyan drug gis brgyan pa/ sbrul reg pa'i dug can gyis rgyan du mdzad cing*/ mthong ba'i dug can lcag gi tshul du bsnams pa/ khas rlangs kyi dug can bdun gyis dbu'i steng du gdengs kar byas shing*/ stag mo 'jigs su rung bar chibs shing*/ sku'i brla g.yon pa'i steng nas gsang ba'i yum g.yung mo rnal 'byor ma mdzes shing lta bas mi ngoms pa pad+ma can gyi mtshan nyid ldan pas 'khyud cing bde ba mchog la dgyes dgu rol pa/

Ḍombi Heruka is white in color, tinged with red, and adorned with the six bone ornaments. He is further ornamented with snakes whose touch is poisonous {72} and holds a whip in the form of a snake, venomous to behold. His head is hooded by seven snakes with noxious breath. He is riding a fearful tigress. On his left thigh is his secret consort, a lower-caste yoginī, who is so beautiful one can never tire of looking at her. She bears the marks of a padminī consort. She is embracing him and delighting with him in the supreme bliss.

kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa'i stan la sha ba ri pa sku mdog nag po/ spyan 'bru tshugs su gzigs shing*/ phyag g.yas na mda' dang*/ g.yon na 'od ma'i gzhu bsnams pa/ gzhu mchog la phag pa'i khog stod dang khog smad bkal ba/ rma bya'i sgro mdangs gshibs pa'i smad g.yogs gsol ba/ me tog dang 'bras bu'i rgyan sna tshogs pas brgyan pa/ sku'i g.yas g.yon rig ma rgyan dang cha lugs gtso bo dang mtshungs pa mda' dong thogs pa gnyis kyis bsten pa/

On an antelope-skin seat is Shavaripa, who is black in color. He stares with protruding eyes. In his right hand he holds an arrow, in his left a bamboo bow. On the ends of the bow are attached the front and rear parts of a boar. He is wearing a lower garment made up of rows of peacock feathers, and he is adorned with all kinds of flowers and fruits. On his right and left he is accompanied by two wisdom consorts who have the same ornaments and attire as himself and are holding quivers.

ri dwags kyi pags pa'i gdan la dpal sa ra ha pa sku mdog dkar dmar/ dbu skra co bregs tshangs skud can/ ras dmar po'i ang+ga rag gsol ba/ phyag gnyis kyis mda' bsrong ba'i tshul gyis lhan skyes de kho na nyid kyi ye shes ma nor drang thad ston pa'i brdas mtshon shing*/ sku'i g.yon phyogs nas zhing gi rnal 'byor ma mda' mkhan mo'i tshul gyis bsten pa/

On a deerskin seat is glorious Saraha, white in color tinged with red. His hair is uncut, and he wears a brahmin’s thread. He is dressed in red cotton shorts. He holds his two hands in the gesture of straightening an arrow, symbolizing that he teaches the coemergent wisdom of thatness without mistake, directly. On his left he is accompanied by a yoginī from the buddha fields, in the guise of a huntress.
kang+ka la pa sku mdog sngo sangs dbu sku co bregs/ phyag mnyam bzhag gis bzhugs shing rgyan med pa/ mdun na bud med kyi ro sha med pa'i keng rus nyal stabs su gnas pa/
Kaṅkālapāda is azure blue in color, with uncut hair. He is seated with his hands in the gesture of meditation and has no ornaments. In front of him lies the skeleton, stripped of flesh, of a woman.

mIn pa chen po sku mdog sngo sangs gcer bu rgyan spangs shing dbu skra 'dzings pa/ phyag gnyis gar bsgyur ba'i tshul/ mIn te nya chen po'i khog pa gshags pa'i dbus nas 'thon pa'i tshul gyis zhabs gnyis gar stabs kyis bzhengs pa'o/ /

The great Mīnapa is azure blue in color, naked and unadorned, his hair in disarray. His two hands perform a dance. He is emerging from the middle of the cut-open abdomen of a great fish (mīna in Sanskrit), standing up with his two feet in a dance posture.
de'i phyi rim du grub thob bcu drug bzhugs pa ni/
In a circle outside them are sixteen siddhas, in successive order clockwise: {73}

mdun nas g.yas bskor gyis rim pas shrI go rak+Sha nA tha sku sha dkar ba/ spyan lta stangs can/ snyan la mu dra nag po dang*/ mgul du ra dung btags pa/ sku lus gcen bu'am tsakra kan+ta te 'khor lo lta bu'i bem po gsol ba sgom shing la kos ko brten pa'i tshul gyis skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/ sku'i nye sgor du ba lang gi khyu'i tshogs kyis bskor ba/

Shrī Gorakṣha[20] is white-fleshed, with a fixed gaze. His ears are adorned with black bone earrings[21] and his throat with a horn trumpet. His body is naked[22] or he is wearing a chakrakanta cloth, with wheel-like motifs, and he is resting his chin on a meditation stick, sitting cross-legged. Close by, he is surrounded by a herd of cows.

tso rang gis dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs chung ngu dang ldan zhing*/ sku sha sngo sangs ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag mnyam bzhag / zhabs skyil krung gis ljon pa'i shing la sku rgyab brten bzhugs pa/

Chauraṅgi has his long hair tied up in a small topknot. His body is azure blue, and he is wearing a cotton dhoti. His hands are in the gesture of meditation, and he sits cross-legged, leaning against a tree.

wI Na pa sku mdog dkar dmar dar zab kyi na bza' dang*/ thod pa cings pa rgyal po'i cha byad/ rin po che'i rgyan du mas brgyan pa/ phyag gnyis dzan+ta ra du ku ba gsum pa'i rgyud mang brdung ba'i sgra la thugs rtse gcig tu gzhol ba'i tshul can rin po che'i khri stan la bzhugs pa/

Vīnapa is white tinged with red, wearing the attire of a king, with silken garments and a turban, and he is adorned with numerous jeweled ornaments. He is seated on a jewel throne, concentrating one-pointedly on the sound of a three-stringed vina[23] that he is playing with his two hands.

rat+na A ka ra shAn+ti pa sku mdog dkar sngo cung zad bgres pa'i rnam pa can/ chos gos rnam pa gsum dang*/ paN+Di ta'i cod pan gsol ba/ phyag g.yas bshad pa'i phyag rgya dang*/ g.yon glegs bam bsnams pa zab dang rgya che'i chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba'i tshul can gdeng pa'i stan la bzhugs pa/

Ratnākarashānti is light blue and looks slightly old. He is wearing the three dharma robes and the paṇḍita’s hat. With his right hand in the teaching gesture and his left holding a book, he is turning the wheel of the profound and extensive dharma. He is sitting on a monk’s mat.

tan+ti pa sku sngo sangs shin tu smin pa'i na tshod can/ ag tshom dang sma ra ring du 'phyar ba dbu skyes thams cad kun+da ltar dkar ba/ ras kyi smad dkris gsol zhing khri thags kyi bya ba la brtson pa'i tshul du chos kyi nges gnas brda' thabs kyis ston pa/

Tantipa is azure blue in color and of a very mature age. His drooping beard and mustache and his hair are all as white as jasmine. He is wearing a cotton dhoti and working hard at a loom, indicating symbolically that he abides in the certainty of the dharma.
tsa ma ri pa sku mdog sngo sangs ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag gnyis lham bzo'i bya ba mdzad pas kun rdzob brdas gnyug ma sems kyi don mtshon pa/
Chamaripa is azure blue in color and wearing a cotton dhoti. His two hands are engaged in the work of a shoemaker, indicating by relative symbols the meaning of the natural state of mind.
khaD+ga pa sku mdog sngo sangs/ ras kyi ang rag gsol pa/ phyag g.yas grub pa'i ral gri ye shes me 'bar ba bsnams te nam mkha' 'phur ba'i tshul/ ral pa'i thor tshugs can/

Khaḍgapa is azure blue in color and wears cotton shorts. In his right hand he holds the sword of accomplishment, blazing with wisdom fire. He is flying through the sky. His locks are tied in a topknot.

dpal mgon 'phags pa klu sgrub sku mdog sngo sangs nor bu rin po che'i mdog ltar dwangs shing dri ma med pa shin tu mtshar ba/ mtshan dpes spras shing*/ phyag gnyis chos 'khor gyi phyag rgya thugs kar mdzad pa/ na bza' chos gos rnam gsum gsol zhing rdo rje'i skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/ klu'i rgyal po mchog rnams sprul gyi rnam pas mchod cing bsnyen bkur ba'i phyir gdengs ka'i grib ma 'bul ba la sku rgyab brten pa/

The glorious protector of beings noble Nāgārjuna is azure blue in color, {74} as bright as a precious jewel and utterly beautiful and free of blemish. Adorned with the major and minor marks, he holds his two hands at his heart in the gesture of teaching the dharma. He is dressed in the three dharma robes and seated cross-legged in the vajra posture. The supreme kings of the nāgas, taking the form of snakes to venerate and honor him, are offering him the shade of their hoods and providing a backrest for him to lean against.

brtul zhugs spyod pa nag po'i zhabs sku mdog nag po/ phyag g.yas cang te'u 'khrol zhing*/ g.yon thod pa bdud rtsis gang ba thugs kar 'dzin cing*/ mchan khung du kha T+wA~M ga 'dzin pa/ sku la rus pa'i rgyan drug dang stag sham gsol ba/ pi shwa rU pi nI zhes pa'i srin mo'i gtso mo 'jigs su rung ba'i gzugs gdan nam bzhon pa'i tshul du gnas pa'i steng na phyed skyil gyis bzhugs pa/ res 'ga' ro langs chen po me tog gis 'phreng bas brgyan pa la chibs pa sogs sna tshogs rdzu 'phrul rol pa ston pa/ steng gi nam mkhar gdugs bdun 'dzin pa med par 'khor zhing*/ DA ma ru bdun 'khrol mkhan med par sgra grags bzhin pa/ res 'ga' gdugs bdun brgya dang DA ma ru bdun brgyar 'phel ba'i cho 'phrul can/ snang dang mi snang ba'i 'khor grub pa dang rig 'dzin gyi rnal 'byor pho mo dpag tu med pa'i 'khor lo'i 'du bar rtag tu spyod pa/

Kṛiṣhṇāchāri is black in color. With his right hand he is playing a hand drum; in his left, at his heart center, he holds a skull cup full of nectar. In the crook of his arm he holds a khātvāṇga trident. On his body he is wearing the six bone ornaments and a tiger-skin skirt. He is sitting with his legs half-crossed on top of a seat or mount of the terrifying form of Pishvarūpinī, the queen of the rākṣhasa ogres. Sometimes he displays various kinds of miraculous powers such as riding on a huge revived corpse garlanded with flowers. In the sky above him seven parasols turn without anyone holding them, and seven hand drums resound without anyone playing them. Sometimes he magically multiplies the seven parasols and seven hand drums a hundredfold. He constantly gathers around him a circle of infinite male and female practitioners—siddhas and vidyādharas—both visible and invisible.
'phags pa lha sngo sangs dge slong gi cha byad chos gos rnam pa gsum dang ldan zhing*/ zhabs skyil mo krung gis gding ba'i stan la bzhugs pa/ kar+Na ri zhes pa'i shing lo chen po phyag na bsnams pa/
Āryadeva is azure blue and has the appearance of a monk, with the three dharma robes. He is seated on a monk’s mat with his legs crossed. In his hand he holds the large leaf of a karnari tree.
thag na sku mdog mi sha kha sngo sangs shing ljon pa la sku rgyab brten pa'i byed snyes kyis pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs shing phyag gnon sogs ci bder spyod pa/
Thaganapa has bluish flesh and is seated on an animal skin leaning against a tree, sitting comfortably with his hand on the ground.

dpal nA ro pa sku mdog smug nag gzi byin mtshungs pa med pa'i zil dang ldan pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs dang*/ sku rus pa'i rgyan drug sogs kyis spras pa/ dar gyi ang+ga rag gsal ba'am stag lpags kyi smad dkris can/ mi lpags kyi steng g.yogs mdzad pa'i rkang lag gnyis phyag gis bzung ste phun tshun du brgyangs pa'am phyag g.yas kyis mi lpags brgyangs shing*/ g.yon thod pa bdud rtsis gang ba 'dzin pa/ zhabs gar stabs sam/ brkyang bskum gyi tshul du bzhugs shing*/ mdun du gsang yum mkha' 'gro ma mi mo'i rnam pa mtshar sdug phun sum tshogs pas bdud rtsi 'bul ba/

The glorious Nāropa is dark maroon in color and overwhelmingly resplendent. His hair is tied up in a topknot, {75} and his body is adorned with the six bone ornaments and so forth. He wears silk shorts or a tiger-skin skirt. In his hands he holds the hands and feet of his human-skin upper garment, stretching them on either side. Alternatively, he is stretching the human skin with his right hand and holding a skull cup full of nectar with his left. He stands with his feet in the dancing posture, or with one leg extended and the other folded. In front of him is his secret consort, a dakinī in the form of a human woman of perfect beauty, making an offering of nectar.
sh+ya li pa sku sngo sangs ras kyi ang rag gsol ba/ lce spyang gi ro phrag par bkal ba/
Shyalipa is azure blue and dressed in cotton shorts. He is carrying a jackal’s corpse on his shoulder.

til+li pa sku sha sngo nag dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs can/ ras kyi ang rag gsol zhing til brdung ba'i rnam pa can/ mdun du rig ma zhing gi rnal 'byor ma til mkhan mo'i rnam pas til lugs pa'i bya ba la brtson pas gnyug ma'i ye shes rang la rang chas su bzhugs pa ngo sprod pa'i brda' mtshon pa/

Tilopa’s flesh is dark blue, and his hair is tied up in a topknot. He is wearing cotton shorts and has the appearance of a sesame grinder. In front of him is his secret consort, a yoginī from a buddha field in the form of a female sesame vendor, hard at work in the sesame trade, symbolizing the introduction to the wisdom of the natural state being inherently present within oneself.[24]
tsakra pa sku mdog dkar dmar rab byung gi cha byad glegs bam gyi khur po rgyab tu bsnams shing phyag tu glegs bam chung du 'dzin pa/
Chatrapa is white in color, tinged with red, dressed in monk’s attire, carrying a load of books on his back and holding a small book in his hand.

b+ha tra pa sku sha dkar dmar lang tsho rgyas pa'i nyams ldan/ dbu skra shad pa bcings pa'i thor cog can/ tshangs skud dang rna rgyan sogs rin po'i rgyan thor bus spras pa/ phyag mnyam par bzhag pa'i phyag rgya dang*/ zhabs skyil krung gi kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa'i sku'i mdun ngos su phag gi sha dang myos byed kyi bum pa bcas pa'o/ /

Bhadrapa’s flesh is white tinged with red, and he is handsome, in the full bloom of youth. His hair is combed and tied in a topknot. He is adorned with the brahmin’s thread and different jewel ornaments such as earrings. He holds his hands in the gesture of meditation, and he is sitting cross-legged on an antelope-skin mat. In front of him is some pork and a jar of liquor.
de'i phyi rim du grub thob nyi shu bzhugs pa ni/
In another circle outside them are twenty siddhas, in successive order clockwise:

mdun nas g.yas bskor gyi rim pas/ d+hu khan+d+hi pa sku mdog sngo sangs dbu skra co bregs/ phyag dar khrod kyi gos hrul po sna tshogs gcig tu bsdus te 'brub pa'i tshul gyis chos can thams cad chos nyid gcig tu 'du ba'i brda' ston pa/ zhabs g.yas mdun du brkyangs shing g.yon phyed krung gis pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa/

Dhukhandi is azure blue in color, with uncut hair. He has the appearance of a sewer, stitching together rags from refuse heaps, symbolizing that all phenomena are gathered together in ultimate reality. He is seated on an animal skin with his right leg stretched out in front and his left leg drawn in. {76}
a dzo gi pa sku mdog sngo skya ral pa'i thor tshugs cung zad dang bcas pa 'phred nyal stabs kyis gzims pa'i tshul can/
Āyogipāda is light blue in color, with his hair partly tied up in a topknot. He has the appearance of being asleep, lying on his side.
ka la pa sku mdog dkar dmar mdzes shing lta bas mi ngoms pa/ ral pa'i thor tshugs chung du can/ phyag gnyis mnyam bzhag gi phyag rgya dang*/ zhabs skyil krung gis bzhugs pa/

Kalapa is white in color, tinged with red, and so handsome one can never tire of looking at him. He has his hair in a small topknot. His two hands are in the meditation gesture, and he is sitting cross-legged.

d+hu pi ra dza sku mdog sngo sangs ras kyi smad dkris gsol zhing zhabs pus btsugs/ mdun du chu rgyun la gos rnying pa sna tshogs pa 'khrud pa'i tshul gyis sems kyi dri ma sbyangs pa'i brda' ston pa/ g.yon du rig ma bsten pa/

Dhombipa[25] is azure blue in color and wears a cotton dhoti. He is kneeling. In front is a stream, in which he is washing a variety of dirty clothes, symbolizing cleansing the mind of impurities. He is accompanied by his wisdom consort on his left.

kang+ka na sku mdog dkar dmar mdangs ldan rgyal po'i cha byad dar dang rin po ches spras pa/ phyag g.yas pa'i gdub bu nor bu rin po che 'od 'bar ba la rtse gcig tu gzigs pa'i tshul dang*/ zhabs rol stabs kyis rin po che'i khri dang dar zab kyi 'bol stan la bzhugs pa/ mtha' bskor btsun mo blon 'bangs kyis bskor zhing*/ steng gi bar snang gi nam mkha' nas lha dang lha mo'i tshogs kyis mchod pa 'bul ba/

Kaṅkana is a radiant white tinged with red, dressed as a king, adorned with silks and jewel ornaments. He is looking fixedly at a precious jeweled bracelet on his right arm shining with light. He is seated with his feet in the posture of royal ease on a jeweled throne and satin cushion. He is surrounded by his queens, ministers, and subjects. From the sky above him, gods and goddesses are making offerings to him.
kam+pa la pa sku mdog dkar dmar dge slong gi cha byad/ sku la l+wa ba'i na bza' gsol zhing*/ phyag mnyam bzhag gi phyag rgyas ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag bzhin pa/
Kambala is white in color, tinged with red, with the attributes of a monk, and wears a rough woolen garment. With his hands in the meditation gesture, he is absorbed in concentration.

Ding+gi pa sku la ras kyi smad dkris gsol zhing*/ ral pa'i thor tshugs can/ phyag gnyis snod du 'bras blugs te gtun shing gis 'bras spru zhib chu la 'khrud pas snying po'i don gyi brda' ston pa/ zhabs pus btsugs kyi rnam pa/ sku yi gam nas rig ma bzang mos chu yi rgyun blugs pa/

Ḍiṅgipa is wearing a cotton dhoti and has his hair tied up in a topknot. With his two hands he is filling a pot with rice and husking it with a wooden pestle, rinsing away the chaff with water. This symbolizes his extracting the essential meaning. He is kneeling. Next to him, his excellent secret consort is pouring a stream of water.
ban+d+he pa rgyal po'i cha byad sku dkar dmar mdangs ldan/ dar gyi mdung ma dang thod bcings rin po che'i sna tshogs pas spras shing rol stabs kyis rin po che'i khri stan dar 'bol la bzhugs pa/

Bhandhepa is attired as a king. His body is radiant white tinged with red. He is dressed in silk robes and a turban and adorned with various jewel ornaments. He is seated in the posture of royal ease on a jeweled throne and satin cushion.

tan+te pa sku mdog sngo sangs rgya gar ba phal pa'i cha byad ras kyi smad dkris dang thod bcings pa/ phyag gnyis rgya gar gyi lugs dang mthun pa'i sho bsnams te shog gdan gyi steng du rol rtsed mdzad pa'i tshul can/
Tandhepa is azure blue in color, dressed as an ordinary Indian, with a cotton dhoti and turban. His two hands hold Indian-style dice, {77} and he is playing on a gameboard.

ku ku ri pa sku mdog mi sha sngo mdangs cung zad yod pa ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus pa'i rgyan gyis mdzes pa ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag g.yon ka pA la bdud rtsis gang ba 'dzin cing*/ sku pang du rdo rje rnal 'byor ma ku ku ri gzhon nu'i gzugs can phyag g.yas kyi bzung ste dgyes rgur rol pa'i tshul can/

Kukkuripa is flesh-colored with a bluish tinge. He has his hair tied up in a topknot and is adorned with bone ornaments. He wears a cotton dhoti. His left hand holds a kapāla filled with nectar. His right hand holds Vajrayoginī on his lap, in the form of a young dog, in whom he takes delight.
ku ri pa sku mdog sngo sangs rnal 'byor pa'i cha byad ras kyi ang rag gsol ba/ / ltag pa'i phyogs su lba bas mtshan pa/ mdun na slob dpon klu sgrub bzhugs pa la gus pas bsnyen pa'i tshul can/
Kujipa[26] is azure blue in color and attired as a yogi, wearing cotton shorts. He has a tumor on his neck. In front of him is the master Nāgārjuna, whom he is serving respectfully.

d+ha ma pa sku sha dkar sngo bram ze'i cha byad gtsug phud dang tshangs skud ril pa dang bcas shing ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag na glegs bam bsnams pa/ sku'i nye skor du yang po ti mang po dang bcas pa/

Dhamapa is bluish white and in the attire of a brahmin, with his hair knot, brahmin’s sacred thread, and small water pot. He has a cotton dhoti. In his hand he holds a book, and around him are numerous volumes of the scriptures.
ma hi la sku lus yan lag sbom zhing sha sul can gzhan la lus stobs 'gran pa'i tshul can/
Mahila is well built in body and limb, with folds in his flesh. His appearance is of one who rivals others with his physical strength.
a tsin+ta pa ras kyi 'doms dkris gsol zhing*/ shing phur dang s+t+wa re bsnams nas shing gcod pa'i tshul gyis 'khrul pa'i drwa ba gcod pa'i brda' ston pa/
Achinta is wearing a cotton dhoti. He has the appearance of a woodcutter, holding a bundle of wood and an ax, to symbolize cutting the net of delusion.

ba b+ha hi mi bdag gi cha byad sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs can la/ na bza' smad g.yogs las gzhan med par dbu rgyan/ phyag zhabs rin po che'i gdu bus mdzes pa sku'i g.yon phyogs nas mtshar sdug phun sum tshogs pa'i btsun mos 'khyud pas pho med bde chen gyi rol dgyes pas rol pa/ rin po che'i khri stan la bzhugs pa/

Babhahi has the attributes of a ruler. He is white in color, tinged with red. Apart from a lower garment, he has no other clothes but is adorned with a crown and jeweled bangles on his arms and legs. On his left he is being embraced by his consort, of astounding and perfect beauty, manifesting the delightful enjoyment of unchanging great bliss. He is seated on a jeweled throne.
nA li nA pa sku mdog dkar dmar bram ze'i cha byad/ mtsho'i dbus na me tog pad+ma'i sdong bu rtsa ba dang bcas te gcod pa/
Nalina is white in color, tinged with red, and has the attributes of a brahmin. He is cutting the stem of a lotus flower and its root, in the middle of a lake.

shAn+ta de ba sku mdog dkar dmar sha nyams rgyas pa/ dge slong gi cha byad chos gos gsol ba gding ba'i steng du zhabs skyil mo krung bcas te/ dge slong gi dge 'dun chen po'i dbus su/ 'jigs pa med pa'i tshul gyis byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la 'jug gsungs bzhin du nam mkha' la je mthor 'phags pa'i tshul can/

Shāntideva is white in color, tinged with red, with healthy features. He is attired as a monk, wearing the dharma robes, and sitting cross-legged on a mat. He appears to be rising higher and higher into the air, from the midst of a great assembly of monks, as he fearlessly teaches The Way of the Bodhisattva (Bodhicaryāvatāra).

chos kyi rgyal po in+d+ra bo d+hi sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs ldan mdzes pa/ 'khor los sgyur ba chen po'i cha byad/ rin po che'i khri dang dar zab kyi 'bol stan la bzhugs pa/ khams gsum dbang phyug chen po'i 'byor pas gtams shing*/ rdo rje rnal 'byor ma mi'i bu mo'i tshul bzung ba'i btsun mo mtshar sdug phun sum tshogs pa lnga brgyas glu gar rol mo reg bya'i mchod pas rtag tu mchod cing*/ 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga'i longs spyod dga' ston lam du khyer ba'i spros bcas kyi spyod pa chen po rtsom pa'i tshul can gyis dgyes rgur rol pa/

The dharma king Indrabhūti is a beautiful white color, tinged with red. He is attired as a great universal monarch {78} and is seated on a jeweled throne and satin cushion. He is surrounded by the riches of the Lord of the Three Worlds. Vajrayoginī, taking the form of five hundred astoundingly beautiful and perfect maidens, is continuously venerating him with offerings of song, dance, music, and caresses. He is delighting in these and a feast of pleasures of the five senses as he undertakes the great practice with conceptual elaborations of taking pleasure as the path.

me ko pa sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs can thod bcings pa/ khyim pa tha mal pa'i cha byad gos phu dud can dang*/ phyag gnyis snum 'khur bzo ba'i bya ba mdzad cing*/ sku'i mdun phyogs su kha zas kyi bye brag sna tshogs pa bkram pa/ rig ma mdzes mas g.yos kyi bya ba mdzad pa'i tshul can/

Mekopa’s body is white tinged with red, and his hair is tied up in a topknot. He has the appearance of an ordinary layman, wearing a short-sleeved garment. With his two hands he is at work making fried pastries. In front of him are displayed a variety of pastries. His beautiful wisdom consort is doing the work of cooking them.

tog rtse pa sku mdog sngo nag dbu la thod bcings shing ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag gnyis kyis tog tse bsnams te zhing tha rengs brko ba'i tshul gyis rang rgyud rengs pa 'dul dgos pa'i brda' mdzad pa rnams bzhugs pa'o/ /

Togchepa is dark blue in color, with his hair tied up in a topknot, and he is wearing a cotton dhoti. In his two hands he holds a mattock, with which he is tilling the hard earth of a barren field, symbolizing the need to break in one’s own rigid mind.
de'i phyi rim du grub thob nyi shu bzhugs pa ni/
In another circle outside them are twenty siddhas, in successive order clockwise:

mdun nas g.yas skor gyi rim pas/ gam+b+ha ri pa sku sngo nag sha na'i gos kyi smad dkris can thod bcings pa/ phyag gnyis tho ba dang skam pa bzung ste/ lcags mgar gyi las la brtson pas dug gsum chos kyi sku ru sbyong ba'i brda' ston pa/

Kamparipa is dark blue in color and wears a hemp dhoti. His hair is tied up in a topknot. His two hands hold a hammer and tongs, and he is hard at work in his trade as a blacksmith, symbolizing training and purifying the three poisons as the body of truth.

dza lan+d+ha ra ba sku mdog dkar dmar/ ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus rgyan can ras dmar gyi 'doms dkris gsol ba/ zhal phyogs gcig rgyab nas dpung par bka' zhing*/ phyogs gcig bzhengs pa'am bus btsugs kyi tshul can/ phyag gnyis rdo rje gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya ldogs te spyi bor 'ching ba/ g.yon gyi phyogs nas rig ma rnal 'byor ma'i cha byad kyis 'dud bzhin pa/

Jālandhara is white in color, tinged with red. His hair is in a topknot, and he is wearing bone ornaments and a red dhoti. With one leg tucked back over his shoulder, he stands on the other leg, or is kneeling. His two hands are opposed in the vajra uṣhnīṣha mudra, binding the crown. On his left, his wisdom consort, in the attire of a yoginī, is bowing down to him.
rA hu la pa sku sngo sangs yid tsam bgres pa/ dbu skra co bregs phyag gnyis mnyam bzhag dang*/ zhabs gnyis skyil krung gis kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa'i/
Rāhula is azure blue and somewhat elderly. His hair is uncut, and he holds his two hands in the meditation gesture. He is sitting with his two legs crossed on an antelope-skin mat. {79}
d+harma pa sku sngo sangs ches cher smin pa'i na tshod can dge sbyong gi chas ldan/ po ti phyag na bsnams shing zhabs sems skyil gyis gding ba'i stan la bzhugs pa/

Dharmapa is azure blue, of a very mature age, and has the attributes of a monk. He is holding a volume of the scriptures in his hand and sitting with his feet in the bodhisattva posture on a monk’s mat.

d+ho ka ri pa sku mdog smug nag slong mo pa'i cha byad/ phyag gnyis dzo la zhes pa dra ba'i snod du kha zas kyi snod chen po dbyug pa'i dpyangs thag can bsnams te slong mo slong ba'i tshul du bzhengs pa/

Dhokaripa is dark maroon in color and has the appearance of a beggar. In his two hands he holds a stick from which, tied with a rope, hangs a large pot of food in a bundle called a jola. He is holding it up in the manner of a beggar begging for alms.

me d+hi na pa sku sngo sangs rmos mkhan gyi cha byad/ ral pa'i thor tshugs cung zad dang bcas shing*/ ras kyi smad dkris can rmos glang gnyis la gnya' shing bcug ste zhing rmo ba'i tshul gyis chos kyi nges gnas ston pa/

Medhina is azure blue in color and has the appearance of a plowman. His hair is slightly tied up, and he is wearing a cotton dhoti. He is yoking a pair of oxen to plow the field, symbolizing his understanding of the dharma.

sang+ka dza pa sku mdog dkar dmar gzhon pa'i nyams dang ldan pa bram ze'i cha byad/ zhabs gar stabs kyis bzhengs shing pad+ma'i rdzing bu'i 'gram na 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs kyi lha khang la bsnyen bkur mdzad pa/

Saṅkaja is white in color, tinged with red, and youthful in appearance, with the attributes of a brahmin. He is standing in the dancing posture, worshipping the shrine of noble Avalokiteshvara on the edge of a lotus pool.

yum rdo rje dril bu pa sku mdog mi sha kha sngo sangs zhi ma khro/ ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus pa'i rgyan drug gis brgyan pa/ stag lpags kyi sham thabs can/ phyag gnyis rdo rje dril bu 'dzin pas yum la 'khyud pa/ yum rdo rje rnal 'byor ma'i rnam pa gri gug dang thod pa 'dzin pa phyag rgya lnga ldan shin tu mdzes ma la mnyam par sbyor ba'i bde bas dgyes pa/ zhabs g.yas brkyang g.yon bskum gyi stabs kyis mkha' dbyings mthon por 'phags pa/

Ghaṇḍhapa is flesh colored with a light-blue tinge. He is semiwrathful. His hair is tied up in a topknot, and he is adorned with the six bone ornaments. He wears a tiger-skin skirt. His two hands hold a vajra and bell, embracing his consort. His consort, in the form of Vajrayoginī, holds a curved knife and skull cup, wears the five symbolic ornaments, and is extremely beautiful. They are delighting in the bliss of union. With his right leg extended and the left bent, they are rising high into the sky.
dzo gi pa rnal 'byor gyi cha byad sku sngo sangs gcer bu/ 'khar ba thogs shing yo byad rnams phrag dbyug gi rtser btags shing thod pa 'dzin pa/

Yogipa has the appearance of a yogi. He is azure blue and naked. He is holding a mendicant’s staff, has his belongings tied to the end of a stick carried over his shoulder, and is holding a skull cup.
tsa lu ki pa rnal 'byor pa'i cha byad/ la Ti zhes pa 'bol stan sngas su bcugs nas gzims pa/ mdun du sgom shing ci bder bskyur ba'i tshul can/ g.yon phyogs nas rig mas bsten pa/
Chaluki has the attributes of a yogi. He is lying asleep on a thick cushion called a laṭi. In front of him is a discarded meditation stick. On his left he is accompanied by his wisdom consort.
go ru ra pa sku mdog sngo sangs sku smad la shing lo'i gos can/ dbu skra co bregs/ snyi btsugs te bya sna tshogs pa gshor ba'i rnam pa can/
Gorura is azure blue in color, his lower body clothed in leaves. His hair is uncut. {80} He has the appearance of a hunter, setting traps to catch different kinds of birds.
lu tsi ka pa sku mdog dkar nyams bram ze'i cha byad/ skra dang kha spu rnams 'jab rtses 'thog ste zad pa'i rnam pa can/
Luchika is white in color and has the attributes of a brahmin. He is plucking out his hair and whiskers with tweezers.
na gu Na pa khyim pa'i cha byad/ sku mdog dkar la dmar mdangs can/ mal khri la rgyab snyes su snyes nas zas za ba'i tshul can/
Naguṇa has the appearance of a layman. He is white in color, tinged with red. He is leaning back on a couch and eating some food.

dza ya nan+ti pa bram ze'i slob dpon dge bsnyen tshangs par spyod pa'i cha lugs can/ ras kyi smad dkris gsol zhing kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa phyag gis ting shag bsnams te brdung ba'i tshul gyis/ gtor ma sna tshogs pa gtong ba'i rnam pa can/ sku'i mdun du bya sna tshogs 'dus shing*/ 'khor slob ma skyes pa dang*/ bud med sna tshogs rdza rnga brdung ba dang*/ gling bu 'bud pa sogs 'bud dkrol kyi bya ba byed pa la bstsom pa rnams kyis bskor ba/

Jayānanti has the attributes of a celibate brahmin master and teacher. He is wearing a cotton dhoti and seated on an antelope-skin mat. In his hands he holds a pair of small cymbals which he is striking, as he offers a variety of tormas. In front of him, all kinds of birds have gathered. He is surrounded by a retinue of different men and women playing music—beating clay drums, blowing wind instruments, and so forth.

pa tsa ri pa rnal 'byor gyi cha byad skra bregs pa/ shing ljon pa'i drung na bzhugs shing*/ 'doms dkris gru gsum pa zhig ma gtogs na bza' med pa/ mdun du me btang ste snum 'khur btsos pa la snum 'khur gcig gi phyed zhal du gsol ba'i rnam pa/ mdun na spya ras gzigs bzhengs te chos ston pa

Pachari has the appearance of a shaven-headed yogi. He is sitting in front of a tree and has no clothes apart from a triangular skirt. He has made a fire in front of him and is frying pastries, while eating a piece of pastry himself. In front, Avalokiteshvara has manifested and is teaching the dharma.

tsam+pa ka pa sku mdog dkar dmar lang tsho rgyas pa/ dar gyi na bza' phu dung can dang rin po ches brgyan pa/ phyag na me tog gi 'phreng ba bsnams pa/ mtha' bskor gyi skyed tshal rnams tsam+pa ka yi shing ste/ yal ga rnams zlum por skyes pa/ lo ma ljang nag me tog gser skya yod pa/ de lta bu'i skyed tshal gyi dbus na rin po che dang dar zab kyi khri stan la bzhugs pa/

Champaka is white in color, tinged with red, in the full bloom of youth. He is wearing a short-sleeved silk robe and is adorned with jewels. In his hand he holds a garland of flowers. All around are groves of champac trees, with their branches growing in round clusters, dark-green leaves and pale golden flowers. He is sitting on a jeweled satin throne in the midst of such a grove.

b+hik+Sha Na pa sku sngo sangs/ phyag na ku pa'i snod bsnams shing*/ phyag gcig gis rang gi tshems gcig / mdun mkhar ye shes kyi mkha' 'gro ma dmar mo zhi ba rus rgyan can gyis chos ston pa la 'bul ba'i tshul can/

Bhikṣhana is azure blue in color. In one hand he holds a gourd, and with the other hand one of his own teeth, which he is offering to a peaceful red wisdom ḍākinī with bone ornaments in the sky in front, who is teaching him the dharma.
d+hi li pa ras kyi thod dkris dang stod g.yogs smad g.yogs can/ mdun du mar nag gi snod chen po mang du bshams te 'tshong ba'i tshul dang*/ kha zas sna tshogs bshams pa/
Dhilipa is wearing a cotton turban and upper and lower garments. In front of him are set out for sale numerous large pots of sesame oil {81} and a variety of foods.
kum+b+ha ri pa rdza mkhan gyi cha lugs 'khor lo bskor te rdza bzo ba'i tshul can/ shes rab mas mtha' bsten pa/
Kumbharipa has the appearance of a potter and is turning a potter’s wheel, making earthenware. He is accompanied by a wisdom consort at his side.

tsar+pa Ti pa sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs chags pa/ na bza' me kha li zhes pa/ dbus kyi bug pa nas mgul bton cing*/ g.yas g.yon gyi phyed phyed mdun rgyab kyi na bza' bgos pa la sku rags bcings pa/ phyag gnyis bcud len gyi snod gser 'gyur gyis rtsis gang ba'i bum pa bsnams pa las/ shing lo'i 'thor g.yab kyis gtor bas/ skyes pa bud med mtha' yas pa don chen po la yud kyis 'god pa rnams so/ /

Charpaṭipa is white in color, tinged with red. He is wearing a garment called a mekhali, with a hole for the head and neck, and right and left halves front and back, tied with a belt. In his two hands he holds a container of elixir and a vase filled with alchemical essence, whose contents he is sprinkling with a leafy twig, thus instantly setting infinite men and women to the great objective.
de'i phyi rol du grub thob nyi shu bzhugs pa ni/ mdun nas g.yas bskor gyis/
Outside them are twenty more siddhas, disposed clockwise starting from the front:

rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug chen po ma Ni b+ha dra bu mo gzhon nu ma'i lang tsho'i gang ba can shin tu mdzes pa'i mtshar sdug phun sum tshogs pa rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa/ nam mkha' la 'phur ba'i tshul can/ 'og gi sa gzhir chu bum chag pa la gzigs pa'i rnam pa/

The great lady of yogis Maṇibhadrā is an astoundingly beautiful and perfect young woman in the full bloom of youth, adorned with all kinds of ornaments. She is flying through the sky, looking at a broken water pot on the ground below.

rnal 'byor ma me kha li sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs chags pa gzhon mdzes lang tsho rgyas shing dbu skra sil bur grol ba/ gcer bu rus pa'i rgyan can/ mchan khung du rdo rje kha T+wA~M ga bzung ba/ zhal las ye shes kyi ral gri phyungs te phyag g.yas kyis 'dzin zhing*/ g.yon thod pa bdud rtsis gang ba 'dzin pa/ zhabs gnyis gar stabs brkyang bskums gyi tshul du bzhugs pa/

The yoginī Mekhali is white in color, tinged with red, a beautiful young woman in the full bloom of youth. Her hair is loose and she is naked, wearing bone ornaments. She holds a vajra khātvāṇga in the crook of her arm. From her mouth she has drawn the sword of wisdom, which she is holding in her right hand. Her left hand holds a skull cup full of nectar. She is standing with her two feet in the dance posture, one leg extended, the other drawn in.

rnal 'byor ma ka na kha la sku mdog dkar dmar gcer mo lang tsho rgyas pa rus pa'i rgyan gyis spras pa/ phyag g.yas pas ye shes kyi ral gri rno ngar dang ldan pa 'dzin cing*/ g.yon pas rang gi dbu bcad de 'dzin pa phag mo dbu bcad ma'i tshul ltar/ zhabs brkyang bskum gar stabs kyis nam mkha' la gar mdzad pa/

The yoginī Kanakhalā is white in color, tinged with red, naked, in the full bloom of youth, and adorned with bone ornaments. In her right hand she holds the sharp sword of wisdom; in her left, she holds her own decapitated head, as if it were a chopped-off sow’s head. She is dancing in the sky with one leg extended and the other drawn in, in the dancing posture.
ka la ka la pa sku sngo nag gcer bu dur dur 'jigs su rung ba'i dbus na ting nge 'dzin la bzhugs pa/ de'i mdun mtho ba na rnal 'byor dbang phyug rus rgyan can zhig gis chos ston pa/

Kalakala is dark blue and naked. He is absorbed in concentration in the middle of a fearful charnel ground. {82} In the air in front of him is a siddha wearing bone ornaments, who is teaching the dharma.
skan+d+ha li pa sku mdog sngo sangs ras kyi smad dkris can/ phyag gnyis khab skud dang bem po bsnams te tshem bu 'drub pa'i tshul can pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa/
Kandhalipa is light blue in color and wears a cotton dhoti. His two hands are holding a needle and thread and a patchwork blanket, which he is sewing. He is seated on an animal hide.
d+ha hu li pa sku sngo sangs ral pa'i thor tshugs cung zad dang bcas pa/ ras kyi smad dkris can g.yon nas rig mas bdud cing*/ rtsa thag grims pa'i khur po 'chis pa'i tshul can/

Dhahulipa is azure blue in color and has his hair partially tied up in a topknot. He is wearing a cotton dhoti. On his left is his wisdom consort bowing to him. He is making[27] a length of twisted grass rope.

u d+hi li pa sku mdog dkar smug sha nyams can sma ra bzang po dang ldan pa/ gos phu dung can gsol zhing dbu la ras kyi thod bcings sogs khyim bdag gi cha byad/ rin po che'i rgyan gyis spras shing gos stan bzang po la bzhugs pa/ spyan nam mkha' la gzigs shing nam mkha'i mthongs su sprin kha dog sna lnga pa/ glang po che dang*/ rta dang bya la sogs pa'i gzugs brnyan 'char ba dang*/ bya ngang pa nam mkha' la 'phur ba/ de'i mdun du rnal 'byor pa shing lo thogs pa zhig gis chos 'chad pa'i tshul can/

Udhilipa has a reddish-brown appearance and a fine beard. He has the attributes of a layman, with his short-sleeved garment, cotton turban, and so forth. He is adorned with precious ornaments and is sitting on a fine seat. He is looking at the sky, in which there appear five-colored clouds shaped like elephants, horses, birds, and other creatures. Some swans are flying through the sky. In front of him is a yogi holding some leaves and teaching the dharma.
ka pA la pa rnal 'byor pa'i cha byad sku mdog sngo nag / 'doms dkris ma gtogs gcer bu rus pa'i rgyan gyis spras pa/ mdun du bud med bzang mo'i ro bzhag pa'i thod pa bregs te phyag tu bsnams pa/

Kapālapa has the appearance of a yogi and is dark blue in color. Apart from a dhoti, he is naked and is adorned with bone ornaments. In front of him lies the corpse of his wife, whose skull he has cut off and is holding in his hand.

ki ra ba la pa sku mdog dkar smug cung zad khro ba'i nyams ldan/ sma ra bzang po can/ dbu la cod pan dbus dang phyogs bzhi ste rtse mo lnga pa rin po che'i tog can gsol ba/ skra mtshams su dpa' bo'i dar dpyangs zhes pa rin chen gser gyi 'khyud mo las rna ltag g.yas g.yon nas mar dar dpyangs 'phyar ba/ phyag g.yas ral gri dang*/ g.yon phu ba bzung ste rol stabs kyis rin po che'i khri stan la bzhugs pa/

Kiravalapa is reddish-brown, with a slightly wrathful look and a fine beard. He is wearing a crown whose five tips (one in the middle and four in the four directions) are topped with jewels. From the precious gold rings in his hair arrangement called the dāka’s crown, silken ribbons flutter behind his right and left ears. In his right hand he holds a sword, in his left a shield. He is seated in the posture of royal ease on a jeweled throne.
sa ka ra pa dge slong gi cha byad/ chos gos rnam pa gsum dang ldan pa/ mdun na 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs sku bzhengs stabs kyis bzhugs pa la gus pas mchod pa'i tshul/
Sakarapa has the attributes of a fully ordained monk. He is wearing the three dharma robes. In front of him stands noble Avalokiteshvara, whom he is venerating. {83}
sarba b+hak+Sha pa sku sngo sangs dmangs rigs kyi cha byad ras kyi 'doms dkris/ skra bcings pa/ mdun du snod gcig gi nang zas sna tshogs pa yod pa longs spyod pa'i tshul can/

Sarvabhakṣhapa is azure blue in color and of low-caste appearance, wearing a cotton dhoti. His hair is tied up. In front of him is a vessel with a variety of foods inside, which he is eating with relish.
nA ga bo d+hi sku mdog mi sha kha sngo sangs dge slong gi tshul can phyag gnyis mnyam bzhag gi phyag rgya mdzad cing gding ba'i stan la ting nge 'dzin gyis bzhugs pa/

Nāgabodhi is flesh colored with a light-blue hue and has the appearance of a fully ordained monk. His two hands are held in the meditation gesture, and he is seated on a monk’s mat, absorbed in concentration.

dA ri ka pa sku mdog sngo sangs phyag gnyis rdo rje dril bu bsnams zhing 'ja' 'od dang bcas nam mkha' la 'phur zhing lding ba'i tshul gyis gshegs pa/ 'khor du mchog tu gyur pa'i bud med gzugs dang lang tsho phun sum tshogs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa dang bcas mkha' spyod du bgrod pa'i tshul can/

Dārikapa is azure blue in color, holding in his two hands a vajra and bell, and flying and soaring through the sky to the accompaniment of rainbow lights. He is attended by the most excellent of women, of inconceivable and perfect form and youth, as he travels to a celestial land.

pu ta li pa rnal 'byor gyi cha byad dbu skra co breg sgom thag dang ang rag gsol nas/ kr-iSh+Na sA ra'i pags pa'i gdan la bzhugs pa/ mdun du dpal dgyes pa rdo rje'i sku ras bris bkram pa la rtse gcig tu gzigs pa/

Putalipa has the attributes of a yogi, with his hair uncut, and is wearing a meditation belt and shorts. He is seated on an antelope-skin mat. He is looking fixedly at a picture painted on cloth of glorious Hevajra, displayed in front of him.

pa na ha pa sku mdog dkar sngo sangs ras kyi smad dkris dang thod can phyag gnyis dkur brten pa ag tshom dang bcas shing*/ zhabs la l+h+wam yu bcad g.yer kha sogs rgyan mang po btags te sil khrol gyi sgra dang bcas rgyug pa'i tshul gyis/ bde chen gyi sar rings par 'gro ba la brtson dgos pa'i brda' ston pa/

Panahapa is white with a pale-blue tinge, wearing a cotton dhoti and turban. His two hands rest on his hips. His chin is bearded. He is running to the musical sounds of the many tinklers and other ornaments attached to the tops of shoes. This symbolizes the need to be diligent in proceeding speedily to the level of great bliss.

ko ki la pa rgyal po'i cha byad sku mdog dkar dmar/ dar zab kyi na bza' dang rin po che'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ rin po che'i khri stan la bzhugs pa'i mtha' skor du skyed mos tshal 'bras bu can gyi shing gis gang ba/ gzhon nu ma mchog gi mdzes sdug can mang pos glu dang gar dang*/ rlung g.yab dang*/ khrus gsol ba'i rnam pa shing rnams la bya ko ki la ste khu byug nag po mang po snyan pa'i sgra 'byin pa/

Kokilapa has the attributes of a king. He is white in color, tinged with red, and adorned with brocade garments and precious ornaments. He is seated on a jeweled throne. All around him is a pleasure grove full of fruit trees, in which the most beautiful young maidens are singing and dancing and fanning and bathing him. From the trees come the sweet calls of many black cuckoos.

a nong+ga pa sku dkar dmar shin tu mdzes pa blta bas chog mi shes pa zhabs skyil krung*/ phyag mnyam bzhag dang sa gnon gyi tshul gyis ting nge 'dzin la mnyam par bzhag bzhin rtsa yi spyil por gnas pa/

Anonga is white in color, tinged with red, and so handsome that one cannot take one’s eyes off him. He is sitting cross-legged in a grass hut, absorbed in concentration, with one hand in the meditation gesture and the other touching the earth. {84}

rnal 'byor dbang phyug chen mo lak+ShI ka ra sku mdog dkar dmar bde ba'i nyams mchog tu rgyas pa'i lang tsho'i gang ba can/ mdzes sdug gi phul du phyin pa/ sku gcer mo nu 'bur dang b+ha ga rgyas pa/ khro 'dzum chags pa'i nyams ldan/ phyag g.yas rdo rje gri gug 'phyar zhing g.yon thod khrag 'dzin pa/ mchan khung du kha T+wA~M ga bsnams zhing rus pa'i rgyan gyis mdzes pa/ zhabs brkyang bskum rol stabs kyis bzhugs pa/

The great lady of yogis Lakṣhmīnkarā is white in color, tinged with red, in the full bloom of youth, with an utterly blissful expression. She is the very height of beauty. She is naked, with fully developed breasts and bhaga. She has a semiwrathful appearance. In her right hand she brandishes a vajra curved knife, in her left a skull cup full of blood. She holds a khātvāṇga in the crook of her arm and is adorned with bone ornaments. She is sitting in the posture of royal ease, with one leg stretched out and the other drawn in.

sa mu dra pa sku mdog dkar dmar ded dpon gyi cha byad gos tsom dang thod bcings/ zhabs phyed krung gis rgya mtsho chen po gru bo che bzo khyad phun sum tshogs pa nor bu rin po ches gang ba'i dbus su bzhugs shing*/ 'khor du mas bskor ba/ steng gi nam mkha' la grub thob a tsin+ta pa gcer bu ral pa can gyis chos ston pa/

Samudrapa is white in color, tinged with red, and has the attributes of a seafarer, with a dyed robe and a turban. He is sitting with his legs half crossed in the middle of a perfectly built oceangoing ship filled with precious jewels. He is surrounded by many attendants. In the sky above him is the long-haired, naked siddha Achinta, teaching the dharma.

byA li pa sku mdog dkar dmar nor bu'i kha dog ltar 'od zer 'bar ba/ bram ze'i cha byad tshangs skud dkar po phrag par thogs pa/ ras kyi smad dkris gsol ba/ phyag gnyis bcud len gyi snod thogs shing*/ sku'i nye logs su gser 'gyur gyi rtsis gang ba'i gzhong pa dang*/ lcags mang po gser du bsgyur ba'i rnam pa can/ sku'i g.yon phyogs su chung ma dang gna' mar bcangs pa/ mdun du rta mchog ste thams cad rig pa 'dzin pa'i lus can rgyan gyis spras pa/

Vyālipa is white in color, tinged with red, and shines with rays of light colored like jewels. He has the attributes of a brahmin, with the brahmin’s sacred white thread tied over his shoulder, and wears a cotton dhoti. In his two hand he holds a vessel of elixir. Next to him is a basin of alchemical essence and piles of iron that he is transforming into gold. With him, on his left are his wife, son, and daughter-in-law. In front is a supreme horse, a creature that possesses knowledge of all things, adorned with ornaments.

de dag thams cad kyang lhan cig skyes pa mi 'gyur ba'i bde ba chen po'i ye shes kyi gzi 'od phyogs brgyar 'bar bas sku bkrag mdangs dang ldan cing bzod par dka' ba'i zil can nyi ma'i snying po lta bu/ gsung gsang sngags theg pa chen po'i chos kyi rang sgra sgrogs pa/ thugs zab gsal gnyis su med pa phyag rgya chen po bde stong zung 'jug chen por rtag tu mnyam par bzhag bzhin pa/ mdzad pa phrin las ma nges cir yang ston pa dpag par dka' ba'i sgyu 'phrul can/ snang srid dbang du sdud cing srid gsum zil gyis gnon pa/ lha dang lha mo dpag tu med pa'i mchod sprin rgya mtshos mchod pa'i sku can du gsal ba'i spyan sngar/ khyed rang rnams kyi sku lus rnam smin gyi phung po 'di nyid kyi dbu'i ya thod hag gis bkog pa'i nang du sku lus lhag ma ril por bcug pa la/ oM AHhU~M zhes brjod pas ye shes kyi bdud rtsi ro brgya dang ldan pa dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs can du mer gyis zhu ba bla ma grub thob pho mo rnams kyi ljags rdo rje'i 'od zer gyi sbu gus drangs te gsol ba'i mos pa dang bcas te 'di'i rjes zlos mdzod/

Visualize all of them shining in a hundred directions with the brilliant light of the coemergent, unchanging wisdom of great bliss. Their bodies are radiant and unbearably bright, like the heart of the sun. Their voices spontaneously proclaim the teachings of the Great Vehicle, the secret mantras. Their minds dwell constantly in meditation on the great union of bliss and emptiness, the Great Seal, profundity and clarity inseparable. In their deeds they display all kinds of unpredictable activities, with magical manifestations that are hard for one to imagine. Bringing phenomenal existence under their power, they overwhelm the three worlds. Infinite gods and goddesses venerate them with ocean-like clouds of offerings. {85} In their presence, consider your body—the aggregates that result from the ripening of your karma—and imagine that the top of your head is sliced off [to form a skull cup], into which the whole of the rest of your body is put. As I say oṁ āḥ hūṁ, it melts completely into wisdom nectar, white with a red luster and endowed with a hundred tastes. The teacher and male and female siddhas drink the nectar, drawing it up through their vajra tongues, which are in the form of tube-like rays of light. As you imagine this, repeat after me:
zhal zas ro brgya ldan zhing yid 'phrog pa/ / legs sbyar 'di ni dpal ldan bla ma la/ / dad pas phul bas 'gro ba 'di dag kun/ / 'byor ldan ting nge 'dzin zas la spyod par shog /
This deliciously prepared food offering, Bewitching with its hundred tastes, I offer with faith to the glorious teacher. May all these beings have the fortune to enjoy the food of concentration.
oM AHhU~M gu ru tsa tu rA shI ti ma hA yo ge shwa ra sa pa ri wA re b+h+yaHi daM ba li g+r+N+Sh-in+tu ma ma sarba sid+hi m+me pra yats+tsha/
oṁ āḥ hūṁ guru caturā śīti mahā yogeśvara sapari vare bhyaḥ idaṃ baling griṇśanantu mama sarva siddhimem prayaccha

de nas lus zhing rdul gyi grangs dang mnyam par sprul te bla ma grub chen rnal 'byor pho mo'i tshogs rnams kyi zhabs la spyi bos gtugs te phyag 'tshal ba'i mos pas thal mo sbyar te 'di'i rjes zlos mdzod/

Next, consider that you emanate bodies numerous as the atoms in the universe and pay homage, touching your head at the feet of the teacher and the male and female mahāsiddhas, and repeat with folded hands:
gang gi drin gyis bde chen nyid/ / skad cig nyid la 'chang ba gang*/ / bla ma rin chen lta bu'i sku/ / grub chen brgyad cu'i zhabs la 'dud/ / lan gsum/
Through their kindness, great bliss Arises in an instant. At the feet of the jewel-like teacher And of the eighty great siddhas I bow.

de ltar dad mos gdung shugs drag pos phyag 'tshal zhing gsol ba 'debs par mdzad pa'i rkyen gyis bla ma grub thob rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug brgyad cu rtsa bzhi'i dpral ba nas sku'i byin rlabs kyi rang bzhin g.yon rkyang ma dang rjes su 'brel ba'i kun da byang sems dkar po'i rgyun byung*/ khyed rang rnams kyi dpral bar thim/

Consider that, as a result of your paying homage and praying like this with intense devotion, from the foreheads of the teacher and the eighty-four siddhas, lords of yogis, there flows a stream of white semen bodhichitta,[28] associated with the kyangma channel on the left and having the nature of the blessings of the body. It dissolves into your forehead.
lus kyi dri ma dag / bum pa'i dbang thob/ sku rdo rje'i byin rlabs zhugs/
The impurities of your body are purified. You receive the vase empowerment, and the blessings of the vajra body enter you.
mgrin pa nas gsung gi byin rlabs kyi ngo bo g.yas ro ma dang rjes su 'brel ba'i rak+ta byang sems dmar po'i rgyun byung ba khyed rang rnams kyi mgrin par thim/

From their throat centers, there flows a stream of red blood bodhichitta,[29] associated with the roma channel on the right and having the nature of the blessings of speech. It dissolves into your throat.
ngag gi dri ma dag / gsang ba'i dbang thob/ gsung rdo rje'i byin rlabs zhugs/
The impurities of your speech are purified. You receive the secret empowerment, and the blessings of the vajra speech enter you. {86}
smin mtshams nas thugs kyi byin rlabs dbu ma dang rjes su 'brel ba'i khu khrag 'dres pa'i byang sems byon/ khyed rang rnams kyi smin mtshams su thim/

From between their eyebrows there comes a stream of bodhichitta, a mixture of semen and blood, associated with the central channel and constituting the blessings of mind. It dissolves between your eyebrows.
yid kyi dri dag / shes rab ye shes kyi dbang thob/ thugs rdo rje'i byin rlabs zhugs par mos mdzod/
The impurities of your mind are purified. You receive the wisdom empowerment, and the blessings of the vajra mind enter you.
de dag ni 'dra ba'i 'dra ba lam du byed pa gong ma'i brda' dbang rnam gsum yin/
With these three empowerments you are empowered to practice the three corresponding paths as indicated earlier.[30]

da bzhi pa ye shes rdo rje'i dbang bskur ba la khyed rang rnams lus gnad lta stangs g.yo ba med pa'i ngang nas sems dus gsum rnam rtog gi spros pas ma bslad par/ rang rig bde stong brjod bral gyi ngang la yud cig mnyam par 'jog par zhu/ de la gnas lugs kyi don ngo sprod pa'i tshul du bla ma grub thob chen po lU yi pas thog drangs rnal 'byor pho mo brgyad cu rtsa bzhis rang rang gi rtogs pa brjod pa do ha rdo rje'i glus rim pa bzhin du gdams pa stsol ba'i mos pa mdzod/

Now, to receive the fourth empowerment, that of the vajra gnosis, without moving from the correct physical posture and the right gaze, please settle in meditation for a moment in the state of intrinsic awareness, the inexpressible bliss-emptiness, unspoiled by the proliferation of conceptual thoughts related to the past, present, and future. In this regard, as an introduction to the meaning of the natural state, consider that the teacher, in the form of the eighty-four male and female yogis beginning with the mahāsiddha Lūyipa, successively gives you instruction by means of the vajra songs or dohās in which they expressed their own realization.

mgur rta shes na de dang sbyar/ ma shes na'ang dal zhing gsal la snyan pa'i tshig gis 'di rnams brjod do/ / khyi rgod mi bsrun sna la sbrang rtsi bkus pas phyogs rnams kun tu za bar byed/ / de bzhin blo dman skal med dag la bla ma'i gdams ngag sbyin pas rang rgyud sreg / skal bzang skye med rtogs pa dag ni snang ba thug 'phrad tsam gyis rnam rtog 'joms/ / dper na glang chen rab brtan myos pa'i sna la ral gri btags pas dgra dpung 'joms/ ! /

If you know the melodies, employ them. If not, voice these songs with sweet words, spoken unhurriedly and clearly. When honey is placed on a wild dog’s nose, it does not choose but eats up everything. So too, when those with little fortune and intelligence receive the highest teachings, they are consumed by fire. Those with good fortune who have realized the unborn nature destroy conceptual thoughts simply by encountering appearances, Like the drunk elephant Rapten[31] whose sword-tipped trunk annihilates the enemy troops. [Lūyipa][32]
tshad med bzhi yi dgon pa ru/ / rnal 'byor rgyal po seng ge bzhin/ / mgo la g.yu mdog ral lngas brgyan/ / rnal 'byor dbang rtags rigs lnga 'chang*/ /
In the jungle of the four boundless attitudes, The king of yogis is like a lion, Its head adorned with a mane of five turquoise locks— The five buddha families arising as the signs of the practice.
seng ge'i sder mo bcu dag gis/ / glang po la sogs sha rus 'byed/ / rnal 'byor pha rol phyin bcu yi/ / rnam rtog mi mthun phyogs rnams 'byed/ / lI las de ltar rtogs pas grol/ ! /

With its ten claws, the lion Rips an elephant’s flesh from the bones; With the ten perfections, the yogi Rips away their opposites, conceptual thoughts. With such realization was Līlapa freed. [Līlapa]

phyag rgya chen po'i ngang nas lhan cig skyes pa deng*/ / mi bsam mi rig bdag med rang gi ngang la bzhag / chad par mi 'gyur nyams su myong ba rang gis rig / rtag par mi 'gyur mngon zhen med par zung du 'jug ! /

Rest in your own natural state—not thought, not known, no self— Coemergent with the state of the Great Seal.[33] Not a nihilist nothing, it is experienced and knows itself. Not an eternalist something, it is union, without grasping. [Virūpa] {87}
gser 'gyur rtsi yi nus pa yis/ / lcags rnams gser du 'gyur pa ltar/ / rin chen dbang gi nus pa yis/ / nyon mongs gnyis med ye shes bsgyur/ ! /
Like the alchemist’s elixir That turns iron into gold, The precious empowerment is able to transform Defilements into nondual gnosis. [Ḍombipa]

ma rig pa yi nags tshal du/ / gzung 'dzin gnyis kyi ri dwags rgyu/ / thabs shes gnyis kyi gzhu brdungs nas/ / snying po don gyi mda' gcig 'phang*/ / 'chi ni rnam par rtog pa 'chi/ / sha ni gnyis su med par zos/ / ro ni bde ba chen por myong*/ / 'bras bu phyag rgya chen po thob/ ! /

In the forest of ignorance There roamed the deer of subject-object dualism. Drawing the bow of means and wisdom, I shot the single arrow of the essential meaning, And death ensued—the death of all conceptual thought. I ate the flesh as nonduality. I savored its taste as great bliss And obtained the result—the Great Seal. [Shavaripa]
kye ho grogs dag lhan cig skyes pa de/ / gzhan nas mi rnyed bla ma dam pa'i zhal las rnyed/ / don dam zhal gyi ngo bo de rtogs na/ / yid la 'chi ba med cing lus la chad pa med/ ! /

Behold, my friends, the coemergent state Is not to be found elsewhere but in the holy teacher’s words. When you realize the essence of that ultimate nature, The mind will never die; the body will not disintegrate. [Saraha]
ji ltar nam mkha' stong pa la/ / gcig dang gzhan gnyis spangs pa'i gzugs/ / rang snang ye shes btsun mo de/ / dpe med tha snyad kun las 'das/ ! /
In the emptiness of space, When one and other are abandoned, The self-appearing queen of gnosis takes form, Beyond compare, beyond all designation. [Kaṅkālapāda]

lcags kyu thogs pa'i nya pa ni/ / las dbang rgya mtsho'i nang du khyer/ / nya chen lus la brten byas nas/ / lha chen gdams ngag nyams blangs pas/ / yon tan sa dang rdo dag gis/ / mthog mI na pa zhes grags/ ! /

A fisherman who held on to his hook Was swept into the sea by karma’s force But kept alive inside a giant fish, Wherein he practiced Mahādeva’s words. Earth and rock could not support his weight, So excellent was he they called Fish Man or Mīnapa. [Mīnapa]

rigs ni mchog dang 'bring dang tha ma ru/ / gnas pa'i rgyu la rkyen gyis stobs ldan pas/ / 'gag med las dbang 'bras bu ngo mtshar che/ / tso raM gi la byang sems bsnyen bskur byas/ / de rkyen stobs kyis khams kyi sa bon btab/ / a tsin+d+ha yis 'chi med bdud rtsi bstan/ / gau rak+kha yis gnyis med de nyid mthong*/ / srid gsum ba rdzi'i rgyal po ngo mtshar che/ ! /

When one’s potential—highest, least, or in between— Is reinforced by circumstance, the unobstructed power of deeds Will lead to the result—a wondrous thing, indeed. With bodhichitta I served Chauraṅgi; Because of that, the seed of enlightenment was sown. Achinta showed me the nectar of deathlessness, And I, Gorakṣha, beheld the nondual ultimate reality. So marvel at me, the cowherd king of the three worlds! [Gorakṣha]

thog med srid pa yun ring du/ / ma rig sdong po'i rtsa ba la/ / 'du byed chu yis legs brlan nas/ / srid pa'i yan lag sna tshogs rgyas/ / ma rig pa yi shing chen de/ / bla ma dam pa'i gdams ngag dang*/ / shes rab gsum gyi ste'u yis/ / tsau ring+ga yis de nyid bcad/ ! /

For ages in this world without beginning, The tree of ignorance had taken root, And watered by conditioning, Its boughs—existence—grew and spread. But I, Chauraṅgi, swung my ax— And with my holy teacher’s words And wisdom gained by threefold means, I felled that mighty tree of ignorance! [Chauraṅgi]
phyin ci log la goms pa'i sgra/ / gus dang brtson pas bcad byas nas/ / ma skyes skye med sgra spyad pas/ / wI na pa yis bdag med rtogs/ ! /
With perseverance and devotion, I distinguished {88} The sound of my habitual errors And then enjoyed the unarisen sound of the unborn. Thus did I, Vīnapa, realize no-self. [Vīnapa]

bu chung ma yis gsos pa yis/ / gyad kyi stobs dang ldan pa bzhin/ / blo chung bla ma'i man ngag gis/ / rim gyis 'khrid pas theg pa che/ / rlung mkhris bad kan 'dus pa yi/ / nad rnams smin gyis sel ba ltar/ / nga dang bdag tu 'dzin pa ni/ / bla ma'i gdams pas lhan cig bsregs/ ! /

Like little boys who, nurtured by their mothers, Grow into able-bodied men, Small-minded folk are counseled by their teachers And led in stages to the Great Vehicle. Like the doctor’s medicine that cures Those with wind or bile or phlegm disease, The teacher’s guidance and advice at once burn up The “I” and the belief in “I.” [Ratnākarashānti]

'jig rten pa yi thags mkhan rnams/ / snal ma thams cad thags su btags/ / nga ni bla ma'i gdams ngag gis/ / chos rnams thams cad thags su 'thag / stong nyid gnas su ye shes lnga'i/ / snal ma man ngag btags so dang*/ / shes rab kyis ni sgrom bu yi/ / dbyings rig gnyis med chos skur btags/ ! /

The weavers of the world Weave together all their threads, While I, listening to my teacher’s words, Weave together all phenomena. Emptiness is my loom, the five wisdoms my threads; The pith instructions are my heddle, And wisdom the shuttle that I use to weave The body of truth, the nonduality of expanse and awareness. [Tantipa]

rnam rtog mtshan ma'i ko ba 'di/ / stong nyid snying rje'i spangs su bcug / chos brgyad spangs pa'i rgyun gyis ni/ / shes rab nyams myong snyung bus btsems/ / lhun grub chos sku'i l+h+wam byed pa/ / tsa ma ri pa l+h+wam mkhan mchog ! /

This leather of attributes and conceptual thoughts I soak in emptiness and compassion, And using the thread of freedom from the eight concerns, I sew it with the awl of wisdom and experience. Spontaneously creating the shoe of the body of truth, I am Chamaripa, the supreme cobbler. [Chamaripa]

mtshon cha med pa'i dpa' bo ni/ / rgyun dang dgra dang g.yul 'gyed kyang*/ / bdag nyid sdug bsngal dbang du 'gyur/ / 'chi med ye shes ral gri yis/ / srid gsum dgra rnams pham byas nas/ / khaD+ga pa yis longs spyod byed/ ! /

However constantly an unarmed warrior Does battle with his enemies, He will be overpowered by suffering.[34] But with the sword of deathless wisdom The enemies of the three worlds were vanquished, And Khaḍgapa enjoys the greatest happiness. [Khaḍgapa]
gang zhig ma rtogs spyod pa mi bya ste/ / byas na rgyal srid 'bangs kyis bzung ba bzhin/ / rtogs pas ma rtogs spyod pa mi bya ste/ / byas na glang chen 'dam du bying ba 'dra/ /

Those who are not realized should not act as if they are: They’d be like common subjects trying to seize the throne. Realized beings should never follow ordinary ways: They’d be like elephants mired in a swamp. [Nāgārjuna]

shing rta'i 'khor lo bzhi dang mi ldan khrid kyang 'gro bar mi nus ltar/ / sbyin sogs 'bad pa byas kyang bla ma mi ldan dngos grub dam pa min/ / bya rgod rtsal rdzogs 'dab gshog rgyas pa dag ni nam mkha' spyod cing rgyu/ / skal bzang rnal 'byor rnams ni dbang gi gdams ngag khong du chud pas bde/ ! /

Without four wheels, a car will never get one anywhere: Without a teacher, efforts on the paramita path will never bring supreme accomplishment. A vulture, fully fledged, on outstretched wings can soar across the sky: Yogis blessed with fortune absorb the teachings that empower and thus gain happiness. [Kṛiṣhṇāchāri]
dus gsum sangs rgyas thams cad ngo bo gcig / de ni rtogs na rang bzhin rang gi sems/ / rtogs par 'dod na ma bcos rang bzhin zhog / goms pa byas na rnal 'byor mngon du 'gyur/ /

The buddhas of the three times are of a single essence. That essence, when realized, is the nature of your own mind. If you wish for realization, settle in the unfabricated nature. {89} Once you are used to that, you will truly be a yogi. [Āryadeva]
gang zhig rna bar chu zhugs pa/ / chu nyid kyis ni 'byin pa bzhin/ / de bzhin snang srid brdzun pa la/ / brdzun par goms pas bden pa mthong*/ ! /
Like someone with water in their ear Using water to blow it out again, Get used to the lie—the falsehood of appearance and existence— And then you’ll come to see the truth. [Thaganapa]
'khor los sgyur rgyal dpung tshogs rnams kyis ni/ / gling dang gling phran rnams la dbang byed ltar/ / lhan cig skyes pa'i ro rnyed rnal 'byor ni/ / 'khor ba dbang sgyur bde ba chen po yin/ ! /
Like the universal monarch and his armies Ruling over the entire world, The yogi who discovers the taste of the innate Dominates samsara and knows great bliss. [Nāropa]
legs sbyangs ri mo mkhan dag gis/ / shin tu 'jigs pa'i gzugs brnyan bris/ / mthong na bdag nyid 'jigs 'gyur la/ / brtags nas ma grub gzugs brnyan snang*/ ! /
Well-trained artists draw and paint Pictures that strike terror in one’s heart. But look at what it is that frightens you: It’s just an image, there’s nothing real there! [Shyalipa]
ri rab ngos la bya gnas pa/ / bya yi rang bzhin gser du snang*/ / mkhas pa skye med rtogs pa yis/ / dngos po bor na bde ba che/ ! /
Birds that dwell on Meru’s heights Look as if they’re made of gold. The wise who realize the unborn Forsake materiality and gain great bliss. [Tilopa]
rnal 'byor pa yis gang mthong gdams pa yin/ / mthong ba skye med rtogs pa slob dpon mchog / byis pa rnams kyi gnyis 'dzin rtogs pa yis/ / dge sdig 'bras bu de la gnyis mi 'byung*/ ! /

Everything that yogis see they see as an instruction; Realization that it is unborn is their greatest teacher. They’ll never taste the fruits of deeds, both good and bad, That come from immature beings’ dualistic thoughts. [Chatrapa]
stong nyid rtogs pas 'khrul pa dag / byams pa sgoms pas spyod pa rdzogs/ / sna tshogs gnyis med sgoms pa yis/ / gzhi mthun ro gcig 'bras bu yin/ ! /

Through the realization of emptiness, delusion is purified. Through meditation on love, conduct is perfected. Through meditation on the absence of two in diversity, The result is the one taste, the common ground. [Bhadrapa]
kun rdzob bskyed pa'i rim pa dang*/ / don dam rdzogs pa'i rim pa gnyis/ / zung 'jug phyag rgya chen pos bsgom/ / 'bras bu sku gsum ye shes 'char/ ! /
Meditating on the Great Seal—the union Of the relative, the generation stage, And the ultimate, the perfection stage— I saw the wisdom of the three bodies, the result. [Dhukhandi]
bla ma dam pa'i gdams ngag gis/ / steng sgo sna rtser thig le sgom/ / de nyid la ni blo brtan pas/ / yungs kar stong gsum dmigs pa rtogs/ ! /
With the instructions of my holy teacher I meditated on a drop on the tip of my nose, And with mind fixed firmly on that upper door, I saw a billion worlds within a mustard seed. [Āyogipāda]
'gro ba 'di dag thog med dus nas 'khrul/ / de yis 'jig rten thams cad smyon par grags/ / bla ma'i gdams ngag bdud rtsi sman gyis ni/ / 'khrul pa'i nad rnams skad cig gcig la bsreg ! /

Since time without beginning these beings have been deluded, And so it is the whole world called me mad. The nectarous medicine of my teacher’s words Consumed in an instant the sickness of delusion. [Kalapa]
yun ring dus na dri ma 'khrud byas kyang*/ / sol ba'i rang bzhin dkar por 'gyur ba med/ / rang bzhin rnam dag stong nyid gos dag la/ / bla ma'i gdams pa rang bzhin khrus mkhan mchog ! /

However long one tries to wash out stains, There is no making charcoal’s nature white. To cleanse the stains that cover emptiness—already pure— The teacher’s counsel is the best of washermen. {90} [Dhombipa]
rtogs pa yid bzhin nor bu la/ / nyams su myong ba'i mdog 'byung bas/ / spyod pa nus pas dgos 'dod 'byung*/ / ro snyoms ldan pa rnams kyis 'grub/ ! /
The wish-fulfilling gem of realization Glows with the luster of experience, Powerful activity fulfilling every need. It is the prize of those with even taste. [Kaṅkana]

rgya mtsho zab cing rgya che'i nang na nor bus gang ba la/ / klu yi rgyal po rnams ni de la longs spyod ngo mtshar che/ / de bzhin snang grags thams cad ye nas chos skur yin pa la/ / rtogs pa dang ldan rnams ni de la longs spyod ngo mtshar che/ ! /

I wonder at the ocean, deep and vast and filled with jewels, And the nāga kings who revel in all that wealth. I wonder at the sights and sounds that are primordially the body of truth, And those with realization reveling in its wealth. [Kambala]

rta dang glang po rgya mtsho 'dra na rab tu bde/ / spre'u byis pa chu yi ri mo 'dra na rtogs pa yin/ / chu bo nyi ma sman dang 'dra na dbyer mi phyed/ / gtsug phud mig dang 'khor lo lta bus 'bras bu thob/ ! /

A horse, an elephant, the ocean illustrate the highest bliss. Monkeys, children, water-drawings illustrate realization. A river, the sun, and medicine illustrate indivisibility. A topknot, an eye, and a wheel symbolize the result attained. [Ḍiṅgipa]
mngon zhen med pa byams pa'i mchog / gnas lugs rtogs pa snying rje yin/ / zag med bde ba dga' ba ste/ / gzhi mthun ro gcig btang snyoms rdzogs/ ! /
Absence of attachment is the highest love. Compassion is to know just how things are. Bliss completely free of taint is joy. Impartiality is basic harmony—one taste. [Bhandhepa]
ji ltar dran rig sna tshogs dag / rtog med dbyings su zad cing 'gag / de bzhin snang srid chos rnams kun/ / stong nyid dbyings su zad cing 'gags/ ! /
All kinds of memories and conscious thoughts Come to an end in the space of thoughtlessness; And likewise all things that appear and exist Come to an end in the space of emptiness. [Tandhepa]
sangs rgyas mchod sogs rnams la don mi 'byung*/ / 'dod dang 'bad rtsol yod na sangs rgyas min/ / byin rlabs bla ma'i zhal las nyams myong dpal/ / cha ldan rang la yod kyang ma mthong ngo*/ ! /

“Buddha, dharma,…” such thoughts do not benefit— Wishes and efforts cannot lead to buddhahood. The glory of experience comes from the teacher’s blessings: It’s there inside you, lucky one, but you can’t see it. [Kukkuripa]
bla ma'i gsung gi 'od zer gyis/ / yod dang med pa'i mtha' ma rnyed/ / gang zhig ma rnyed de mtha'o/ / mtha' de rtogs na don gyi mchog ! /
Under the spotlight of the teacher’s words, One fails to find extremes like “is” and “isn’t.” Finding nothing is itself an extreme; To realize that is the ultimate goal. [Kujipa]
gnyis 'dzin ma rig dug dbang gi / rig pa'i skyes bu rgyun du bzung*/ / bla ma'i gsung gi byin rlabs kyis/ / snang srid 'khrul pa'i dug nad sel/ /
The poison of dualism and ignorance Constantly afflicts the rational. The blessings of the teacher’s word Remove the poison of delusion in the world. [Dhamapa]
ma rig nga rgyal ri bo yis/ / rtogs pa yid bzhin nor bu sgribs/ / spyod pa nus pas dgos 'dod 'byung*/ / ro snyoms ldan pa rnams kyis 'grub/ ! /
The mountain of one’s ignorance and pride Conceals the wishing gem of realization, Whose powerful activity fulfills one’s every need. It is the prize of those with even taste. [Mahila]
dmigs med phyag rgya chen po ru/ / 'khrul pa'i dran rig sna tshogs stong*/ / ye shes rig pa'i snang ba yis/ / rang snang phyag rgya chen por mthong*/ ! /
In the nonconceptual Great Seal, Empty all your deluded thoughts. With the light of gnosis and awareness, See everything that appears as the Great Seal. [Achinta]
dper na ngang pa'i rgyal po yis/ / chu las 'o ma 'byed pa bzhin/ / bla ma dam pa'i gdams ngag gis/ / byang chub sems kyi bdud rtsi blangs/ /
Like the king of swans, Which separates milk from water, {91} The holy teacher’s words Distill the nectarous bodhichitta.[35]
