zhes dmigs la bsam med gnyug ma'i rang ngor mnyam par 'jog / de las ldang ba na/ e ma ma la dus gsum dge ba 'dis/ / bdag dang mar gyur mtha' yas sems can kun/ / grub pa mchog gis rtag par rjes bzung nas/ / phyag rgya chen po'i dngos grub myur thob shog / mgo bor bla ma'i cod pan 'chang*/ / lag tu rdo rje dril bu 'dzin/ / ngag tu gsang sngags rgyal po bzla/ / yid kyis zung 'jug bsgom par shog / ces sogs thun mong ma yin pa'i bsngo smon gdab cing shis brjod kyis mtha' brgyan no/ ! /

Now settle in meditative equipoise in your true nature, the natural state beyond thought. Arising from that state, say extraordinary prayers of dedication and aspiration, beginning with: Wonderful! Excellent! By the merit of this and all virtue, past, present, and future, May we and all the infinite beings who have been our mothers Always be guided by the supreme accomplished beings And swiftly attain the accomplishment of the Great Seal. May our heads be crowned by the teacher, Our hands hold the vajra and bell, Our voices recite the kingly secret mantras, And our minds meditate on the union state. Conclude beautifully with prayers for auspiciousness.

de bzhin du gzhan 'dra ba la/ mngon rtogs kyi skabs/ pags pa'i gdan la rtsa ba'i bla ma dang gnyis su med pa'i dpal mgon 'phags pa klu sgrub sku mdog sngo sangs nor bu'i kha dog lta bu dwangs shing dri ma med pa mtshan dang dpe byad kyis spras shing phyag gnyis chos 'khor gyi phyag rgya thugs kar 'ching ba/ na bza' chos gos gsum dang bcas shing rdo rje'i skyil mo krung gi bzhugs pa shaM kha la sogs pa'i klu'i rgyal po mchog rnams sbrul gyi rnam pas gdengs ka'i grib ma 'bul ba la sku rgyab brten pa/ thugs gnyis su med pa'i ye shes man gong bzhin la/ bstod pa'i skabs/ nA gA rdzu na'i zhabs la 'dud/ /

The ritual procedure for other siddhas is similar. At the stage of the visualization, begin the above visualization and continue, for example, with: {141} …seated upon an antelope skin is the glorious protector noble Nāgārjuna, inseparable from my root teacher. He is azure blue in color, as radiant as a jewel, free of blemish, and adorned with the major and minor marks. His two hands are held at his heart in the gesture of teaching the dharma. He is dressed in the three dharma robes and seated cross-legged in the vajra posture. Shaṃkha and other supreme kings of the nāgas, taking the form of snakes, are offering him the shade of their hoods and providing a backrest for him to lean against. His mind constantly rests in meditation in the state of nondual gnosis, the Great Seal, the body of truth. From here on, continue as above until the last line of the praise, where you should say: Nāgārjuna, at your lotus feet I bow down.
mtshan sngags kyang sa ra ha'i tshab tu/ /nA gA rdzu na ma gtogs gzhan gong dang 'dra ba nyid do/ / ! /
For the name mantra, in place of Saraha, you should say Nāgārjuna. The rest is the same as above.
de bzhin sha ba ri la'ang*/
The same principle applies for Shavaripa:

bla ma dang grub pa'i dbang phyug dpal ri khrod pa chen po/ 'gyur ba med pa'i chos nyid mtshon pa'i sku mdog nag po/ dbu skra ral pa spyi bor bcings pa smyug ma'i shun pas bsdams pa/ spyan 'bru tshugs su gzigs shing spyan rtsa dmar ba/ phyag gnyis mda' dang 'od ma'i gzhu mchog la phag rgod kyi khog stong dang khog smad bkal ba/ rma bya'i mdangs sgro gshibs pa'i sham thabs dang*/ me tog 'bras bu'i rgyan sna tshogs pas brgyan te 'gyings bag dang bcas pa'i rol stabs su bzhugs pa/ sku'i g.yas g.yon nas rig ma rgyan dang cha lugs gtso bo dang mtshungs shig mda' dong 'dzin pa gnyis kyis brten pa/ lhan cig skyes pa'i bde ba man 'dra/ ri khrod dbang phyug zhabs la 'dud/ / sha ba ri pA da zhes bsgyur ba ma gtogs 'dra/ bstod pa'i skabs spro na nags rin gyis mdzad pa'i sha ba ri pa'i bstod chen sogs kyang 'don no/ ! /

…the lord of accomplished beings, the glorious Great Hermit, inseparable from my root teacher. He is black in color, symbolizing the unchanging ultimate reality. His long hair is tied up on his head, held with a bamboo stem. He stares with protruding, bloodshot eyes. In his two hands he holds an arrow and a bamboo bow, on the ends of which are attached the front and rear halves of a wild boar. He is adorned with a skirt made up of rows of peacock feathers, and with all kinds of flower and fruit ornaments. He is seated in the posture of royal ease, with a dignified air. On his right and left he is accompanied by two wisdom consorts who have the same ornaments and attire as himself and are holding quivers. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is as the same as above, except for Lord of the Mountains, at your lotus feet we bow down and śavari pāda in the name mantra. For the praise, if you wish, you can recite the great praise of Shavaripa composed by Vanaratna.[5]

de bzhin du grub chen nag po spyod pa la'ang*/ rtsa ba'i bla ma dang gnyis su med pa'i grub pa'i slob dpon brtul zhugs spyod pa'i dbang phyug kah+na pa chen po sku mdog nag po dpa' zhing sgeg pa hur bag chags pa phyag g.yas cang te'u 'khrol zhing*/ g.yon ka pA la bdud rtsis gang ba 'dzin pa'i mchan khung du rdo rje kha T+wA~M ga bsgreng ba/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs can sku la mi rus kyi phyag rgya drug gis brgyan cing stag gi pags pa'i shams thabs gsol ba/ pi shwa rU pi nI zhes bya ba'i srin mo'i gtso mo 'jigs su rung ba gdan nam bzhon pa'i tshul du gnas pa'i steng na rol stabs su bzhugs pa/ res 'ga' ro langs chen po me tog gi phreng bas brgyan pa la chibs pa sogs sna tshogs pa'i rnam 'phrul ston par mdzad bzhin pa'i/ steng gi nam mkha' la gdugs bdun 'dzin pa med par 'khor zhing*/ DA ma ru bdun 'khrol ba po med par rang 'khrol ba/ res 'ga' gdugs bdun brgyad DA ma ru bdun brgyar 'phel ba'i cho 'phrul can/ snang ba'i 'khor bdun brgya dang mi snang ba'i 'khor bdun brgya la sogs pa grub pa dang rig pa 'dzin pa'i rnal 'byor pho mo grangs med dbus na rol ba/ lhan cig skyes pa'i bde ba man 'dra/ spyod 'chang dbang po'i zhabs la 'dud/ / tsar+Ya badz+ra ram/ kah+nar+Ya ka pA da zhes sbyar ba dang*/

Likewise, for the mahāsiddha Kāṇḥapa:[6] …the master of accomplished beings, lord of yogic practitioners, the great Kāṇḥapa, inseparable from my root teacher. He is black in color, looking brave, attractive, and calmly poised. With his right hand he is playing a hand drum; in his left he holds a skull cup full of nectar, with a vajra khātvāṇga rising from the crook of his arm. {142} His hair is tied up in a topknot, and his body is ornamented with the six ornaments made from human bones. He is wearing a tiger-skin skirt. He is sitting in the posture of royal ease on top of a seat or mount of the terrifying form of Pishvarūpinī, the queen of the rākṣhasīs. From time to time, he displays various kinds of miraculous powers such as riding on a revived corpse adorned with garlands of flowers. In the sky above him seven parasols turn without anyone holding them, and seven hand drums sound spontaneously without anyone playing them. Sometimes he magically multiplies the seven parasols and seven hand drums a hundredfold. He manifests in the middle of countless male and female yogis—siddhas and vidyādharas—a visible following of seven hundred, an invisible following of seven hundred, and so on. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Lord of Practitioners, at your lotus feet we bow down and cāryavajra or kāṇḥacārya pāda in the name mantra.

! gnyis su med pa grub pa'i dbang phyug bi rU pa chen po sku mdog smug nag sbom zhing thung la gsus khyim che ba/ dbu skra co bregs la me tog gi phreng bas spud pa/ lhag ma rgyan spangs shing phyag g.yas sdigs mdzub kyi phyag rgya gdengs pas nyi ma brtod la gnon pa'i tshul dang*/ g.yon pa man gyi rwa zhal chang gis gang ba dkur brten pa/ sha na'i gos kyis 'doms dkris can rol pa'i 'dug stangs su bzhugs pa/ g.yon gyi phyogs nas rig ma chang snod 'dzin pas 'dud pa'i tshul can/ lhan cig skyes pa'i man 'dra/ bi rU pa la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / bi rU pA da zhes bsgyur ba dang*/

[For Virūpa:]…the lord of accomplished beings, the great Virūpa, inseparable from my root teacher. He is dark brown, short and fat, with a large belly. His uncut hair is decorated with a garland of flowers. He is devoid of any other ornaments. His right hand is raised in the threatening gesture, tethering and subduing the sun. His left hand rests on his hip holding a decorative drinking horn filled with liquor. He is wearing a hemp loincloth and sitting in the posture of royal ease. To his left is his spiritual consort, holding a bowl of liquor and bowing down to him. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Virūpa, to you in homage we bow and virūpāda.

! grub pa'i dbang phyug Dom+b+hi he ru ka sku mdog dkar dmar ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus pa'i rgyan drug gis brgyan pa/ shin tu 'jigs pa'i sbrul reg pa'i dug can gyis rgyan du mdzad cing*/ mthong ba'i dug can lcag gi tshul du bsnams pa/ kha rlangs kyi dug can bdun gyis dbu'i steng du gdangs gar byas shing*/ stag mo mi bzad 'jigs su rung ba la chibs pa'i brla g.yon pa'i steng nas gsang ba'i gzungs ma g.yung mo rnal 'byor ma gcer mo pad+ma can gyi mtshan nyid yongs su rdzogs pas dam du 'khyud cing 'khril ba'i bde bas dgyes rgur rol pa/ lhan cig skyes man 'dra/ Dom+b+hi pa la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / Dom+b+hi he ru ka pA da zhes bsgyur/

[For Ḍombi Heruka:]…the lord of accomplished beings, Ḍombi Heruka, inseparable from my root teacher. He is white in color, tinged with red, with his hair in a topknot, and bedecked with the six bone ornaments. He is adorned with terrifying snakes, poisonous to the touch, and holds a whip in the form of a snake, venomous to behold. {143} His head is hooded by seven snakes with noxious breath. He is mounted on a fearful man-eating tigress. On his left thigh is his secret consort, a lower-caste yoginī, who is naked and possesses all the marks of a padminī consort. They are in close embrace, delighting in the bliss of their union. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Ḍombipa, to you in homage we bow and ḍombi heruka pāda.

! grub pa'i dbang phyug lU hi pa chen po sku mdog sngo sangs skems shing rid pa'i tshul can ral pa'i thor tshugs cung zad dang bcas shing ras kyi smad dkris gsol ba/ sku'i mdun phyogs su nya'i rgyu lto spungs pa las phyag gis blangs te zhal du gsol ba'i rnam pa can phyed skyil gyis bzhugs pa/ lhan cig skyes man 'dra ba la/ lU hi pa la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / lU hi pA da zhes bsgyur ba dang*/

[For Lūyipa:]…the lord of accomplished beings, the great Lūhipa,[7] inseparable from my root teacher. His body is azure blue in color, and he looks emaciated. His hair is partly tied in a topknot, and he is wearing a cotton dhoti. In front of him is a meal of heaped-up fish entrails, which he is picking at and appearing to eat. He is seated with his legs half-crossed. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Lūhipa, to you in homage we bow and lūhi pāda.

! bla ma dang gnyis su med pa'i grub pa'i dbang phyug gau rak+Sha nA tha sku mdog dkar sngo snum pa'i mdangs can shangs rgyud mtho zhing 'dzum bag gi mdangs dang ldan pa/ ag tshom dang dbu skra ljang ser/ lta stangs cer re pa/ snyan la mu dra nag po dang*/ mgul du sing+ga nA da'i rwa dung 'chang zhing sku la tsakra kan+ta ste 'khor lo lta bu'i bem po gsol ba/ sgom shing la kos go brten pa'i tshul gyis skyil krung dang bcas drang por bzhugs shing*/ phyag mnyam bzhag gi steng na ku ba'i snod thogs pa/ mthong ba'i mod la nyams dga' zhing tha mal gyi snang ba hrul por 'jig pa/ lhan cig skyes pa man 'dra/ gau rak+Sha la gus pas 'dud/ / gau rak+Sha nA tha pA da bsgyur ba dang*/

[For Gorakṣha:]…the lord of accomplished beings, Gorakṣhanātha, inseparable from my root teacher. He is light blue in color, with a shiny complexion. He has a protruding nose and is smiling. His beard and hair are yellowish green. His gaze is fixed in a stare. He is wearing black bone earrings, a siṅganāda horn trumpet round his neck, and on his body a chakrakanta cloth, with wheel-like motifs. He is resting his chin on a meditation stick, sitting straight with his legs crossed. In his hands in the gesture of meditation he holds a gourd. Seeing him instantly brings delight and utterly destroys ordinary perceptions. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Gorakṣha, to you respectfully we bow and gorakṣhanātha pāda.

! grub pa'i slob dpon chen po tin+ti pa sngo sangs shin tu smin pa'i na tshod can gyi sku lus/ ag tshom dang sma ra ring du 'phyang ba dbu skyes dang bcas pa rab tu dkar ba'i mdangs can/ ras kyi smad dkris gsol zhing khri 'thags kyi bya ba la brtson pa'i tshul du bzhugs pa/ lhan cig skyes pa sogs dang*/ tan+ti pa la gus pas 'dud/ tan+ti ka pA da sogs/

[For Tantipa:]…the great master of accomplished beings, Tantipa, inseparable from my root teacher. His body is azure blue, and he is of an advanced age, with drooping beard, mustache, and hair all completely white. He is wearing a cotton loincloth and working hard at a loom. {144} Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… The rest is the same as above, with the following adaptations: Tantipa, to you respectfully we bow and tantika pāda.

! grub pa'i dbang phyug dril bu pa sku mdog sngo sangs ral pa'i thor tshugs can/ rus pa'i rgyan drug dang stag gi pags pa'i shams thabs 'phyang ba/ phyag gnyis rdo rje dang dril bu 'dzin pas yum pad+ma can gyi mtshan nyid yongs su rdzogs pa rdo rje rnal 'byor ma'i rnam pa dkar gsal lta bas chog mi shes pa la 'khyud de mnyam par sbyor ba'i bde ba rgyas pa/ zhabs g.yas brkyang gi stabs can zhes dang*/ dril bu pa la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / badz+ra g+haN+Da pA da zhes so/ /

[For Ghaṇḍhapa:]…the lord of accomplished beings, Ghaṇḍhapa, inseparable from my root teacher. He is light blue in color. His hair is tied up in a topknot, and he is draped with the six bone ornaments and a tiger-skin skirt. His two hands hold a vajra and bell, embracing his consort: she has all the marks of a padminī consort, in the form of Vajrayoginī, radiant white and entrancingly beautiful. They are delighting in the bliss of union. He is standing with his right leg extended… Bell-ringer Ghaṇḍhapa, to you in homage we bow and vajra ghaṇḍa pāda.

! grub pa'i dbang phyug chen po dzA lan+da ra sku mdog dkar dmar ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus pa'i rgyan can ras dmar po'i 'doms dkris gsol ba/ zhabs phyogs gcig rgyab nas dpung par bkal zhing phyogs gcig bzhengs pa'i tshul can/ phyag gnyis rdo rje gtsug tor gyi phyag rgya ldog ste spyi bor 'chings pa/ g.yon gyi phyogs nas rig ma rnal 'byor ma'i cha byad can gyis 'dud bzhin pa zhes dang*/ dzA lan+dA ra'i zhabs la 'dud/ / dzA lan+d+ha ra pA da zhes so/ /

[For Jālandhara:]…the great lord of accomplished beings, Jālandhara, inseparable from my root teacher. He is white in color, tinged with red. His hair is dressed in a topknot, and he is wearing bone ornaments and a red dhoti. With one leg tucked back over his shoulder, he stands on the other leg. His two hands are opposed in the vajra uṣhnīṣha mudra, binding the crown. On his left, his wisdom consort, in the attire of a yoginī, is bowing down to him… Jālandhara, to you respectfully we bow and jālandhara pāda.

! grub pa'i slob dpon chen po ku ku ri pa sku mdog sngo sangs rus pa'i rgyan dang ral pa'i thor tshugs can/ phyed skyil gyis bzhugs shing thod pa 'dzin pa'i pang du rdo rje yan lag ma ku ku ri gzhon nu'i gzugs can bzung ste dgyes rgur rol pa/ zhes dang*/ ku ku rI par phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / ku ku ri pA da zhes so/ /

[For Kukkuripa:]…the great master of accomplished beings, Kukkuripa, inseparable from my root teacher. He is azure blue in color, wears bone ornaments, and has his hair tied up in a topknot.Sitting with his legs half-crossed, he holds a skull cup. On his lap he holds Vajrayoginī, in the form of a young dog, in whom he takes delight… Kukkuripa, to you in homage we bow and kukkuri pāda.

! grub pa'i slob dpon chen po l+wa ba pa sku mdog dkar dmar tshangs pa spyod pa'i cha byad can/ sku la l+wa ba'i dum bu brgya phrag bsdus te drubs pa'i na bza' gsol zhing phyag gnyis mnyam bzhag gi phyag rgyas skyil mo krung bcas te gnyid 'thug gi zol gyis 'od gsal bsam gyis mi khyab pa la mnyam par 'jog pa'i tshul can/ zhes dang*/ l+wa ba pa la phyag 'tshal 'dud/ / kam+pa la pA da bsgyur ba dang*/

! nyer spyod mtha' klas pas brgyan pa'i dbus su grub pa'i slob dpon chen po in+d+ra b+hU ti mi'i bdag po stobs kyis 'khor los bsgyur ba'i cha byad sku mdog dkar dmar mdzes shing brjid la chags pa'i nyams can dar dang rin po che'i rgyan spras te nor bu'i khri stan mtho zhing yangs la bkod legs pa'i steng du bde lugs su bzhugs pa'i sku'i mtha' bskor du bud med rin po che'i mtshan nyid rdzogs pa'i btsun mo'i tshogs lnga brgyas bskor ba 'dod pa'i yon tan thams cad la rjes su chags pas rtag tu dgyes rgur rol pa'i rnam pa can/ zhes dang*/ in+d+ra b+hu ti la phyag 'tshal/ / shrI na ren+d+ra b+hU ti pA da/ zhes so/ /

[For Indrabhūti:]…and celestial offerings. In the center of the palace is the great master of accomplished beings Indrabhūti [inseparable from my root teacher]. Being the sovereign of humankind, he is attired as a universal monarch, resplendent and beautiful, white in color, tinged with red, with an attractive expression. He is adorned with silks and jewels and is comfortably seated on a lofty, broad jeweled throne, perfectly disposed. He is surrounded by five hundred queens bearing all the marks of the most precious ladies and is constantly and passionately delighting in all the pleasures of the senses… Indrabhūti, to you we pay homage and śrī narandra bhūti pāda.

! grub pa'i slob dpon chen po dpal bde ba chen po pad+ma kI ra sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs chags pa/ zhal gyi dkyil 'khor rab tu gang zhing rgyas la/ pad+ma rgyas pa lta bu'i spyan ras dang mchu sgros mnga' ba/ dbu'i dpral ba'i dbyibs su rdo rjes mtshan pa'i pad+ma rgyas pa'i re khAs spras zhing*/ / sku'i cha shas thams cad du pad+ma ut+pal lcags kyu zhags pa la sogs pa'i sha mtshan dge ba sha stag gis spras pa/ kAN+Ta ka'i cod pan mnabs shing*/ gsang gos kyi steng du chos gos rnam pa gsum gsol ba/ phyag g.yas rdo rje rtse lnga la thugs kar gdengs shing*/ g.yon ka pA la bdud rtsis gang ba dkur brten pa'i mchan du rdo rje'i kha T+wA~M ga bcug pa/ zhabs rdo rje'i skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa'i sku'i g.yas g.yon nas mtshan nyid thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa'i pad+ma nI bcu drug pa'i lang tsho can gyis brten pa/ lhan cig skyes pa'i sogs dang*/ pad+mA kar ra phyag 'tshal 'dud/ shrI ma hA su kha pad+ma badz+ra pA da zhes bsgyur ba dang*/

[For Padmākara:]…the great master of accomplished beings, Glorious Great Bliss, Padmākara, inseparable from my root teacher. He has a white complexion, tinged with red. His face is round and full, his eyes and lips like lotuses in full bloom. His forehead is ornamented with the figure of a blossoming lotus marked with a vajra. Every part of his body is adorned with exclusively virtuous marks—lotuses, utpalas, hooks, lassos, and the like. He wears a kāṇṭaka crown[9] and is dressed in the three dharma robes on top of the secret undergarment. In his right hand he holds up a five-pronged vajra at the level of his heart, and in his left hand, resting on his hip, he holds a kapāla full of nectar. A vajra khātvāṇga is tucked into the crook of his left arm. He sits with his legs crossed in the vajra posture and is accompanied on his right and left by sixteen-year-old maidens bearing all the marks of padminīs. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss…. Padmākara, to you in homage we bow. and śrī mahāsukha padma vajra pāda.

! grub pa'i slob dpon chen po nag po bi rU pa/ dbu la rdo rje thod ces bya ba rten 'brel gyi byin rlabs kyi cod pan sngon po gsol zhing*/ phyag g.yas ba men gyi rwa ba bdud rtsis gang ba 'dzin zhing gsol ba/ g.yon pus mo'i steng du bzhag pa/ sku'i mdun du ka pA la ma hA ba las gang ba bzhag cing*/ dbu skra co breg lpags pa'i gdan dang 'doms dkris can/ lhag ma rgyan dang na bza' spangs shing rnal 'byor pa hur bag chags pa'i rnam pa/ sku'i g.yon nas rig ma thal mo sbyar ba dang bcas pa/ lhan cig sogs dang*/ nag po bi rU pa la 'dud/ / kr-iSh+Na pi rU pA da zhes bsgyur/

[For Kṛiṣhṇavirūpa:]…the great master of accomplished beings Kṛiṣhṇavirūpa, inseparable from my root teacher. On his head he wears the blue Vajra Skull crown, which confers blessings through any connection with it. {146} He is drinking from a decorative drinking horn full of nectar, which he holds in his right hand. His left hand rests on his knee. In front of him is a kapāla filled with mahābala. His hair is uncut; he is seated on an animal skin and wearing a loincloth. He wears no other ornaments and has the appearance of an elegant yogi. To his left is his spiritual consort, with her hands folded. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… Kṛiṣhṇavirūpa, to you we bow and kṛṣṇa virū pāda.

! brgyan pa'i dbus su grub pa'i dbang phyug til+li pa chen po sku mdog chen po sku mdog sngon ga dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs can/ ras kyi ang+ga rag gsol zhing ming 'greng gang tsam gyi nam mkha' la 'phags te til brdung ba'i rnam pa can/ sku'i mdun du rig ma til mkhan mo'i rnam pas bar snang la gnas bzhin tu til lugs pa'i bya ba la brtson pa dang thabs cig tu lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes ji ltar 'byung ba'i brda ston par mdzad pa/ bde ba chen po'i ye shes kyi sogs dang*/ til+li pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / til+li ku pA da hU~M hU~M/

[For Tillipa:]…In the center of the palace is the lord of accomplished beings, the great Tillipa,[10] inseparable from my root teacher. He is dark blue in color, with his hair tied up in a topknot. He is wearing cotton shorts and is levitating to the height of a person. He has the appearance of a sesame grinder. In front of him in the air is his spiritual consort, in the form of a female sesame vendor, hard at work in the sesame trade, symbolically showing how the coemergent gnosis arises with skillful means. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… Tillipa, to you we pay homage and tilliku pāda hūṁ hūṁ.

! grub ba'i slob dpon chen po dpal nA ro pa sku mdog smug nag lta bar mi bzod pa'i zil dang ldan pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs dang rus pa'i rgyan drug gis spras shing dar gyi ang+ga rag gsol ba/ zhing chen gyi pags pa bshus ma thag pa khrag 'dzags pa stod g.yogs kyi tshul du mnabs pa'i rkang lag gnyis nas phyag gis bzung ste phan tshun du brgyangs pa/ zhabs brkyang bskum gyi tshul du bzhugs pa'i gar stabs can/ lhan cig skyes sogs dang*/ nA ro pa yi zhabs la 'dud/ / nA ro pA da zhes bsgyur ba dang*/

[For Nāropa:]…the great master of accomplished beings, glorious Nāropa, inseparable from my root teacher. He is dark maroon in color, dazzlingly resplendent. His locks are tied up in a topknot, and his body is adorned with the six bone ornaments. He wears silk shorts. As an upper garment, he is wearing a freshly flayed human skin, dripping blood, the hands and feet of which he holds in his hands, stretching them to either side. He stands in the dancing posture, with one leg extended and the other bent. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… Nāropa, at your feet we bow and nāro pāda.

! dbus su grub pa'i slob dpon chen po dpal shrAn+ti pa sku mdog sngo skya gnas brtan rdo rje 'dzin pa chen po/ cung zad smin pa'i na tshod can gyi rnam pa chos gos rnam pa gsum dang paN+Di ta'i cod pan mnabs shing*/ phyag gnyis chos 'chad kyi phyag rgya dang bcas te ta la'i byang bur bris pa'i glegs bam bsnams pa/ zhabs rdo rje'i skyil mo krung gis gding ba la bzhugs pa dang*/ shIn+ti pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ / rat+na A ga ra shAn+ti pA zhes sbyar/ de bzhin tu/

[For Ratnākarashānti:]…In the center of the palace is the great master of accomplished beings Ratnākarashānti,[11] inseparable from my root teacher. He is light blue in color and takes the form of a sthavira, a great vajra holder of rather mature years. He is wearing the three dharma robes and the paṇḍita’s hat. {147} With his two hands in the gesture of teaching the dharma, he holds a book written on palm leaves. He is sitting on a mat with his legs crossed in the vajra posture… Shāntipa, to you we pay homage and ratnākaraśāntipā.

! brgyan pa'i dbus su slob dpon chen po shrI satwa nA tha shAn+ti gup+ta sku mdog smug nag / rin po che dang rus pa'i rgyan tho re bas spras pa/ sku sha nyams rgyas shing brjid la hur bag chags pa/ dbu skra co breg ras kyis 'doms dkris gru gsum pa gsol zhing zhabs gnyis bzang po'i 'dug stangs kyis rin po che'i khri la pags pa'i gdan gyi steng du bzhugs pa/ phyag gnyis chos kyi 'khor lo'i phyag rgya thugs kar 'ching ba/ lhan cig skyes sogs dang*/ shAn+ti gup+ta la phyag 'tshal/ / shrI satwa nA tha shAn+ti gup+ta hU~M hU~M/ zhes sbyar/

[For Shāntigupta:]…In the center of the palace is the great master of accomplished beings Shrī Satvanāthashāntigupta, inseparable from my root teacher. He is dark maroon in color and adorned with a few jewel and bone ornaments. Fully fleshed and resplendent, he has the appearance of a calmly poised yogi. His hair is uncut, and he wears a triangular cotton loincloth. He is sitting in the style [of Maitreya] on a jeweled throne covered with an animal skin, with both feet [flat on the ground]. His two hands are held at the level of his heart in the gesture of teaching the dharma. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… Shāntigupta, to you we pay homage and śrī satvanāthaśāntigupta hūṁ hūṁ.

! de bzhin du/ pags pa'i gdan la rtsa ba'i bla ma dang gnyis su med pa'i slob dpon chen po shrI bud+d+ha gup+ta dzo gi'i cha byad can sku mdog dkar la dmar ba'i mdangs chags pa/ sku bong che zhing lhun chags la dang ba 'dren pa/ mthong ba'i mod la ba spu g.yo zhing skyi bung zhes byed pa'i bril dang ldan pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor tshugs su bcings pa'i rtse mo nas ral pa'i zar bu cung zad rgyab tu 'phyang ba/ me tog ser po kha bye ma thag pa'i thod bcings gsol pa/ bgres rgud spangs pa'i lang tshos gang ba lag nas shing hur bag chags pa/ ras kyi 'doms dkris dang na bza' gsol zhing pus 'khyud can/ phyag g.yas sa gnon pus steng du bkab cing g.yon ka pA la bdud rtsis gang ba dkur brten pa'i tshul gyis 'dzin pa/ sku drangs por bsrangs te skyil krung phyed pa'i 'dug stangs kyis bzhugs pa/ lhan cig skyes pa'i sogs dang*/ bud+d+ha gup+tar gus phyag 'tshal/ / shrI bud+d+ha gup+ta nA tha hU~M hU~M/ zhes sbyar ba ma gtogs gong dang 'dra'o/ /

[For Buddhagupta:]…on an animal-skin seat is the great master Shrī Buddhagupta, inseparable from my root teacher. He takes the form of a yogi, with a white complexion tinged with red. He is physically large and dignified, inspiring clear faith. The sight of him immediately makes one’s hairs stand on end, and he has a fearful presence. His long hair is tied in a topknot, from the top of which a few locks of hair are hanging down his back. He is wearing a head wrapping of freshly bloomed yellow flowers. He has avoided becoming old and senile and remains youthful and elegant. He wears a cotton loincloth and clothes and has a meditation belt. His right hand is covering his knee and touching the earth, his left holding a kapāla full of nectar against his hip. He is sitting with his body erect and straight and his legs half-crossed. Shining in a hundred directions with the radiance of the gnosis of coemergent great bliss… Buddhagupta, to you respectfully we pay homage and śrī buddhaguptanātha hūṁ hūṁ. {148} Apart from these differences, the rest is as above.

'di rnams kyis mtshon nas rang rang gis dmigs bsal du dad pa'i yul sogs grub thob rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug gang la'ang sbyor du rung bar gsungs pas/ so so'i mngon rtogs dang mtshan dang mtshan sngags kha spos pas chog go /

As these examples show, the text says that one may adapt this ritual to any of the great siddhas in whom one especially has faith. It is sufficient to change the visualization, name, and name mantra in each case.
dge bas grub pa mchog rnams kyi/ / byin rlabs bdag gi rgyud la zhugs/ / rtogs grol dus mnyam mkha' spyod tshe'i/ / grong khyer nyams dgar dbugs dbyung shog /

By this merit, may the blessings of the supreme siddhas Permeate our streams of being. May we attain realization and liberation at the same time And find relief in the joyous city of the great celestial lands.

tshul 'di lta bu'i bla ma'i rnal 'byor mdzad byang mi gsal yang rje btsun thams cad mkhyen pa tA ra nA tha'i gsungs zin yin nges par bzhugs pa la tshigs zin gyi kha skong 'os rigs 'thad ldan rnams dkyus su btsud pa'i bklags chog nyid du blo gros mtha' yas pa'i sdes rdzong gsal bkra shis lha rtse'i chos grwar bkod pa

Although the author’s colophon of this guru yoga is not clear, I am certain that it was written by the venerable omniscient Tāranātha. I, Lodrö Tayepai De, have arranged it as a liturgical text with the insertion here and there of some appropriate supplementary verses. I wrote it in the dharma college of Tashi Lhatse at Dzongsar.
dge legs 'phel//
May virtue and excellence increase.
@#/ /grub thob brgyad cu rtsa bzhi'i rdzogs rim rin chen phreng ba rtsa 'grel bzhugs so/ /
5. A PRECIOUS NECKLACE. Perfection Stage Teachings of the Eighty-Four Siddhas, the Root Text and a Commentary[1]
[rtsa ba]
THE ROOT TEXT
@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ rat+na mA la nA ma/ bod skad du/ rin chen phreng ba zhes bya ba/
In Sanskrit: Ratnamāla-nāma In Tibetan: Rin chen phreng ba zhes bya ba [In English: A Precious Necklace]
bcom ldan 'das ngag gi dbang phyug la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the perfect, transcendent conqueror, the Lord of Speech!
dbu skra kham nag gyen du brjes/ / spyan ni mthon mthing ud pal mdog / 'jigs pa'i nga ro sgrags pa'i sku/ / mi g.yo khyed la rab btud nas/ /
Your reddish-brown hair streaming up, Dark-blue eyes the color of utpalas, Your terrifying roar— Achala, to you I bow.
mngon dga'i zhing du lhag pa yi/ / grub thob brgya cu rtsa bzhi las/ / d+ha ma d+hu mas legs spyad pas/ / mthong thos la sogs 'dir ma bkod/ /
I have not set forth here All that Dhamadhuma enjoyed By seeing and hearing the eighty-four siddhas Gathered in the realm of Manifest Joy.
gnod sbyin mo la gdams pa yi/ / rin chen phreng ba bshad par bya/ / dngos med rgyun mi chad pa ru/ / mtha' dbus med par khyab byas pa'i/ /
Rather will I explain the precious necklace Of the instructions to the yakṣhiṇī. In the uninterrupted flow of insubstantiality There is no periphery or center; it pervades everywhere.
dngos po de nyid rab tu zab/ / ma la ya yi me bzhin du/ / khyod ni ji ltar dngos po yi/ / mtsho las skyes shing 'dam la zhen/ /
That reality is extremely profound, Like the fires of Mount Malaya. Born from the ocean of substantiality, You cling to the mire.

bung ba sbrang rtsi me tog dang*/ / mi ldan pa ni ci zhig myong*/ / phyi nang snod bcud tshangs pa dang*/ / bus kyi drod dang zho rtsi dang*/ / nyungs dkar la ni mar bzhin du/ / nges par rtogs na nges pa yin/ / mi mngon mi snang gsal ba ru/ / nam mkha' de nyid ston par byed/ /

Without bees, flowers, and nectar, What is there to taste? Just as Brahmā knows the world and its inhabitants, Certainty comes from definitive realization, As with the season of warmth, Yogurt culture, and oil in mustard seed. It manifests as the very nature of space— Inevident, invisible, and clear. {151}

gang gis bzung ba med pa'i sku ni rab tu mdzes/ / bum pa bzang dang dpag bsam nor bu rin chen ltar/ / grong khyer thams cad stong pa la/ / khams gsum srid gsum lus ngag gi / byed po gang yin bdag la dris/ / bdag gi bdag nyid stong pa ste/ / gang gi mtha' la mi gnas so/ /

The body that cannot be apprehended by anyone is utterly beautiful: It is like a treasure vase, a wish-fulfilling tree, or a precious gem. All cities are empty: Ask yourself, What is it that created The three worlds, the three existences, the body and speech? The nature of the self is empty; It does not dwell in any extremes whatsoever.

grong khyer thams cad stong pa la/ / dngos por grub pa ga la yod/ / snang grags rtogs pa'i grong khyer la/ / gzung ba'am ni 'dzin pa yis/ / srin bu mi bde kha chus bsdams/ / ma bzung btang na bde bar 'gyur/ / mi spangs pa dang mi ldan par/ / shes par gyur na grong mi 'jug /

All cities are empty. Where is there anything that exists substantially? Because of dualistic grasping to the city Of appearances, sounds, and thoughts, one is bound, Like the unhappy silkworm trapped inside its own saliva. Happiness comes when one lets go and does not grasp. When you know how to not reject and not possess, You will not enter the city.

dga' bos nor bu'i 'od bzhin du/ / grong khyer bde ba chen por 'gyur/ / gang zhig chos rnams ci smra ba/ / smra ba de dag dran pa ste/ / ci ltar mya ngan 'das smra ba/ / dran pa'i dbang mo ma yin nam/ / sa chu me rlung gar snang ba/ / stong pa nyid dang dus mnyam 'gyur/ /

As with Nanda and the jewel’s light, The city will become great bliss. When people talk about phenomena, Everything they say is a recollected thought. And when they talk about nirvana, Is that not too the faculty of thought? All that appears—earth, water, fire, or wind— Is simultaneous with emptiness.

ye shes snang ba lam me ba/ / dran pa gcig pa nyid du gyur/ / nyi zla gnyis sbyor ma shes pa/ / chu yi rlabs ltar rnam pa mang*/ / de nyid gcig tu gyur bas na/ / 'di la tha dad 'byung ba med/ / 'di la nyes pa rdul tsam med/ / sbyor bas byung ba ma yin no/ /

The vivid appearances of gnosis {152} Are identical with thought. When you do not know how to unite the sun and moon, All sorts of things manifest, like waves on water. Because that very state is single, Distinctions do not occur therein. Here there is not even an atom of anything wrong. This does not come about through effort.

mi rtog pa yi rgya mtsho la/ / rtog pa'i ri bo rnam par nub/ / 'dzin pa'i snang ba chos nyid la/ / gzung ba'i rtog pa ga la yod/ / bum pa'i lus la 'byung ba'i 'od/ / steng du lha yi bdud rtsir zhu/ / chos nyid kyi ni gong bu la/ / tshogs drug rtog pa rnam par zad/ /

Into the ocean of nonconceptuality Sinks the mountain of conceptual thought. The appearance of a subject is ultimate reality, So where can there be the concept of an object? In your vaselike body is the light of the elements, And on top of it, the deity melts into nectar. In a mass of light, ultimate reality, The concepts related to the six consciousnesses are exhausted.

rigs drug rtog pa sna tshogs pa/ / log srid brtas pa'i mthu las byung*/ / de bzlog rig pa'i mthu las ni/ / sangs rgyas yin phyir gang 'dod 'byung*/ / yul rkyen snang ba 'gag pa med/ / chu la chu bur ji lta bur/ / rjes kyi gnyen pos ldog pa ste/ / chu yi dbyug pa de lta bu/ /

The various conceptual thoughts of the six classes of beings Arise through the power of their full-grown obsession with evil. Through the power of knowledge, which reverses it, You awaken as buddha, so all your desires are fulfilled. The appearances of the objects that cause them never cease; They are like bubbles in water. They are stopped by the subsequent antidote, As if by a stick in the water.

gzhon nu mdzes pa'i sa bon can/ / 'gro ba kun la khyab par gnas/ / dbang po rab snang 'dzin par 'gyur/ / ye shes gcig gi snang ba yin/ / nam mkha' sprin gyi gzugs byed 'dzin/ / me long la ni gzugs brnyan snang*/ / rang gis brtags na de lta bur/ / mun pas snang ba'i don byed min/ /

It contains the seed of youth and beauty That dwells in all beings, pervading them. The highest faculty will apprehend its appearance; It apprehends the appearance of gnosis alone. It apprehends the sky and the forms of the clouds, The mirror and the reflections that appear in it— Thus it is when one examines it. Darkness is of no use in illuminating that.

de yang gsang ba'i stobs kyis spyad/ / ye shes gsal ba'i phyag rgya ni/ / phyogs gcig lus kyi gnad la bcas/ / sgyu ma'i 'khrul 'khor de las ni/ / dbang po'i nus pa brtas par byed/ / na ri ke la'i shing bzhin du/ / sha dang rus pa rkang mar rnams/ / skyed par byed pa gang yin pa/ / de bzhin rtsa dang rlung rnams so/ /

It is enjoyed by the power of secrets. The seal that makes gnosis manifest Is, for some, related to the vital point of the body. By means of the magical machinery The power of the faculties is developed. As it is for the coconut tree, What makes the fibrous husk, The hard shell, and the white flesh grow Is likewise the channels and winds.
rgyu med 'bras bu med pa ru/ / kun gyi gsal ba ston par byed/ / dpe yis ma yin tha snyad med/ / ma bral ba la gsal ci dgos/ / shor dang gol bas ma bskyed/ /

In that which is without cause and without result Everything is clearly revealed. It is without analogy and cannot be designated. What is the need for revealing something from which one is never separated? Deviations and errors will not produce it. {153}
'khyams med ltengs pa de las log / skyes nas ma shi'i bar do ru/ / rnam smin lus kyi rtog pa la/ / 'dod chags 'od gsal dag tu 'gyur/ /

Free of wandering, it is the opposite of stagnation. In the intermediate state between birth and death, With regard to the concept of the body that is the ripening of karma, Attachment is purified into luminosity.
bla ma'i gdams ngag ngo mtshar che/ / sbyor ba dang ni dngos gzhi las/ / gzung ba dag ni sbyong ba dang*/ / sgyu mar bslab cing ya nga spang*/ / de nyid mi 'da' bsgom par bya/ /

Thus are the teacher’s marvelous instructions. Of the preparation and the main practice, In the latter one must apprehend [one’s dreams], refine them, Bless them as illusions and get rid of fear, And meditate without leaving thatness.
rnam shes 'gyur ba'i bar do ru/ / bag chags lus kyis kun nas bslangs/ / mtshams sbyor mngon du rmi lam bya/ / gti mug 'od gsal nyid du gyur/ / 'dun pa drag pos rab tu sbyor/ /

In the intermediate state of the transformation of consciousness, One is driven by the body of habitual tendencies. The connection, for the manifestation of dream, In which bewilderment is transformed into luminosity, Is made by one’s strong aspiration.
rnam smin lus ni zhig pa na/ / bag chags dang bcas yid kyis lus/ / 'dod chags 'od gsal mngon du bya/ / pha ma la sogs chags pa spangs/ /
When this body resulting from the ripening of karma perishes, One has a mental body, with habitual tendencies. Attachment manifests as luminosity. Attachment to parents and so forth is abandoned.

dus dang lus kyi bca' ba dang*/ / yul ni dag po'i sbyor ba ste/ / gtum mo'i gnad ni rlung bzhir bshad/ / 'od gsal bzhi ru 'dod pa ste/ / 'chi ba bslu bar ma nus na/ / 'pho ba rnam pa gsum yin te/ / dang po snying kha lte ba'o/ /

The initial practice concerns the time, Bodily control, and the object [of concentration]. The essential point of tummo is explained as four winds, Which are held to be the four luminosities. If death is unavoidable, There are three kinds of transference: The first is from the heart and from the navel.
dang po sbyor ba sgo dgu dgag / kha dog ser po 'od 'bar ba'i/ / ka Sha nis 'gyur yi ge ni/ / dang por ldan pa'i sa bon gyis/ / tshangs pa'i sgo ru des bsrung ngo*/ / dril bu yi ge mig la'o/ /

Begin, in preparation, by closing the nine openings. The double letter kaṣa, Yellow and blazing with light—Mahaāsiddha The upright seed syllable Keeps guard in the aperture of Brahmā. The syllable of the bell is in the eye.

stong pa'i sa bon ldan pa ni/ / rna ba sna yi dbang por bzhag / bdud rtsi chu yi sa bon gyis/ / lce yi dbang po'i rtse mor bzung*/ / seng ge'i sa bon brtsegs pa yis/ / spro ba bsdud sgo yang des bsrung*/ / stag mo'i sa bon brtsegs pa yis/ / thong ka kun tu bzhag par bya/ / lce spyangs sa bon brtsigs pa yis/ / snying ga'i gnas su bzhag par bya/ / gnad kyi tshigs pa'i lte ba ru/ / shugs kyis sa bon gyis bsrung ngo*/ /

That which has the seed syllable of emptiness Is placed on the tip of the ear. The seed syllable of nectarous water Is held on the tip of the tongue. The stacked seed syllable of the lion Guards the door of emanation and absorption.[2] The stacked seed syllable of the tigress Is to be placed on the breast. The stacked seed syllable of the jackal Is to be placed in the heart center. In the navel, the vital center of burning, {154} The seed syllable of power keeps guard.

de nas 'og gi sgo yang bsrung*/ / chu yi sa bon dkar ser po/ / chu dang chu min sa yi ni/ / de yis sa bon 'bar bar byed/ / lus la rlung gi sa bon dang*/ / sems kyi rlung ni dkyil 'khor la/ / rlung gi sa bon rlung mtho rtsar ba ni/ / thig pa nga ro ldan pa yis/ / sems kyis de ni drang bar bya/ / ma lus kun gyi mngon rtogs ni/ / gnod sbyin mo yi don ched du/ / d+ha ma d+hU mas legs spyad pas/ / 'gro rnams rdzogs pa'i sa thob shog /

Then, guard the lower opening as well With the light-yellow seed syllable of water. In the urethra and anus Make the seed syllables blaze. In the body, the seed syllable of the wind, And in the mandala of mind and wind, On the base of the final fading breath, With a cry, the essence drop Is to be guided by the mind.[3] As a result of Dhamadhuma’s virtuous deed Of bringing to light all these [verses] With the aim of helping the yakṣhiṇī, May all beings attain the level of perfection.
gdams pa rin chen phreng ba'i gzhung chung rdzogs so/ /
This completes the short instruction text A Precious Necklace.
['grel]
THE COMMENTARY
@#/ /bcom ldan 'das ngag gi dbang phyug la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the perfect, transcendent conqueror, the Lord of Speech!
'gro ba rnams la phan pa dang*/ / bdag blo dad pas rtse gcig tu/ / bla ma'i gsung gi rjes 'brangs nas/ / rin chen phreng ba'i bshad TIka dgod/ /
For the benefit of beings, With a devoted, single-pointed mind I will compose a commentary on the Precious Necklace Following my teacher’s very words.

'dir mkha' 'gro ma d+harma wang dang*/ ko ka la gnyis kyis bsdu ba mdzad pa'i grub thob brgya cu rtsa bzhi'i rdzogs rim la tshan lnga mchis pa las 'dir rin chen phreng ba ston/ / 'di la don bsdus bshad par bya ba la/ don gsum gyis bshad de/ klad dang*/ gzhung dang*/ mjug gi don gsum mo/ / de la dang po la gsum gyis bstan no/ / mtshan bstan pa dang*/ mchod par brjod pa dang*/ bshad par dam bca' ba'o/ /

I will explain here A Precious Necklace, one of the five sections of the perfection stage teachings by the eighty-four siddhas summarized by the ḍākinīs Dharmavang and Kokala. For this I will give a brief exposition, commenting on it in three sections: (1) introduction; (2) main body of the text; and (3) conclusion. The first of these has three parts: (1) an explanation of the title; (2) homage; and (3) the promise to explain it.
[klad]
I. Introduction
mtshan bstan pa ni/
A. Explanation of the Title
In Sanskrit: Ratnamāla-nāma In Tibetan: Rin chen phreng ba zhes bya ba [In English: A Precious Necklace]
rgya gar skad du/ /rat+na mA la nA ma/ bod skad du/ rin po che phreng ba zhes bya bas mtshan bstan te/ rgya gar skad du/ zhes pa ni/ bod skad du zhes pa'i dod po yin te/
The title is indicated in Sanskrit by Ratnamāla-nāma, in Tibetan by Rin chen phreng ba zhes bya ba, [and in English by A Precious Necklace]. The titles in Sanskrit and Tibetan are equivalent.
'di dang por smos pa'i dgos pa ji ltar yin na/ lo tsA ba ska ba dpal brtsegs kyis lo tsA ba chung ba rnams la gsungs pa/ gzhan yang khyad par bshad pa'i cho ga 'di skad bshad de/ /
What is the reason for mentioning it first? Because the translator Kawa Paltsek told the junior translators to do so. Moreover, the following specific explanation was given. {155}

khungs btsun yid ches bla ma dran/ / bkra shis rang bzo mi 'jug dang*/ / 'jug 'dod rtogs sla bstan pa'i don/ / sgra yi yan lag brgyad po 'di/ / bstan bcos 'di lugs shes pa yis/ / mkhas pa rnams kyis bshad byar 'os/ / zhes pas na dang por smos pa'o/ /

It shows that the source is authentic and it inspires confidence, reminds one of the teacher, Is auspicious, is not one’s own invention, Indicates the intention, is easy to understand, and indicates the subject that is taught— By knowing the tradition of these eight branches of writing, The wise should explain this shastra.

bod skad du/ zhes pa ni/ mi go ba go bar byed pa saM skr-ita lha'i skad las/ rang yul gyi skad du bsgyur bas na/ lo tsA ba'i drin bzhag pa'o/ / ji ltar bsgyur na byas pa las/ rat+na zhes pa ni rin po che yin la/ ma la ni phreng ba yin/ nA ma ni zhes bya'o/ /

The phrase “In Tibetan” indicates that, in order to enable those who do not understand Sanskrit, the language of the gods, to understand the text, it was translated from Sanskrit into the language of our own country. So it is a grateful acknowledgment of the translator. How was it translated? Ratna means “precious” and māla means “necklace.” Nāma means “entitled.”

'dir rin po che zhes pa'i don ni/ dpe don gnyis te/ dpe ni bsam 'phel gyi nor bu rin po che yin te/ nor bu de la mchod pa dang*/ rim gro phun sum tshogs pa byas na/ yon tan gyi rnam du ma yod kyang*/ bsdus na gnyis yin skad/ mi 'dod pa'i phyogs mi mthun pa spang ba yang 'byung skad/ 'dod pa'i phyogs dgos pa thams cad 'byung skad/ phreng ba zhes pa ni nor bu de phreng bar rgyus pa ltar grangs dang grangs su bcad pa yod na/ sems can thams cad kyi don go bar byed pas ngo mtshar che skad/ dpe de bzhin du grub thob rnams kyi gdams ngag rin po che'i phreng ba de yang mi mthun pa'i phyogs thams cad spong la/ mthun pa'i yon tan thams cad ldan pa'i gdams ngag de yang*/ dper na phreng ba brgyus pa'i rnam pa ltar yod pas/ rin po phreng ba zhes bya'o/ /

Here the meaning of “precious” is shown by an analogy. A wish-fulfilling jewel is precious in that if one makes offerings to that jewel and venerates it on a grand scale, it brings numerous benefits. These can be summarized as of two kinds: it gets rid of all that is unwanted and unfavorable, and it brings about everything that one wants or needs. “Necklace” is explained as follows. If there is a certain number of such jewels strung into a necklace, they will enable all beings to understand the meaning and to marvel. By analogy, this series of the precious instructions of the siddhas that get rid of unfavorable elements and have every kind of benefit are like a threaded necklace, and so they are given the title “Precious Necklace.”
des mtshan bstan nas/ [mchod par brjod pa]
B. Homage
da mchod par brjod pa la gnyis te/ sdud pa po paN+Di ta yis mchod par brjod pa dang*/ bsgyur byed lo tsA ba'i mchod par brjod pa'o/ /
Next, for the homage, there are two parts: (1) the homage by the paṇḍita who compiled this work and (2) the homage by the lotsawa who translated it.
[sdud pa po paN+Di ta yis mchod par brjod pa]
1. Compiler’s Homage
bcom ldan 'das ngag gi dbang phyug la phyag 'tshal lo zhes pa ste/
Homage to the perfect, transcendent conqueror, the Lord of Speech![4]

bcom ldan 'das zhes pa bdud bzhi bcom pas yin te/ nyon mongs pa'i bdud/ / phung po'i bdud/ 'chi bdag gi bdud/ lha'i bu'i bdud bzhi'o/ / gong ma gsum gyis tshe la bar du gcod pa dang*/ lha'i bu'i bdud kyis yon tan khyad par can bar du gcod par byed pas na/ de dag bcom pa dang ldan pa'o/ / yang de nyid 'dus pa'i bshad rgyud nas gsungs pa/

{156} A bhagavān—perfect, transcendent conqueror—is so called because he has conquered the four demons. These are the demon of defilements, the demon of the aggregates, the demon of death, and the demon “child of the gods.” The first three interrupt one’s span of life, while the demon child of the gods creates obstacles to the development of extraordinary qualities.[5] It is these demons that the bhagavān has conquered. This is summarized in an explanatory tantra:
dbang phyug dang ni gzugs bzang dang*/ / dpal dang grags dang ye shes dang*/ / brtson 'grus phun sum tshogs pas na/ / drug po de la ldan zhes bya/ / zhes bshad pa'o/ /
Power, a fine body, Glory, renown, gnosis, And diligence—since he has these six In abundance, he is “perfect.”[6]

ngag gi dbang phyug ces pa ni/ ser sna dang nga rgyal rnam par dag pa'i ye shes mnyam pa nyid la mnga' brnyes shing dbang ba'am/ de la longs spyod pas na/ dbang phyug ces bya'o/ / phyag 'tshal ba ni yul khyad par can de la phyag 'tshal ba'o/ / gang zag gang gis btsal na sdud pa pa sur+Ya rasmi nyid kyis btsal ba'o/ / dgos pa gang gis phyir btsal na/ dbu nas zhabs su brtsam pa la bar chad mi 'byung zhing gzhan 'jug pa'i yan lag tu 'gyur ba'i dgos pa yod ces pa'i don to/ /

He is the Lord of Speech because he has mastery over, or enjoys, sameness, the pure gnosis devoid of stinginess and pride, or because he enjoys it, hence his being called “Lord.” It is to that extraordinary object that homage is paid. The individual who is paying homage is the compiler of these instructions, Suryarasmi. His purpose in doing so is so that no obstacles occur between the beginning and the end of this undertaking and to encourage others to pay homage as well.
gnyis pa ni/
2. Lotsawa’s Homage
sgyur byed lo tsA bas yi dam gyi lha la phyag 'tshal ba'o/ /
The homage by the lotsawa who translated it is made to the yidam deity:
Your reddish-brown hair streaming up, Dark-blue eyes the color of utpalas, Your terrifying roar— Achala, to you I bow.
des mchod par brjod pa bstan nas/ da bshad par dam bca' ba bstan pa ni/
C. Promise to Explain the Text
mngon dga'i zhing du lhag pa'i zhes pa nas/ rin chen phreng ba bshad par bya zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan te/

I have not set forth here All that Dhamadhuma enjoyed By seeing and hearing the eighty-four siddhas Gathered in the realm of Manifest Joy. Rather will I explain the precious necklace Of the instructions to the yakṣhiṇī.

mngon dga'i zhing du lhag pa yi/ /zhes pa mngon dga' ni dur khrod chen po sa ma'i 'tshal te/ mngon par cis dga' byas pa la/ grub thob rnams 'du ba'i gnas tshogs dkyil 'khor bskor ba'i zhing yin pas na/ las can rnams kyis thos pa'am mthong ba tsam gyis dga' bas na/ mngon dga'i zhing zhes pa'o/ /lhag pa ni tshogs la 'dus pa'o/ /

“Gathered in the realm of Manifest Joy” is explained as follows. “Manifest Joy” refers to the great charnel ground, the Sama Grove. It is called the “realm” of Manifest Joy because it is a realm in which the feast-offering mandala is performed, a place where the siddhas gather; {157} merely seeing or hearing of it makes fortunate beings joyful. “Gathered” means gathered in an assembly.

grub thob brgya cu rtsa bzhi la/ /d+ha ma d+hu mas legs spyad pa ni/ /gsungs pa'i chos rnams la spyad pa'o/ /ci ltar spyad na/ mthong ba'am thos pa la sogs pa thams cad 'dir ma bkod skad/ 'o na ci 'dra ba cig bkod byas pa la/ gnod sbyin mo la gdams pa'i rin chen phreng ba 'dir bkod ces pa'i don to/ /gnod sbyin mo la gang gdams byas pa la/

It was there that Dhamadhuma enjoyed the teachings that the eighty-four siddhas gave, enjoying them in the sense of seeing or listening to them, and so on. These teachings are not all recorded here. What then is presented in this text? The precious necklace of instructions to the yakṣhiṇī. The story of these instructions given to the yakṣhiṇī is as follows.

dur khrod de na yi dwags kyi rang bzhin log nang duHkha bya ba gcig yod de/ des sha dang khrag gi dri tshor na/ dpag tshad brgyar yang skad cig la thogs pa med par rgyu gnas 'ongs pas/ dus nam zhig gi tshe na/ dur khrod chen po de'i byang shar na shing chen po gcig yod pa la/ de'i khog pa stong par yod pas de'i nang du dred mo ma smad bdun nyal zhing rtag tu gnas pa la/ dus lan cig bse chen po yang dag pa gcig gis shing de la bsnyel te nyal tsam na/ shing 'gyel bas/ de'i nang na gnas pa'i dred rnams kyang shi/ bse de yang 'gyel nas yod pa la/ de'i dus su gnod sbyin mo des rnyed nas/ bse yang bsad/ dred kyi sha yang yod pa la/ de'i tshe'am dus na nags de'i lho phyogs nas/ srin po rak+Sha ko Ti bya bas/ sha dang khrag gi dri tshor nas phyogs dang phyogs mtshams su btsal te/ gnod sbyin mo la sha bslangs pas mkhugs nas/ der srin po khros te/ lho phyogs kyi brag chen po gcig la zangs ma mju ba mang po yod pas des zangs ma'i zhun ma brkus nas gnod sbyin mo la bar snang nas mar blugs pas/ gnod sbyin mo de lta zur g.yas pa rus pa la thug par tshig nas/ skye ba snga ma'i las kyi dbang gis srog ma chad par sdug bsngal gyi me 'bar nas yod pa las/

In that charnel ground there was a sort of hungry spirit, a carrion eater called Dukha. When she smelled flesh and blood, she would race unimpeded and arrive at the site in an instant, even from a distance of a hundred yojanas. At one time, in the northeast of that great charnel ground, there was a large tree, and since it was hollow, a female bear and her seven cubs made it their home. One day, a huge, fully grown rhinoceros fell asleep against the tree, which caused the tree to collapse, killing the bears living in it. The rhinoceros too had fallen over, and when the yakṣhiṇī found it, she immediately killed it. At this point, a rākṣhasa ogre called Koti from the south of the forest smelled the bears’ flesh and blood and came looking everywhere for it. He begged the yakṣhiṇī for some meat but got none and consequently flew into a rage. On a large rock to the south, there were a number of copper smelters, so he stole some molten copper and poured it from the air above onto the yakṣhiṇī. {158} It burned the yakṣhiṇī’s right hip down to the bone. Because of her karma from previous lives, it failed to kill her but it left her consumed by pain.

de ri dus na mkha' 'gro ma d+harma de wI dang*/ ko ki la gnyis kyis mthong nas snying rje skyes nas sngags mang po btab nas sha'i rma ni sos/ rus pa skya seng nge yod pa de ma sos par/ sdug bsngal zhing yod pa las/ mkha' 'gro ma gnyis po des grub thob rnams la yun du tshogs kyi 'khor lo bskor ba'i dus kyi tshe dang 'dzom par gyur nas/ gnod sbyin mo de'i rtog pa zad par bya ba'i phyir na/ bag la nyal dang mthun pa'i zhu ba phul bas/ bla ma rnams kyis kyang gong ltar zhus pa ltar gnang ngo*/ / de dag gi don ni rin chen phreng ba brgyus pa ltar byung ngo*/ / de'i gdams pa ni rin chen phreng ba zhes bya'o/ / des bshad par dam bca' ba'o/ / gang la bshad par dam bcas na/ phyi rabs kyi gang zag skal pa dang ldan pa rnams la bshad par dam bcas so/ / dgos pa gang gi phyir bshad na/ zhi ba bde ba mya ngan las 'das pa'i sa thob par bya ba'i phyir bshad do/ /

Just then, two ḍākinīs, Dharmadevī and Kokila, saw her. Taking pity on her, they chanted numerous mantras and healed the wounds in her flesh. The exposed bone, however, did not heal, and she continued to suffer. To put an end to the yakṣhiṇī’s concepts, the two ḍākinīs made a request to the siddhas, who had gathered for a lengthy celebration of the feast offering, to teach her in accord with her particular predispositions. The masters granted this request, teaching her a series of topics strung together like a precious necklace, hence the title of these instructions, A Precious Necklace. It is these that the commentator is promising to explain to fortunate individuals of future generations, so that they may attain the peaceful, blissful state of nirvana.
des klad kyi don bstan nas/ da gzhung gi don bstan pa ni/
II. Main Body of the Text
dang po lU i pas snang ba thug phrad kyi gdams ngag gcig bstan te/ de yang 'di la phan pa'i gdams ngag gcig zhu byas pas/ bla ma'i zhal nas/
First, Lūyipa gave an instruction on directly encountering appearances. When the yakṣhiṇī requested him to give an instruction that would help her, the master replied:
rang ngo ma shes pas nyes pa yin/ de shes na snang ba med par gzugs kyi snang ba yang gal ci yod gsungs nas/
“The trouble is that you do not know your own nature. Once you know it, [you will know that] there are no appearances that exist, so how could physical appearances exist?”
rang ngo shes pa gang lags zhus pas/
“What is it to know one’s own nature?” she asked.
rgyun zad 'od gsal gyi ye shes gcig yin gsungs/
“It is the gnosis of clear light, the exhaustion of the stream.”
mi 'tshal zhus pas/
But she did not understand this, so he spoke the following verse: {159}
dngos med rgyun mi 'chad pa ru/ / mtha' dbus med par khyab byas pa'i/ / dngos po de nyid rab tu zab/ / ma la ya mi ye bzhin du/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
In the uninterrupted flow of insubstantiality There is no periphery or center; it pervades everywhere. That reality is extremely profound, Like the fires of Mount Malaya.

dngos med ces pa ni/ de gang gis gang la dngos po med ces pa la/ gnas lugs de la dngos po med pa yin te/ dper na nam mkha'i me tog de la btags pa tsam yod kyang dngos po med pas dbyibs dang kha dog tu ma grub pas/ nam mkha'i me tog gi rtog pa zad pa'o/ / dpe de bzhin du/ gnas lugs skye ba med pa de la/ dngos po gang du yang grub pa med pas dngos med ces pa'o/ /

“Insubstantiality” means there is nothing substantial whatsoever in anything: in the actual condition of things, there is nothing substantial. To make an analogy, although one can speak of a flower in the sky, it exists only in name: when one realizes that there is no such substantial thing, and that it cannot exist as something with shape and color, the concept of a flower in the sky ceases. In the same way, the actual condition of things is unborn; there is no substantial thing whatsoever that exists, and thus we speak of insubstantiality.
grub pa med tsam na/ dngos po'am/ snang ba'am/ stong pa'am/ blo'am/ sems sam/ sems las byung ba'i rnam par rtog pa thams cad kyi rgyun zad pas na de ka la rgyun zad 'od gsal gyi ye shes zer skad/

As soon as one realizes that there is nothing that exists, the stream of all the concepts of substantiality, appearances, emptiness, mind, mentation, and mental factors comes to an end. That is what we call the exhaustion of the stream, the gnosis of clear light.
'o na rtog pa zad pas ye shes kyang zad dam byas pa la/ rtog pa zad pa la ye shes bya ba'i rtog pa ga la yod de/ rang bzhin 'od gsal du ni rgyun mi 'chad pa yin gsungs/

In that case, when concepts come to an end, does gnosis also come to an end? If concepts have come to an end, how can there be a concept of a so-called gnosis? The nature of gnosis is clear light; it is uninterrupted.
de yang rgyun mi 'chad pa ru/ /zhes pa ste/ gang gis rgyun mi 'chad byas pa la/ 'od gsal du rgyun mi 'chad/ dper na nor bu rin po che la gnas pa'i 'od de rgyun mi 'chad pa lta bu'o/ /
With regard to that “uninterrupted flow,” in what way is it uninterrupted? In its being clear light, in the same way that the radiance in a precious jewel never ceases.

'o na de rang gi mtshan nyid gang yin byas pa la/ mtha' dbus med pas khyab byas pa'i/ /zhes pa/ dpe 'dus byas kyi nam mkha' lta bu yin te/ phyogs dang ris med pas mtha' dang dbus med pa yin la/ khyab pa'i zhes pa ni 'dra ba des/ mtho srid pa'i rtse mo nas/ dma' 'jigs tshogs kyi dmyal ba yan chad du khyab par zhes pa'i don to/ /

What then are its characteristics? It is without periphery or center, and so it pervades everywhere. It is like [un]compounded space: without direction or bias, without boundary or center, and thus “pervasive,” pervading everywhere from the peak of existence above to the terrifying hells below. {160}

dngos po de nyid rab tu zab/ /ces pa ni/ dngos po ni gnod sbyin mo'i lus kyi na tsha dang sems kyi rtog tshad dang*/ snang 'dzin la sogs pa rnams dngos po yin la/ zab pa ni de dag thams cad dngos med 'od gsal du rtogs na zab ces pa'i don to/ /

That reality is extremely profound. “Reality” refers to the yakṣhiṇī’s experiences[7] such as her physical ailments and her mental concepts and grasping at appearances. It is “profound” when one realizes that all those things are insubstantial, clear light.

ma la ya yi me bzhin du/ /zhes pa ni dpe yin te/ ma la ya zhes pa ni ri bo yin te/ ri bo chen po la phyogs bzhi nas me 'bar ba'i dbus su rtsa dang shing dang gel ba dang*/ sa dang rdo dang chu la sogs pa'i dngos po thams cad snang ba thug phrad du me'i grogs su 'gyur ba ltar/ / dngos po thams cad zab mo 'od gsal du rtogs pa'i dus na/ snang ba thams cad thug phrad du bcom nas 'od gsal du rtogs pas/ rnam par rtog pa chos nyid du sad pa'am/ bcom pa yin zhes ston to/ /

“Like the fires of Malaya” is an analogy. Malaya is a huge mountain, and when it finds itself in the middle of fires blazing from the four directions, everything such as the roots, trees, branches, earth, rocks, and rivers—all the appearances that are encountered—serve to fuel the fire. Similarly, when one realizes everything as profound clear light, all appearances are destroyed as they are encountered and realized as clear light. Conceptual thoughts are killed[8] or destroyed in ultimate reality.
de dag rgyud la shar ba ma gyur nas/ lI la sa la zhus pas/ bla mas bstan pa ji lta bu/ / 'di la ji ltar mtshon par zhu/ / zhes zhus pas/
This teaching did not make any impression on the yakṣhiṇī, so she asked Lūyipa to clarify what he had taught. He replied with the following instruction:
khyod ni ji ltar dngos po yi/ / mtsho las skyes shing 'dam la zhen/ / bung ba me tog sbrang rtsi dag / mi ldan par ni ci zhig myong*/ / zhes gsungs pa'o/ /
Born from the ocean of substantiality, You cling to the mire. Without bees, flowers, and nectar, What is there to taste?

de la khyod ni zhes pa ni/ gnod sbyin mo khyod ji ltar dngos po'i mtsho'am/ srid pa'i 'dam la zhen nas 'dug / ma legs/ khyod dang po'i dus na yang skye rga na 'chi'i mtsho la skyes/ da lta yang lus dang na ba dang tsha bas dngos por 'dzin pa ni srid pa'i 'dam las zhen pas sdug bsngal las thar ba ma yin/ me tog dang*/ ge sar gyi sbrang rtsi dang*/ bung ba dang gsum 'dzom na mngar ba'i ro myong bar 'gyur gyis/ de dag mi ldan na yul so so ba des myong bar mi 'gyur/ de bzhin du 'od gsal yang ma rtogs/ lus la yang ched du bzung*/ dngos po'i 'dzin pa dang ma bral bar gnyug ma lhan skyes kyi ro bde ba mi myong*/ de ma myong bar sdug bsngal dang bral bar ga la 'gyur zhes gdams so/ /

You, Yakṣhiṇī, are attached to the ocean of substantiality, or the mire of existence. This is no good. In the first place, you have been born in the ocean of birth, aging, sickness, and death. Now too, on account of your body, ailments, and heat, you grasp at substantiality: because of your attachment to the mire of existence, you are not free from suffering. When flowers, nectar, and bees come together, you get something that tastes sweet. But if you do not have these things {161} and they remain separate, you will never taste honey. In the same way, as long as you have not realized luminosity, as long as you consider your body as something special and are not free from the belief in substantiality, you will not experience the blissful flavor of the innate natural state. And until you experience that, how will you ever be free from suffering?
de rgyud la brten par byed pa'i thabs ko ka las gsungs pa/
Next, Kokala gave an instruction on how to make use of this in one’s mind stream.
phyi nang snod bcud tshangs pa dang*/ / dus kyi drod dang zho rtsi dang*/ / nyungs kar la ni mar bzhin du/ / nges par rtogs na nges pa yin/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Just as Brahmā knows the world and its inhabitants, Certainty comes from definitive realization, As with the season of warmth, Yogurt culture, and oil in mustard seed.

de la phyi nang snod bcud tshangs pa dang zhes pa ste/ phyi ste snod kyi 'jig rten 'di la ji ltar dang*/ ji snyed par gnas pa dang*/ nang ste bcud kyi sems can ji ltar srid pa 'di/ gzhan gyis shes par dka' yang*/ lha tshangs pa nyid kyis de dag ma lus par mkhyen par de bzhin du/ bla mas bstan pa'i sems nyid 'od gsal gyi ngo bo de/ dngos por rang gis ngo shes dgos pa yin gsungs/ shes nas ci byed byas pa la/ shes nas rgyud la brten dgos pa yin gsungs/ de ji ltar brten byas pa la/ dus kyi drod dang zho rtsi dang*/ /nyungs kar la ni mar bzhin du/ /zhes pa/

While it is difficult for others to know the nature and the extent of this outer world and the existence of the sentient beings contained in it, the god Brahmā himself knows all these things without exception. Similarly, what you need to know by yourself is the nature of mind, whose essence is luminosity, which the teacher has shown you. Once you have recognized it, you need to make use of it in your mind stream. How you do this is indicated by “As with the season of warmth, yogurt culture, and oil in mustard seed.”

de bzhin du brten dgos skad/ phyi bzung ba'i yul la mi 'jug pa dus kyi drod lta bur nyams rgyud la brten dgos skad/ de rang gang yin na/ dus kyi drod ces pa ni lo gsar shar nas zla ba gsum tshad du zhugs tsam na rlung nang du bsum nas tshogs drug gi rtog pa'i rjes su 'brengs pa'i phyi bzung yul la mi 'jug par gnas so/ / dpe de bzhin du/ 'od gsal rgyud la brten pa'i gang zag ni/ yul tshogs drug gi rtog pa las log nas yul de nyid rang 'od gsal du rgyud la brten dgos skad/ dpe byas pa la zho rtsi dang zhes pa ste/ ma he'i 'o ma de la zho rtsi song bas 'o ma zhor gnas gyur nas/ 'o ma rang spangs la 'o ma rang dang mi ldan par zhor gnas gyur pa/ dpe de bzhin du 'od gsal rgyud la shar ba'i gang zag gi/ tshogs drug gi rtog pa ma spangs la mi ldan pa/ tshogs drug gi rtog pa ye shes su gnas gyur pa gcig rgyud la brten dgos gsungs/

You need to make use of it by not engaging with the outer apprehended object, as happens during the season of warmth. “The season of warmth” refers to the time almost three months after the New Year,[9] when the subtle wind withdraws and one remains without engaging with objects outside or pursuing concepts related to the six consciousnesses. Analogous to this, a person who makes use of the luminosity in their mind needs to turn away from the object, the conceptual thoughts related to the six consciousnesses, and {162} makes use in their mind stream of the object that is their own luminosity. The analogy of the yogurt culture is as follows. When a yogurt culture is introduced into buffalo milk, the latter turns into yogurt. The milk itself has not been got rid of, but it has been transformed into yogurt and is no longer milk. Similarly, a person in whose mind stream luminosity has dawned has to make use of the transformation of the conceptual thoughts related to the six consciousnesses into gnosis without rejecting them.

'o na tshogs drug gi rtog pa ye shes yin par cis shes byas pa la/ nyungs kar la ni mar bzhin du/ / nges par rtogs na nges pa yin/ / zhes pa ste/ nyungs kar la ni zhes pa ste/ nyungs kar du 'dug kyang*/ khyab pa mar gyis khyab pa de bzhin du/ sems can gyi don kun gzhi la 'dug kyang*/ khyab pa gnyug ma 'od gsal gyi rang bzhin gyis khyab ces pa'o/ / nges par rtogs na zhes pa the tshom mam/ som nyi med par rtogs na ma nor ba yin ces pa'i don to/ /

How then does one know that the thoughts related to the six consciousnesses are gnosis? “Certainty comes from definitive realization, as with oil in mustard seed.” Just as a mustard seed is pervaded by oil, the ground of all that characterizes sentient beings is pervaded by the natural state whose nature is luminosity. “Definitive realization” means that if you realize this without any doubts or uncertainties, you will not be mistaken.
de ltar rtogs na 'bras bu gang yin na/ de'i don rtsa ma ri pas gsungs pa/ mi mngon mi snang gsal ba ru/ / nam mkha' de nyid ston par byed/ / ces gsungs so/ /
What is the result of such realization? This question was answered by Chamaripa: It manifests as the very nature of space— Inevident, invisible, and clear.

mi mngon mi snang zhes pa ni/ chos sku de nam mkha'i mtshan nyid ltar/ mi mngon mi snang ba yin te/ dngos po'am/ dngos med dam/ blo'am/ sems sam/ sems las byung ba gang gis kyang brtag tu med pas na/ mi mngon mi snang zhes pa'i don to/ /

“Inevident, invisible” refers to the fact that the body of truth is inevident and invisible, like space. It does not stand up to analysis in terms of anything: it is neither substantial nor insubstantial, nor mind, nor mentation, nor a mental factor, and therefore it is said to be “inevident, invisible.”

'o na chos sku de dngos po med pas thugs rje rgyun chad dam byas pa la/ gsal ba ru zhes pa dang*/ nam mkha' de nyid ston par byed gsungs pa ste/ nam mkhar de nyid dam/ dbyibs dang kha dog gam mtshan ma'i dngos po med kyang*/ nyi zla gza' skar ram/ sprin dang na bun 'ja' tshon la sogs pa gsal bar ston pa de bzhin du/ chos sku mi mngon mi 'gag kyang thugs rje'i rgyun mi 'gag ste/ longs sku dang sprul sku gnyis 'gag pa med par smon lam gyis 'gag pa med par shugs las byung zhes pa'o/ /

In that case, if the body of truth is insubstantial, does the flow of compassion cease? Even though space has no identity, or shape or color, {163} or substantial attributes, the sun and moon, planets and stars, clouds, mist, rainbows, and so forth manifest clearly in it. Similarly, although the body of truth is invisible and uninterrupted, the flow of compassion never ceases: it occurs automatically and uninterruptedly in the unceasing manifestation of the bodies of perfect enjoyment and manifestation, through the power of aspiration.
sa ra ha'i zhal nas/ gang gis bzung ba med pa'i sku ni rab tu mdzes/ / bum pa bzang dang dpag bsam nor bu rin chen ltar/ / ces gsungs so/ /
Saraha then said: The body that cannot be apprehended by anyone is utterly beautiful: It is like a treasure vase, a wish-fulfilling tree, or a precious gem.
gzung 'dzin gyi rtog pa spangs pa'i sems nyid de rab tu mdzes/ dpe cing 'dra na/ bum pa'am dpag bsam shing ngam nor bu rin po che ltar mdzes zhes so/ /

The nature of mind, which is divested of the dualistic concepts of subject and object, is utterly beautiful. How can that be illustrated? It is as beautiful as a treasure vase, a wish-fulfilling tree, or a precious gem.
de nas slob dpon birba pas gdams pa ni/ grong khyer stong pa bya ba gcig gsungs te/ /
Next, the master Birvapa gave an instruction called “The Empty Cities.” All cities are empty:
khams gsum srid gsum lus ngag gi / byed po gang yin bdag la dris/ / bdag gi bdag ni med pa ste/ / gang gi mtha' la mi gnas so/ / ces pa'o/ /
Ask yourself, What is it that created The three worlds, the three existences, the body and speech? The nature of the self is empty; It does not dwell in any extremes whatsoever.

khams gsum srid gsum lus ngag gi / ces pa ni/ phyi 'jig rten pa'i khams la sogs pa gsum po de'am/ srid gsum la sogs pa'am/ nang lus ngag yid gsum mam/ dus gsum la sogs pa'i grong khyer 'di dag stong pa yin gsungs/ de ji ltar du stong byas pa la/ phyi snod ni rgyu'i gzugs bzhi yis bskyed pa yin la/ de bzhin bskyed pa'i rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yin te/ 'bras bu'i gzugs yin/ lus ngag gi ces pa ni lus ngag gi khongs su yid 'gro ste/ yid las byung ba'i dus gsum la sogs pa'i rtog pa'i grong khyer de thams cad stong pa yin ces pa'o/ /

The “cities” of the three worlds or the three existences (on the outer level) or of the body, speech, and mind (on the inner level), or of the three times and so forth—these cities are empty. In what way are they empty? The outer universe is produced by four kinds of causal matter. It is produced from these four through interdependence and is therefore the resultant matter. “Body and speech” here include mind, and from the mind there arise the cities of conceptual thoughts related to the three times and so forth. All these cities are empty.

de ci ste byas pa la/ byed po gang yin bdag la dris ces pa ste/ de dag gi byed pa po rgyu'i gzugs bzhi yis byas sam/ 'on te yid las byung ba'i dus gsum gyi bdag de yis byas/ rgyu yi gzugs bzhi yis byas na ni gzugs bzhi po de rang yang gcig la gcig gnod pas mi rtag la stong pas na/ de yis bskyed pa'i phyir na khams gsum gyi grong khyer de yang mi rtag pas na stong pa yin ces pa'o/ /

Why is that? Ask yourself, What is it that created these? {164} Were they created by the four kinds of causal matter or by the mentally produced self associated with the three times? If they were created by the four kinds of causal matter, those four kinds of matter must have an effect on one another, so they must be impermanent and empty. And since the cities of the three worlds are produced from the four kinds of matter, they too must be impermanent and therefore empty.

yid las byung ba'i dus gsum gyi bdag de yis byas na/ dus gsum gyi byed pa po de dngos por yod pa gcig gis byas sam/ med pa zhig gis byas/ dngos por yod pa gcig gis byas na/ dngos po ni rdzas yin/ rdzas thams cad 'dus byas yin/ 'dus byas thams cad mi rtag pas na/ des bskyed pa'i grong khyer de stong ces pa'o/ / dngos med gcig gis byas na dngos med kyis dngos po byas pas na/ nam mkha' yis kyang me tog byas par rig pa lam byas par 'dug pas na/ de dag thams cad kyi grong khyer stong pa yin gsungs/

If they were created by the mentally produced self associated with the three times, were they made by a creator associated with the three times that exists substantially, or by an insubstantial entity? Supposing that they were made by something that exists substantially, since substantial entities are material things, and all material things are compounded, and all compounded entities are impermanent, the cities made by it must be empty. If they were made by an insubstantial entity, then that insubstantial entity would be making a substantial entity and it would follow that space could create flowers, so that cannot be the case either. The cities of all these, therefore, are empty.

de yang byed pa po gang yin pa dag la dris ces pa de dag gi byed pa po gang gis byas pa'i bdag dris pas bdag med pa ni bdag nyid stong pa ste/ ces pa ni byed pa po'i bdag nyid ma rnyed pa de stong pa'o/ / stong pa gcig rang kho na yin nas byas pa la de ma yin te/ gang gi mtha' la mi gnas so ces pa ni stong pa'am mi stong pa'am gnyis ka'am gnyis ka ma yin pa'am/ gang gi mtha' la yang mi gnas ces pa'o/ /

Furthermore, when you ask yourself, Is it the self that created those cities, [the answer is that] there is no self; its nature is empty. You will never find an existent entity that constitutes a creator. It is empty. Is it all just a uniform emptiness? No. “It does not dwell in any extremes whatsoever.” It is neither empty nor not empty, nor both empty and not empty, nor neither empty nor not empty. It does not dwell in any of these extremes.
de nyid kyi don dom+bi pas gsungs pa/ grong khyer thams cad stong pa la/ / dang por grub pa ga la yod/ / ces gsungs/ de'i don ni/ go bar gda' bas 'dir ma bkod/
The meaning of this was affirmed by Ḍombipa: All cities are empty. Where is there anything that exists substantially? This point can be understood without being set out here.
go rak+Sha pas gsungs pa/ snang grags rtogs pa'i grong khyer la/ / gzung ba'am ni 'dzin pa yis/ / srin bu mi bde kha chu bsdams/ / ma bzung btang na bde bar 'gyur/ / ces gsungs so/ /

Gorakṣha then gave the following teaching: {165} Because of dualistic grasping to the city Of appearances, sounds, and thoughts, one is bound, Like the unhappy silkworm trapped inside its own saliva. Happiness comes when one lets go and does not grasp.

de yang snang grags zhes pa snang ba ni phyi nang snod bcud la sogs pa ni dngos po'i chos yin la/ grags pa ni rtog thun mkhan gyis btags pa yin pas na/ de dag thams cad kyang rtog pa las ma 'das pas na/ rtog pa'i grong khyer la ces pa'o/ / de la yang dag par gzung ba'am 'dzin pa'i dbang gis rang gis rang bcings pa'i dpe ni srin bu'i kha chus rang nyid bsdams la/

“Appearances” refers to the world and its inhabitants and so on, which are physical phenomena, while “sounds” refers to conceptual, conventional labels. All these are nothing other than concepts, which is why Gorakṣha speaks of “the city of conceptual thoughts.” Because of one’s dualistic subject-object grasping at them as real, one binds oneself, like a silkworm that binds itself inside the cocoon secreted from its mouth.

ma bzung btang na bde bar 'gyur ces pa/ ma bzung ces pa ni phyi'i yul la bden par ma bzung ba yin la/ btang ba ni dngos por 'dzin pa de btang nas chos nyid gnyug mar gnas na bde bar 'gyur zhes pa'o/ /

“Happiness comes when one lets go and does not grasp.” “Not grasping” is ceasing to believe in the true existence of the object outside. “Letting go” means giving up the belief in a substantially existing subject and resting in the natural state, ultimate reality. When one does so, one will be happy.
tan ta pas gsungs pa/ mi spangs pa dang mi ldan par/ / shes par gyur na grong ma 'jug / dga' bos nor bu'i 'od bzhin du/ / grong khyer bde ba chen por 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Tantipa spoke as follows: When you know how to not reject and not possess, You will not enter the city. As with Nanda and the jewel’s light, The city will become great bliss.

de la mi spong ba ni phyi nang snod bcud la sogs pa thams cad mi spong ba'o/ / de ci ste mi spong na/ snod bcud de'i byed pa po'am bdag nyid dam/ spang bar bya ba'i rdzas de ma grub pas mi spong zhes pa'o/ / 'o na gong du 'khrul pa mi spang ngo byas na/ shes par gyur na 'khrul pa'i grong khyer la mi 'jug pa de mi 'thad do byas pas/ de'ang yin te 'khrul pa rang kha ma'i grogs la mi 'jug pa ste/ 'khrul pa de rang chos nyid kyi rang bzhin bde ba chen po'i grong khyer du gyur te/ dga' bos nor bu'i 'od bzhin du/ / grong khyer bde ba chen por 'gyur/ /zhes gsungs pa/ dga' bos nor bu'i 'od bzhin du zhes gsungs pa dpe yin te/ dga' bo zhes pa ni klu'i rgyal po yin la/ nor bu ni nor bu rin po che yin/ de'i 'od de klu'i rgyal po des mthong ba yin la/ gzhan gyis de mthong ba ma yin dpe de bzhin du mi spong mi ldan gcig gi don shes par gyur na/ rtog pa'i grong khyer rang bde ba chen por 'gyur zhes pa'o/ /

“Not rejecting” refers to not rejecting all the outer and inner phenomena, the world and its inhabitants. In what way should one not reject them? One should not reject them because there is no existent creator of the world and its inhabitants, neither an atman nor anything to be rejected. You might argue that this is saying, “Do not reject delusion,” and therefore that to say, “When you know that, you will not enter the city of delusion” is a non sequitur. That is true, but it is not that you enter the city of delusion as such: that delusion itself is by nature the ultimate nature and becomes the city of great bliss. “As with Nanda and the jewel’s light, the city will become great bliss”: {166} The analogy here is of Nanda, a nāga king, and a precious jewel. The nāga king can see the light of that jewel, but to others it is invisible. Similarly, when one knows the meaning of not rejecting it and simultaneously not possessing it, the city of conceptual thought will itself become great bliss.

de ltar slob dpon bi ra pas/ grong khyer bde ba'i gdams ngag bshad nas/ de nas slob dpon sa ra ha yis gnod sbyin mo la gdams pa/ gang zhig chos rnams ci smras pa/ / smra ba de dag dran pa ste/ / ji ltar mya ngan 'das smra ba/ / dran pa'i dbang po ma yin nam/ / zhes gsungs pa'o/ /

Following this explanation of the master Birvapa’s instruction on the city of bliss, the master Saraha gave the yakṣhiṇī the following instruction: When people talk about phenomena, Everything they say is a recollected thought. And when they talk about nirvana, Is that not too the faculty of thought?
