'chi ka'i 'od gsal ni lus kyi 'byung ba rnams rim gyis bsdus nas/ bar do dang po'i dus na/ da ltar gyi rnam par rtog pa ni 'gags/ bar do ni da rung rlung ma langs pa'i dus na/ shi ba'i 'od gsal spros bral stong pa nyid kyi sku ji lta ba gcig sems can thams cad kyi rgyu la 'byung ste/ de tha mal pa la rnam rtog gis ngo ma shes pas yang yang 'khor bar 'khor ba'o/ /

The luminosity of the moment of death occurs after the gradual dissolution of the body’s elements, during the first intermediate state, when thoughts of the present life stop. In this intermediate state, the wind has still not arisen, and at that time the luminosity of death occurs—emptiness free of elaborations, the body of truth as it is. This happens in the minds of all beings. Ordinary beings fail to recognize it because of their conceptual thoughts, and so they circle again and again in samsara.

de ltar bzhi yod pa las/ 'dir gnyid kyi 'od gsal zin nam blta'o/ / de la dus kyi gnad ni dus su stan bde ba la seng ge'i nyal stabs kyis nyal lo/ / dang po bdag gis gnyid kyi 'od gsal spros bral stong pa nyid zin par bya'o/ / zin nas kyang ngo shes par bya'o snyam pa'i 'phen pa dung dung pa yang yang bya'o/ / de nas gnyid thum thum bro ba'i dus dang*/ yul gyi gnad ni a nu ta ra bzhi la sems bzung bas/ gnyid kyi 'od gsal bde stong dbyer med/ 'od gsal gyi nyams myong phril ba skyes pa'o/ / de ltar gnyid kyi 'od gsal de zin nas/ brtson 'grus byas nas bsgom na tshe 'di la 'tshang rgya'o/ / le lo can bar dor 'tshang rgya/ 'da' ka ma rig pa'i 'od gsal dang gnyid du bsre ba 'brel/ gnyid dang bsam gtan bsre ba 'od gsal gyi rdzogs rim mo/ / gdams ngag bsre 'pho gnyis las des bsre ba bstan nas/ da 'pho ba bstan pa ni/

Of these four kinds of luminosity, it is the luminosity of sleep that is apprehended or observed. For this, when the essential point of time occurs, lie down in the sleeping-lion posture[29] on a comfortable mat. First, you should be motivated by repeatedly thinking and yearning, “I must apprehend the luminosity of sleep, emptiness free of elaborations. And having apprehended it, I must also recognize it.” Then, concentrate on the moment when you experience deep sleep and on the essential point of the object, the four letters A, nu, ta, and ra. Doing so will give rise to the complete experience of luminosity, the luminosity of sleep, inseparable from bliss and emptiness. From apprehending the luminosity of sleep in this way, if one trains in it diligently, one will attain enlightenment in this life. Lazy people will attain enlightenment in the intermediate state, {192} connecting the luminosity of awareness at the moment of death with sleep mixing. Mixing sleep and concentration is the perfection stage of luminosity. Of the two instructions on mixing and transference, the above concerned mixing. Next, there is the teaching on transference.

'chi bar bslu bar ma nus na/ / 'pho ba rnam pa gsum yin te/ / dang po snying kha lte ba'o/ / dang po sbyor ba sgo dgu dgag / kha dog ser po 'bar ba yi/ / ka Sha gnyis 'gyur yi ge ni/ drang por ldan pa'i sa bon gyis/ / tshangs pa'i sgo ru des bsrung ngo*/ / dril bu'i yi ge mig la'o/ /

If death is unavoidable, There are three kinds of transference: The first is from the heart and from the navel. Begin, in preparation, by closing the nine openings. The double letter kaṣa, Yellow and blazing with light— The upright seed syllable Keeps guard in the aperture of Brahmā. The syllable of the bell is in the eye.
zhes pa nas/ lus la rlung gi sa bon dang*/ zhes pa'i bar gyis

That which has the seed syllable of emptiness Is placed on the tip of the ear. The seed syllable of nectarous water Is held on the tip of the tongue. The stacked seed syllable of the lion Guards the door of emanation and absorption. The stacked seed syllable of the tigress Is to be placed on the breast. The stacked seed syllable of the jackal Is to be placed in the heart center. In the navel, the vital center of burning, The seed syllable of power keeps guard. Then, guard the lower opening as well With the light-yellow seed syllable of water. In the urethra and anus Make the seed syllables blaze. In the body, the seed syllable of the wind…
sgo dgag pa bstan no/ /de ltar rab 'bring dgu yi sgo dgag pa bstan nas/ de nas dngos gzhi la/ snying kha nas 'pho ba dang*/ lte ba nas 'pho ba bstan/

This comprises the teaching for closing the openings, showing how the nine openings are closed in the case of superior and middling [transference]. Next, for the main practice, there is transference from the heart center and transference from the navel.
And in the mandala of mind and wind, On the base of the final fading breath, With a cry, the essence drop Is to be guided by the mind.
des 'pho ba dang po bstan nas/ gnyis pa nyal thabs kyi 'pho ba dang rtsol bas 'pho ba'o/ /
This teaches the first kind of transference. After that there is transference lying down and forceful transference.

grong 'jug ni sbyar ba dang gcig / las la sbyar ba dang gnyis/ las la sbyar ba la gsum/ rnam shes thong gzhan du 'jug pa dang*/ de nyid gzhan gyi sems shes pa'i mngon shes bsgrub pa dang*/ rgyal po la sogs pa dbang bya ba'o/ / de dag gi don zhal nas blang*/ de yan chad du lta ba'i don gdams ngag rnam pa lnga/ gnad kyi gzer bu chung bzhi ste dgu/ bsre pho yan chad du bdun te bcu drug de gzhung nan yod pa'i chos tshig lags so/ / go cha bzhi ma rig pa rtsad gcad pa lnga ni zhal la blang ngo*/ /

Entering a residence is divided into application, application to karma, and application to activities, referring to ejecting the consciousness and entering another [body], practicing clairvoyance in knowing that other one’s mind, and subjugating kings and so forth. These are given as oral teachings. The five instructions on the meaning of the view and four little nails of essential points make nine instructions, which, together with the seven on mixing and transference, make sixteen instructions that comprise the teachings in the source text. There were also five [instructions] on the four armors and uprooting ignorance, which were transmitted orally.

gnod sbyin mo la bsre pho'i gdams ngag de mngon du gyur nas/ lus ngan pa spangs/ rnal 'byor ma su ma ti bya ba'i lus la 'pho ba byas nas gnas chen thams cad du rgyu zhing*/ bla ma rnams la bsnyen bkur byed pa'i dus su/ nub phyogs kha cher nA ro pa la lung bstan te/ / gti mug zad cing lta ba rtogs pa 'dod pa dang*/ / lam med lam la sbyor bar 'dod pa rnams/ / shar phyogs te lo zhes pa'i grong khyer du/ / rdo rje 'chang chen sangs rgyas te lo pa/ / lam 'bras mngon du gyur byed de la btug na rung*/ / zhes lung bstan no/ /

The yakṣhiṇī realized the instructions on mixing and transference and, abandoning her evil body, transferred into the body of a yoginī called Sumati. Journeying to all the sacred places, {193} she venerated her teachers. At that time, to the west in Kashmir, she made the following prediction to Nāropa: “In a city to the east, called Telo, dwells the great Vajradhara, the buddha Telopa. For those who wish to bring an end to bewilderment and to realize the view, and those who wish to practice the path without a path, he enables them to realize the path and result. You should try to reach him.”

gnod sbyin mo'i ming du yang rnal 'byor ma su ma ti bya bar gyur nas dur khrod sa la'i nub phyogs/ sar re bar tha bya ba'i grong du/ rnal 'byor pho bdun mo bdun la nyams thams cad nor bu lugs su gsungs pas de thams cad kyang grol zhing smin par byas so/ / de ltar gzhung chung du bcu drug bstan no/ /

Having also changed her name to the yoginī Sumati, the yakṣhiṇī went to a village called Sarrevartha to the west of the Sala charnel ground and described all her experiences, like jewels, to seven yogins and seven yoginīs. As a result, they were all liberated and brought to maturation. This teaching comprises sixteen small source texts.
mjug gi don
III. Conclusion
As a result of Dhamadhuma’s virtuous deed Of bringing to light all these [verses] With the aim of helping the yakṣhiṇī, May all beings attain the level of perfection.
dge ba'i rtsa ba cha phra ba ma yin par bla na med pa'i don du sngo ba bstan to/ /
The conclusion indicates the dedication of virtue not to some trifling goal but to the unsurpassed goal.
[This completes the short instruction text A Precious Necklace.]
rin po che'i phreng ba'i bshad TI ka rdzogs so/ / bla ma a b+ha ya shrIs gsungs pa/ me nyag lo tsA bas bsgyur ba'o// ! //
This completes the commentary (ṭīkā) on A Precious Necklace. It was composed by Guru Abhayashrī and translated by Menyak Lotsawa.
gnod sbyin mo'i rtogs pa rin chen phreng ba'i zhal gdams bzhugs so/ /
THE YAKṢHIṆĪ’S REALIZATION: ORAL INSTRUCTIONS ON A PRECIOUS NECKLACE
bla ma rnams la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the teachers.
chos kyi phyag rgya la/ bdag byin gyis brlabs pa'i chos bzhi las/ dang po rmi lam lam du 'khyer ba'o/ / de la sbyor ba dang dngos gzhi gnyis las/
Of the four topics on the dharma seal with which I have been blessed, the first is incorporating dreams on the path. For this there are two parts, preparation and main practice.

dang po sbyor ba ni/ bla ma dang dkon mchog la dad gus bya ba dang*/ yi ge brgya pa bzlas pa la sogs pa dam tshig nyams pa bshags par bya'o/ / dngos gzhi la bzhi ste/ dang po rmi lam bzung ba dang*/ gnyis pa sbyang ba dang*/ gsum pa sgyu mar bslab cing yang bslang pa dang*/ bzhi pa de kho na nyid bsgom pa'o/ /

First, for the preparation, develop faith and respect for the teacher and the Three Jewels and confess breaches of samaya by reciting the hundred syllables, and so on. For the main practice, there are four parts: apprehending dreams, refining them, training in them as illusory and getting rid of fear,[30] and meditating on thatness.

de la bzung ba'i dus su sngon du dad pa dang 'dun pa drag po yid la bya'o/ / de rnams mal stan 'bol ba sngas 'bol ba mtho bar byas la/ gzhogs g.yas pa sa la phab ste/ lag pa g.yon pa brla'i steng du brkyang la/ lag pa g.yas pa 'gram pa la sbyar la nyal lo/ / mgrin par pad+ma dmar po 'dab ma bzhi pa bsgom/ de'i lte ba la a dkar po gcig bsam ste/ de yang srod la smin par du thig le dkar po gcig la shes pa gtad la gnyid nyal lo/ / de nas tho rangs kyi dus su a la sems bzung ste/ rmi lam la rmi lam du ma shes na sad pa dang*/ da ci rmi lam la rmi lam du ma shes snyam pa'i 'dun pa drag po bya'o/ / nang par gyi dus su yang*/ snang srid thams cad rmi lam dang 'dra bar shes par bya ste/ mdang gi rmi lam dang khyad med snyam du bsam zhing nyin par gyi dus su/ do nub rmi lam la rmi lam du shes par bya snyam pa'i 'dun yang dang yang du bya'o/ / de ltar nyin mtshan du byas pas rmi lam zin te 'ong*/ zin pa'i rtags ni rmi lam du mi 'tsham pa la sogs pa 'byung ste/ de yang chu chen po dang*/ g.yang la mi thar ba dang*/ khyis ded pa dang*/ lus la 'od 'byung ba dang*/ de la sogs pa sna tshogs pa rmi ba 'byung ste/ de'i rkyen gyis rmi lam yin snyam pa'i shes pa 'ga' 'byung ngo*/ / de ltar 'byung ba dang rmi lam gyi dus su chos thams cad rmi lam dang 'dra zhes bshad pa de'i bden snyam pa'i 'dun pa'am mos pa drag po bya'o/ / nang par mdang gi rmi lam dran par bya ste/ mdang gi rmi lam de dag da ltar gyi shes pa 'di la khyad ci yod snyam pa'i 'dun pa drag tu bya'o/ / rmi lam zin no/ /

For this, when you are practicing apprehending dreams, as a preliminary, develop intense faith and yearning. {194} After that, pile your bed high with cushions. Lie down with your right side on the bed, stretching your left hand along the top of your thigh and placing your right hand against your cheek. In your throat center visualize a red four-petaled lotus. In its center visualize a white letter A. At dusk, directing your consciousness toward a white sphere between your eyebrows, go to sleep. Then, at dawn, concentrate on the A. If you have failed to apprehend your dreams while dreaming, you should feel a strong yearning, thinking, “I have woken up and failed to recognize any of my dreams.” In the morning also, think, “I should understand that the whole of phenomenal existence is like a dream: there is no difference between it and last night’s dream.” During the daytime, repeatedly make the aspiration, “Tonight, I must recognize my dreams.” By doing this day and night, you will apprehend your dreams. The sign of doing so is that various untoward things may happen to you in your dreams. You will have all kinds of dreams, of being in a great flood, being in an abyss from which you cannot escape, being chased by dogs, your body shining with light, and so on. Because of these, you will sometimes recognize them, thinking, “It is a dream.” When this happens and during your dreams, you will feel strong faith and inspiration, thinking, “The teachings that all phenomena are like a dream are true.” In the morning you should remember the previous night’s dreams and feel strongly, “What is the difference between last night’s dream and my present perceptions?” This is apprehending one’s dreams.

de nas zin nas srod kyi dus rang nas rmi lam rmi lam du shes par bya'o snyam pa'i 'dun pa drag po bya'o/ / de nas rmi lam sbyang ba ni/ rmi lam yin pas ji ltar yang byar btub snyam pa'i 'dun pa drag po bya ste/ rmi lam gyi dus su chur mchong ba dang*/ mer mchong ba dang*/ g.yang la 'dzegs pa dang*/ sum cu rtsa gsum gyi gnas blta ba dang*/ rgya gar gyi yul thams cad blta ba dang*/ nyi zla rkang pas mnan pa dang*/ yi dam lha'i zhal lta zhing chos nyan pa dang*/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhing khams lta zhing de dag la chos nyan pa dang*/ rang gi sems ci mno ba thams cad bya'o/ / de bzhin du goms pas bslab pa ni rmi lam sbyong ba'o/ /

After that, once you can apprehend your dreams, at dusk make a strong aspiration, thinking, “I must recognize my dreams as dreams.” Then, to train in dream, {195} resolve, “Since it is a dream, no matter what I do, it will be all right.” During the dream, do all the things that you think of—plunging into water, jumping into a fire, climbing a precipice, looking at the Heaven of the Thirty-Three, looking at all the sacred places in India, trampling on the sun and moon, having a vision of the yidam deity and receiving teachings, seeing the buddha fields of the tathāgatas and hearing them teach, and so forth. To train in habituating yourself in this way is to refine the dream state.

de nas rmi lam sgyu mar shes par bya zhing ya nga ba spang ba ni/ sbyor ba'i dus su chur mchong ba byas pas/ da rung du ya nga dang bag tsha ba'i 'jigs pa yod pa snyam byed na/ rmi lam yin sgyu ma yin pas de 'jigs rgyu ga la yod snyam du bsgom pas ya nga ba med par bya'o/ / de ni rmi lam sgyu mar shes par bya'o/ /

Next, for recognizing dreams as illusion and getting rid of fear, if you still feel apprehensive or afraid when jumping into water and so on during this training, meditate thinking, “It is a dream, it is an illusion, so what is there to be afraid of?” By doing so, you will free yourself of fear. This is recognizing dreams as illusion.

de nas de kho na nyid bsgom pa ni/ rmi lam yin pas sbyang du yang ci yod de rang sems kyi 'khrul par shes par bya ste/ de kho na nyid bsgom pa'o/ / de bsgom thabs ni rang gis sngar gang bsgoms pa de bsgom la/ de min na rang gi dpral ba'i thig le'am gsang ba'i thig le gang yang rung bar shes pa gtad de bde stong la mos pa byas pa tsam gyis shin tu bde ba cher 'byung ngo*/ / de ni rmi lam du de kho na nyid bsgom pa'o/ / de ni rmi lam du 'khyer ba ste tshe 'di la bslab pa'o/ /

Then there is meditating on thatness. You should recognize that since it is a dream, what is there to refine? It is a delusion of your own mind. This is meditating on thatness. The way to meditate on that is to meditate on whatever you meditated on previously, and otherwise to focus on a sphere in the forehead center or in the secret center, whichever is suitable, and to aspire to bliss-emptiness. Merely doing this will give rise to extremely great bliss. This is the meditation on thatness in one’s dreams. Incorporating dreams on the path is a practice that one trains in in this life.
! gnyid 'thug por 'od gsal du gzhug pa'i man ngag ni/
A PITH INSTRUCTION ON ENTERING LUMINOSITY IN DEEP SLEEP

dang por gnyid nyal ba ste/ de yang dang po zhag gsum tsam du lus thang chad du bcug la/ de'i dus su nub mo gnyid bsrung ste/ dge sbyor ci nus kyang bya/ de nas lus la bsku mnye yang bya/ khams brtas su yang bcug la/ lus kyi gzhog g.yas pa sa la phab la nyal bar bya'o/ /

First of all, go to sleep. For this, begin by tiring out the body for three days. During that time, keep yourself from falling asleep in the evening by doing whatever virtuous activities you can. Massage your body {196} and build up your physical strength. Lie down on your right side.

dus ni gnyid kyi dus so/ / yul ni snying kha ste/ snying ga'i 'khor lo pad+ma bzhi la a nu ta ra bzhi bsgom/ hU~M dbus su bsam te tha mal gyi dus su mdun gyi a la sems gtad do/ / de nas phung po khams dang skye mched la sogs pa'i rtog pa rags pa nub par gyur nas/ gnyid hri ba yong dus su nu la sems bzung ste sems snang ba zhes bya'o/ / de nas rnam rtog phra ba nub dus su ta la dmigs te sems snang ba mched pa stong pa chen po'o/ / de nas rtog pa shin tu phra ba nub dus gnyid hri ba byung dus na ra la dmigs te snang ba theb pa zhes bya ste/ shin tu stong pa'o/ / de nas gnyid hrul gyis 'gro dus su shes pa hU~M la bsdu ste/ der bde stong gi ngo bo/ lhan gyis nyal bas gnyid kyi ro bde stong du skyed pa'i bde stong 'od gsal gyi nyams 'ong ngo*/ / de'i dus su rmi lam ni bsrung ste 'di'i 'gal rkyen du bzhed do/ / de nas gnyid thun gcig log la slong du bcugs ma rig pa'i gnyid du song ngam ma song blta bar byas la sngar bzhin nyal lo/ / de'i nub mo thun bzhi'am lnga ci rigs par nyal lo/ / de nas phyis thun gnyis sam gsum la sogs par bsgom par bya zhing nyal te/ sngar bzhin du phung po la sogs ni khams phra ba 'jug go / khams phra ba sems la gzhug go / sems ni yang sems la gzhug go / sems pa yang ma rig pa la gzhug ste/ de ltar gnyid log pas ma rig pa ngang gis 'gags shing rnam rtog gi dran pa brjed pa 'ong ngo*/ /

The time is the period of sleep. The object is the heart center. In the heart chakra, visualize the four letters A, nu, ta, and ra on the four petals of a lotus, and the syllable hūṁ in the center. When you are in your ordinary state, focus your mind on the A in front. Then, when gross thoughts of the aggregates, elements, senses-and-fields, and so on have subsided, at the moment you start to fall asleep, concentrate on the letter nu. This is what is called mind appearing. After that, when subtle thoughts subside, concentrate on the ta. This is called the increase in mind appearing, the great emptiness. Then, when the extremely subtle thoughts subside, as your sleep becomes deeper, focus on the letter ra. This is called the attainment of appearances; it is extreme emptiness. Then, when you are completely asleep, gather your consciousness into the hūṁ, the nature of bliss-emptiness. As you maintain that, sleep is experienced as bliss-emptiness and you will experience the luminous bliss-emptiness. Preserving the dream state at that time is viewed as an adverse condition. Then, as you begin to rise out of a session of sleep, check whether you were in the sleep of ignorance or not, and then go to sleep as before. During the night, do four or five sessions, as suitable. Thus, in the last two or three sessions, meditate and sleep as before: the aggregates and so on dissolve into the subtle elements, the subtle elements dissolve in the mind, the mind again dissolves into the subtle mind, the subtle mind too dissolves into ignorance. In this way, as one falls asleep, ignorance will naturally cease and ordinary thoughts will vanish.

de'i 'bras bu ni ye shes kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal bar 'char bar 'ong ngo*/ / ma rig pa'i gnyid lcags kyu dang 'dra ba de bzung nas bde stong gi ngang du nyal bas rnam par shes pa gang la yang 'dre bar mi byed/ 'od gsal gnyid mngon sum du nyams su myong bar 'gyur zhes so/ /

The result of this is that the nature of gnosis will dawn as luminosity. The sleep of ignorance {197} will be apprehended as if with a hook, and one’s sleep in a state of bliss-emptiness will not be mixed with any consciousness. The sleep of luminosity will be experienced in reality.

de nas gnyis sad pa'i rjes thob ni 'di ltar bsgom ste/ mdun du yi dam lha'i thang ka bkram la/ de la sems rtse gcig pas bltas la/ de rang nyid la tshul gsal bar bsgom mo/ / gsal bar 'dug na gsal ba de nyid bde stong du lhan gyis mi dmigs par bsgom la/ yang slar gsal bar bya ba ste thad ka la blta/ de nas thad ka kho na bzhin gsal bar bsgom la de nyid bde stong du lhan gyis bsgom ste/ de yang stong nyid ngang las ro bde bar phril phril shar bar bsgom mo/ da ltar de rang bde stong du bsgoms pas/ goms pa'i tshad ni rang nyid bde stong skye med du gnas la ro bde bar shar ba'o/ / de'i dus su nub mo la sogs pa gnyid nyal dus su gnyid la bsgom/ rjes thob la de ltar bsgoms pas lus yangs bde ba la sogs pa'i rtags yong*/ snang ba thams cad bde stong du lhang lhang shar ba 'ong ngo*/ / tshe 'di nyid la 'od gsal du gnas te mchog gi dngos grub thob par 'gyur ro/ / gal te tshe 'di la ma thob kyang bar dor shes pa 'od gsal du zin pa 'ong*/ de nas bar do nas sangs rgyas te/ rang la dbang med par mngal du 'jug mi srid do/ / gal te mngal du zhugs te lus lan dus na yang gzhan gyi don du rang la dbang yod pas rang dgar zhugs te lus len pa ni sgyu lus bsgom pa'i gang zag dang gnyid 'od gsal du bsgom pa'i gang zag dang ldan pa gnyis srid kyis de ma yin na lus len mi srid gsungs/ slob dpon l+wa ba pas kyang lo bcu gnyis kyi bar du gnyid log pas mchog thob gsungs/ de ni sgyu lus dang gnyid 'od gsal du gzhug pa gnyis char gyi bsgom pa'o/ /

Next, in the postmeditation period after waking from sleep, you should practice as follows. In front of you, put up a scroll painting of the yidam deity and look at it concentratedly. Visualize it clearly in your mind. When it is clear, meditate without concepts on that clarity as bliss-emptiness together. Again, make it clear by looking at the scroll painting. Then, visualize it clearly, exactly as in the scroll painting, and do the combined meditation on that as bliss-emptiness, meditating on the blissful taste arising vibrantly from emptiness. As you meditate in this way on the [visualization] as bliss-emptiness, the measure of your having trained is that you will remain in the unborn state of bliss-emptiness and arise in the experience of bliss. At that time, when you go to sleep in the evening and so on, do the meditation in your sleep. From your meditating thus in the postmeditation, signs will occur, such as the body becoming light and comfortable. All appearances will arise vividly as bliss-emptiness. In this very life you will dwell in luminosity and attain the supreme accomplishment. Even if you do not achieve that in this life, in the intermediate state you will apprehend consciousness as luminosity. Then, in the intermediate state, you will attain enlightenment: for you, helplessly entering a womb will no longer be possible. If you have entered a womb, it is because when you take a body, you will have done so voluntarily in order to benefit others, and you will have entered the womb of your free accord. For someone who has meditated on the illusory body and someone who has trained in sleep as luminosity, their taking a body is not through becoming[31]—it is impossible for them to take a body in that way. {198} The master Lvavapa (Kambala) too declared that by doing sleep practice for twelve years one attains the supreme level. He practiced the two practices of illusory body and sleep luminosity together.
[INTERMEDIATE STATES]

na mo gu ru/ bar do gsum/ sgyu lus gsum/ mngon du bya ba gsum/ bsre ba gsum/ mtshams sbyor gsum/ de la skye shi bar do/ lus rnam smin gyi lus/ mngon du 'od gsal bya/ bsre ba ni 'dod chags dang bsre'o/ / de las 'dod chags dang bsre ba ni/ grol lam pas gtum mo la brten nas bsgom pas lus bde bas rgyas te/ de la ma zhen par 'od gsal du 'khyer ba'o/ / mtshams ni bla ma'i gdams ngag gi sbyar ba'o/ / bar do rmi lam gyi bar do/ lus bag chags kyi lus/ mngon du rmi lam bya/ bsre ba gti mug dang bsre ba'o/ / gti mug dang bsre ba ni gnyid thug po'am/ zang zing du btang bar sra ba 'thug dran pa la rmi lam sbyang ngo*/ / mtshams ni dran pa dang 'dun pas sbyar ro/ / bar do ni srid pa'i bar do/ lus ni yid kyi lus/ mngon du 'od gsal bya*/ bsre na zhe sdang dang bsre/ zhe sdang dang bsre ba ni bar do tha ma'i dus su/ pha la zhe sdang mi bskyed/ ma la 'dod chags mi bskyed par 'od gsal du 'khyer ba'o/ / bla ma dang yi dam sngar bzhin no/ / mtshams ni pha ma yab yum gnyis kyis sbyar ro/ / [⁽14b4⁾] /

namo guru There are three intermediate states, three illusory bodies, three things that manifest, three mixings, and three connections. In the intermediate state between birth and death, the body is the body that results from the ripening of karma, what manifests is luminosity, and the mixing is mixing with attachment. Mixing with attachment means that practitioners on the path of liberation make use of the practice of tummo, and by doing so seal the body with bliss. Without grasping at that [bliss], they take luminosity as the path. The connection is made by the teacher’s instructions. In the intermediate state of dream, the body is the body of habitual tendencies, and what manifests is dream. The mixing is mixing with bewilderment. Mixing with bewilderment consists of refining dreams in deep sleep or in a balance[32] between deep sleep and light sleep, without one’s getting lost in confusion. The connection is made through one’s devotion and aspiration. In the intermediate state of becoming, the body is a mental body, and what manifests is luminosity. The mixing is mixing with aversion. Mixing with aversion means that at the time of the last intermediate state, one takes luminosity as the path without developing aversion to the father or attachment to the mother [or vice versa]. [One recalls one’s] teacher and yidam as in one’s previous life. The connection is made with the father and mother, male and female deities.
[DEVIATIONS AND ERRORS]

na mo gu ru/ shor sa bzhi dang gol sa gsum spangs nas/ bzhag par ma ltengs/ btang bar ma 'byams/ btang snyoms kyi shes pa las log pa'i shes pa ma bcos pa la g.yar ba bag thon par byas la bsgom pas rnal 'byor rnam pa bzhi bskyed gsungs te/ de la dang po shor sa gzhi la stong pa nyid shes bya'i gshis la shor ba na/ mtshan nyid pa'i lugs gcig dang du bral gyis stong nyid du gtan la phab nas/ stong pa nyid nam mkha'i dkyil lta bu de/ rnam rtog gis byas pas rtog pa bsgom pa yin/ sngags pas phyi snod nang bcud la rim gyis bsdus pa'am/ swa b+hA wa la sogs pa sngags kyi sgo nas blos stong pa nyid nam mkha' rnam par dag pa lta bur byas nas de la blos 'jog pa'o/ / de gnyis ka blos byas yin pas shor sa yin no/ /

gnyis pa stong pa nyid rgyas 'debs su shor ba ni/ sbyin pa la sogs pa gtong ba'i yul dang*/ gtong mkhan dang*/ dngos po thams cad mi dmigs par stong pa nyid du rgyas btab nas bsgom pa yin te/ de yang blos byas yin pas so/ /

Second, the deviation into sealing emptiness: This is to meditate by placing the seal of emptiness on the absence of concepts (in generosity, for example) of a recipient, a giver, and a gift. This too is a mental creation.

gsum pa stong pa nyid nyon mongs pa'i gnyen por shor ba ni/ 'dod chags la sogs pa gang skyes kyang*/ de dang po gang nas ma skyes/ da lta ci'i ngo bor yang ma grub/ tha ma 'dir 'gags bya ba'i 'gags pa med par stong pa nyid du blo yis 'jog pa'o/ /

Third, the deviation into using emptiness as an antidote to defilements: This is to settle the mind on whatever arises (attachment, aversion, and so forth) being empty—in that first it has not been born from anywhere, at present it does not exist as the essence of anything, and finally there is nothing to be stopped, or no cessation.
bzhi pa stong pa nyid lam du shor ba ni/

Fourth, the deviation with regard to the path of emptiness: Practitioners on the path of desire consider that a good result exists elsewhere, and as their path or method, they train in making emptiness the object of the mind. By doing so, they are mentally creating the hope that they will attain the body of truth.
gang tshe stong pa thabs yin na/ / de tshe sangs rgyas nyid mi 'byung*/ / rgyu las 'bras bu gzhan yin phyir/ / thabs ni stong pa nyid ma yin/ / zhes pa ste/
If emptiness were the means, Then buddhahood would never occur, For cause and result would conflict. Means is not emptiness.

'bras bu chos sku bzang po gcig gud na yod par byas nas/ de'i lam du stong pa nyid blo yis byas nas bsgom pas kyang chos sku de mi thob pa'o/ / shor sa de bzhi spangs ba'i gnas lugs ni rtog pa thams cad dang bral ba'i blo'i yul las 'das pa'o/ /

From believing that there is a result elsewhere—something good, a body of truth—even by mentally creating emptiness on that path and training in it, one will not attain that body of truth. The actual condition of things, in which these four deviations have been abandoned, is free of all conceptualization and transcends the realm of the mind.

gol sa bzhi ni/ bla ma dam pa gcig gis spyan sngar bsgom khrid pas/ bde ba nyams su myong ba skyes nas/ bla ma 'di bsgom lags sam ma lags zhus pas/ de yin pas skyong shig gsungs nas skyong ba'i tshe/ bde ba phril phril byung na dga' mi dga' gnyis dang bcas pa'i tshul gyis nyams su blangs pas 'dod khams su gol/ de bzhin du mi rtog pa gong ma bzhin du nyams su blangs pas gzugs med du gol/ de bzhin du gsal ba skyes nas nyams su blangs pas gzugs khams su gsol/ de gsum dbyer med la chags shing zhen na nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas su gol te blos byas pa yin pas so/ /

The four errors are as follows. As a result of being guided in meditation by a sublime teacher, the experience of bliss arises. When one asks the teacher whether this is the meditation or not, {200} one is told that it is and that one should preserve it. If, in doing so, one feels happy when the thrill of bliss happens and unhappy [when it does not], one’s practice will lead to the error of one’s straying into the world of desire. If one practices in the same way with regard to [the experience of] absence of thought, one will stray into the world of formlessness. Likewise, such a way of practicing when clarity arises will lead to one’s straying into the world of form. If one is attached and grasps at these three together, one strays into the state of the listeners and solitary realizers, because these [states] are mind created.
de rnams spangs pa'i shes pa ma bcos pa la bzhag pas bzhag par ltengs pa ni mi rtog pa lteng nge 'dug go /
If one settles in an uncontrived consciousness devoid of these [errors], one may become stagnant in a thoughtless inertia.
btang sar 'byams pa ni/ rtog pa gcig rting nas brgyud mar byung ba'o/ /
Getting lost in apathy is related to indifference, thinking to oneself, when thoughts occur one after the other, “There is no need to meditate; this is the body of truth.”
btang snyoms gnod sbyin rtog pa'i zhal gyi gdams ngag [⁽14b4⁾] / dge'o/ /

The eighty-four siddhas taught A Precious Necklace to a yakṣhiṇī. Since she did not understand its meaning, the teacher Tilopa gave her instructions, of which this is the oral instruction from the yakṣhiṇī’s realization.
[skabs gsum pa]
PART THREE. MITRAYOGIN’S EMPOWERMENTS AND AUTHORIZATION RITUALS FOR THE SIX DEITIES
@#/ /'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi lam gyi rim pa'i mngon rtogs dbang bskur thugs rje chen po'i chu rgyun bzhugs so/ /
6. A RIVER OF GREAT COMPASSION. The Empowerment for the Sādhana in the Stages of the Path of Noble Avalokiteshvara[1]

@#/ /'jig rten gsum gyi 'dren pa mchog gi gtso/ / skye med chos kyi dbyings las ma g.yos par/ / sprul pa du mas 'gro kun 'dren mdzad pa/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / de nyid ji ltar dbang bskur bya ba'i tshul/ / snyan brgyud dbang gi chu rgyun ma chad pa/ / ji ltar bla ma'i zhal gyi pad+mo las/ / byung ba 'di ni bdag gis bkod par bgyi/ /

{202} Supreme lord, leader of the three worlds, Without moving from the unborn expanse of reality You guide all beings through numerous manifestations. To you, Avalokiteshvara, I pay homage. The way to bestow the empowerment of Avalokiteshvara I shall now write down exactly as I heard it In the words that blossomed lotus-like from my teacher’s mouth, Transmitted through the aural lineage in an uninterrupted series of empowerments.
'dir spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi ting nge 'dzin gyi dbang bskur ba la don gnyis te/ lha sgrub cing mchod pa dang dbang bskur ba'o/ /

Here is the ritual for bestowing the empowerment of the concentration of Avalokiteshvara. There are three main sections: (1) performing the sādhana of the deity and making offerings; (2) bestowing the empowerment; [and (3) the concluding stages].
dang po
I. Performing the Sādhana of the Deity and Making Offerings
['di] la gnyis te/ bkod pa bshams pa/ mngon rtogs bsgom pa'o/ /
This is divided into making the preparations and practicing the sādhana.
dang po ni/
A. Making the Preparations

maN+Dal khru gang ba gzhal yas khang gru bzhi sgo bzhi rta babs 'khor yug dang bcas pa bris pa'i dbus su/ pad+ma 'dab ma brgyad pa bris pa'i lte ba dkar/ 'dab ma bzhi phyogs mdog / mtshams bzhi mdzes tshon bya/ shar sngo/ lho ser/ nub dmar/ byang ljang*/ dbus dkar ba'i tshon 'gyed/ tha ma phyi mchod/ nang mchod/ mchod gtor rnams kyis bskor/ dbang bum dang las bum gnyis/ kha rgyan mgul chings dang bcas pa bshams/ ka pA la bdud rtsis bkang ba sin+d+hu ras byugs pa la/ dbus su hrIHbaM gnyis bri/ 'dab ma bzhi ha ri ni sa bris nas bshams/ rdo rje dril bu la sogs dbang rdzas rnams kyang sta gon bya'o/ /

Draw a mandala, one cubit in size, consisting of a square measureless palace with four gates, arched pediments, and surrounding wall, and in the middle of it draw an eight-petaled lotus. Its center should be white, the four petals in the cardinal directions should be correspondingly colored, and the four petals in the intermediate directions beautifully painted. Distribute the colors with the east blue, the south yellow, the west red, the north green, and the center white. Lastly, around it arrange the outer offerings, the inner offerings, and the offering tormas. Set out the empowerment vase and the activity vase, with their ornamental stopper[2] and ribbon tied round the neck. Prepare a kapāla filled with nectar and a [mirror] covered with sindhūra powder, {203} on which are drawn, in the middle, the two letters hrīḥ and baṃ, and on the four petals, the letters ha ri ni sa. Prepare as well the vajra, bell, and other articles for the empowerment.
gnyis pa mngon rtogs sgom pa
B. Practicing the Sādhana
['di] la gsum ste/ bdag bskyed/ mdun bskyed/ bum bskyed do/ /
There are three parts: (1) self-visualization; (2) front visualization; and (3) vase visualization.
dang po bdag bskyed
1. Self-Visualization
['di] la gsum/ skyabs 'gro sems bskyed byang*/ yan lag bdun pas tshogs bsags pa/ bskyed rim bsgom zhing bzlas pa bya ba dang gsum las/

This is divided into three: (1) purifying oneself with refuge and bodhichitta;[3] (2) gathering the accumulations with the seven branches; and (3) meditating on the generation stage and reciting the mantra.
dang po ni/
a. Refuge

bdag gzhan pha ma sems can thams cad bla ma la skyabs su mchi'o/ / sangs rgyas la skyabs su 'chi'o/ / chos la skyabs su 'chi'o/ / dge 'dun la skyabs su 'chi'o/ / 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi lha tshogs 'khor dang bcas pa rnams la skyabs su 'chi'o/ / zhes lan gsum bya/

I and all beings who have been my parents go for refuge in the teacher. We take refuge in the Buddha. We take refuge in the dharma. We take refuge in the sangha. We take refuge in the host of deities of noble Avalokiteshvara and their retinues. Say this three times.
b. The Seven Branches

de nas byang chub mchog tu sems bskyed pa'i thog mar/ yan lag bdun pas tshogs bsags pa ni/ rang nyid skad cig gis spyan ras gzigs su gyur ba'i thugs ka'i hrIHlas 'od 'phros pas spyan ras gzigs la rgyal ba sras bcas kyi bskor ba spyan drangs/

Next, to arouse the mind set on supreme enlightenment, begin by gathering the accumulations with the seven branches: In an instant I become Avalokiteshvara. In my heart is the syllable hrīḥ, from which lights radiate, inviting Avalokiteshvara surrounded by buddhas and bodhisattvas. {204}
Ar+Ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra badz+ra sa ma ya dza dza/ pad+ma ka ma la ye s+t+waM swA hA/
ārya avalokiteśvara vajra samaya ja jaḥ padma kamala ye stvaṃ svāhā

dkon gsum la phyag 'tshal lo/ / mchod pa'i tshogs kyis mchod par bgyi/ / sdig pa thams cad so sor bshags/ / dge ba kun la rjes yi rang*/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor bar bskul/ / mya ngan mi 'da' bzhugs gsol 'debs/ / dge bas byang chub mchog thob shog / ces dang*/

I pay homage to the Three Jewels. I venerate them with a multitude of offerings. I confess each and every one of my evil deeds. I rejoice in all virtue. I beseech you to turn the wheel of dharma. I pray to you to remain without passing into nirvana. By this merit, may we attain supreme enlightenment. And:
dkon mchog gsum la bdag skyabs mchi/ / *

To the Three Jewels I go for refuge, All my evil actions I confess, And in the virtue of all beings I rejoice. The enlightenment of buddhahood I will hold in mind, And till enlightenment is reached I will take refuge in the Buddha, dharma, and supreme assembly. To achieve my own and others’ aims, I’ll arouse the mind intent on enlightenment. Having set my mind on supreme enlightenment, I invite all beings, each and every one, to be my guests And joyfully partake of the sublime ways of the bodhisattvas. To benefit all beings, may I achieve buddhahood!
zhes sogs rdo rje gur las byung ba bzhin lan gsum bya/ de nas tshogs zhing mi dmigs/
and so on, as is found in the Vajrapañjara Tantra.[4] Repeat this three times. Then dissolve the field of accumulation.
gsum pa ni/
c. Meditating on the Generation Stage and Reciting the Mantra
thog mar tshad med bzhi bsgom pa ni/ sems can thams cad bde ba dang bde ba'i rgyu dang ldan par 'gyur cig / ces sogs tshad med bzhi bsgom/ de nas mngon byang lngas bskyed rim bsgom pa ni/

Begin by meditating on the four boundless attitudes: May all beings come to possess happiness and the causes of happiness…[5] and so on. Next, meditate on the generation stage with the five factors of awakening.
oM swa b+hA wa shud+d+ha sarba d+harma swA b+hA wa shud+d+ho\u0f85 haM/
oṁ svabhāva śuddāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ
chos thams cad rang bzhin gyi stong zhing bdag med par gyur/
All phenomena are by nature empty and devoid of intrinsic existence.

stong pa'i ngang las 'byung ba rim brtsegs lnga'i steng du ri bo mchog rab kyi steng du sna tshogs pad+ma 'bum ldan gyi steng du sna tshogs rdo rje las 'od 'phros/ srung ba'i 'khor lo yangs por gyur ba'i dbus su b+hU~M kha dog lnga ldan 'od du zhu ba las/ gzhal yas khang pa gru bzhi sgo bzhi rtsigs pa rim pa lnga las/ rta babs bzhi tog dang bcas pa/ rdo ra me ri dang bcas pa/ gzhal yas khang gi mtshan nyid thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa'i dbus su/ paM las sna tshogs pad+ma 'dab ma brgyad pa/ a las zla ba'i dkyil 'khor nya gang ba'i steng du hrIHdkar po tsheg drag dang bcas pa/ baM yig dmar po las dpag tu med pa'i 'od zer 'phros/ gzhal du med pa'i sems can gyi don byas jo bo spyan ras gzigs kyi sar bkod/ 'od zer tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las pad+ma'i sdong po dkar po/ lte ba hrIHdang baM gis mtshan pa las 'od zer 'phros/ sangs rgyas byang sems thams cad spyan ras gzigs kyi rnam par spyan drangs pad+ma hrIHdang baM la thim yongs su gyur pa las rang nyid 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug sku mdog dkar po gangs ri la nyi ma shar ba lta bu/ zhal gcig phyag bzhi pa/ zhabs gnyis rdo rje'i skyil mo krung gis bzhugs pa/ lha'i dar sna tshogs kyis stod g.yogs dang smad g.yogs dang*/ nor bu'i ske rags grol thabs su 'ching bu/

From the state of emptiness there arise the five elements, stacked in order, on top of which is the supreme mountain. On top of it is a multicolored lotus with a hundred thousand petals, and on it, a crossed vajra, from which light radiates, forming a vast protection circle. In the middle of it is the five-colored syllable bhrūṃ. It melts into light to become a measureless palace, which is square, with four doors and five-layered walls, four arched pediments, a top ornament, a vajra fence, and a mountain of flames—all the features of a measureless palace being complete. In the middle of it is the syllable paṁ, from which there appears a multicolored lotus with eight petals. From the letter A appears the mandala of a full moon, on which appear the white syllable hrīḥ, complete with visarga,[6] and the red syllable baṁ. From them infinite light rays emanate, benefiting immeasurable sentient beings and setting them on the level of Lord Avalokiteshvara. {205} The light rays are gathered back and transform into a white lotus plant, marked in its center with hrīḥ and baṁ, from which rays of light emanate, inviting all the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the form of Avalokiteshvara. They dissolve into the lotus, hrīḥ, and baṁ, which are transformed into oneself as noble Avalokiteshvara. His body is white in color, like a snow mountain with the sun shining on it. He has one face and four arms and is seated with his two legs crossed in the vajra posture. He is wearing upper and lower garments of multicolored celestial silks, loosely tied with a jeweled sash.

phyag dang po gnyis thugs thal mo sbyar ba'i bar na nor bu rin po che dbang gi rgyal po 'dzin pa/ g.yas kyi gnyis pas nor bu rin po che'i phreng ba 'dzin pa/ g.yon pas pad+ma 'dab ma brgyad pa'i yu ba nas 'dzin cing rab rgyas snyan gyi thad kar kha bye ba/ zhal 'dzum bag dang bcas pa/ spyan dkyus dang smin dkyus ring ba mdzod spu dkar pos brgyan pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i cod pan nag po gyen la bcings shing ral pa'i zar bu rked sor g.yogs pa me tog gi phreng bas skra chings can/ ut+pal sngon po gnyis kyis snyan gong brgyan pa/ ri dwags lpags pas phrag pa g.yon pa bkab pa/ rin po che sna lngas rtse phran lnga dang*/ snyan cha dang*/ mgul rgyan dang*/ do shal dang*/ phyag gdub dang*/ zhabs gdub dang*/ dpung rgyan dang*/ 'og pag dang*/ mu tig sna lngas chun po dang*/ dar gyi cod pan gyis brgyan pa/ 'od zer sna la 'khrigs pa'i dbus na bzhugs pa/

His first two hands are joined at the level of his heart, holding between them the wish-fulfilling jewel. Of his other two hands, the right one is holding a rosary of precious jewels and the left is holding an eight-petaled lotus by its stem, with the flower blooming at the level of his ear. His smiling face is adorned, between his almond eyes and long eyebrows, with a coil of white hair (ūrṇā). His hair is tied up to form a black crown, while locks of hair hang down to his waist, with a garland of flowers for a hair ribbon. He is adorned with two blue utpalas as ear ornaments. His left shoulder is draped with the skin of an antelope. He is adorned with the five-tipped crown, earrings, necklet, long necklace, bracelets, anklets, armlets, and girdle, all made of the five precious materials, and a garland of five kinds of pearls, together with a silken head ornament. He is seated in the middle of a dense mass of multicolored rays of light.

de'i pang na yum gsang ba ye shes sku mdog pad+ma rA ga ltar dmar ba/ zhal gcig phyag gnyis zhabs gnyis yab kyi rked pa la 'khril ba/ phyag g.yas pas gser gyi DA ma ru nam mkhar 'khrol ba/ g.yon pas ka pA la bdud rtsi dmar po'i rgyun gyis bkang nas yab kyi zhal du stob pa/ zhal 'dzum zhing cung zad bzhad pa/ khro 'dzum spyan gsum dang ldan pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor cog dang zar bu rked sor g.yogs pas/ thod skam rin po che'i rtse phran gyis mtshan pa lngas dbu brgyan cing*/ dkar 'dzin dang chu 'dzin rgyas pa/ zhi ba 'dzum pa/ gzhon cing sgeg pa/ bcu drug lon pa'i na tshod dang ldan pa/ rus pa'i rgyan cha lngas brgyan pa 'od zer sna lnga 'phro ba'o/ /

On his lap is his secret wisdom consort, who is red in color, like a ruby. {206} She has one face, two hands, and two legs, embracing the male deity around the waist. Her right hand is held up in the air, playing a golden dāmaru. Her left hand holds a kapāla filled with a stream of red nectar to the mouth of the male deity. Her mouth is smiling and peaceful, laughing slightly, while in her three eyes there is an angry smile. Her hair is tied in a topknot, with plaits hanging down to her waist. Her head is crowned with a tiara of five dry skulls crested with jewels. With her fully developed breasts and vulva, her peaceful smile, and her youth and charm, she has the marks of a sixteen-year-old. Adorned with the five bone ornaments, she emanates five-colored rays of light.

de'i gnas lngar pad zla'i steng du spyi bor oM las rnam snang spyan ras gzigs yab yum dkar po/ mgrin par hrI las pad+ma spyan ras gzigs yab yum dmar po/ snying gar hU~M las mi bskyod pa spyan ras gzigs yab yum sngon po/ lte bar trAM las rin 'byung spyan ras gzigs yab yum ser po/ gsang gnas su AHlas don grub spyan ras gzigs yab yum ljang gu/ de thams cad kyang gtso bo'i cha lugs su bzhugs pa/

In their five centers, upon lotus and sun, are the syllables: oṁ, in the crown center, from which appears white Vairochana Avalokiteshvara with his consort; hrīḥ, in the throat center, from which appears red Padma Avalokiteshvara with his consort; hūṁ, in the heart center, from which appears blue Akṣhobhya Avalokiteshvara with his consort; trāṃ, in the navel center, from which appears yellow Ratnasambhava Avalokiteshvara with his consort; and āḥ, in the secret center, from which appears green Amoghasiddhi Avalokiteshvara with his consort. All of them have the same attributes as the principal deity.

de'i shar du ha las rdo rje mkha' 'gro ma sngon po/ lhor ri las rin chen mkha' 'gro ma ser mo/ nub tu ni las pad+ma mkha' 'gro ma dmar mo/ byang du sa las las kyi mkha' 'gro ma ljang gu/ de thams cad kyang zhal gcig phyag gnyis spyan gsum mche ba bzhi cung zad tsam gtsigs pa/ g.yas gri gug g.yon thod khrag / gru khug tu kha T+wAM ga / zhabs gnyis g.yon brkyang g.yas bskum pa'i gar gyis/ me ri'i klong na bzhugs shing rus pa'i rgyan cha lngas brgyan pa/ ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs pa'o/ /

To the east of him, arising from the letter ha, is the blue vajra ḍākinī; to the south, arising from ri, is the yellow ratna ḍākinī; to the west, arising from ni, is the red padma ḍākinī; and to the north, arising from sa, is the green karma ḍākinī. They all have one face, two hands, three eyes, and their four canine teeth slightly bared. In their right hands they each hold a curved knife; in their left, a skull cup full of blood. In the crook of their arms, they hold a khātvāṇga. With their two feet they dance, the left leg bent, the right one extended, dwelling in a mountainous expanse of flames and adorned with the five bone ornaments. All are surrounded by blazing wisdom fire. {207}
de'i spyi bor oM dkar po/ mgrin par AH dmar po/ snying gar hU~M las 'od zer 'phros pas rang bzhin chos kyi dbyings nas rang 'dra ba'i ye shes pa spyan drangs/

From the white oṁ in the crown center, the red āḥ in the throat center, and the blue hūṁ in the heart center, light rays emanate, inviting the wisdom deity similar to oneself from the natural expanse of reality.
Ar+Ya a ba lo ki te shwa ra badz+ra sa ma ya dza dzaH
ārya avalokiteśvara vajra samaya ja jaḥ
dzaHhU~M baM hoH dbyer med gcig tu gyur/
jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ—they become inseparable.

slar yang thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od 'phros/ rigs lnga 'khor bcas spyan drangs/ de bzhin gshegs pa rigs lngas dbang bskur du gsol/ zhes rigs lngas dbang bskur/ bdud rtsi'i rgyun gyis lus kyi nang gang*/ lhag ma yar 'khyil ba las tshe dpag med kyis dbu brgyan/ rang gi snying gar pad zla'i steng du/ rang 'dra ba'i ye shes sems dpa' tshon gang ba'i thugs kar hrIHgnas pa'i mtha' mar sngags kyis bskor ba las 'od zer 'phros/ lus kyi nang thams cad spyan ras gzigs rigs lnga zhing rdul gyi grangs dang mnyam pas gang*/ phyir 'phros snod kyi 'jig rten gzhal yas khang*/ bcud kyi sems can thams cad spyan ras gzigs yab yum gyi skur gyur/ thams cad zhal nas gsang sngags 'dren par bsams la/ sngags ni/

Again from hūṁ in the heart center, light radiates, inviting the buddhas of the five families and their retinues, with the prayer that the tathāgatas of the five families bestow empowerment, as a result of which one is empowered by the five families. The stream of nectar fills the inside of one’s body, and from the excess nectar overflowing above, one’s crown is ornamented by Amitāyus. In one’s heart center is a lotus and moon, on which is the thumb-sized wisdom deity (jñānasattva), similar to oneself. In his heart is the syllable hrīḥ, encircled by the mantra. Rays of light emanate from it, filling the whole of the body with the five families of Avalokiteshvara, as numerous as the atoms in the universe. They radiate outside, transforming the universe into a measureless palace and all the sentient beings inhabiting it into the form of Avalokiteshvara and his consort. All of them are reciting the secret mantra.
oM ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ DA ki nI ha ri ni sa hU~M/ zhes ma yengs pa'i sems kyis 'dren no/ /
Visualizing this, recite the mantra with undistracted mind: oṁ maṇi padme hūṁ ḍākinī harinisa hūṁ

mthar/ jo bo spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis bden pas/ bdag dang sems can thams cad phyag rgya chen po mchog gi dngos grub thob par mdzad du gsol/ zhes gsol ba btab bo/ / 'di ni bsnyen pa bya ba ste/ dus zla ba gsum/ grangs kyi bsnyen pa bye ba gsum/ mtshan ma'i rtags rab mngon sum du spyan ras gzigs yab yum gyi zhal mthong ba dang*/ lung ston pa 'byung*/ 'bring nyams snang*/ tha ma rmi lam du mi dkar po dang*/ bud med dmar mos dngos grub ster ba dang*/ khro ma 'du ba la sogs pa'i rtags 'byung ngo*/ /
! gnyis pa mdun bskyed ni/
2. Front Visualization
rdul tshon nam/ tshom bu'i dkyil 'khor la/ a mr-itas bsangs/
Cleanse the mandala of colored powder or of piles of grain with oṁ amṛtakuṇḍali hana hana hūṁ phaṭ
swA b+hA was sbyangs/
and purify it with oṁ svabhāva śuddāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ
stong pa'i ngang las 'byung ba rim brtsegs lnga'i steng du ri bo mchog rab/ ces pa nas sngags 'dren pa'i bar bdag bskyed ltar du bsgom bzlas bya'o/ /

Perform the meditation and recitation as for the self-visualization, from From the state of emptiness there arise the five elements, stacked in order, on top of which is the supreme mountain… up to the recitation of the mantra.
gsum pa bum bskyed ni/
3. Vase Visualization
rnal rgyal bum dang las bum gnyis/ snying po bzhugs pa/ mgul chings kha rgyan rnams tshul bzhin bshams la/
Properly prepare the all-victorious vase and activity vase, containing the essential ingredients, with their ornamental stoppers and ribbons tied around the neck. Banish obstacle makers with
oM pad+mAn+ta kr-i ta badz+ra kro ta h+ya grI ba hu lu hu lu hU~M phaT/ ces pas bgegs bskrad/ oM swa b+hA wa shud+d+ha sarba d+harmA swa b+hA wa shud+d+ho\u0f85 haM/ stong pa nyid du gyur/
oṁ padmānta kṛta vajra krota hayagrīva hulu hulu hūṁ phaṭ [Then:] oṁ svabhāva śuddāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ All becomes emptiness.

stong pa'i ngang las b+h+rU~M las rin po che las grub pa'i bum pa zhabs zhum pa/ lto ba ldir ba/ mgul pa ring ba/ mchu 'phyang ba/ lha'i dar gyis mgul pa dkris pa/ dpag bsam shing gis kha brgyan pa'i nang du 'o ma'i rgya mtsho las skyes pa'i dbus su paM las pad+ma'i sdong po/ a las zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du hrIHdang baM las 'od zer 'phros/ gzhal du med pa'i sems can gyi don byas/ jo bo spyan ras gzigs kyi sar bkod/ 'od zer de tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ pad+ma'i sdong po dkar po lte bar hrIHdang baM gyis mtshan pa/ zhes pa nas/ zhal nas sngags 'dren par bsam/ zhes pa'i bar bdag skyed ltar bskyed la/ rang gi snying khar zhes pa'i skabs su/ bum skyed kyi lha'i khar zhes 'don pa dang dmigs pa bsgyur/ thams cad zhal nas sngags 'dren par bsam zhing*/ zhal nas bdud rtsi'i rgyun babs pas bum pa gang bar bsam la/ sngags ni/

From the state of emptiness, there appears the syllable bhrūṃ, and from that a vase made of precious materials, with a round base, bulbous body, long neck, and spout. The neck is tied with a celestial silk ribbon, and the opening decorated with the wish-fulfilling tree. Inside is an ocean of milk, from the middle of which arises the syllable paṃ, and from it a lotus plant. From the letter A there appears the mandala of the moon, on top of which are the syllables hrīḥ and baṃ, from which rays of light emanate, benefiting immeasurable numbers of sentient beings and setting them on the level of Lord Avalokiteshvara. The light rays are gathered back and transform into a white lotus plant, marked in its center with hrīḥ and bam… and so on, continuing the visualization as in the self-visualization, down to …are reciting the secret mantra but replacing “In one’s heart center…” with: In the heart center of the deity visualized in the vase… and adapting the visualization accordingly. Consider that As all of them recite the secret mantra, a stream of nectar flows from their mouths, filling the vase.
oM ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ DA ki ni ha ri ni sa hU~M/ zhes pa brgya rtsa brgyad 'dren/ oM badz+ra ut+ta ka swA hA/ zhes pa yang brgya 'dren no/ /
And recite the mantra one hundred eight times: oṁ maṇi padme hūṁ ḍākinī harinisa hūṁ Recite the following one a hundred times as well: oṁ vajra uttaka svāhā
mthar/ jo mo spyan ras gzigs/ ces pa nas/ mdzad du gsol/ zhes gsol ba gdab bo/ / de nas/ ar+g+haM la sogs pas mchod nas/

chos sku nam mkha' bzhin du dbyer med kyang*/ / gzugs sku 'ja' tshon lta bur so sor gsal/ / thabs dang shes rab mchog la mnga' brnyes pa'i/ / rigs lnga bde bar gshegs la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / ces pa dang*/

Although you are inseparable from the body of truth, like space, You manifest distinctly in the body of form, like a rainbow. To you who have mastery of supreme means and wisdom— To the sugatas of the five families I make homage and praise. And:
sangs rgyas kun gyis rab tu bsngags/ yon tan kun gyi gter gyur pa/ / spyan ras gzigs su mtshan gsol ba/ / rtag par brtse la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / ces pas bstod/
Praised highly by all the buddhas, You are a mine of all good qualities. You who received the name All-Seeing,[7] To you who are always full of love I make homage and praise.
las bum/ oM pad+man+ta kr-i ta ces sogs kyis bsangs/ swA b+hA was sbyangs/
Cleanse the activity vase with: oṁ padmānta kṛta vajra krota hayagrīva hulu hulu hūṁ phaṭ And purify it with: oṁ svabhāva śuddāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ

stong pa'i ngang las paM las pad+ma/ raM las nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du hrIHyig las 'od zer 'phros 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ khro bo rta mgrin sku mdog dmar po zhal gcig phyag gnyis g.yas pad+ma'i dbyug to/ g.yon sdigs mdzub mdzad pa/ g.yas bskum g.yon brkyang stag lpags kyis sham thabs can/ khro zhal spyan gsum mche ba bzhi gtsigs pa/ dbu skra ngan ra ser gyen la brdzes pa/ spyi bor rta mgo ljang zhur rta skad phyogs bcur sgrogs pa/ rngog ma dmar po me ltar 'bar ba/ sbrul dang rin po ches brgyan pa/ ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs pa de'i spyi bor oM dkar po/ mgrin par aHdmar po/ snying gar hU~M mthing ga las 'od zer 'phros/ rang 'dra ba'i ye shes pa spyan drangs/

From the state of emptiness there appears the syllable paṃ, and from it a lotus. From the syllable raṃ there appears the mandala of the sun, on top of which is the syllable hrīḥ, from which rays of light emanate and gather back, transforming into the wrathful Hayagrīva, who is red in color, with one face and two hands. The right hand holds a lotus stick; the left makes the threatening gesture. His right leg is bent, his left stretched out, and he is wearing a lower garment of tiger skin. His wrathful face has three eyes, and his four canine teeth are bared. His reddish-yellow hair streams upward. On the crown of his head is the green head of a horse, its neighs filling the ten directions and its red mane blazing like fire. He is adorned with snakes and precious ornaments and dwells amid a blazing mass of wisdom fire. From the white oṁ in his crown, red āḥ in the throat, and blue hūṁ in the heart center, light rays emanate, inviting the wisdom deity similar to himself.
dzaHhU~M baM ho \u0f7fsa dbyer med du gyur/
With jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ—they become inseparable.

slar yang thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od zer 'phros/ rigs lnga 'khor bcas spyan drangs/ rigs lngas dbang bskur/ dri ma dag / chu lhag ma yar lud pa las 'od dpag med kyis dbu brgyan thugs kar pad nyi'i steng du hrIH'i mtha' mar sngags kyis bskor ba las bdud rtsi'i rgyun babs pas bum pa gang bar bsam la/ oM pad+mAn+ta kr-i ta badz+ra kro ta h+ya grI wa hu lu hu lu hU~M phaT swA hA/ ces brgya rtsa brgyad 'dren/

Again from hūṁ in the heart center, light radiates, inviting the buddhas of the five families and their retinues. The five families bestow empowerment, purifying stains, and from the excess nectar overflowing above, his crown is ornamented with Amitābha. {210} In his heart, upon a lotus and sun, is the syllable hrīḥ, encircled by the mantra, from which flows a stream of nectar, filling the vase. With this in mind, recite the mantra one hundred eight times: oṁ padmānta kṛta vajra krota hayagrīva hulu hulu hūṁ phaṭ svāhā

mchod mthar mchod nas/ ma chags pad+ma rigs kyi rnam 'phrul las/ / klu rgyal tshul gyis gdug pa kun 'dul ba/ / dbang chen bskal pa'i me ltar gzi brjid 'bar/ / khro rgyal rta mgrin mgon la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / ces bstod do/ / de nas 'dod pa'i don la gsol ba gdab bo/ /

At the end, make the offerings and recite the praise: Manifesting from the lotus family, free from attachment, In the guise of a nāga king, you tame all vicious beings. Great powerful one, blazing with majesty like the fire at the end of the kalpa, King of wrathful deities, Lord Hayagrīva, to you I make homage and praise. Then pray for the fulfillment of all wishes.
! gnyis pa dbang bskur
II. Bestowing the Empowerment
['di] la don gsum ste/ sngon 'gro/ dkyil 'khor du gzhug pa/ dbang bzhi bskur ba/ mjug rjes gnang sbyin pa'o/ /
There are three parts: (1) the preparation, entering the mandala; (2) the main part, bestowing the four empowerments; and (3) the conclusion, giving authorization.
dang po
A. Preparation

sngon 'gro dkyil 'khor du gzhug pa la don bcu gsum ste/ gsol ba btab pa/ sdom pa bzung ba/ mig dar bcings pa/ me tog sbyin pa/ bsrung bar bya ba/ sems skyed pa/ phyag bya ba/ dam la bzhag pa/ ye shes phab cing gnang ba dri ba dang*/ me tog dor bar dang*/ spyan dbye ba dang*/ lha ngo bstan pa dang*/ ched du brjod pa'o/ /

The preparation, entering the mandala, is divided into thirteen parts: (1) praying; (2) taking the vows; (3) attaching the blindfolds; (4) giving the flowers; (5) protection; (6) arousing bodhichitta; (7) obeisance; (8) binding under oath; (9) the descent of gnosis and inquiry [as to what the disciple] sees; (10) throwing the flower; (11) opening the eyes; (12) revealing the deity; and (13) special utterances.
1. Praying
dang po ni slob ma rnams khrus bya/ maN+Dal phul/ gsol ba gdab pa ni/
First, the disciples should perform ablutions, offer the mandala, and pray:

dga' chen ston pa khyod gcig pu/ / byang chub chen po'i tshul ston pa/ / mgon po chen po bdag 'tshal lo/ / dam tshig de nyid bdag la stsol/ / byang chub sems kyang bdag la stsol/ / sangs rgyas chos dang dge 'dun ste/ / skyabs gsum dag kyang bdag la stsol/ / thar pa chen po'i grong mchog tu/ / mgon pos bdag ni gzhug tu gsol/ / ces sogs/

Sole revealer of great joy, Who shows us the way of great enlightenment, To you, great protector, we pay homage. Bestow on us the sacred commitments, Bestow on us the bodhichitta, Bestow on us the triple refuge Of the Buddha, dharma, and sangha. Protector, please bring us Into the sublime city of great liberation!…and so on.
gnyis pa ni/
2. Taking Vows
dang po thun mong gi sdom pa bzung ba ni/ dkon mchog gsum la bdag skyabs mchi/ /ces thun mong gi sdom pa bzung*/
First, the common vows are taken by reciting: In the Three Jewels we go for refuge…and so on.[8]
de nas khyad par sdom pa bzung ba ni/ sras bcas sangs rgyas thams cad dang*/ / spyan ras gzigs kyi lha tshogs rnams/ / ma lus bdag la dgongs su gsol/ /
After that, the particular vows are taken by reciting three times: All you buddhas, bodhisattvas, And hosts of deities of Avalokiteshvara, Without exception, think of us. {211}

ji ltar dus gsum mgon po rnams/ / byang chub tu ni nges mdzad pa'i/ / byang chub sems ni bla na med/ / dam pa bdag gis bskyed par bgyi/ / sangs rgyas rnal 'byor sdom pa la/ / tshul khrims kyi ni bslab pa dang*/ / dge ba'i chos ni sdud pa dang*/ / sems can don byed tshul khrims gsum/ / bdag gis brtan por bzung bar bgyi/ /

Just as the buddhas, past, present, and to come, Resolved to attain enlightenment, We will arouse the sacred, unsurpassed Enlightened attitude of mind. For the yogic vows of the buddha [family], We will train in the discipline of restraint, Gather virtuous deeds, And work for the benefit of beings, Firmly keeping these three kinds of discipline.

sangs rgyas chos dang dge 'dun te/ / bla na med pa'i dkon mchog gsum/ / deng nas brtsam ste bzung bar bgyi/ / nam du yang ni mi spang ngo*/ / rdo rje rigs mchog chen po la/ / rdo rje dril bu'i phyag rgya yang*/ / yang dag nyid du bzung bar bgyi / slob dpon dag kyang bzung bar bgyi/ /

And from this day onward we will firmly hold The vows pertaining to the Buddha, dharma, and sangha— The Three Jewels unsurpassed! Never will we give them up. For the supreme vajra family, We will perfectly uphold The seals of vajra and bell; The masters too will we uphold.

rin chen rigs mchog chen po yi/ / dam tshig yid du 'ong ba la/ / nyin re bzhin du dus drug tu/ / sbyin pa rnam bzhi rtag tu sbyin/ / byang chub chen po las byung ba/ / pad+ma'i rigs mchog dag pa la/ / phyi nang gsang ba'i theg pa gsum/ / dam pa'i chos ni ma lus bzung*/ /

For the delightful pledges Of the great and supreme jewel family, Every day on six occasions We will constantly perform four kinds of generosity. For the supreme lotus family, We will uphold all the sacred teachings Of the outer, inner, and secret vehicles, Which have sprung from great enlightenment.

las kyi rigs mchog chen po la/ / sdom pa thams cad ldan pa ni/ / yang dag nyid du bzung bar bgyi/ / mchod pa'i las kyang ci nus bgyi/ / byang chub sems ni bla na med/ / dam pa bdag gis bskyed par bgyi/ / sems can kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / bdag gis sdom pa ma lus bzung*/ / ma bsgral ba rnams bdag gis bsgral/ / ma grol ba rnams bdag gis dgrol/ / dbugs ma phyin pa dbugs dbyung zhing*/ / 'gro kun mya ngan 'das la 'god/ / ces lan gsum brjod la sdom pa bzung ngo*/ /

For the supreme action family, All the vows that we have taken We will perfectly observe And make offerings as much as we are able. Arousing the awakened mind, Supreme and unsurpassed, We will hold these vows without exception For the benefit of every living being. We will save all those as yet unsaved. We will free all those as yet unfreed. We will bring relief to those not yet relieved And set all beings in the state beyond all pain.
gsum pa ni mig dar bcings la/
3. Attaching the Blindfolds
oM tsak+Shu ban+d+ha wa ra ma Na ye swA hA/
oṁ cakṣu bandha vara maṇaye svāhā
bzhi pa me tog phreng ba gtad la/
4. Giving the Garlands of Flowers
oM AHkhaM bI ra hU~M swA hA/
oṁ āḥ khaṃ vīra hūṁ svāhā {212}
lnga pa bsrung bar bya ba ni/
5. Protection
rta mgrin gyi snying pos bsangs la/ rang nyid skad cig gis spyan ras gzigs su mos pa'i spyi bor oM dkar po/ mgrin par A dmar po/ snying gar hU~M sngon po bsam la/ oM AHhU~M/ zhes dris thig le bya/

Cleanse with the mantra of Hayagrīva, then consider that: Visualizing yourselves in an instant as Avalokiteshvara, in your crown center is the white syllable oṁ, in the throat center a red āḥ, and in the heart center a blue hūṁ. And as you place a drop of scented water, say oṁ āḥ hūṁ.
drug pa ni/
6. Arousing Bodhichitta
snying gar zla ba'i steng du rdo rje dkar po rtse lnga pa 'od zer 'phro ba zhig bsgom la/ ngag tu/ sarba ta thA ga ta yo ga tsit+ta u pa ta yA mi/ zhes brjod do/ /
Visualize upon a moon in the heart a white five-pronged vajra emanating rays of light. And say: oṁ sarva tathāgata yoga citta upata yāmi
rdo rje me tog dang bcas pa snying gar bzung ste/ oM su ra te sa ma yas+t+waM ho/ sid+d+ha badz+ra ya wA su khaM/ zhes pa brjod do/ /
Holding a vajra and flower at the heart center, recite: oṁ surate samaya stvaṃ hoḥ siddha vajra ya vā su khaṃ
bdun pa phyag byar ni/
7. Obeisance

khro bo rta mgrin gyis khrid nas dkyil 'khor gyi nang du khrid par mos te/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal bar mos la/ oM na mo te hU~M/ oM na mo me hU~M/ na mo na ma hU~M/ oM na mo lo ke shwa ra yA/ zhes phyag bya'o/ /

Consider that you are led by the wrathful Hayagrīva, who leads you into the mandala. Consider that you pay homage to Ārya Avalokiteshvara. Perform prostrations, saying: oṁ namo te hūṁ oṁ namo me hūṁ namo nama hūṁ oṁ namo lokeśvarayā
brgyad pa dam la bzhag pa
8. Binding under Oath

['di] la bzhi/ dang po phan yon gyi sgo nas dam la bzhag pa ni/ deng khyod de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi rigs su zhugs kyi/ de na sangs khyod la rdo rje'i ye shes bskyed par bya ste/ ye shes gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi dngos grub thob par gyur na/ dngos grub gzhan rnams lta smos kyang ci dgos/ khyod kyi dkyil 'khor 'di ma mthong ba'i mdun du smra bar mi bya ste/ khyod dam tshig nyams par 'gyur ta re/ zhes so/ /

First, binding under oath with respect to the benefits: Today, you have entered the family of all the tathāgatas, but now I[9] must make the vajra gnosis develop in you. If, through gnosis, you will obtain the accomplishment of all the tathāgatas, what need is there to mention other accomplishments? Do not speak in front of those who have not seen this mandala, for you will deteriorate the sacred commitments.
gnyis pa gnyis ka'i sgo nas dam la bzhag pa ni/ rdo rje snying gar bzhag nas/
Second, binding under oath with respect to both [the benefits and dangers]. Place the vajra at the heart center and say:
oM de ring spyan ras gzigs dbang rang*/ / khyod kyis snying la yang dag zhugs/ / gal te khyod kyis 'ga' zhig la/ / 'di smras na ni mgo bo 'gems/ / zhes brjod/
oṁ Today Avalokiteshvara himself Has truly entered your heart. If you speak of this to anyone, Your head will be destroyed.

gsum pa nyes dmigs kyi sgo nas dam la bzhag pa ni/ dam tshig gi chu blud la/ 'di ni khyod kyi dmyal ba'i chu/ / dam tshig 'das na sreg par byed/ / dam tshig bsrung na dngos grub ni/ / rdo rje bdud rtsi'i chu 'dis 'grub/ / oM a mr-i ta u da ka Tha/ / zhes chu blud do/ /

Third, binding under oath with respect to the dangers. Pouring the samaya water, say: This is the water of your hell: If you transgress the commitments, it will burn you up. {213} If you keep the commitments, with this water of adamantine nectar You will achieve accomplishment. oṁ amṛta udakaṭha

bzhi pa slob dpon gyi sgo nas dam la bzhag pa ni/ deng nas bzung ste khyod kyi ni/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang nga yin gyi/ / nga yi 'di gyis gang bsgo ba/ / khyod kyis kyang ni bya dgos so/ / zhes dam tshig bsgrag go /
Fourth, binding under oath with respect to the master. Proclaim the commitment as follows: From now on, for you, I am Avalokiteshvara. Therefore, whatever I command, You must carry it out.
dgu pa
9. The Descent of Gnosis and Inquiry
ye shes dbab pa ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis byin gyi brlab tu gsol/ spyan ras gzigs dbang bdag la dbab par gyur cig / ces brjod nas/
Bringing down the gnosis: All you tathāgatas, bestow your blessings. Pour down blessings on us, Avalokiteshvara. After saying this, describe the following visualization:

stong pa'i ngang las AHlas byung ba'i snang ba mtha' yas su bsgoms pa'i rkang zhabs su yaM las rlung gi dkyil 'khor/ ba dan g.yo ba yaM gyis mtshan pa/ dz+haiHdz+haiHdmar po gnyis gnyis kyis 'degs pa/ sum mdor raM las me'i dkyil 'khor gru gsum dang me 'bar bas mtshan pa/ snying gar laM las sa'i dkyil 'khor gru bzhi pa rdo rjes mtshan par nyi ma la hU~M sngon pos mtshan pa/ mgrin par baM las chu'i dkyil 'khor bum pa zla ba la AHdmar pos mtshan pa/ mgor yaM las rlung gi dkyil 'khor sngon po zla ba la haM dkar pos mtshan pa/ rkang zhabs kyi dz+haiHgyi 'od zer rkang pa'i rtsa bo che nas zhugs/ sum mdor me dang 'dres nas cher 'bar/ snying ga'i sa'i dkyil 'khor dmar lam lam par bsregs/ mgrin pa'i chu'i dkyil 'khor dkar bun bun par bskol/ spyi bo'i haM las bdud rtsi'i rgyun babs/ hU~M haM las 'od zer 'phros/ ba spu'i rtse nas phyir 'phros pas/ spyan ras gzigs dang mkha' 'gro sde lnga'i lha tshogs rnams spyan drangs nas mtsho la kha ba babs pa ltar rang gi lus ngag yid gsum la thim par bsgom la/

From the state of emptiness, there appears the syllable āḥ, from which visualize yourselves as Amitābha, on whose feet, from yaṃ, appears the mandala of wind, a fluttering banner marked with yaṃ, raised by the two red syllables jhaiḥ jhaiḥ. At the junction [of the legs], from raṃ there appears the triangular mandala of fire, marked with a raṃ and blazing fire. In the heart center, from laṃ there appears the square mandala of earth, marked by a vajra in which is a sun marked by a blue hūṁ. In the throat center is the syllable baṃ, from which there appears the mandala of water, a vase with a moon marked with a red āḥ. In the head, from yaṃ there appears the blue mandala of wind, with a moon marked with a white haṃ. Rays of light from jhaiḥ jhaiḥ in the feet enter through the great veins of the legs. They mix with the fire at the junction of the legs and it burns brighter and brighter. It heats the mandala of earth in the heart center to a glowing red. The mandala of water in the throat center boils into a white misty vapor. From the haṃ in the crown center flows a stream of nectar. From hūṁ and haṃ rays of light emanate, radiating out through the tips of the hairs on the body and inviting the hosts of deities of Avalokiteshvara and the five classes of ḍākinīs. Like snow falling on a lake, they all dissolve into your body, speech, and mind.
gu gul dang spos kyis 'dug /
Burn gugul and incense and bring about the descent of gnosis with:

oM ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ DA ki ni ha ri ni sa hU~M/ a be sha ya/ staM b+ha ya/ ra ra ra ra/ tsa la ya/ tsa la ya/ hU~M hAH a \u0f7fdz+haiH zhes ye shes gdab bo/ / de nas dkyil 'khor kha dog 'dri zhing*/ las bzhi grub par lung bstan no/ /
bcu pa ni/
10. Throwing the Flower
de nas me tog phreng ba traM gyis sngags pa gsar zhing ma rnying pa/ oM AHhU~M gis 'od gsal bar byas/ spyan ras gzigs yab yum gyi dbu la dor bar mos la/
Next, Consider that the garland of flowers, consecrated with traṃ, fresh, not wilted, and made radiant with oṁ āḥ hūṁ, is thrown over the head of Avalokiteshvara and his consort. And

yang dag gsang ba'i dkyil 'khor 'dir/ / bdag gis slob ma gzhug pa 'di/ / lha rnams rigs kyi rim pa 'di/ / bsod nams ji ltar de ltar zhog / 'di yi dngos grub ci 'drar 'gyur/ / rigs ni gang gi snod du gyur/ / bsod nams mthu yang ci 'dra bar/ / de 'dra dkyil 'khor du gyur cig /

These disciples whom I have introduced Into this mandala of the true secret— Deities, according to their merit, Place them in the appropriate family! Whatever the accomplishment they may gain, Whatever the family for which they are proper vessels, Whatever the power of their merit, May the mandala appear accordingly.
AHkhaM bI ra hU~M pra tIts+tsha ku su mAny+tsa liM nA tha hoH zhes me tog gtor/ slar pra ti grih+Na daM i maM sa twa hA ba la/ zhes me tog phreng ba mgo la bcing ngo*/ /
āḥ khaṃ vīra hūṁ pratīccha kusu māñca liṃ nātha hoḥ Saying this, throw the flower. Again, with prati grihaṇa daṃ imaṃ svāhā mahābala tie the garland of flowers over the head.
bcu gcig pa spyan dbye ba ni/
11. Opening the Eyes
oM de ring spyan ras gzigs dbang rang*/ / khyod kyi mig ni phye bar brtson/ / rdo rje'i mig ni bla na med/ / thams cad mig ni 'byed par mdzad/ /
oṁ Today Avalokiteshvara himself Has roused himself to open your eyes. The vajra eyes are unsurpassed; They open the eyes to everything.
oM dz+nyA na tsak+Shu hU~M AHswA hA/
oṁ jñāna cakṣu hūṁ āḥ svāhā
bcu gnyis pa lha ngo bstan pa ni/
12. Revealing the Face of the Deity
kye rdo rje ltos shig / ces brjod nas/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi lha ngo bstan pas mthong bar mos te/
Say: Oh, look at the vajra! Then say: Consider that it is showing the face of the deity, and thus you see it.

da ni dad pa'i shugs kyis su/ / dkyil 'khor 'di de nyid la ltos/ / khyod ni sangs rgyas rigs su skyes/ / phyag rgya sngags kyi byin gyis brlabs/ / dngos grub kun ni phun sum tshogs/ / dam tshig mchog tu khyod 'gyur gyi/ / thabs dang shes rab dang ldan pas/ / gsang sngags rnams la bsgrub par gyis/ / zhes brjod cing*/

Now, by the force of faith, Look at the very nature of this mandala. You have been born in the family of the buddhas. You have received the blessing of the mudrā and mantra. You will attain all accomplishments And have made the supreme commitment. Using skillful means and wisdom, Practice the secret mantras!
bcu gsum pa ched du brjod pa ni/
13. Special Utterances
oM rdo rje'i dkyil 'khor chen por bdag zhugs so/ / rnal 'byor gyi dkyil 'khor chen po bdag gis mthong ngo*/ / gsang ba'i dkyil 'khor chen por bdag dbang bskur/ / zhes ched du brjod par bya'o/ /
! gnyis pa dngos gzhi dbang bskur ba
B. The Main Part: Bestowing the Four Empowerments
['di] la bzhi ste/ bum dbang dang*/ gsang dbang dang*/ shes rab ye shes kyi dbang dang*/ dbang bzhi pa tshig dbang rin po che'o/ /
This is divided into four: (1) the vase empowerment; (2) the secret empowerment; (3) the wisdom empowerment; and (4) the fourth empowerment or precious word empowerment.
dang po
1. Vase Empowerment
['di] la gnyis te/ rang don sgrub pa rdo rje slob ma'i dbang dang*/ gzhan don sgrub pa rdo rje slob dpon gyis dbang ngo*/ /
There are two parts: (1) the empowerment of the vajra disciples for their own fulfillment and (2) the empowerment of the vajra master for others’ fulfillment.
dang po
a. Empowerment of the Vajra Disciples for Their Own Fulfillment

['di] la lnga ste/ mi bskyod pa chu'i dbang dang*/ rin chen 'byung ldan dbu rgyan gyi dbang dang*/ snang ba mtha' yas rdo rje'i dbang dang*/ don yon grub pa dril bu'i dbang dang*/ rnam par snang mdzad ming gi dbang ngo*/ /

This empowerment is divided into five: (1) the water empowerment of Akṣhobhya; (2) the crown empowerment of Ratnasambhava; (3) the vajra empowerment of Amitābha; (4) the bell empowerment of Amoghasiddhi; and (5) the name empowerment of Vairochana.
! dang po la mi bskyod pa chu yi dbang
i. Water Empowerment of Akṣhobhya
['di] la gnyis te gsol ba gdab pa dang dbang bskur ba dngos so/ /
This empowerment is divided into two parts: the request and the actual empowerment.

dang po gsol ba gdab pa ni/ byang chub rdo rje sangs rgyas la/ mchod chen ji ltar stsal ba ltar/ / bdag kyang bskyabs pa'i don gyi phyir/ / nam mkha'i rdo rje deng bdag stsol/ / zhes gsol ba gdab bo/ /
First, the request: Just as adamantine enlightenment Is the great offering bestowed upon the buddhas, In order to protect us, we pray, Bestow on us today the vajra space.[10]
gnyis pa ni/ rta mgrin gyi sngags/ las bum gyi chus dbang rdzas dang slob pa rnams bsang la/ slob dpon dang slob ma dbang rdzas gsum/ swA b+hA was sbyang*/

Second, the actual empowerment. With the mantra of Hayagrīva and the water from the activity vase, cleanse the empowerment materials and the disciples: The master, disciples, and empowerment materials— are purified with oṁ svabhāva śuddāḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ

stong pa'i ngang las hU~M las mi bskyod pa spyan ras gzigs sku mdog sngon po zhal gcig phyag bzhi zhabs gnyis skyil krung can/ de'i pang na yum gsang ba ye shes sngon mo/ rdo rje dang bum pa 'dzin pas yab la sbyor ba/ yab yum gnyis ka yang mtshan dpe'i 'od dang ldan zhing*/ rgyan thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i spyi mgrin snying khar/ oM AHhU~M las 'od 'phros/ rang lta bu'i ye shes pa spyan drangs/ dzaHhU~M baM hoH

From the state of emptiness there appears the syllable hūṁ, from which there arises Akṣhobhya Avalokiteshvara, blue in color, with one face, four arms, and Blue Gnosis (ye shes sngon mo), holding a vajra and vase. Both male and female deities are radiant with the major and minor marks and adorned with all the ornaments. In their crown, throat, and heart centers are the syllables oṁ āḥ hūṁ, radiating light, inviting the wisdom deities similar to themselves. jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ

dbyer med du gyur par bsam/ slar 'od 'phros/ dbang gi lha rigs lnga 'khor bcas spyan drangs/ de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyis dbang bskur ba'i dgongs pa mdzad/ yum rnams kyi bdud rtsi'i rgyun gyis spyi bo nas dbang bskur/ rdo rje'i sgeg ma rnams kyis glu len zhing*/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis me tog mngon par gtor zhing bkra shis brjod par bsam la/ sangs rgyas rab bdun pa'am/ phun sum tshogs pa'i bkra shis brjod/ de nas dbang bum gyis spyi bo nas dbang bskur ro/ /

Consider that they become inseparable. Again, lights emanate, inviting the five families of empowering deities and their retinues and invoking all the tathāgatas’ intentions to bestow empowerment. A stream of nectar from the female buddhas enters through the crown, conferring the empowerment. {216} The vajra goddesses of charm sing. The bodhisattvas strew flowers and proclaim good auspices. With this in mind, recite the auspicious prayer of the seven universal buddhas or the prayer of perfect auspiciousness. Next, bestow empowerment with the empowerment vase through the crown, as follows:
rdo rje dbang bskur chen po ni/ / khams gsum kun gyis phyag byas pas/ / sangs rgyas kun gyis bum pa'i dbang*/ / deng 'dir khyod la bskur bar bya/ /
The great vajra empowerment, Revered by the whole of the three worlds, The vase empowerment of all the buddhas, Is here and now conferred on you.

oM sarba ta thA ga la u da ka a b+hi Shiny+tsa maM zhes dbang bskur/ slar spyan ras gzigs yab yum gyi thugs ka nas rdo rje mkha' 'gro sngon mo bum pa 'dzin pa zhig chad nas/ bum chus dbang bskur bar bsam la/

oṁ sarva tathāgata udaka abhiṣiñca maṃ Again, from the heart of Avalokiteshvara and his consort there emanates a blue vajra ḍākinī holding a vase. Consider that with the water from the vase, she bestows empowerment.
oM ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ badz+ra DA ki ni a b+hi Shiny+tsha maM/ zhes bdud rtsi'i rgyun gyis dbang bskur/
oṁ maṇi padme hūṁ vajra ḍākinī abhiṣiñca maṃ— With this, the flow of nectar confers empowerment.

byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyis/ / bkra shis gang zhig sems can kun gyi snying la gnas/ / kun gyis phyag byas rigs kun gyi ni bdag ni bdag po mchog / sems can thams cad bskyed mdzad bde ba chen po ster/ / deng 'dir dbang bskur mchog thob khyed la bkra shis shog / ces bkra shis brjod/

May all the bodhisattvas’ good auspices Remain in the hearts of all sentient beings. May I, the supreme lord of all families, revered by all, confer and give rise to great bliss in all sentient beings. May everything be auspicious that here and now you receive the supreme empowerment. In this way, say the prayer for auspiciousness.

sgeg mo rnams kyis/ oM sarba badz+ra su sang gra he/ badz+ra ma nut+ta ra ni/ badz+ra d+harmA kA ya ni/ badz+ra karma ka rod b+ha we/ zhes rdo rje'i glu blangs/ khro bo rnams kyis/ / oM pad+mAn+ta kr-i ta badz+ra kro ta h+ya grI wa hu lu hu lu hU~M phaT/ ces bgegs bskrad/

The goddesses of charm sing vajra songs: oṁ sarva vajra su sang gra he vajra manuttara ni vajra dharmakāya ni vajra karma karod bhave The wrathful deities banish obstacle makers: oṁ padmānta kṛta vajra krota hayagrīva hulu hulu hūṁ phaṭ

gu gul la sogs me tog gi char phab/ rnga bo che la sogs pa rol mo'i sgra bsgrag / bdud rtsi'i rgyun dang spyan ras gzigs kyi sku zhing rdul gyi grangs dang mnyam pas lus kyi nang gang*/ lhag ma yar 'khyil ba las mi bskyod pas dbur brgyan cing khyed rang rnams mi bskyod pa spyan ras gzigs kyi ngo bor gyur pa la mchod pa'i lha mo rnams kyis mchod par/

With gugul incense and the like, a rain of flowers descends. The sound of the great drum and other musical instruments resounds.
