mdun gyi dkyil 'khor las sngags kyis bsang*/ oM swab+hA wa shud+d+haHsarba d+harmAHswab+hA wa shud+d+ho \u0f85 haM/ stong pa nyid du gyur/
Cleanse the mandala in front with the activity mantra. oṁ svabhāva śuddhaḥ sarvadharmāḥ svabhāva śuddho ’haṃ All becomes emptiness.

stong pa'i ngang las 'byung ba rim brtsegs pa'i steng du/ zhes pa nas/ dpag tu med pa'i 'os zer 'phros/ zhes pa'i bar gong ltar ro/ / 'phags pa mchod/ sems can gyi don byas tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs sku mdog dkar po zhes pa nas/ snying gar hU~M sngon po/ zhes pa'i bar gong bzhin no/ /

From the state of emptiness appear the five elements, one above the other, and on top of them… and so on, as above, down to …from which infinite rays of light emanate, Making offerings to the noble beings And benefiting sentient beings. The lights are gathered back and transform into Noble Avalokiteshvara, who is white in color… and so on, as above, down to …and blue hūṁ in their heart centers.

mdun bskyed kyi dus su gong gi mgrin pa snying gar lte ba gsang gnas kyi spyan ras gzigs yab yum rnams mdun nas brtsams te/ g.yas skor du gdan la 'khod pa'i lugs kyang yod do/ / mkha' 'gro bzhi mtshams bzhir bkod pa'o/ /

There is also a tradition, when one is doing the front visualization, in which the Avalokiteshvaras with their consorts in the throat, heart, navel, and secret centers mentioned above are seated clockwise around, starting in front. The four ḍākinīs are disposed in the four intermediate directions. {307}

bdag mdun gnyis ka'i thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od zer 'phros/ rang bzhin chos kyi dbyings nas bka' brgyud bla ma/ yi dam lha tshogs dpa' bo mkha' 'gro chos skyong srung ma rnams mdun gyi nam mkhar spyan drangs/ badz+ra sa ma ya dzaH zhes

From hūṁ in the heart centers of the self-visualized deity and the deity visualized in front rays of light emanate, Inviting from the natural expanse of reality into the sky in front the teachers of the instruction lineage,[6] The hosts of yidam deities, ḍākas and ḍākinīs, and dharma protectors and guardians. vajra samaya jaḥ
spos dang rol mo 'dzin pas/ hrIH sku gsum dbyer med gzhal yas nas/ / dus gsum sangs rgyas ngo bo nyid/ / sems can smin mdzad thugs rje can/ / bka' brgyud bla ma gshegs su gsol/ /

Holding incense and musical instruments: hrīḥ From the measureless palace of the three bodies inseparable, Very essence of the buddhas of the three times, Compassionate ones who bring sentient beings to maturation, Teachers of the instruction lineage, come, I pray.

rang bzhin gnas mchog gzhal yas nas/ / sku gsum lha tshogs 'khor gyis bskor/ / stong nyid snying rje'i bdag nyid can/ / snyan brgyud lha tshogs gshegs su gsol/ / 'og min chos dbyings pho brang nas/ / dkyil 'khor lha tshogs ma lus kun/ / thugs rje'i spyan gyis 'gro la gzigs/ / yi dam lha tshogs gshegs su gsol/ / mkha' spyod u rgyan gzhal yas nas/ / byin rlabs dngos grub ster mdzad pa'i/ / las dang ye shes las la sogs/ / dpa' bo mkha' 'gro gshegs su gsol/ /

From the measureless palace of the supreme natural state, Hosts of deities of the three bodies surrounded by your retinues, Embodiments of emptiness and compassion, Deities of the aural lineage, come, I pray. From the palace of the Unexcelled, the expanse of reality, All you hosts of deities of the mandala without exception, Watching over beings with the eye of compassion, Hosts of yidam deities, come, I pray. From the measureless palace of the celestial land of Oḍḍiyāna, You who bestow blessings and accomplishments, Karma ḍākinīs, wisdom ḍākinīs, and other kinds, Ḍākas and ḍākinīs, come, I pray.
rang bzhin dur khrod gzhal yas nas/ / sangs rgyas bstan pa rgyas mdzad cing*/ / phyi nang bar chad sel mdzad pa'i/ / chos skyong srung ma gshegs su gsol/ /
From the measureless palace of the charnel ground, You who spread the Buddha’s teachings And dispel outer and inner obstacles, Protectors and guardians of the dharma, come, I pray.
bzhugs su gsol ba ni/ hrIH rin chen sna tshogs pho brang 'dir/ / sna tshogs pad zla'i gdan steng du/ / yid 'ong mdzes pa'i zhal yas su/ / snyan brgyud lha tshogs bzhugs su gsol/ /

The request to be seated: hrīḥ In this palace made of all kinds of precious materials, Upon seats of multicolored lotuses and moons, In the immeasurably beautiful delightful palace, Deities of the aural lineage, please be seated.
dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH dam tshig pa dang dbyer med du gyur/ / ces pas nas/ 'od dpag med kyis dbu brgyan par gyur/ / ces pa'i bar gong ltar ro/ / skabs 'dir bzlas pa byed par spro na'ang gong ltar bya'o/ /
jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ They become inseparable from the meditation deities… and so on, as above, down to …is crowned with Amitābha. At this point, if you wish to recite the mantra, do so as above.
[C. Offerings and Praises]

de nas phyag 'tshal ba ni/ hU~M/ chos dbyings mnyam nyid ngang las ma g.yos kyang*/ / longs spyod rdzogs sku 'dza' tshon lta bur sprul/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba ma lus 'dren mdzad pa/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang lha tshogs phyag 'tshal lo/ / de nas phyi mchod 'bul ba ni/ hrIH yon tan me tog bdug spos dang*/ / snang gsal dri chab zhal zas dang*/ / rol mo sil snyan mchod pa rnams/ / dkyil 'khor lha yis bzhes su gsol/ /

Next, paying homage: hūṁ Though you never move from the expanse of reality, the state of sameness, You manifest in the body of perfect enjoyment, like a rainbow, And compassionately guide all beings without exception. {308} To the deities of Avalokiteshvara, I pay homage. After that, make the outer offerings: hrīḥ Water, flowers, incense, Lamps, scented water, food, Musical instruments and cymbals—all these offerings, Deities of the mandala, please accept.
nang gi mchod pa 'bul ba ni/ mdzes pa'i gzugs dang snyan pa'i sgra/ / zhim pa'i dri dang mngar ba'i ro/ / reg bya 'dod yon mchod pa rnams/ / dkyil 'khor lha yis bzhes su gsol/ /
Offering the inner offerings: Beautiful forms, pleasing sounds, Fragrant smells and sweet tastes, And pleasurable sensations—all these offerings, Deities of the mandala, please accept.
nang mchod bdud rtsis kyang mchod do/ /gsang mchod 'bul ba ni/
Also make the “inner offering” of amṛita. Offer the secret offering:

sha lnga dang ni bdud rtsi lnga/ / phung po khams dang skyed mched lnga/ dbang po yul lnga 'byung ba lnga/ / dkyil 'khor lha yis bzhes su gsol/ / dga' ba bzhi dang bde ba brgyad/ / skad cig bzhi dang ye shes lnga/ / zung 'jug dga' bde'i mchod pa 'di/ / dkyil 'khor lha yi bzhes su gsol/ /

The five fleshes and five nectars; The five aggregates, constituents, and senses-and-fields; The five objects of the senses and the five elements— Deities of the mandala, please accept. The four joys, eight kinds of bliss, Four instants and five kinds of gnosis, And the nondual joy and bliss— These offerings, deities of the mandala, please accept.
de kho na nyid kyi mchod pa ni/ mchod mkhan mchod pa mchod pa'i yul/ / sgyu ma rmi lam ltar shes pa/ / spros bral don dam mchod pa 'di/ / dkyil 'khor lha yis bzhes su gsol/ /

The offering of thatness: The knowledge that offerer, offering, and object of offering Are like magical illusions and dreams Is the ultimate offering, free of elaboration. This offering, deities of the mandala, please accept.
de nas bstod pa ni/ gang gi drin gyis bde chen nyid/ /ces tshig bzhi dang*/

Next, the praise. Repeat these four lines: Through your kindness [Great bliss arises in an instant: To the teacher whose body is like a precious jewel, At the lotus feet of the vajra being I bow down.]
skyon gyis ma gos sku mdog dkar/ /ces tshig bzhi dang*/

And this four-line homage: You are pure white, unsullied by defects. [Your crown is adorned with the perfect buddha. You watch over beings with eyes of compassion. To you, Avalokiteshvara, I pay homage.]
And make the following praise and prayer:

hrIH rnam par snang mdzad gti mug rnam dag pas/ / gzugs phung gnas gyur chos dbyings ye shes bdag / rang bzhin mi g.yo mchog gi bdag nyid can/ / rnam snang spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / rdo rje sems dpa' zhe sdang rnam dag pas/ / rnam shes gnas gyur me long ye shes bdag / rang bzhin mi g.yo mchog gi bdag nyid can/ / mi bskyod spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal lo/ /

hrīḥ You who personify Vairochana, bewilderment purified, The aggregate of form transformed into the gnosis of the expanse of reality, Master of the supreme immutable nature— To you, Vairochana Avalokiteshvara, homage and praise! You who personify Vajrasattva, aversion purified, The aggregate of consciousness transformed into mirrorlike gnosis, Master of the supreme immutable nature— To you, Akṣhobhya Avalokiteshvara, homage and praise!

rin chen 'byung ldan nga rgyal rnam dag pas/ / tshor phung gnas gyur mnyam nyid ye shes bdag / rang bzhin mi g.yo mchog gi bdag nyid can/ / rin 'byung spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / snang ba mtha' yas 'dod chags rnam dag pas/ / 'du shes gnas gyur sor rtogs ye shes bdag / rang bzhin mi g.yo mchog gi bdag nyid can/ / snang mtha' spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal bstod/ /

You who personify Ratnasambhava, pride purified, The aggregate of feeling transformed into the gnosis of equality, Master of the supreme immutable nature— To you, Ratnasambhava Avalokiteshvara, homage and praise! You who personify Amitābha, attachment purified, {309} The aggregate of perception transformed into all-discerning gnosis, Master of the supreme immutable nature— To you, Amitābha Avalokiteshvara, homage and praise!

don yod grub pa phrag dog rnam dag pas/ / 'du byed gnas gyur bya grub ye shes bdag / rang bzhin mi g.yo mchog gi dag nyid can/ / don grub spyan ras gzigs la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / bde stong gnyis su med pa yi/ / gsang ba ye shes phyag 'tshal bstod/ / nam mkha' rnam par dag pa yi/ / chos dbyings lha rnams 'byung ba'i gzhi/ / dbyings phyug ma la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / chu khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / rdo rje'i lha rnams 'byung ba'i gzhi/ / ma mA ki la phyag 'tshal bstod/ /

You who personify Amoghasiddhi, jealousy purified, The aggregate of conditioning factors transformed into all-accomplishing gnosis, Master of the supreme immutable nature— To you, Amoghasiddhi Avalokiteshvara, homage and praise! Bliss and emptiness inseparable, To Secret Wisdom, homage and praise! Ground from which the deities of the expanse of reality arise, Space completely purified— To Dhātishvarī, homage and praise! Ground from which the deities of the vajra family arise, The water element completely purified— To Māmakī, homage and praise!

sa khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / rin chen lha rnams 'byung ba'i gzhi/ / sangs rgyas spyan mar phyag 'tshal bstod/ / me khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / pad+ma'i lha rnams 'byung ba'i gzhi/ / gos dkar mo la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / rlung khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / las kyi lha rnams 'byung ba'i gzhi/ / dam tshig sgrol mar phyag 'tshal bstod/ /

Ground from which the deities of the ratna family arise, The earth element completely purified— To Buddhalochanā, homage and praise! Ground from which the deities of the padma family arise, The fire element completely purified— To Pāṇḍaravāsinī, homage and praise! Ground from which the deities of the karma family arise, The wind element completely purified— To Samayatārā, homage and praise!

zhi ba'i phrin las sgrub mdzad pa'i*/ / rdo rje mkha' 'gror phyag 'tshal bstod/ / rgyas pa'i phrin las sgrub mdzad pa'i/ / rin chen mkha' 'gror phyag 'tshal bstod/ / dbang gi phrin las sgrub mdzad pa'i/ / pad+ma mkha' 'gror phyag 'tshal bstod/ / mngon spyod phrin las sgrub mdzad pa'i/ / las kyi mkha' 'gror phyag 'tshal bstod/ /

To you who carry out the activities of pacifying, Vajra ḍākinīs, homage and praise! To you who carry out the activities of increasing, Ratna ḍākinīs, homage and praise! To you who carry out the activities of magnetizing, Padma ḍākinīs, homage and praise! To you who carry out the activities of forcefully subjugating, Karma ḍākinīs, homage and praise!
khyed la phyag 'tshal bstod pa yis/ / mchog dang mthun mong dngos grub stsol/ / don gnyis 'grub par mdzad du gsol/ /
As a result of my homage and praise to you, Grant the supreme and common accomplishments And help me to achieve the twofold goal.
zhes bstod cing gsol ba btab bo/ /
lag mchod bdud rtsi byin gyis brlab ni/ / las sngags kyis bsang*/ swa b+hA was sbyangs/
Bless the hand offering of nectar as follows. Cleanse it with the activity mantra and purify it with the svabhāva mantra.

stong pa'i ngang las ya~M las rlung*/ ra~M las me/ kaM gsum las thod pa'i sgyed po gsum gyi steng du a las ka pA la phyi dkar la nang dmar ba yangs shing rgya che ba'i nang du/ zla ba'i gdan gyi steng du/ /

go ku da ha na las sha lnga de nyid kyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du bi mu ma ra shu las bdud rtsi lnga la de nyid kyis mtshan pa/ de'i steng du hU~M b+h+rU~M aM dz+riM khaM las ye shes lnga/ de'i steng du oM AHhU~M gis mtshan pa/ rang gi thugs ka'i hU~M las 'od zer 'phros/ rlung g.yos me sbar/ thod pa dros rdzas rnams khol/ rlangs pa oM AHhU~M la phog / de las bdud rtsi'i rgyun babs/ oM AHhU~M dang bcas pa thod par lhung zag pa med pa'i bdud rtsi'i rgya mtsho chen por gyur/ oM AHhU~M ha ho hrIH ces lan gsum gyis byin gyis brlabs/

From go, ku, da, ha, and na, the five fleshes marked with those same syllables, And on top of them, from vi, mu, ma, ra, and shu, the five nectars marked with those same syllables. On top of that, from hūṁ, bhrūṁ, aṃ, jriṃ, and khaṃ, the five gnoses, Topped by the syllables oṁ, āḥ, and hūṁ. From hūṁ in one’s heart center rays of light emanate, as a result of which The wind blows, fanning the fire; It heats up the skull cup, in which the ingredients boil. The steam touches the syllables oṁ, āḥ, and hūṁ, And from them a stream of nectar flows down. With the oṁ, āḥ, and hūṁ, it descends into the skull cup and becomes a great ocean of untainted nectar. Bless it by saying three times oṁ āḥ hūṁ ha ho hrīḥ

g.yon pa'i srin lag gis rim pa bzhin du bdud rtsi gtor zhing*/ ngag tu/ drin chen rtsa ba'i bla ma'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ mgon po 'od dpag med kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ rnal 'byor mi tra dzo ki'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ paN chen shrI pu tra'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ rtogs ldan girti rat+na'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ mtshungs med 'od dpag rdo rje'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ drin chen rtsa ba'i bla ma'i zhal du oM AHhU~M/ gzhan yang dbang rgyud man ngag ston pa'i bla ma dam pa rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ thugs rje chen po 'jig rten dbang phyug gi lha tshogs 'khor dang bcas pa rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/

With each line, sprinkle the nectar with the left ring finger as you say: To the gracious root teacher [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To Lord Amitābha [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To noble Avalokiteshvara [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To the accomplished practitioner Mitrayogin [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To the great paṇḍita Shrīputra [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ, To the realized yogi Girti Ratna [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To peerless Öpak Dorje [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To my gracious root teacher [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. As well as them, to the holy teachers who bestow empowerment and teach the tantras and pith instructions [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To the hosts of deities of the Great Compassionate One, Lord of the World [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ.

mkha' 'gro sde lnga la sogs gnas gsum gyi mkha' 'gro rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ / brag mgon la sogs dam pa chos skyong ba'i srung ma rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ tshangs pa phyogs skyong bcu po sogs 'jig rten skyong ba rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ bod khams skyong ba'i brtan ma bcu gnyis sogs gzhi bdag gnyug mar gnas pa rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ 'gro ba rigs drug / lam rgyud lnga/ skye ba gnas bzhir bsdus pa'i rigs drug gi sems can thams cad bdud rtsis tshims nas myur du sangs rgyas kyi go 'phang rin po che thob par gyur cig /

To the five classes of ḍākinīs and other ḍākinīs of the three sacred places [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To Draklha Gönpo and the other protectors and guardians of the teachings [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To Brahmā and the guardians of the ten directions, and the other worldly protectors [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. To the twelve tenmas who protect Tibet and Kham and the other indigenous local deities [I offer], oṁ āḥ hūṁ. May all the beings of the six realms, included in the six classes of beings, the five paths of being, {311} and the four modes of birth, be satiated by [this] nectar and swiftly attain the precious level of buddhahood.
III. Conclusion
gsum pa rjes la gnyis/ tshogs mchod dang gtong rag gi mchod pa'o/ /
Third, the conclusion. There are two parts: the feast offering and the thanksgiving offering.
A. Feast Offering

dang po ni/ tshogs kyi byin rlabs nang mchod ltar byas la/ na mo thabs dang shes rab gnyis su med pa'i tshogs kyi 'khor lo rgya chen po rang bzhin rnam par dag pa skye ba med pa ngo bo rnam par dag pa A li kA li mtshan nyid rnam par dag pa sha lnga bdud rtsi lngas rgyas btab pa 'di dag / byin rlabs kyi rtsa ba bka' brgyud bla ma rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ dngos grub kyi rtsa ba yi dam lha tshogs rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ phrin las kyi rtsa ba chos skyong srung ma rnams kyi zhal du oM AHhU~M/ pany+tsa a mr-i ta la khA hi/ ga Na tsakra la khA hi/ zhes pa ni bsdus pa'o/ /
rgyas par byed na/ hrIH bla ma brgyud par bcas pa dang*/ / yi dam lha tshogs ma lus dang*/ / mkha' 'gro chos skyong 'khor bcas rnams/ / zhal zas tshogs la spyan 'dren gshegs su gsol/ /

To make the offering more elaborately, recite the following invitation: hrīḥ Teacher and teachers of the lineage, All you yidam deities without exception, Ḍākinīs and dharma protectors, with your retinues, I invite you to a feast of food, please come!
ces spyan drangs la/ tshogs bstab pa ni/
Then, offer up the feast:

spyi gtsug pad zla'i gdan steng du/ / chos longs sprul sku'i lha tshogs dang*/ / bka' rgyud bla ma 'khor dang bcas/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

Above the crown of my head, upon seats of lotus and moon, Are the assembled deities of the bodies of truth, enjoyment, and manifestation And the teachers of the instruction lineage and their retinues— To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

spyi bo bde chen 'khor lo ni/ / rnam par snang mdzad yab yum dang*/ / sangs rgyas rigs kyi lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

In the wheel of great bliss in my crown Are Vairochana and his consort And the assembled deities of the buddha family. To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

mgrin pa longs spyod 'khor lo na/ / tshe dpag med pa yab yum dang*/ / pad+ma rigs kyi lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

In the wheel of enjoyment in my throat Are Amitāyus and his consort And the assembled deities of the lotus family. To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

snying kha chos kyi 'khor lo na/ / mi bskyod rdo rje yab yum dang*/ / rdo rje rigs kyi lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

In the wheel of ultimate reality in my heart center {312} Are Vajra Akṣhobhya and his consort And the assembled deities of the vajra family. To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

lte ba sprul pa'i 'khor lo na/ / rin chen 'byung ldan yab yum dang*/ / yon tan rigs kyi lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

In the wheel of manifestation in my navel Are Ratnasambhava and his consort And the assembled deities of the qualities family. To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

gsang gnas bde skyong 'khor lo na/ / don yod grub pa yab yum dang*/ / las kyi rigs kyi lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /

In the bliss-preserving wheel in my secret center Are Amoghasiddhi and his consort And the assembled deities of the action family. To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
mig sogs skye mched dag pa yi/ / byang chub sems dpa' sems ma la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the male and female bodhisattvas, Who are the pure aspects of the senses-and-fields of the eye and so forth, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
mgo sogs lhu tshigs dag pa yi/ / khro bo khro mo bcu po la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the ten male and female wrathful deities, Who are the pure aspects of the head and other parts of the body, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
rtsa khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / dpa' bo'i lha tshogs ma lus la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To all the assembled ḍāka deities without exception, Who are the pure aspects of the subtle channels, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
rlung khams rnam par dag pa yi/ / ye shes mkha' 'gro ma lus la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To all the wisdom ḍākinīs without exception, Who are the pure aspects of the subtle winds, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
thig le rnam par dag pa yi/ / gsang sngags lha tshogs thams cad la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To all the assembled deities of the secret mantras Who are the pure aspects of the essence drops, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
lus kyi zhing rdul rnam dag pa/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the buddhas and bodhisattvas Who are the pure aspects of the atoms of the body, {313} To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
rang lus rnam par dag pa yi/ / sku yi rdo rje'i lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the assembled deities of the vajra body Who are the pure aspects of my own body,[7] To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
rang ngag rnam par dag pa yi/ / gsung gi rdo rje'i lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the assembled deities of the vajra speech Who are the pure aspects of my own speech, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!
rang sems rnam par dag pa yi/ / thugs kyi rdo rje'i lha tshogs la/ / zhal zas tshogs kyi mchod pa 'bul/ / bde ba chen pos mnyes gyur cig / a la la ste dgyes par rol/ /
To the assembled deities of the vajra mind Who are the pure aspects of my own mind, To you I offer the feast of food. May it delight you with great bliss. A la la, enjoy!

dur khrod chen po'i gnas brgyad nas/ 'jig rten mkha' 'gro rdzu 'phrul can/ / 'dir gshegs tshogs kyi mchod pa bzhes/ / phrin las rnam bzhi sgrub tu gsol/ / dam tshig chen po'i gnas brgyad nas/ / dam can rgya mtsho sku bskyod 'tshal/ / 'dir gshegs tshogs kyi mchod pa bzhes/ / pho nya las mkhan mdzad du gsol/ /

From the eight sites of the great cemeteries, Worldly ḍākinīs with miraculous powers, Come here, accept this offering of the feast And accomplish the four activities, I pray. From the eight great samaya sites, Ocean-like loyal protectors, please come. Come here, accept this offering of the feast. Carry out your deeds as messengers and servants.
pany+tsa a mr-i ta la khA hi/ / ga Na tsakra la khA hi/
pañca amṛta la khā hi gaṇacakra la khā hi

tshogs chang lag mchod ltar 'bul zhing nam mkha' gtor/ tshogs phud bcad la dkyil 'khor dang gtor ma 'bul lo/ / gtor ma ni/ gong gi las sngags kyis bsang*/ swa b+hA wa sa sbyang*/ gong gi lag mchod ltar byin gyis brlab/ gtor mgron spyan drangs shing 'bul ba ni/

Offer the feast liquor in the same way as the hand offering, sprinkling it in the air. Separate the first part of the feast and offer it to the mandala and to the torma. Cleanse the torma with the above activity mantra and purify it with the svabhāva mantra. Bless it as with the hand offering above. Invite the torma guests and offer it to them:
bla ma yi dam dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs thams cad bdun gyi nam mkhar badz+ra sa ma ya dza dzaH pheM leM/
All you teachers and hosts of yidam deities, come before me in the sky— vajra samaya ja jaḥ pheṃ pheṃ
ljags rdo rje'i sbu gu gtor ma la zug te gsol bar gyur/
They penetrate the torma with their tubular vajra tongues and consume it.

na mo gu ru rat+na i daM ba liM ta kha kha khA hi khA hi/ gsum gyis bla ma dang*/ oM AHhU~M hrIH o ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ DA ki ni ha ri ni sa hU~M/ i daM ba ling ta kha kha khA hi khA hi/ gsum gyis 'bul/

namo guru ratna idam baliṅgta kha kha khā hi khā hi Say this three times for [the offering to] the teacher. And make the offering three times with: oṁ āḥ hūṁ hrīḥ oṁ maṇi padme hūṁ ḍākinī harinisa hūṁ idam baliṅgta kha kha khā hi khā hi

ar+g+haM sogs kyis mchod/ bla ma dang 'jig rten dbang phyug la sogs dkyil 'khor gyi lha tshogs rnams kyi sku gsung thugs mnyes nas/ bdag dang sems can thams cad la mchog thun mong gi dngos grub ma lus par stsal du gsol/ ces gsol ba gdab bo/ / chos skyong ba'i gtor ma ni/ / bsang sbyang gong ltar dgra bgegs kyi sha khrag tu byin gyis brlabs la/ bskyed chog bsdus pa ni/ / oM swa b+hA wa zhes sogs/

On other occasions too, insert the [offering to the] yidam deity after this. {314} Make the offerings with arghaṃ and so on, and pray as follows: Teachers and hosts of deities of the mandalas of Avalokiteshvara and the others, may this delight your body, speech, and mind: Grant me and all sentient beings, I pray, all the supreme and common accomplishments without exception. The torma for the dharma protectors. Cleanse and purify the torma as above, blessing it as the flesh and blood of the enemies and obstacle makers. The following is a condensed visualization ritual. oṁ svabhāva…and so on.

gzhan yang yi dam gang byed 'di'i gsham du bzud do/ /stong pa nyid du gyur/ stong pa'i ngang las mdun gyi nam mkhar mdung dang ral gri gshibs pa'i gur khang*/ ma mo dang rlung nag 'tshub pa'i dbus/ gru gsum mthing nag 'bar ba'i dkyil 'khor/

All becomes emptiness. From the state of emptiness, in the sky before me appears a tent of rows of spears and swords. In the middle of mobbing mamos and swirling dust devils Is a blazing dark-blue triangular mandala.

dgra bgegs pho mo bsnol ba'i steng*/ gnam lcags kyi 'khor lo rtsibs stong dang ldan pa'i dbus su/ pad nyi'i gdan la hU~M dang gri gug las skyes pa'i dpal ye shes kyi brag mgon sku mdog dmar nag zhal gcig phyag gnyis spyan gsum sdang mig phyogs bcur gzigs pa/ 'jigs pa'i zhal gdangs shing mche ba bzhi gtsigs pa/ ljags glog ltar du 'khyug pa dbu skra dmar ser gyen du brdzes pa/

On top of male and female obstructor-enemies, face down and face up, In the middle of a thousand-spoked wheel of meteoric iron, On a seat of lotus and sun appears a syllable hūṁ and thence a curved knife, from which arises the glorious wisdom protector Draklha, dark red in color, with one face, two arms, and three eyes looking with angry glares in the ten directions, His mouth fearfully agape and four canine teeth bared, Tongue darting like lightning, orange hair streaming upward.

g.yas kyi phyag na beng dbyug zur bzhi rtse mor nor bus mtshan pa me stag 'phro ba 'dzin pa/ g.yon pas par bu'i nang du dgra snying dang bcas pa 'dzin pa/ thod skam lnga'i dbu rgyan/ thod rlon lnga bcus do shal/ sbrul nag gdug pa can gyi se ra kha dang yan lag thams cad brgyan pa/ sku smad la stag lpags rlon pa'i sham thabs gsol ba/ zhabs g.yas bskum zhing g.yon brkyang ba/ dar nag po'i 'jog ber gsol ba/ sku la me'i tsha tsha 'phro ba/ gdug pa can thams cad bsreg pa'o/ /

In his right hand he holds a four-faceted club, marked on its tip with a jewel and emitting sparks. His left hand holds a small vessel with the heart of an enemy inside it. He is adorned with a crown of five dry skulls, A long necklace of fifty fresh heads, And a shoulder belt and hand and foot ornaments of vicious black snakes. On his lower body he is wearing a skirt of a fresh tiger skin. His right leg is bent, his left leg extended. He wears a gown of black silk. His body emits fiery sparks, Burning up all evil beings.

de'i mdun du las mkhan mon pa nag po sku mdog mthing nag zhal gcig phyag gnyis spyan gsum bsgrad pa/ dbu skra kham ser gyen du brdzes pa/ phyag g.yas kyis gri gug nam mkhar phyar ba/ g.yon pas thod pa dgra snying gis bkang ba gtso bo'i zhal du stobs pa/ gzhan yang ye shes kyi mgon po sprin ltar du gtibs pa/ las kyi mgon po dang*/ 'jig rten gyi mgon po rlung ltar 'tshubs pa/ gzhan yang ma mo dang gshin rje'i tshogs dpag tu med pas bskor bar gyur/ mgon po'i dpral bar oM/ mgrin par AH thugs kar hU~M/

In front of him is his henchman, Black Mönpa, who is dark blue in color and has one face, two arms, and three eyes, wide open. His yellowish-red hair streams upward. His right hand brandishes a curved knife in the air. With his left hand he offers his master a skull cup containing an enemy’s heart. {315} Besides him, the protector is surrounded by wisdom protectors massed like clouds, Activity protectors and worldly protectors swirling around like the wind, And countless hosts, as well, of mamos and lords of death. On the protector’s forehead is the syllable oṁ, on his throat the syllable āḥ, and on his heart center the syllable hūṁ.

de las 'od 'phros bsil ba'i tshal nas ye shes pa spyan drangs/ rgyas par spro na/ hU~M dad pa dang ni dam tshig gis/ /zhes sogs spyan 'dren no/ / dzaHhU~M ba~M hoHsa gnyis su med par gyur/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis dbang bskur chu'i lhag ma yar lud pa las mi bskyod pas dbu brgyan par gyur pa'i ljags rdo rje'i sbu gu gtor ma la zug par gyur/

From these light radiates, inviting the wisdom deities from the Shītavana Cool Grove. If you wish to make a detailed invitation, recite the following: hūṁ As, with faith and [pure] commitments… and so on.[8] With jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ they become inseparable. The tathāgatas bestow empowerment, the [empowerment] water overflows, and the excess becomes Akṣhobhya, adorning his crown. His tubular vajra tongue penetrates the torma.

oM ma hA kA la d+hu ru swa hU~M hU~M phaT phaT/ i daM ba liM ta kha kha khA hi khA hi/ zhes gsum dang*/ shA sa na 'i sngags kyis mgon po spyi la 'bul/ dpal ldan lha mo gang byed bskyed la/ rang sngags sam/ yang na/ trag rag mo ba li ti khA hi/ trag rak+Sha ma hA rak+Shi Na nag mo dun ting b+h+yo/ i daM ba liM ta khA hi/ dpal ye shes kyi mgon po yab yum sras 'khor dang bcas pa rnams kyis mchod sbyin gyi gtor ma rgya chen po 'di bzhes la/ bdag dang sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa srungs/ mthun rkyen sgrubs/ 'gal rkyen zlog / dgra bgegs tshar bcad du gsol/

oṁ mahākāla dhurusva hūṁ hūṁ phaṭ phaṭ idam baliṅgta kha kha khā hi khā hi Say this three times and with the śāsana mantra, make the offering to the general protectors. Visualize Palden Lhamo as you usually do, and use her own mantra, or alternatively: trag rakṣa mahā rakṣiṇ nagmo dunting bhyo idam baliṅgta khā hi Glorious wisdom protectors with your consorts and retinue of sons, accept this vast torma, offered and given; Protect me and the Buddha’s teachings, Bring about favorable conditions, Repel adverse conditions, And destroy enemies and obstacle makers, I pray.

mkha' 'gro spyi gtor ni/ spyan drangs la rang sngags kyis 'bul ba'am/ yang na/ mkha' 'gro lnga'i 'khor na gnas pa/ yul sum cu so gnyis/ gnas nyi shu rtsa bzhi/ dur khrod chen po brgyad na gnas pa'i sprul pa'i sku 'gro ba sems can gyi don la bzhugs pa rnams kyi zhal du khA hi/ sku gsung thugs mnyes nas mchog thun mong gi dngos grub stsol cig /

For the general torma to the ḍākinīs, invite them and offer it with their respective mantras, or alternatively: All you manifestation bodies who dwell in the retinues of the five ḍākinīs, Who dwell in the thirty-two sacred lands, The twenty-four sacred places, And the eight great charnel grounds, Dwelling there for the benefit of sentient beings, To you [I offer this torma]—khā hi. May it delight your body, speech, and mind: Grant the supreme and common accomplishments.

gzhi bdag gtor ma ni/ dkar gtor du byin gyis brlabs la/ gzhan yang bod khams skyong bar byed pa'i brtan ma bcu gnyis yul so so'i gzhi bdag / gnas ri khrod kyi srung ma dam tshig can 'khor dang bcas pa rnams la 'bul lo/ / mnyes shing tshims nas chos dang mthun pa'i sdong grogs mdzod cig / gzhan yang 'gro ba rigs drug lam rgyud lnga skye ba gnas bzhir bsdus pa'i sems can rnams gtor ma 'dis tshims nas myur du sangs rgyas kyi go 'phang rin po che thob par gyur cig /

The torma for the local protectors. Bless the white torma, then: To the twelve tenmas, who protect Tibet, the local protectors of each region, {316} And the loyal protectors of mountain solitudes, along with your retinues, to you I also make this offering. Pleased and satisfied by this, be my friends, helping me to practice the dharma. And may all beings included in the six realms, the five paths of being, and the four modes of birth be satiated by this torma and swiftly attain the precious state of buddhahood.
ar+g+haM la sogs kyis mchod/ nang mchod kyis kyang mchod la/ bstod pa ni/
Make offerings with arghaṃ and so on, and also offer the inner offering. Then do the praise:

gang gis 'khor ba'i nyes pa ni/ / dran pa tsam gyis 'joms mdzad cing*/ / bla med byang chub thob mdzad pa/ / bla ma rnams la phyag 'tshal bstod/ / hrIH rnam par snang mdzad gti mug rnam dag pas/ / ces pa nas/ don gnyis 'grub par mdzad du gsol/ / ces pa'i bar gyis bstod/ hU~M las byung ba'i nag po mthu bo che/ / spyan ras gzigs mgon bka' srung dam tshig can/ / brag lha mgon po mgon po 'bum gyi rje/ / sangs rgyas bstan srung nag po khyod la bstod/ / b+h+yo/ gang gi sku gsung thugs kyis mthus/ / 'dod pa'i khams kun zil mnan nas/ / 'dod pa'i khams la dbang sgyur ma/ / 'dod khams dbang phyug ma la 'dud/ /

Merely thinking of you destroys All the faults of samsara And brings one to unsurpassed enlightenment— To all you teachers I make homage and praise. hrīḥ You who personify Vairochana, bewilderment purified,… and so on, down to …And help me to achieve the twofold goal. Mighty Black One arisen from hūṁ, Loyal guardian of Lord Avalokiteshvara’s words, Draklha Gönpo, lord of the hundred thousand protectors, Great protector of the Buddha’s doctrine, to you I give praise. bhyo By the force of your body, speech, and mind, You overpower the whole world of desire. Mistress of the world of desire, Queen of the world of desire, to you I bow.

lha chen brgyad po 'khor dang bcas/ / klu chen brgyad po 'khor dang bcas/ 'jig rten skyong ba brgyad po dang*/ / gnod sbyin tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / yi dwags tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / sha za'i tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / smyo byed tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / brjed byed tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / ma mo'i tshogs rnams ma lus dang*/ / mkha' 'gro'i tshogs ma lus dang*/ / de la sogs te 'byung po'i tshogs/ / ma lus par ni thams cad dag / 'dir gshegs bdag la dgongs su gsol/ /

Eight classes of mahādevas and your retinues, Eight classes of nāgas and your retinues, Eight guardians of the world and your retinues, All you hosts of yakṣhas, All you hosts of preta spirits, All you hosts of flesh-eating demons, All you hosts of demons that produce insanity, All you hosts of demons that produce oblivion, All you hosts of mamos, All you hosts of ḍākinīs, And all you hosts of other spirits, without exception, Come to this place and think of me. {317}

mchod sbyin gtor ma 'di bzhes la/ / rnal 'byor bdag cag 'khor bcas la/ / nad med tshe dang dbang phyug dang*/ / dpal dang grags dang skal ba bzang*/ / longs spyod rgya chen kun grub cing*/ / zhi dang rgyas la sogs pa yi/ / las kyi dngos grub bdag la stsol/ / dam tshig can gyis bdag la srung*/ / dngos grub kun gyi sdong grogs mdzod/ /

Accept this torma, offered and given, And for us practitioners and our followers Bring about freedom from disease, longevity, power, Glory, renown, good luck, And wealth, all on a vast scale. Grant us the accomplishment of the activities Of pacifying, increasing, and the rest. Keep your promise to protect us, And help us attain all the accomplishments.

dus min 'chi dang nad rnams dang*/ / gdon dang bgegs rnams med par mdzod/ / rmi lam ngan dang mtshan ma ngan/ / bya byed ngan pa med par mdzod/ / 'jig rten bde zhing lo legs dang*/ / 'bru rnams 'phel shing chos 'phel dang*/ / bde legs phun sum tshogs pa dang*/ / yid la 'dod pa kun grub shog /

Keep us from untimely death, and rid us Of sicknesses, negative forces, and obstacles. Put an end to nightmares, bad omens, And evil activities. Increase happiness in the world, Good harvests, and supplies of grain; Spread the dharma and bring about perfect happiness And the accomplishment of all we desire.
de nas tshogs la rol ba ni/ / las kyi slob dpon gyis thabs shes kyi rdzas steng 'og tu bzung la bsnol nas/
After that, enjoy the feast. The master of ceremonies takes the ingredients of skillful means and wisdom, crossing his hands one above the other and saying:

kyai rdo rje slob dpon dgongs su gsol/ / gzigs shig mdzes ldan dam pa'i chos/ / 'di la the tshom byar mi rung*/ / bram ze khyi dang gdol ba gsum/ rang bzhin gcig tu dgongs te rol/ / a ho ma hA su kha hoH zhes slob dpon la drang ngo*/ / slob dpon gyis pad kor dang ldan pas/ hU~M/ bde bar gshegs pa chos kyi sku/ / 'dod chags la sogs dri ma spangs/ / gzung dang 'dzin pa dang bral ba'i/ / de kho na nyid la gus phyag 'tshal/ / a la la ho/

O vajra master, listen to me. Look at these beautiful sacred substances; You should have no doubts about them. Consider that brahmins, dogs, and outcastes Are of the same nature, and enjoy! a ho mahā sukha hoḥ He takes it to the master. Making the circular lotus gesture, the master says: hūṁ To the sugatas’ body of truth, Free of attachment and other stains, Free of subject-object duality. To the ultimate nature, respectfully I pay homage. a la la ho

tshul des mched lcam rnams la yang drang ngo*/ / thams cad kyi lus lha/ ngag sngags/ sems chos nyid kyi ngang nas tshogs la rol lo/ / de nas lhag ma rnams snod gcig tu bsdus la/ rdo rje slob dpon gyis 'bar ba'i phyag rgyas kha chus bran la/ oM badz+ra A ra li ho pheM pheM/ zhes 'bar ba'i phyag rgyas g.yon nas g.yas su smin mtshams su skor/

In this way, take it also to the brothers and sisters. They all enjoy the feast while [preserving] the state of their bodies being deities, their speech being mantra, and their minds being ultimate reality. After that, collect the leftovers in a single container. The vajra master makes the blazing mudra and sprinkles them with saliva. Saying, oṁ vajra ārali ho pheṃ pheṃ with the blazing mudra, he makes a circular movement from left to right between his eyebrows.

yaM raM khaM/ oM AHhU~M/ phud dang lhag ma'i gtor ma bzang zhing chu che ba/ zad mi shes pa 'dod pa'i yon tan lnga dang ldan par gyur/ oM AHhU~M/ oM u ts+tshiSh+Ta ba liM ta b+hak+Sha b+hak+Sha yi swA hA/ lhag ma dbang ba'i 'byung po thams cad tshims par gyur cig

yaṃ raṃ khaṃ oṁ āḥ hūṁ The torma of the first-portion leftovers becomes an excellent, vast [offering],[9] Inexhaustible and possessed of the five pleasurable qualities. {318} oṁ āḥ hūṁ oṁ ucchiṣṭa baliṅgta bhakśa bhakśayi svāhā May it satisfy all the beings who have a right to the leftovers.

lhag ma bskyang ba ni/ hU~M gzhan yang las kyi mkha' 'gro ma/ / myur mgyogs rtsal ldan thams cad dang*/ / 'jig rten mkha' 'gro rdzu 'phrul can/ / khro gtum 'jigs par ston rnams dang*/ / sha za mkha' 'gro rdzu 'phrul can/ / stong gsum dbang du sdud rnams dang*/ / las la myur ba'i pho nya rnams/ / dam tshig dbang gis 'dir gshegs la/ /

Offering the leftovers: hūṁ All you karma ḍākinīs too, You who have the skill and power of speed, Worldly ḍākinīs with magical powers, You who display terrifying wrath, Flesh-eating ḍākinīs with magical powers, You who have control over the billion worlds, And all you messengers swift in your activities— By virtue of your commitments, come!

phud lhag bshal chu'i gtor ma bzhes/ / dkon mchog gsum gyi bstan pa srungs/ / log par lta ba'i dgra bgegs thul/ / rnal 'byor bcol ba'i phrin las mdzod/ / ces nam mkha' mthong sar gtor la/ bshal chu bskyangs la/ phyogs bcu 'jig rten skyong ba yi/ / bod khams skyong ba'i brtan ma rnams/ / 'dir gshegs bshal chu'i gtor ma bzhes/ / rnal 'byor bcol ba'i phrin las mdzod/ / ces nam mkha' gtor ro/ /de nas gtor snod kha sbub la gtor bro ni/

Accept the torma of the first-portion leftovers and rinsing water. Guard the teachings of the Three Jewels. Subdue the enemies and obstacle makers—wrong views. Carry out the activities that the practitioners entrust you with. Scatter it in an open place. Offering the rinsing water: All you tenmas, guardians of Tibet, Who protect the world in the ten directions, Come here and accept this torma of rinsing water. Carry out the activities the practitioners have assigned. Scatter it in the air. Next, turning the torma container upside down, perform the torma dance.

hU~M/ chos dbyings rab 'byams dkyil 'khor du/ / snang srid dbang du sdud pa'i lha/ / mkha' 'gro kun la dbang sgyur ma/ / 'jig pa'i gad mo hU~M sgra can/ / DA ki rgya mtsho spungs se spung*/ / mdzes pa'i gar thabs sha ra ra/ / 'dir gshegs bstan la sdang ba rnams/ / rdul phran bzhin du brlag par mdzod/ / oM ma Ni pad+me hU~M/ DA ki nI ha ri ni sa hU~M phaT swA hA/ gnod byed thams cad sta b+ha ya nan nan/ zhes dgra bgegs thams cad ri rab kyi 'og tu mnan par bsam/

hūṁ In the infinite mandala of the expanse of reality, Deities who have control over phenomenal existence, Ḍākinīs who have dominion over all— With your terrifying laugher, resounding hūṁ, A billowing ocean of ḍākinīs, Dancing gracefully, in continuous movement, Come to this place, and reduce to dust Those who are hostile to the teachings. oṁ maṇi padme hūṁ ḍākinī harinisa hūṁ phaṭ svāhā all harmdoers staṃ bhaya nan nan With this, consider that all the enemies and obstacle makers are crushed underneath Mount Meru.
gnyis pa rjes chog ni/
B. Concluding Ritual[10]

rgyas par spro na mchod pa byin rlabs dang*/ gtsang sbyar ma sogs mchod pa rgyas par bya/ bsdu na/ oM sarba ta thA ga ta lo ke shwa ra sa pa ri wA ra badz+ra ar+g+haM sogs gong bzhin mchod/ nang mchod bdud rtsis kyang mchod la bstod pa ni/

If you wish to do this elaborately, bless the offerings and make the detailed offerings with, for example, the tsang jar ma [torma offering].[11] For a condensed version, make the offerings as above with: oṁ sarva tathāgata lokeśvara saparivāra vajra arghaṃ… and so on. Offer the inner offering of nectar as well. Then do the praise: {319}
sangs rgyas mang pos rab tu bsngags/ / yon tan mchog gi gter gyur pa/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang 'khor dang bcas/ / rtag par brtse la phyag 'tshal bstod/ /
Praised by numerous buddhas, You are a treasure of sublime qualities. To you, Avalokiteshvara and all your retinue, Constant in your compassion, I give homage and praise.
de nas bzod par gsol ba ni/ yi ge brgya pa lan gsum brjod cing*/
After that, request forgiveness, reciting the hundred-syllable mantra three times and praying:
bdag ni ma rig dbang gyur pas/ / legs spyad 'di la nyes gyur gang*/ / cho ga lhag chad ci mchis pa/ / dkyil 'khor lha yi bzod par mdzod/ /
Whatever faults I have made in this virtuous practice On account of ignorance, And whatever additions or omissions I have made in the ritual, I beg the deities of the mandala to forgive.
de nas bsngo ba ni/ phyogs bcur bzhugs pa'i bla ma yi dam rgyal ba sras dang bcas pa thams cad bdag la dgongs su gsol/
Next, say the dedication: All you teachers, yidam deities, buddhas, and bodhisattvas dwelling in the ten directions, think of me.
dge ba 'di yi myur du bdag / bla ma yi dam grub gyur nas/ / 'gro ba gcig kyang ma lus pa/ / de yi sa la 'god par shog /
As a result of this virtuous practice, May I swiftly accomplish the teacher-yidam And, not leaving out a single being, May I set them all on his level.
ces brjod/ bkra shis ni/
Prayer for auspiciousness:

sangs rgyas kun dngos bla ma rin po che/ / yon tan phun tshogs chos kyi dbyings dang mnyam/ / bdag cag skye gu'i 'gro ba 'dren mdzad pa/ / bka' brgyud bla ma rnams kyi bkra shis shog / spyan ras gzigs dbang la sogs pa'i/ / bdag gis me tog phog pa'i lha/ / las dang skal ba ldan pa yi/ / yi dam rnams kyi bkra shis shog /

True manifestations of all the buddhas, precious teachers, Whose perfect and abundant qualities are as great as the expanse of reality, You who guide all us beings, Teachers of the instruction lineage, may all be auspicious! Deities on whom my flower fell, Avalokiteshvara and the rest, You to whom I am linked by karma and fortune, Yidam deities, may all be auspicious!

nam mkha'i lus can gar yang thogs med pa/ / 'dod dgur sgyur pa'i gzugs can 'phrul mo che/ / ma sring byams pa'i tshul kyis grogs mdzad ma/ / phyi nang mkha' 'gro rnams kyi bkra shis shog/ / bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga ru/ / sgrub par byed pa'i gang zag la/ / bu bzhin skyong bar zhal bzhes pa'i/ / chos skyong srung ma rnams kyi bkra shis shog /

You whose bodies of air are unobstructed wherever you go, Great illusionists, with bodies you can change at will, Who accompany me in the guise of loving mothers and sisters, Outer and inner ḍākinīs, may all be auspicious! You who in Lord Buddha’s presence Promised to protect, as you would your children, Those who are striving for accomplishment, Dharma protectors and guardians, may all be auspicious!
hU~M las byung ba'i nag po mthu po che/ / spyan ras gzigs kyi bka' srung dam tshig can/ / brag lha mgon po mgon po 'bum gyi rje/ / sangs rgyas bstan srung chen po'i bkra shis shog/ /

Mighty Black One arisen from hūṁ, Loyal guardian of Lord Avalokiteshvara’s words, Draklha Gönpo, lord of the hundred thousand protectors, Great guardian of the Buddha’s doctrine, may all be auspicious!
ces bkra shis brjod/ brtan bzhugs bya ba ni/ /
After saying this prayer for auspiciousness, request [the deities] to remain firmly [in the images].

mgon po thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa rnams kyis rten 'di la 'byung ba sa chu me rlung gis ma gnod kyi bar du brtan par bzhugs nas bdag dang sems can thams cad kyi mgon skyabs dam pa mdzad du gsol/ / oM su pra tiSh+Tha badz+ra ye swA hA/

Lord and all you who possess great compassion, {320} as long as they are not damaged by the elements earth, water, fire, and wind, please remain firmly in these images and act as the supreme refuge and protector for me and all sentient beings. oṁ supra tiṣtha vajra ye svāhā

rten mi bzhugs na gshegs su gsol ba ni/ oM khyed kyis sems can don kun mdzad/ / rjes su mthun pa'i dngos grub stsol/ / sangs rgyas yul du gshegs nas kyang*/ / sems can rnams kyi don slad du/ / slar yang 'byon par mdzad du gsol/ / badz+ra muH zhes gshegs/ dam tshig pa rnams bdag nyid la thim par gyur/ /

If there are no images, request [the deities] to depart: oṁ You who do everything for beings’ welfare, Grant accomplishment accordingly. Return to the land of the buddhas, And in order to benefit sentient beings, Come again, I pray. With vajra muḥ, let them depart. The meditational deities dissolve into myself.
oM AHhU~M/ gis bsdu'o/ sarba b+hU ta gats+tsha/ / zhes se gol brdeb cing*/ 'jig rten pa rnams rang gnas su gshegs su gsol/ /
With oṁ āḥ hūṁ, they dissolve. Snapping your fingers, say sarva bhūta gaccha and: Worldly deities, please return to your own abodes.

de nas snod bcud rten gzhal yas khang nas/ / sa bon nA da'i bar dang de las 'das te/ / don dam pa stong pa nyid kyi rang la yun ring du mnyam par gzhag / slar zung 'jug gi skur ldangs te gong bzhin bskyed rdzogs kyi gdams pa rnams tshul bzhin du nyams su blang ngo*/ / spyod lam rnal 'byor dang rdzogs rim zhib par sgrub thabs chen mor ltos shig /

After that, settle in meditative equipoise for a long while in the state[12] of ultimate emptiness, transcending everything that acts as a support—a container and contents—from the measureless palace to the seed nāda. Again, arise in the union body and properly practice the instructions on generation and perfection as above. For details of the practice of daily activities and the perfection stage, refer to the great sādhana.

spyan ras gzigs dbang sgrub/ [⁽1763⁾] mi tra'i lugs/ pa'i thabs/ / bde gsal don [⁽1763⁾] blo dman kyi/ du 'thad ldan pa'i/ / lung dang bla ma'i man ngag bzhin/ / gzhan gyis bya btang chos rje bskul phyir kho bos 'od dpag rdo rje/ / bsdebs/ nongs par mkha' 'gros bzod par bzhes/ / dge ba sems can don phyir bsngo/ / 'dis rgyal ba rnams kyi dam pa'i chos 'dzin par gyur cig/ /

The sādhana of Avalokiteshvara (Note: in Mitra’s tradition)[13] I (Note: Öpak Dorje) arranged in response to someone else’s (Note: Chatang Chöje’s) request, According to the transmission and the teacher’s pith instructions In a form suitable (Note: for those of modest intellect), for the sake of ease and clarity. I beg the ḍākinīs to pardon any errors, And I dedicate the merit for the benefit of sentient beings. Through this, may they come to hold the sacred teachings of the conquerors.
dge legs 'phel/
May virtue and excellence increase.
@#/ /'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi byang chub lam gyi rim pa'i khrid yongs su sdud pa bdud rtsi'i dga' ston bzhugs so/ /
16. A BANQUET OF NECTAR. A Complete Instruction on Noble Avalokiteshvara’s Graded Path to Enlightenment[1]

@#/ /dge legs rgya mtsho'i gter chen las 'khrungs pa/ / don gnyis lhun grub nor bu rin po che/ / 'gro ba'i dgos 'dod mtha' dag yongs skong ba/ / brgyud pa'i bla ma rnams kyi zhabs la 'dud/ / gang gis bskal pa grangs med sngon rol nas/ / spyan ras gzigs dbang thugs mchog gcig tu bskyed/ / mgon po de yi phrin las rgyas mdzad pa/ / bla med grub pa mi tra'i zhabs la 'dud/ / spyan ras gzigs kyis rjes bzung de nyid de/ / de yi rjes bzung shrI pu tra'o/ / de yi rjes bzung bla ma mchog gi ni/ / man ngag snyan nas snyan du legs brgyud pa'i/ / gdams pa 'di la blo bzos ma bslad cing*/ / ci ltar zhal nas gsungs pa'i rim pa rnams/ / 'gro la phan phyir brjed thor bkod pa la/ / bla ma mkha' 'gros bdag rgyud byin gyis rlobs/ /

{322} Born from the great treasure of the ocean of virtue and excellence, Precious jewel spontaneously accomplishing the two goals, Completely fulfilling all the wants and needs of beings— Lineage teachers, at your feet I bow. He who, countless cosmic eons before, With Avalokiteshvara gave rise to supreme bodhichitta And carried out on a vast scale the activities of the lord— Unexcelled siddha Mitrayogin, at your feet I bow. Guided by Avalokiteshvara, You in turn guided Shrīputra, And he in turn guided my sublime teacher. These instructions are his pith instructions, Perfectly transmitted down the lineage and uncorrupted by intellectual inventions. May the teachers and ḍākinīs bless my being That I may write down the stages [of the path] just as they were taught, Without forgetting anything, in order to benefit beings.

'dir 'phags pa spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gi lam gyi rim pa'i khrid ston par byed pa 'di la don bzhi ste/ thog mar gdams pa'i byang tshul dang*/ gnyis pa sngon 'gro'i man ngag dang*/ gsum pa bskyed pa'i rim pa'i khrid dang*/ byams snying rje byang chub kyi sems dang 'brel ba dang*/ bzhi pa rdzogs pa'i rim pa'o/ /

Here I will reveal the instructions on Avalokiteshvara’s graded path.[2] For this there are four main topics: {323} (1) historical background[3] of the instructions; (2) pith instructions on the preliminary practices; (3) instructions on the generation stage and the related [practices] of love, compassion, and bodhichitta; and (4) instructions on the perfection stage.[4]
dang po ni/
I. Historical Background of the Instructions

rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug mi tra dzo ki de nyid/ sngon bskal pa dgu bcu rtsa gcig gi sngon rol du dge slong sprul pa 'od du sku 'khrungs nas rgyal bu 'jig rten dbang phyug la chos bshad pa'i bla ma yang yin cing*/ bod yul du thon mi sa 'bo rar sku 'khrungs nas rgya gar du byon cing lots+tsa bsgyur/ bod du thub pa'i bstan pa rgyas par mdzad/ slar yang rgya gar gdul bya 'dul ba'i dus mkhyen nas/ sku skye ba bzung zhing spyan ras gzigs grub pa'i tshul mdzad nas 'chi med rdo rje'i sku thob ste/ sems can gyi don la rdzu 'phrul ya ma zung du ma dang*/ bshad sgrub smin byed kyi dbang dang*/ gang la gang 'dul gyi sgo nas sems can gyi don 'bad med lhun grub mdzad pa'o/ / de yang rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug de nyid dur khrod so sa gling du byon nas thugs dam lha lnga bsgrubs pas/ de rnams grub nas mngon sum du zhal bstan cing*/ so so'i bskyed rdzogs kyi khrid kyi rim pa rnams gsungs pa'o/ / de'i tshul yang*/ 'jam dpal dbyangs sku'i khrid shes rab 'phel byed ye shes rgyan gyi 'khor lo/ spyan ras gzigs gsung gi khrid byang chub lam gyi rim pa thams cad yongs su sdud pa bdud rtsi'i dga' ston/ phyag na rdo rje thugs kyi khrid bdud dpung 'joms byed 'od zer rgyas pa/ tshe dpag med yon tan kyi khrid 'chi med rdo rje'i sku sgrub pa'i thabs/ sgrol ma 'jigs pa brgyad skyobs 'khor ba'i 'phrang sgrol phrin las lhun grub ces bya ba'i khrid/ dzam b+ha la ser po'i khrid dngos grub char 'bebs zhes bya ba ste/ khrid drug po 'di dag lha so so'i zhal nas rang rang gi sgo nas khrid kyi rim pa gsungs pa'o/ /

Ninety-one kalpas ago the mahāsiddha Mitrayogin took birth as the monk Emanated Light and was the teacher who taught the dharma to the prince Lokeshvara. In Tibet, he took birth as Tönmi Sambhota, traveled to India, became a translator, and propagated the teachings of Shākyamuni in Tibet. Later, knowing that the time had come to train disciples in India, he took birth and, having acted out the sādhana of Avalokiteshvara, attained the immortal vajra body. For the benefit of sentient beings, he displayed numerous paradoxical paired miracles,[5] taught, practiced, bestowed maturing empowerments, and trained beings according to their needs. In such ways he effortlessly and spontaneously worked for the welfare of sentient beings. {324} Moreover, that great siddha journeyed to the Sosaling charnel ground. There he practiced the five yidam deities and accomplished them. They appeared to him in reality, each teaching him the graded instructions on their respective generation and perfection stages. In that way, Mañjughoṣha gave him the Body instruction, The Wheel of Ornaments of Gnosis That Makes Wisdom Grow. Avalokiteshvara taught him the Speech instruction, A Banquet of Nectar, a complete instruction on the whole graded path to enlightenment. Vajrapāṇi taught him the Mind instruction, The Spreading Rays of Light That Vanquish the Hordes of Demons. Amitāyus gave him the Qualities instruction, the method for Accomplishing the Immortal Vajra Body. Tārā taught him the instruction that protects one from the eight fears, called Spontaneous Activities That Free One from the Perilous Path of Samsara. And Yellow Jambhala gave him the instruction called A Shower of Accomplishments. These six instructions are the respective graded instructions that each of the deities taught him.

de yang*/ lha de dag gi zhal nas khrid 'di dag nyams su long la gzhan la gcig brgyud du ston cig dang*/ brgyud pa bdun gyi bar du bdag cag rnams kyi byin gyis brlabs pa yin no gsungs/ khyad par khrid 'di dag nyams su len pa'i gang zag de mi rabs bdun gyi bar du spyan ras gzigs kyi byin gyis brlabs pa sha stag yin no gsungs nas lung bstan pa'o/ / rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug mi tras rjes su bzung ba ni/ paN+Di ta shrI pu tra/ de nyid kyi rjes bzung ba ni rtogs ldan g+hirti rat+na/ de'i bar la gcig brgyud du 'dug cing*/ man ngag snyan nas snyan du brgyud pa yin pa la/ bdag gis brjed kyi dogs nas yi ger bkod pa'o/ / de ni brgyud tshul lo/ /

These deities told him to put these instructions into practice and to reveal them to one other lineage holder, saying that their blessings would carry for up to seven generations of lineage holders. In particular, they predicted that for seven generations the individuals who practiced these instructions would be exclusively ones blessed by Avalokiteshvara. The great siddha Mitrayogin’s disciple was the paṇḍita Shrīputra. The latter’s disciple was the realized being Girti Ratna. As far as him, there has been only a single lineage holder [at a time], [holding] the pith instructions transmitted through an aural lineage. To prevent my forgetting them, I have put them down in writing. This, then, is the transmission lineage of these instructions.
gnyis pa
II. Pith Instructions on the Preliminary Practices
sngon 'gro la gnyis te/ thun mong gi sngon 'gro dang thun mong ma yin pa'o/ /
The preliminary practices are divided into sections: (1) the common and (2) the specific preliminaries. {325}
dang po
A. Common Preliminaries

['di] la bzhi ste/ dal 'byor rnyed par dka' ba sgom pa dang gcig / 'chi ba mi rtag pa sgom pa dang gnyis/ las rgyu 'bras 'khor pa'i nyes dmigs sgom pa'i dmigs rim rnams khrid gzhan dang mtshungs so/ /

The common preliminaries are divided into four: meditation on the difficulty of finding the freedoms and advantages; meditation on death and impermanence; meditation on action, cause and effect; and meditation on the defects of cyclic existence. The procedures for these are the same as in other instruction manuals.
gnyis pa
B. Specific Preliminaries

khyad par gyi sngon 'gro la la bzhi ste/ ci byas thams cad thar pa'i lam du 'gro bar byed pa skyabs 'gro sems bskyed kyi khrid/ sdig sgrib thams cad myur du dag par byed pa hrIH yig bzhi sbyor man ngag / tshogs gnyis rdzogs par byed pa maN+Dal gyi khrid/ byin rlabs myur du 'jug par byed pa bla ma'i rnal 'byor gyi khrid dang bzhi'o/ /

The specific preliminaries are divided into four: (1) instructions on going for refuge and arousing bodhichitta, which make everything one does become the path to liberation; (2) a pith instruction on the four applications of the syllable hrīḥ, which enable one to swiftly purify all one’s negative deeds and obscurations; (3) instructions on the mandala practice, which enables one to complete the two accumulations; and (4) instructions on the guru yoga, which enables one to quickly receive blessings.
dang po
1. Instructions on Going for Refuge and Arousing Bodhichitta

mdun gyi nam mkhar rin po che'i khri yangs shing rgya che ba/ gyad dang seng ges btegs pa/ sna tshogs pad+ma 'bum ldan gyi steng na/ zla ba'i dkyil 'khor yongs su rgyas pa/ de'i dbus su rang gi rtsa ba'i bla ma 'od dpag med longs spyod rdzogs sku'i cha lugs su bzhugs pa bka' brgyud bla mas bskor ba/ mdun na yi dam thugs rje chen po la yi dam rgya mtshos bskor ba/ g.yas su sangs rgyas shAkya thub pa la bskal bzang gi sangs rgyas stong la sogs pa sangs rgyas rgya mtshos bskor ba/ rgyab tu yum chen mo la po ti dang glegs bam dam chos rgya mtshos bskor ba/ g.yon tu byang chub sems dpa' nye ba'i sras brgyad dang nyan thos mchog brgyad la/ theg chen theg dman gyi dge 'dun rgya mtshos bskor ba/ phyogs dang phyogs mtshams thams cad dpa' bo dang mkha' 'gros gang ba/ 'og tu phyag drug pa dang brag lha mgon po la sogs chos skyong ba'i srung ma rgya mtshos bskor ba/ srung skyob kyi tshul du bzhugs pa/ de dag gi skyabs zhabs na bdag dang mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad tshud par bsams la/ ngag tu/

In the sky before one, raised by herculean men and lions, is a vast, spacious throne with a multicolored lotus of a hundred thousand petals. On top of it is a full-moon disk, in the middle of which is one’s own root teacher [in the form of] Amitābha, wearing the attributes of the body of perfect enjoyment. He is surrounded by the teachers of the instruction lineage. In front of him is the yidam deity, the Great Compassionate One, surrounded by an ocean of yidam deities. On his right is Buddha Shākyamuni surrounded by an ocean of buddhas, such as the thousand buddhas of the good kalpa. Behind is the Great Mother[6] surrounded by an ocean of the sacred dharma in the form of books and volumes of the scriptures. On the left are the eight close bodhisattva sons and the eight sublime listeners, surrounded by an ocean of the sanghas of the Great and Lesser Vehicles. All the directions and intermediate directions are filled with ḍākas and ḍākinīs. He is surrounded below by an ocean of protectors who guard the teachings—the six-armed Mahākāla, Draklha Gönpo, and others, {326} who are present as a defense. Considering that you and all the infinite beings are under their protection, repeat the following aloud, many times, as you develop devotion and respect:

ma nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad phyogs bcu'i dpal ldan bla ma dam pa rnams la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i yi dam rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i dam chos rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i dge 'dun rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i mkha' 'gro rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / phyogs bcu'i chos skyong rgya mtsho la skyabs su mchi'o/ / skyabs 'og dam par tshud par mdzad du gsol/ zhes mang du bzlas shing mos gus bskyed do/ /

All sentient beings, my mothers, as numerous as space is vast, take refuge in the glorious holy teachers in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite yidam deities in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite buddhas in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite sacred dharma teachings in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite sanghas in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite ḍākinīs in the ten directions. We take refuge in the infinite dharma protectors in the ten directions. Keep us perfectly under your protection, we pray.

tshad med bzhi sgom/ de nas skyabs gnas de dag 'od du zhu nas rang la thim pas/ rang gi lus ngag yid gsum dang dbyer med pa chu la chu bzhag pa ltar ma bcos pa'i ngang la 'jog pa ni/ don gyi skyabs 'gro'o/ /

Meditate on the four boundless attitudes. After that, the sources of refuge melt into light and dissolve into you, so that they are inseparable from your own body, speech, and mind, like water poured into water. To settle in that state without contrivance is the ultimate [practice of] taking refuge.
gnyis pa ni/
2. A Pith Instruction on the Four Applications of the Syllable hrīḥ

rang tha mal par gnas pa'i spyi bo'i gtsug tu hrIHyig dkar po tshegs drag dang bcas pa las 'od zer 'phro ba'i rang bzhin can du bsams/ de la bdud rtsi 'o ma lta bu babs pas/ lus kyi nang gi sdig pa dang sgrib pa thams cad bkrus/ ba spu'i bu ga dang*/ rtsa sgo dang*/ chu sgo rkang zhabs sen mo'i bar nas dud khu dang sol khu'i rnam pa nag nu nu ru bud par bsams la/ lus kyi nang thams cad ye shes kyi bdud rtsis dkar ltem gyis gang bar bsam pa ni sdig pa dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba'o/ /

a. While remaining in your ordinary form, visualize on the crown of your head a white syllable hrīḥ, complete with visarga, radiating light. Nectar flows down from it like milk, washing away all the negative deeds and obscurations inside your body. Consider that from the pores of your body, from the anus and urethra, and from your legs and feet, including your toenails, they emerge as black matter oozing out in the form of smoke and liquid charcoal. Imagine that the whole of the inside of your body is completely filled with the white nectar of primordial wisdom. This is the application that purifies one’s negative deeds.
gnyis pa nad gdon dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba la lnga ste/
b. The application that purifies illness and negative forces consists of five parts. {327}
dang po tshad pa'i nad dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba ni hrIHyig las bdud rtsi'i rgyun gangs chu dang ga bur lta bu bsil ba'i ngad dang ldan pa'i chu rgyun babs pas/ lus grang sil sel song bar bsams/

i. The application for purifying fevers involves considering that from the syllable hrīḥ a stream of nectar flows down as a cooling stream of water, like meltwater or camphor, so that one’s body becomes cool.[7]
gnyis pa grang ba'i nad dag par byed pa la bdud rtsi khro chu khol ma lta bu tsha ba'i rang bzhin babs pas/ lus me 'bar ba lta bur tsha chil chil 'bar bar bsam/
ii. To purify cold diseases, one considers that the stream of nectar flowing down is hot, like boiling molten metal, so that waves of heat like a blazing fire flow into one’s body.
gsum pa 'dus pa'i nad dag par byed pa la/ bdud rtsi kha dog lnga dang ldan pa bde ba'i rang bzhin can babs pas/ lus bde stong du phril phril song bar bsams pa ni/ nad dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba'o/ /

iii. To purify illnesses due to multiple imbalances, one considers that five-colored nectar flows down, blissful in nature, so that one’s body becomes vibrant with bliss-emptiness. [These three] comprise the application that purifies illness.

bzhi pa gdon dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba ni hrIHyig las khro chung phyag na rdo rje dang rta mgrin gyi rnam pa can la/ sku chung la yan lag dod pa skye mched gsal ba/ 'jigs pa'i gad mo sgrogs pa/ phyag na mtshon cha sna tshogs 'dzin pa/ ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs pa/ zhal nas hU~M hU~M dang ha ha phaT phaT kyi sgra sgrogs par byed pa/ dpag tu med par du ma byung nas/ lus kyi nang gi gdon thams cad ba spu'i sgo nas bud par bsams pa ni/ gdon dag par byed pa'i sbyor ba'o/ /

iv. The application that purifies negative forces consists of the following visualization. From the syllable hrīḥ infinite small wrathful emanations in the form of Vajrapāṇi and Hayagrīva appear, with the details of their tiny bodies—their limbs, expressions, and everything—all very clear, laughing terrifyingly, holding all sorts of weapons in their hands, and surrounded by blazing wisdom fire. Their mouths roar hūṁ hūṁ and ha ha phaṭ phaṭ. As a result, all the negative forces inside your body are expelled through the hairs of your body. This is the application that purifies negative forces.

lnga pa sdig sgrib thams cad sbyong bar byed pa 'od zer spro bsdu'i sbyor ba ni/ hrI las 'od zer kha dog lnga dang ldan pa nyi ma stong gi 'od lta bu 'phros pas/ lus kyi nang gi sdig sgrib pa thams cad dag / mun pa la nyi ma shar ba lta bur sbyangs/ lus kyi nang 'od zer gyis gang nas/ 'od zer sna lnga phyir 'phros/ sems can thams cad kyi nang gdon sdig sgrib dag par bsgoms pa ni/ sgrib pa thams cad sbyong bar byed pa'i sbyor ba'o/ /

v. The application of emanating and gathering back rays of light that cleanses away all negative deeds and obscurations. From the syllable hrīḥ five-colored rays of light emanate, like the light of a thousand suns, purifying all the negative deeds and obscurations within your body and cleansing them away like the rising sun dispelling darkness. The inside of your body is filled with rays of light. After that, visualize five-colored rays shining outward, purifying the illnesses, negative forces, negativedeeds, and obscurations of all sentient beings. This is the application that cleanses all obscurations. {328}

de dag gis skabs su ngag tu yang hrIH'don par bya'o/ / mthar rang lus 'od du zhu nas hrIHla thim/ hrIHyig ra ta la/ ra ta khog pa la/ de gi gu la/ rim gyis nam mkha' la 'ja' yal ba ltar dmigs med kyi ngang la 'jog pa ni spyod byed chen po'o/ / de dag gis hrIHyig bzhi sbyor gi gdams pa song ngo*/ /

In all these cases you should also recite the syllable hrīḥ. At the end, your body melts into light and dissolves into the hrīḥ. The [different elements] of the syllable hrīḥ dissolve in stages—[first] into the rata,[8] then the rata into the body of the syllable, the body into the gigu,[9] which itself dissolves like a rainbow vanishing in the sky. Settle in the nonconceptual state. This is the great purificator. All this was the instruction on the four applications of the syllable hrīḥ.
gsum pa ni/
3. Instructions on the Mandala Practice
phyi'i maN+Dal zhing la bkod pa/ nang gi maN+Dal lus la bkod pa/ gsang ba'i maN+Dal rtsa la bkod pa dang gsum las/

The instructions on the mandala practice are divided into three: (1) the outer mandala, the universe presented as a mandala; (2) the inner mandala, the body presented as a mandala; and (3) the secret mandala, the channels presented as a mandala.
dang po phyi'i maN+Dal
a. Outer Mandala
['di] la gnyis te/ bsgrub pa'i maN+Dal dang mchod pa'i maN+Dal lo/ /
This has two aspects: (1) the accomplishment mandala and (2) the offering mandala.

dang po rgyu rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'am/ ma 'byor na sa gzhi spos gyis chag chag gdab la/ tshom bu bkod pa ni rgyu rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa'i gling bzhi ri rab dang bcas pa'i steng na/ rin po che sna tshogs las grub pa'i gzhal yas khang gru bzhi sgo bzhi rgyan rta babs bang rim tog dang bcas pa'i dbus su/ rin po che'i khri'i steng du/ pad+ma zla ba'i steng na/ dbus su rang gi rtsa ba'i bla ma sangs rgyas 'od dpag med kyi cha lugs su bzhugs pa la/ brgyud pa'i bla mas bskor ba/ mdun du yi dam/ g.yas su sangs rgyas/ rgyab tu dam chos/ g.yon du dge 'dun/ 'og tu mkha' 'gro chos skyong thams cad bzhugs par bsams la/ tshom bu bkod/ gu ru bud+d+ha/ d+harma/ saM g+ha maN+Dal la badz+ra sa ma ya dzaH dzaHhU~M ba~M hoH pad+ma ka ma lA ya s+t+waM/ zhes brjod do/ /

i. The accomplishment mandala should be one made of the five kinds of precious materials, or, if you do not have one, an earthen base, sprinkled with scented water. On it should be disposed the piles, composed of various precious materials, [representing] the four continents and Mount Meru, on top of which is the measureless palace, made of different precious materials, with its four sides, four gates, ornaments, arched pediments, terraces, and top ornament. In its center is a throne of precious materials, on which is a lotus and moon disk, and on top of that, in the middle, one’s own root teacher appearing as Buddha Amitābha, surrounded by the lineage teachers. In front are the yidam deities; to the right, the buddhas; behind, the sacred dharma; to the left, the sangha; and below, the ḍākinīs and dharma protectors. Visualizing all these, set out the piles and say: guru buddha dharma saṅgha maṇḍal la vajra samaya jaḥ jaḥ hūṁ baṁ hoḥ padma kamalā ya stvaṃ

de nas mchod pa'i maN+Dal ni/ gser dang dngul la sogs pa rin po che'i maN+Dal gyi steng du/ tshom bu nye ring ran par bkod/ maN+Dal gnyis med na/ bsgrub pa'i maN+Dal gyi lha rnams mdun gyi nam mkhar btegs nas bzhugs par bsgoms la/ bsgrub pa'i maN+Dal de ka'i steng du tshom bu bkod pa ni/

ii. Next, prepare the offering mandala. This should be a mandala of precious material such as gold or silver, on which the piles should be spaced correctly. {329} If you do not have two mandalas, visualize the deities of the accomplishment mandala up in the air in front of you and use the same accomplishment mandala on which to set out the piles, as follows.
oM badz+ra b+hu mi A hU~M/ dbang chen gser gyi sa bzhi/ oM badz+ra re khe A hU~M/ phyi lcags ri 'khor yug gi dbus su rgyu rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'i ri bo mchog rab/

oṁ vajra bhumi āḥ hūṁ—corresponding to the mighty golden ground. oṁ vajra rekhe āḥ hūṁ—corresponding to the outer ring of iron mountains, in the middle of which is Mount Meru, made of the five kinds of precious materials.

shar lus 'phags po zla gam shel las grub pa ma rmos pa'i lo tog gis brgyan pa/ lho dzam bu gling sog kha rin po che bai DUr+Ya las grub pa nor bus rgyan pa/ nub ba glang spyod zlum po pad+ma rA ga las grub pa 'dod 'jo'i bas brgyan pa/ byang sgra mi snyan gru bzhi rin po che gser las grub pa dpag bsam shing gis brgyan pa/ gling phran brgyad kyis bskor ba/ shar lho gnyis kyi nam mkhar me shel las grub pa'i nyi ma/ nub byang gnyis kyi nam mkhar chu shel las grub pa'i zla ba/ byang shar gnyis kyi nam mkhar dus me ser po/ lho nub gnyis kyi nam mkhar sgra gcan nag po/ bar mtshams rnams su 'khor lo rin po che/ nor bu rin po che/ btsun mo rin po che/ glang po rin po che/ blon po rin po che/ rta mchog rin po che/ dmag dpon rin po che ste rgyal srid sna bdun/ rin po che'i gdugs/ phyogs las rnam par rgyal ba'i rgyal mtshan/ gser las grub pa'i nya/ rab tu mdzes pa'i pad+ma/ chos kyi sgra dbyangs sgrogs pa'i dung*/ gter chen po'i bum pa/ dgos 'dod 'byung ba'i dpal be'u/ chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba'i 'khor lo ste bkra shis pa'i rtags brgyad/ gzhan yang me tog ma/ bdug spos ma/ snang gsal ma/ dri chab ma ste phyi'i sgeg mo bzhi/ glu ma/ gar ma/ phreng ba ma/ / sgeg mo ma ste nang gi sgeg mo bzhi/

In the east is Pūrvavideha, which is semicircular and made of crystal, embellished with uncultivated crops of grain. In the south is Jambudvīpa, which is trapezoidal and made of precious beryl, embellished with jewels. In the west is Godānīya, which is round and made of ruby, embellished with bountiful cows. In the north is Uttarakuru, which is square and made of precious gold, embellished with wish-fulfilling trees. They are flanked by the eight subcontinents. In the sky to the southeast is the sun, made of fire crystal. In the sky to the northwest is the moon, made of water crystal. In the sky to the northeast is the yellow Ketū, and in the sky to the southwest is the black Rāhu.[10] In the space in between are the seven attributes of royalty, namely the precious wheel, the precious jewel, the precious queen, the precious elephant, the precious minister, the marvelous and precious horse, and the precious general; and the eight auspicious symbols, namely the precious parasol, the banner of universal victory, the golden fish, the utterly beautiful lotus, the conch that resounds to the melodious sound of the dharma, the vase of great treasure, the eternal knot that fulfills all needs and desires, and the wheel that turns the wheel of dharma. Besides these, {330} there are the four outer offering maidens—the lady of flowers, the lady of incense, the lady of lamps, and the lady of perfume—and the four inner offering maidens: the lady of song, the lady of dance, the lady of garlands, and the lady of charm.

mdor na lha dang mi'i longs spyod ma tshang ba med pa du mas kun tu gang zhing*/ bdag gi lus longs spyod bcas pa 'di dag bla ma dkon mchog mchod 'os rgya mtsho dang bcas pa rnams la 'bul lo/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes nas byin gyis brlab tu gsol/ / zhes lan nyi shu rtsa gcig gam/ bcu bzhi'am/ bdun gyi bar du 'bul lo/ /

In short, [everything] is completely filled with the many riches of gods and humans, with nothing missing, and these, along with your own body and possessions, are offered to the teacher and the Three Jewels and infinite objects worthy of veneration. Saying “Accept these with compassion for the sake of beings, and grant your blessings, I pray,” make this offering twenty-one, fourteen, or seven times.
gnyis pa nang gi maN+Dal lus la bkod pa ni/
b. Presentation of One’s Body as the Inner Mandala
oM badz+ra b+hU mi A hU~M/ pags pa dbang chen gser gyi sa gzhi/ oM badz+ra re khe A hU~M/ rgyu ma lcags ri'i 'khor yug / de'i dbus su sgal tshigs dbus kyi ri bo mchog rab/

oṁ vajra bhumi āḥ hūṁ—one’s skin corresponds to the mighty golden ground. oṁ vajra rekhe āḥ hūṁ—one’s innards correspond to the outer ring of iron mountains. In the middle of them is the backbone, the central Mount Meru.

mgo bo rnam par rgyal ba'i khang bzang*/ lag pa g.yas shar lus 'phags po/ rkang pa g.yas lho dzam bu gling*/ rkang pa g.yon nub ba lang spyod/ lag pa g.yon byang sgra mi snyan/ mig gnyis nyi ma dang zla ba/ rna ba gnyis sgra gcan dang dus me/ sna gter chen po'i bum pa/ lce 'dod 'jo'i ba/ rkang sor bcu phyi'i lha mo bcu/ lag sor bcu nang gi lha mo bcu/ lhu'i tshigs chen brgyad bkra shis pa'i rtags brgyad/ don snod bdun rgyal srid sna bdun/ skra dang ba spu lha dang mi'i longs spyod phun sum tshogs pa ma tshang ba med pa 'di dag thams cad ji srid 'khor ba ma stong gi bar du rtsa ba dang brgyud par bcas pa'i bla ma dam pa rnams dang*/ dkon mchog yi dam mkha' 'gro/ chos skyong gi tshogs dang bcas pa rnams la 'bul lo/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes su gsol/ zhes brjod/

The head corresponds to the Mansion of Complete Victory, the right arm to the eastern continent of Pūrvavideha, the right leg to the southern continent of Jambudvīpa, the left leg to the western continent of Godānīya, and the left arm to the northern continent of Uttarakuru. The two eyes correspond to the sun and moon, the two ears to Rāhu and Ketū, the nose to the vase of great treasure, the tongue to the bountiful cow, the ten toes to the ten outer goddesses, the fingers to the ten inner goddesses, the eight main articulations to the eight auspicious symbols, the seven internal organs to the seven attributes of royalty. The hair on the head and body hairs correspond to the bountiful riches of gods and humans, with nothing missing. All these are “offered to the holy root and lineage teachers, to the Three Jewels, and to the hosts of yidam deities, ḍākinīs, and dharma protectors until samsara has been emptied. Accept them with compassion for the sake of beings.” {331}
gsum pa gsang ba'i maN+Dal rtsa la bkod pa ni/
c. Presentation of One’s Channels as the Secret Mandala
gsang gnas rtsa mchog dbang chen gser gyi sa gzhi/ yan lag gi rtsa rnams lcags ri'i 'khor yug /
The supreme channel in the secret center corresponds to the mighty golden ground. The channels in the limbs correspond to the outer ring of iron mountains.

dbus su dbu ma ri rgyal lhun po/ snying kha shar lus 'phags po/ lte ba lho dzam bu gling*/ mgrin pa nub ba glang spyod/ spyi bo byang sgra mi snyan/ rtsa ro ma nyi ma/ rkyang ma zla ba/ dbu ma'i mar sna sgra gcan/ yar sna dus me/

In the middle is the avadhūtī, corresponding to Mount Meru, the king of mountains. The heart center corresponds to Pūrvavideha in the east, the navel center to Jambudvīpa in the south, the throat center to Godānīya in the west, and the crown center to Uttarakuru in the north. The rasanā channel is the sun, the lalanā the moon, the lower end of the avadhūtī is Rāhu, and the upper end is Ketū.

snying kha chos kyi 'khor lo/ lte ba sprul pa'i 'khor lo/ mgrin pa longs spyod 'khor lo/ spyi bo bde chen gyi 'khor lo lnga/ 'dod yon gyi lha mo lnga/ rtsa 'dabs rnams bkra shis rtags brgyad/ rgyal srid sna bdun/ lha mi'i dpal 'byor ma tshang ba med pa 'di dag rtsa brgyud kyi bla ma rnams dang*/ yi dam gyi lha la 'bul lo/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes su gsol/

The five chakras—the wheel of dharma in the heart, the wheel of manifestation in the navel, the wheel of enjoyment in the throat, the wheel of great bliss in the crown, [and the bliss-preserving chakra in the secret center]—correspond to the five goddesses of the sense pleasures. The radial channels are the eight auspicious symbols, the seven attributes of royalty, and the riches of gods and humans, with nothing missing. All these “are offered to the root and lineage teachers and the yidam deities. Accept them with compassion for the sake of beings.”

bdag gzhan lus ngag yid gsum dus gsum dge tshogs rnams/ / rin chen maN+Dal kun bzang mchod pa'i tshogs bcas pa/ / blo yis blangs nas bla ma rnams dang yi dam lha la 'bul/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes su gsol/ / bzhes nas byin gyis brlab tu gsol/

The virtue gathered by myself and others, with our body, speech, and mind, in the past, present, and future, Together with all the offerings of precious mandalas and offerings made in the manner of Samantabhadra, I take mentally and offer to the teachers and yidam deities. Accept them with compassion for the sake of beings, And accepting them, grant your blessings, I pray.
gu ru maN+Dal la pU dza me g+ha sa mu dra s+pha ra Na sa ma ye hU~M/ zhes brgya rtsa brgyad dam nyi shu rtsa gcig bar du dbul bar bya'o/ /
guru maṇḍala pūja megha samudra spharaṇa samaye hūṁ Make this offering one hundred eight or twenty-one times.
