Consider that they dissolve into your five centers. During these stages, when you send the light rays out, you should also breathe out. When you gather in the qualities, you should breathe in and hold the breath in the vase for a while, pressing down. This is a pith instruction.
gsum pa ni/
3. Instructions on the Deity’s Speech

stong pa'i ngang las rab rgyas pad zla'i steng du/ sa las seng ge sngon po gdong thur la phyogs pa'i steng du/ zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi dbus su d+hIHyig dmar ser las 'od 'phros/ 'phags pa mchod/ sems can gyi don byas/ tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ rang nyid rje btsun ngag gi dbang phyug sku mdog pad+ma rA ga ltar dmar ba'i mdangs dang ldan pa/ zhabs gnyis rgyal po rol pa'i stabs kyis bzhugs pa/ dar sna lnga'i sham thabs can/ phyag gnyis chos ston pa'i phyag rgya mdzad cing*/ g.yas pa'i mtheb mdzub gnyis kyis pad+ma ral gris mtshan pa'i yu ba 'dzin pa/ g.yon pa'i mtheb mdzub gnyis kyis ut+pa la'i steng na rin po che'i glegs bam 'dzin pa/ zhal 'dzum pa/ spyan dkyus dang smin dkyus ring zhing*/ mdzod spu dkar pos mdzes pa/ dbu skra ral pa'i thor cog phyed bcings shing*/ phyed grol bas rked sor slebs pa'i zar bu gyen du 'dril ba/ me tog gi phreng bas skra bcings dang*/ rin po che du ma dang*/ mu tig sna lnga'i chun pos rab tu brgyan cing*/ dar gyi cod pan gyis mdzes par brgyan pa'i bdag nyid can du gsal bar bsgom/

From the state of emptiness there appears a fully bloomed lotus and moon disk. On it is the syllable sa, from which appears a blue lion, looking downward. On top of that is a moon disk, and in its center a yellowish-red syllable dhīḥ. It emanates rays of light, making offerings to the noble ones and benefiting sentient beings. They are gathered back, and it transforms into oneself as the noble Lord of Speech,[4] who is a radiant ruby red and is seated with his two legs in the posture of royal ease. He is wearing a skirt of five-colored silk. He holds his two hands in the teaching gesture. With the thumb and finger of his right hand, he holds the stem of a lotus, marked with a sword; with the thumb and finger of his left hand he holds an utpala, on top of which is a precious volume of the scriptures. He has a smiling face, with long eyebrows and almond eyes, and his [forehead] is adorned with a coil of white hair. Half of his hair is tied up in a topknot; the other half is loose, hanging down and curling up at the waist. His hair is bound with a garland of flowers and decorated with a multitude of jewels and five-colored pearls, and he is beautifully adorned with a silken crown. {385} Visualize him clearly in this manner.

de'i spyi mgrin snying khar oM AHhU~M las 'od 'phros pas/ rang lta bu'i ye shes pa spyan drangs la bstim/ slar rigs lnga spyan drangs la dbang bskur/ rnam snang gis dbur brgyan par bsam/ bcom ldan 'das de'i spyi bor/ mgrin pa/ lte ba/ gsang gnas lngar/ 'ja' tshon gyis 'od bskor ba'i dbus su/ pad zla'i gdan steng du rin po che'i po ti shes rab kyi ral gri me 'bar bas mtshan pa/ yu ba d+hIHdang bcas pa/ po ti'i steng na ral gri gyen la lang ba'o/ / spyi bor shes rab kyi ral gri dkar po/ de bzhin du mgrin par dmar po/ snying khar sngon po/ lte bar ser po/ gsang gnas su ljang khu lnga la yi ge d+hIHdkar dmar sngo ser ljang khus mtshan pa las 'od 'phros/ phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas thams cad mchod pa'i sprin gyis mchod/ de dag gi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi ye shes kyi snang ba rgyas par byas/ sems can thams cad la phog / mi shes pa'i mun pa mtha' dag dang dug lnga sbyangs/ 'jam dbyangs rigs lnga'i go 'phang la bkod/ ye shes lnga'i snang ba rgyas par bsam pa ni/ rlung phyir 'gro ba'i tshe dmigs pa bzung ba'o/ / rlung tshur rngub pa'i tshe/ sangs rgyas byang sems thams cad rigs lnga 'jam dbyangs su gnas pa'i sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi byin rlabs/ ye shes dang yon tan/ mkhyen brtse nus pa/ 'chad rtsod rtsom gsum mi brjed pa'i gzungs kyi sgo dang bcas pa'i shes rab dang nus pa thams cad 'od zer dkar dmar mthing ser ljang khu'i dbyibs can du bsdus nas/ rang gi gnas lnga'i 'jam dbyangs gyi ngo bo phyag mtshan la thim par bsam la rlung 'dzin/ des rang bzhin ye shes lnga dang ldan cing*/ 'chad rtsod rtsom 'dzin mi brjed pa'i gzungs dang bcas pa'i shes rab kyi sgo dang nus pa rnams thim par bsgom la rlung bzung*/ des rang nyid ye shes lnga dang ldan cing*/ 'chad rtsod rtsom 'dzin mi brjed pa'i gzungs dang bcas pa'i shes rab kyi snang ba rgyas shing*/ 'jam dbyangs kyi go 'phang mngon du byas par bsgom mo/ /

In his crown, throat, and heart centers are the syllables oṁ, āḥ, and hūṁ, from which light radiates, inviting the wisdom deity, identical to himself, who dissolves into you. Again, consider that the buddhas of the five families are invited and bestow empowerment, and that you are crowned by Vairochana. In each of the lord’s five centers—crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret center—in the midst of spheres of rainbow-colored light, upon a lotus and moon, is a precious volume of the scriptures, marked with a sword of wisdom blazing with fire, the handle [marked with] the syllable dhīḥ. The sword is standing on top of the volume, pointing upward. In the crown center, the sword of wisdom is white, and similarly red in the throat center, blue in the heart center, yellow in the navel center, and green in the secret center; and each is marked with a white, red, blue, yellow, or green syllable dhīḥ. From them, light radiates, venerating all the buddhas of the ten directions with clouds of offerings and making the wisdom of their body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities shine ever brighter. It touches all sentient beings, dispelling all the darkness of their ignorance and purifying the five poisons; they are brought to the level of the five families of Mañjushrī. Consider that the light of the five gnoses grows. Keep this in mind as you breathe out. As you breathe in, consider that the blessings of the body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas present as the five families of Mañjushrī, along with their gnosis and qualities; their knowledge, love, and power; and all the wisdom and power of their teaching, debating, and composing, together with their unforgetting powers of retention—all these are gathered in the form of white, red, blue, yellow, and green rays of light {386} and dissolve into the attributes in your own five centers, which are Mañjushrī by nature. Hold the breath, considering that they have the nature of the five gnoses and that the power of the wisdom of teaching, debating, and composing, along with unforgetting memory, dissolves, as you [continue to] hold the breath. Consider that, as a result, you yourself have the five forms of gnosis, and the light of the wisdom of teaching, debating, and composing, along with unforgetting memory, increases, and you realize the level of Mañjushrī.

mthar ni snod bcud rang la bsdu/ thig le dang phyag mtshan la yang mas rim gyis spyi bor thim/ rang lus kyang spyi bo'i phyag mtshan la thim/ de 'ja' 'od du yal nas/ nam mkha' gang bar bsam la dmigs med kyi ngang la bzhag go / de ni gsung longs skur mngon du byed pa'i khrid do/ /

At the end, consider that the world and its inhabitants dissolve into you. The spheres and attributes dissolve in turn from the bottom into the crown center. Your own body too dissolves into the attributes in the crown, which vanish into rainbow light, filling space. Rest in the state of nonconceptuality. This is the instruction on realizing speech as the body of perfect enjoyment.
gsum pa ni/
4. Instructions on the Deity’s Mind

mngon byang lngas/ rang nyid 'jam dbyangs gsal bar bsgom/ de yongs su gyur pa las/ pad nyi ro'i steng du/ rang nyid rdo rje 'jigs byed sku mdog mthing nag zhal gcig phyag gnyis/ zhabs g.yas brkyang g.yon bskum pa/ mi mgo dang rus pas brgyan pa/ ling ga gyen la 'greng ba/ gsus khyim che ba/ phyag gnyis thugs khar gri gug thod khrag bsnol thabs su 'dzin pa/ zhal ma he rab tu khros pa'i gdong pa can/ ljags 'dril zhing mche ba gtsigs pa/ spyan gsum dmar zhing g.yo ba/ rwa rnon po sngo zangs zangs pa la rus pa'i rgyan drug khrol ba/ dbu skra khams ser gyen du 'khyil pa'i dbus su/ 'jam dbyangs zhal gser gyi mdog can zhi ba'i tshul can/ sku stod la glang chen gyi stod g.yogs can sbrul nag rab tu 'jigs pas se ral khar brgyan cing*/ mi mgo lnga bcus do shal/ thod skam lnga dang rin po ches dbu la brgyan pa/ gzhan yang rin po che dang rus pa'i rgyan drug gis brgyan pa/ ha ha dang hU~M hU~M gi gad rgyangs 'brug ltar sgrogs shing*/ srid pa gsum po skad cig gis 'jigs par byed pa'i bdag nyid du bsgom par bya'o/ /

With the five factors of awakening, visualize yourself clearly as Mañjushrī. Through his being transformed, visualize yourself on a lotus, sun, and corpse as Vajrabhairava, with dark-blue body and one face and two arms. His right leg is stretched out, his left leg bent. He is adorned with human heads and bones. His phallus is erect, his belly distended. He has his two hands crossed at the level of his heart, holding a curved knife and skull cup full of blood. His head is the extremely wrathful head of a buffalo. He is rolling his tongue and baring his canine teeth. His three red eyes flash. His sharp horns are of blue copper, rattling with the six bone ornaments. In the middle of his upward-swirling, yellowish-red hair is the golden-faced Mañjushrī, {387} in peaceful form. On the upper part of his body he is wearing an elephant skin, and he is adorned with a vicious black serpent as a shoulder belt. He wears a long necklace of fifty human heads and has a crown of jewels and five skulls. As well as these, he is adorned with the six jewel and bone ornaments. His roars of laughter—ha ha and hūṁ hūṁ—resound like thunder. Visualize him as the great being who, in a single instant, terrifies the three worlds.

de'i spyi mgrin snying kha lte ba gsang gnas lngar pad nyi'i steng du/ oM AHhU~M trAM hrIHlnga zhu ba las byung ba'i bcom ldan 'das gti mug gshin rje gshed dkar po spyi bor/ 'dod chags gshin rje gshed dmar po mgrin par/ zhe sdang gshin rje gshed nag po snying kha/ ser sna gshin rje gshed ser po lte ba/ phrag dog gshin rje gshed ljang khu gsang gnas rnams su bskyed de/ de dag gtso bo'i cha lugs ji lta ba bzhin la/ phyag g.yas pa rnams kyis 'khor los mtshan pa'i gri gug dang*/ de bzhin du pad+ma/ rdo rje dang*/ nor bu/ rgya gram gyis mtshan pa'i gri gug 'dzin par bsgom pa'i snying khar pad nyi'i steng du/ 'khor lo/ pad+ma/ rdo rje/ nor bu/ ral gri lnga/ oM AHhU~M trAM hrIHlngas mtshan pa las/ 'od zer dkar dmar ser ljang khu lnga 'phros/ phyogs bcu'i sangs rgyas sras bcas mchod/ sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi mthu stobs rgyas par byas/ slar phyogs bcu'i rigs drug rnams la phog / rigs drug gi gti mug / 'dod chags/ zhe sdang*/ nga rgyal/ phrag dog lnga sbyangs/ gti mug gshin rje gshed dang*/ 'dod chags gshin rje gshed dang*/ zhe sdang gshin rje gshed dang/ nga rgyal gshin rje gshed dang*/ phrag dog gshin rje gshed kyi go 'phang la bkod/ chos dbyings ye shes/ sor rtogs/ me long*/ mnyam nyid/ bya grub ye shes mngon du byas par bsgom la rlung phyir gtong*/ tshur bsdus pa'i tshe/ de dag gi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi byin rlabs thams cad sku lnga ye shes mkhyen brtse mthu stobs thams cad/ 'od zer dkar dmar mthing ser ljang khu'i dbyibs can du bsdus nas/ spyi mgrin snying kha lte ba gsang gnas lngar thim par bsam la/ rang la sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las sku lnga ye shes mkhyen brtse nus pa mthu stobs thams cad kyi byin rlabs zhugs pas/ rang nyid gshin rje gshed rigs lnga'i go 'phang mngon du gyur par bsgom la rlung bum pa can bzung skabs su mtshan sngags sam/ oM ya ma rA dza hU~M phaT/ oM hrIHSh+TiHwi kr-i tA nan hU~M phaT/ ces snying po'am/ sngags ring yang bgrang ngo gsungs/

In his five centers—crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret center—upon lotus and sun, are respectively the five syllables oṁ, āḥ, hūṁ, trāṃ, and hrīḥ. These melt and appear as the lord White Yamāntaka, slayer of bewilderment, in the crown; Red Yamāntaka, slayer of attachment, in the throat; Black Yamāntaka, slayer of aversion, in the heart; Yellow Yamāntaka, slayer of miserliness, in the navel; and Green Yamāntaka, slayer of jealousy, in the secret center. Their appearance and attributes are similar to those of the main deity. Visualize each of them holding in their right hand a curved knife marked respectively with a wheel, lotus, vajra, jewel, and crossed vajra. In each of their heart centers are a lotus and sun, on which are the five attributes—respectively wheel, lotus, vajra, jewel, and sword—marked with the five syllables oṁ, āḥ, hūṁ, trāṃ, and hrīḥ. From these, rays of white, red, blue, yellow, and green light emanate, making offerings to the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the ten directions and enhancing the power of their bodies, voices, minds, qualities, and activities. After that, the rays touch the six classes of beings in the ten directions, purifying the bewilderment, attachment, aversion, pride, and jealousy of the six realms and {388} bringing them to the level of Yamāntaka the slayer of bewilderment, Yamāntaka the slayer of attachment, Yamāntaka the slayer of aversion, Yamāntaka the slayer of pride, and Yamāntaka the slayer of jealousy. Consider that they realize the gnosis of the expanse of reality, all-discerning gnosis, mirrorlike gnosis, the gnosis of equality, and all-accomplishing gnosis. As you do so, breathe out. When you breathe in, consider that all the blessings of their body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, and the five buddha bodies, gnoses, knowledge, love, and power are all gathered in the form of white, red, blue, yellow, and green rays of light, which then dissolve into your crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret center. All the blessings of body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, and of the five buddha bodies, gnoses, knowledge, love, and power, enter you. Consider that you realize the level of the five families of Yamāntaka and hold the vase breath. From time to time, it has been taught, you should recite the name mantra or the essence mantra (oṁ yama rāja hūṁ phaṭ oṁ hrīḥ ṣṭiḥ vi kṛtā na na hūṁ phaṭ) or the long mantra.

mthar gsang gnas kyi las kyi gshin rje gshed lte bar thim/ de snying gar thim/ de mgrin par thim/ de spyi bor thim/ de nam mkha' la 'ja' yal ba ltar/ gsal stong mtha' dbus med pa/ skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral ba nyi ma phyed kyi nam mkha' g.ya' dag pa ltar/ / gsal stong spros pa thams cad dang bral ba'i ngang la sems ma bcos par mnyam par bzhag par bya'o/ / de ni thugs 'jigs byed rigs lnga bsgom pa'i khrid kyi rim pa'o/ /

At the end, the action Yamāntaka in the secret center dissolves into the one in the navel center. It in turn dissolves into that in the heart center, which dissolves into the throat center, which dissolves into the crown center. That one vanishes like a rainbow in space. Settle in meditative equipoise with the mind free of contrivance, in the state of clarity-emptiness, without center or circumference, free of arising, ceasing, and staying, as pure as the sky at noon, clarity-emptiness devoid of all elaborations. This is the graded instruction on the mind, meditating on the five families of Bhairava.
gnyis pa
B. Instructions on the Perfection Stage
don dam rdzogs pa'i rim pa la bzhi ste/ zhi gnas/ lhag mthong*/ zung 'jug / 'pho ba/ bar do'o/ /
The ultimate perfection stage {389} is divided into four parts: (1) sustained calm; (2) profound insight and their union; (3) transference; and (4) the intermediate state.
dang po
1. Sustained Calm
zhi gnas la yang don gsum ste/ mtshan ma la brten pa'i zhi gnas dang*/ rtog pa la sems gtad pa'i zhi gnas dang*/ rtog med du 'jog pa'i zhi gnas dang gsum mo/ /

Sustained calm is treated under three sections: (1) sustained calm making use of conceptual attributes; (2) sustained calm focusing on conceptual thoughts; and (3) sustained calm settling in [a state] without conceptual thoughts.
dang po
a. Sustained Calm Making Use of Conceptual Attributes
['di] la gnyis te/ phyi la sems bzung ba dang*/ nang la sems bzung ba'o/ /
Sustained calm making use of conceptual attributes is divided into two parts: (1) holding the mind on an object outside and (2) holding the mind on an object inside.
dang po
i. Holding the Mind on an Object Outside
['di] la gnyis te/ ma dag pa dang dag pa'o/ /
This is divided into two aspects: (1) impure and (2) pure.
dang po ni/
A) Holding the Mind on an Impure Object

lus rnam snang gi chos bdun dang ldan par byas la/ rang gi mdun du/ ka ba/ bum pa/ mar me/ shing bu/ rde'u la sogs pa gang mthong ba'i mtshan ma zhig la/ lus gnad lta stangs dang bcas pas sems bzung*/ de la yengs su yang mi 'jug / rtog par yang mi 'gyed par/ de thog tu lhod de glod la ma bcos par rtog med du bzhag / de la byings rgod byung na steng 'og dang g.yas g.yon du sems 'dzin pa'ang shes par bya'o/ /

Adopt the seven-point posture of Vairochana and hold the mind on anything with attributes that you can see—a pillar, vase, lamp, stick, pebble, or whatever—all the while maintaining the right physical posture and gaze. Without getting distracted or getting involved in thoughts, settle the mind on it without conceptual thoughts, in an uncontrived, relaxed state. Should wildness or dullness occur, you should know how to focus the mind up or down or right or left.
gnyis pa
B) Holding the Mind on a Pure Object

dag pa rgyal ba'i sku la sems 'dzin pa ni/ rang gi mdun du 'jam dbyangs kyi sku gzugs bzhag pa'am/ med na bsgom la/ de la rtog pa yang mi spro/ yengs su yang mi 'jug / de thog tu ma yengs tsam du glod nas 'jog pa ni dag pa rgyal ba'i sku la sems 'dzin pa'o/ /

For this one holds the mind on a buddha image. In front of you place an image of Mañjushrī or, if you do not have one, visualize him. Do not get scattered in thoughts or involved in distraction. To settle the mind on it in a relaxed way, without any distraction, hold the mind on a pure object, an image of a buddha.
gnyis pa
ii. Holding the Mind on an Object Inside
nang na sems 'dzin pa la gnyis/ ma dag pa dang dag pa'o/ /
Holding the mind on an object inside has two aspects: (1) impure and (2) pure.
dang po
A) Holding the Mind on an Impure Object
ma dag pa thig le la sems bzung ba ni/ rang gi snying khar thig le dud kha 'od zer 'phro ba sran 'bru tsam zhig bsgom la/ de la yengs su yang mi 'jug rtog pa yang mi 'gyed par sems bzung ngo*/ /

This consists of holding the mind on a sphere. Visualize in your heart center a pea-sized, smoke-colored sphere, emanating rays of light. Hold the mind on it without getting distracted or involved in thoughts.
gnyis pa
B) Holding the Mind on a Pure Object

dag pa rgyal ba'i sku la sems bzung ba ni/ rang gi snying khar pad nyi'i steng du 'jam dbyangs sku tshon gang ba la sems bzung ngo*/ / de la yengs su yang mi 'jug rtog pa yang mi 'gyed par ma yengs tsam du sems bzung ngo*/ /

This {390} consists of concentrating on the form of a buddha. Hold the mind on a thumb-sized form of Mañjushrī on top of a lotus and sun disk in your heart center. Without wandering or getting involved in thoughts, concentrate on it without any distraction.
gnyis pa rtog pa la sems 'dzin pa ni/
b. Sustained Calm Focusing on Conceptual Thoughts

rnam par rtog pa thol gyis skyes pa'i dus ngos bzung nas/ rtog med kyi mig gis lhang lhang bltas las/ 'dzin med du zhig nas/ rang rig gsal stong yul med du gsal gsal 'char bar 'gyur/ rnam rtog gang skyes pa'i ngo bo la gtad nas/ rang ngo rang gis shes par byas la bskyang ngo*/ / de ni rtog pa la sems bzung ba'o/ /

When a thought suddenly arises, recognize it and look at it clearly with the eye devoid of concepts. By this means, you will destroy it without grasping, and natural awareness, clear and empty, devoid of object, will vividly arise. Focusing on the nature of any thought that arises, recognize your own nature and preserve that state. This is concentrating on conceptual thoughts.
gsum pa/ mi rtog pa la sems bzung ba ni/
c. Sustained Calm Settling in [a State] without Conceptual Thoughts

lus rnam snang gi chos bdun dang ldan par byas la/ mig nam mkhar gtad de/ 'das ma 'ongs da ltar gyi rtog pa'i rgyu 'grul thams cad rbad chod la gtong la/ yid la ci yang mi bsams par stong gsal mtha' dbus med par/ sems nyid ma bcos pa rtog med du gsal le hrig ge par mnyam par bzhag par bya'o/ / des bde gsal mi rtog pa'i zhi gnas kyi ting nge 'dzin skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

Adopt the seven-point posture of Vairochana and gaze into space. Cutting off all thought movements related to the past, present, and future, without thinking of anything, rest in meditative equipoise in the state of clarity-emptiness, without extremes or middle, the uncontrived nature of the mind free of concepts, vivid and awake. This will give rise to the concentration of the sustained calm of bliss, clarity, and absence of thought.
gnyis pa
2. Profound Insight
lhag mthong la don gsum ste/
Profound insight is treated under three headings:
dang po rgyu'i lhag mthong sems la rnam par brtag cing dpyad pa ni/
a. Causal Profound Insight: Examining the Mind

bdag gi sems 'di gang nas byung zhing gang du gnas/ gang du 'gro bar 'gyur zhes skye 'gag gnas gsum gyi ngo bo la brtag cing*/ 'byung ba lnga rang lus la skyes sam 'chi'am snyam du brtag gzhan yang sems la kha dog dkar dmar sngo ser ljang khu la sogs pa'i kha dog yod pa zhig gam/ 'on te med pa zhig snyam du brtag cing dpyad/ gang du bdag gi sems ni sa chu me rlung nam mkha'i dbyibs sam/ zlum po/ gru bzhi/ zla gam/ gru gsum/ nar mo/ 'jong mo la sogs pa'i dbyibs su grub pa zhig yin nam/ gcig yin nam/ du ma yin snyam du brtag / sems las rnam par rtog pa gzhan cig yin nam/ 'on te rnam par rtog pa sems yin zhes brtag / gzhan yang phyi rol gyi snang ba las sems byung ngam/ 'on te sems las phyi rol gyi snang ba byung snyom du brtag cing dpyad/ slar brtag mkhan gyi sems la yang sems kyis brtag cing dpyad/ sems de nyid yod pa zhig gam/ 'on te med pa zhig gsal ba zhig gam/ 'on te mi gsal ba zhig / bde ba zhig gam 'on te sdug bsngal ba zhig / rtag pa zhig gam 'on te mi rtag pa zhig / snang ba zhig gam 'on te mi snang ba zhig / rig pa zhig gam 'on te ma rig pa zhig / bdag yod pa zhig gam bdag med pa zhig ces brtag cig dpyad du gzhug go / de'i tshe sems kyi ngo bo skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral ba/ ngo bo stong pa nyid nam mkha' lta bu/ rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba/ rig pa 'gag med cir yang 'char zhing snang ba 'di thams cad skye ba med par ro mnyam/ gnas pa med pa dang 'gag pa med par ro mnyam zhing*/ brtag cing dpyad pas gsal rig snang stong gnyis dbyer med pa blo 'das nam mkha' lta bu'i don mthong nas/ de kho na nyid do zhes gzhi lam 'bras bu'i yon tan thams cad sems nyid rtogs pa'i steng na tshang bar ngo sprad/

Examine the essential nature of the mind’s arising, ceasing, and staying, asking yourself, From where has this mind of mine arisen? Where does it stay? Where will it cease? Examine and check, asking yourself, Has it arisen from the five elements or from my own body? Does it dwell there? Will it die there? Check further: Does the mind have a color—white, red, blue, yellow, or green? Or is it colorless? {391} Was this mind of mine produced with a shape—the form of earth, water, fire, wind, or space, or round, square, semicircular, triangular, oblong, or oval, and so on? Check whether it is single or multiple. Are thoughts something other than the mind, or are thoughts the mind? Again, does the mind arise from appearances outside, or do appearances outside arise from the mind? Now, use the mind to examine and analyze the mind that is analyzing. Does that mind exist or not? Check: Is it clear or unclear? Happy or unhappy? Is it permanent or impermanent? Is it visible or invisible? Is it aware or unaware? Is there a self or no self? When you check like this, you will see that the essential nature of the mind is devoid of arising, staying, and ceasing. Its essence is emptiness, like space. It is naturally radiant. It is unobstructed awareness, arising in every kind of way, and all these appearances are of the same taste in being unborn; they are of the same taste in not dwelling and not ceasing. By examining and analyzing, you will see its ultimate nature, which is clarity and awareness, appearance and emptiness inseparable, inconceivable like space. In that way, as you realize the nature of mind, you will be introduced to thatness, in which all the qualities of the ground, path, and result are complete.
gnyis pa lam gyi lhag mthong
b. Path Profound Insight

tha mal gyi shes pa so ma cig car du ngo sprod cing nyams su blangs par bya ba ni/ sems nyid yod med skye 'gag gnas gsum gyi 'dzin pa'i mtha' dang bral ba/ bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa'i mtshan ma'i gzung 'dzin las 'grol zhing*/ mthong bya mthong byed dang bral ba/ ngo bo stong pa rang bzhin gsal ba/ rnam pa 'gag med kyi rig pa du mar gsal cing snang ba/ bcos bslad ma byas pas ma bcos pa/ rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal bas sal le ba/ rang ngo rang gis shes pas hrig ge ba/ rnam rtog gzung 'dzin gyis ma gos pas rjen ne ba/ gang yang mi bsgom pa'i yid byed dang bral ba/ sems nyid la bzo bcos ma byas pas lhug pa/ gang shar ngos bzung dang bral bas 'dzin med/ 'dzin med rang bab tu rang lugs ma bcos par 'jog pa tha mal gyi shes pa/ rnam rtog lu gu rgyud nyid du mi 'jug pas so ma zhes bya ste/ lhag mthong gi dngos gzhir nyams su blang byar ngo sprad do/ /

The fresh, “ordinary” mind[5] is introduced and simultaneously experienced as follows. The nature of mind is devoid of the conceptual extremes of existence and nonexistence, of birth, cessation, and dwelling. It is free of the dualistic concepts of subject and object that grasp at “I” and “mine.” It is beyond something to be seen and something that sees. Its nature is emptiness; its character is luminous clarity. Its manifestation is unobstructed awareness, appearing clearly in a multitude of ways. Unspoiled by fabrication, it is uncontrived. Naturally radiant, it is vividly clear. Recognizing its own nature, it is fully awake. Uncontaminated by dualistic concepts, it is fresh and naked. There being nothing to meditate on, it is free of mental activity. Since there is no modifying or fabricating the nature of the mind, it is a state of relaxation. There is no identifying whatever arises, so it is free of grasping. Since it rests naturally as it is, without grasping or contrivance, it is the ordinary mind. And since it does not continuously indulge in chains of thoughts, it is known as the “fresh” state. This is an introduction to experiencing the main practice of profound insight.
gsum pa/ mthar thug gi lhag mthong zhi lhag zung 'jug tu nyams su blangs par bya ste/
c. Ultimate Profound Insight: Practicing Sustained Calm and Profound Insight Together

sems skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral ba/ gsal rig stong gsum dbyer med pa ma bcos pa'i ngang la 'jog pa ni zhi gnas/ de'i rang bzhin mthong zhing shes pa ni lhag mthong yin/ de yang sems nyid mtha' gnyis dang bral ba ni/ gnas lugs kyi zhi lhag zung 'jug ste/ sems nyid skye ba med pas rtag pa'i mtha' dang bral/ 'gag pa med pas chad pa'i mtha' dang bral/ kha dog dang dbyibs su grub pa med pas rtag pa'i mtha' dang bral/ rtsal snang sna tshogs su shar bas chad pa'i mtha' dang bral/ rang bzhin stong pa nyid du gnas pas rtag pa'i mtha' dang bral/ sna tshogs du mar rig cing gsal bas chad pa'i mtha' dang bral/ des na rtag chad mtshan 'dzin las 'das pa/ gsal rig stong gsum dbyer med pa zung 'jug tu nyams su len pa'i tshul ni/

To settle in the uncontrived state of clarity, awareness, and emptiness inseparable, the mind being devoid of birth, cessation, and dwelling, is sustained calm. To see and recognize the nature of that is profound insight. The nature of mind, free of the two extremes, is the union of sustained calm and profound insight, which is the actual way things are. Since the nature of mind is unborn, it is free of the extreme of eternalism. And since it has no cessation, it is free of the extreme of nihilism. It has no existence as color or shape, so it is free of the extreme of eternalism. Its manifesting power appears in all sorts of ways, so it is free from the extreme of nihilism. {393} Its nature is to dwell as emptiness, so it is free of the extreme of eternalism. Yet it is aware and manifests in multifarious ways, so it is free of the extreme of nihilism. Thus, since it transcends the conceptual extremes of eternalism and nihilism, it is the inseparable union of clarity, awareness, and emptiness. The manner in which this union is experienced is as follows.

sems kyi ngo bo rang gis rang la cer gyis bltas pa'i tshe/ gzung 'dzin mtha' dag dang bral ba/ bde gsal mi rtog pa'i ngang la gnas pa ni zhi gnas yin la/ ngo bo rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag pa mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / bla ma'i mos gus la sems gnas pa ni zhi gnas yin la/ de'i ngo bo stong nyid blo 'das su mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / bskyed rim chu zla lta bu la sems gnas pa zhi gnas/ ngo bo stong nyid skye 'gag gnas gsum dang bral bar mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / sems can thams cad la khyab pa'i byams pa dang snying rje'i dmigs pa la sems gnas pa zhi gnas/ rang bzhin stong pa nyid du mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / thabs bsod nams kyi tshogs sgyu ma lta bu la sems gnas shing de dag rang bzhin med pa stong pa nyid du mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / gzhan du bde ba chen po la sems gnas shing de nyid zhen med stong pa nyid du mthong ba lhag mthong*/ snang ba thams cad sems snang chu zla lta bu snang stong dbyer med la sems gnas shing*/ de dag rten 'brel skye med chu zla ltar mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ / bcos bslad dang bral pa'i rig pa so ma la sems gnas shing*/ bdag med rig stong yul med du mthong ba ni lhag mthong ngo*/ /

When one looks directly at the nature of one’s mind, to rest in a state of bliss, clarity, or absence of thought, devoid of the extremes of an apprehended object and apprehending subject, is sustained calm, while to see that its nature is naturally pure is profound insight. To settle the mind on devotion to the teacher is sustained calm, while to see that the essence of [that state of mind] is emptiness, transcending the intellect, is profound insight. Settling the mind on the visualization in the generation stage, which is like the reflection of the moon in water, is sustained calm, while seeing that its nature is emptiness, beyond birth, cessation, and dwelling, is profound insight. Settling the mind on love and compassion embracing all sentient beings is sustained calm, while seeing that their nature is emptiness is profound insight. Settling the mind on the illusion-like skillful means, the accumulation of merit, [is sustained calm,] while seeing that these are devoid of intrinsic nature and empty is profound insight. Settling the mind on the great bliss is sustained calm; seeing that very state as emptiness, without clinging, is profound insight. Settling the mind on all appearances being the appearances of the mind, on appearance and emptiness inseparable like the reflection of the moon in water [is sustained calm]; seeing that those appearances are interdependent and unborn, like the reflection of the moon in water, is profound insight. Settling the mind on the fresh state of awareness uncontaminated by contrivance [is sustained calm]; seeing that there is no-self, awareness and emptiness, without there being an object,[6] is profound insight. {394}

mdor na chu zla dang me long gi gzugs brnyan dang brag ca ltar snang ba las gzhan pa'i stong pa med/ stong pa las gzhan pa'i snang ba med/ des na snang stong skye med nam mkha' la 'ja' shar ba ltar rtogs nas/ de'i ngang la gnas shing*/ sems nyid rang ngo mthong ba ni lhag mthong ste/ zhi lhag zung 'jug go / de ni sems nyid sku gsum dbyer med kyi ngo bor ye nas bzhugs pa'i don no/ / gnyis 'dzin mtha' dag sangs nas rang rig ye shes rgyas pas/ sangs rgyas zhes te de nyid 'jam dpal gzhon nur gyur pa yang yin te/ dug lnga dag pas 'jam dpal zhes bya'o/ / zhi lhag zug 'jug gi tshogs gnyis kyi dpal dang ldan pas dpal zhes bya la/ gzhon nu'i gzugs sku mtshan dpes brgyan pa dang*/ chos sku la skye 'chi med pa'o/ / de nyid sems nyid sku gsum gyi ngo bor ye nas bzhugs pa'i don te/ de ltar sku gsum ye shes lnga la sogs pa'i lam dang 'bras bus bsdus pa'i yon tan thams cad sems la rdzogs par ngo sprad par bya'o/ /

In short, there is no emptiness that is other than appearances, which are like the reflection of the moon in water, a reflection in a mirror, or an echo. And there are no appearances that are other than emptiness. To realize the unborn nature[7] of appearances and emptiness, like a rainbow appearing in the sky, and to settle in that state [is sustained calm], while seeing one’s own nature, the nature of the mind, is profound insight. This is the union of sustained calm and profound insight. This is the meaning of the nature of the mind being present since the beginning as the nature of the three buddha bodies inseparable. By purifying all dualistic concepts and developing the gnosis of pure awareness, one becomes what is called a buddha, and that state is also Mañjughoṣha—the youthful Mañjushrī. Because he has purified the five poisons, he is called Gentle and Glorious.[8] Because he possesses the glory of the two accumulations of the union of sustained calm and profound insight, he is called Glorious. And he is called Youthful in that his form body is adorned with the major and minor marks, and that the truth body is beyond birth or death. That is the meaning of the nature of mind being present since the beginning as the nature of the three buddha bodies. This is an introduction to the fact that all the qualities included in the path and result, such as those of the three bodies and five gnoses, are complete in the mind.
gsum pa 'chi kha 'pho ba'i gdams ngag
3. Instructions on Transference at the Moment of Death
['di] la gnyis te/ dang po sbyong ba/ gnyis pa las la sbyar ba'o/ /
This has two parts: (1) training and (2) putting transference into practice.
dang po ni
a. Training

rang nyid 'jam dbyangs su bskyed pa'i gnas lngar/ 'jam dbyangs rigs lnga bskyed pa'i 'od zer spro bsdu bya/ de nas gsang gnas kyi 'jam dbyangs thig le lngar khur zhu nas lte ba'i 'jam dbyangs la thim/ de thig le ser por gyur nas snying kha'i 'jam dbyangs la thim/ de sngon por gyur nas mgrin pa'i 'jam dbyangs la thim/ de dmar por gyur nas spyi bo'i 'jam dbyangs la thim/ de dkar por gyur nas tshangs bug rgya mthong kha bye ba lta bu'i nang nas don nas/ steng gi nam mkhar rin po che'i khri pad zla brtsegs pa'i steng du 'jam dbyangs gnas pa'i thugs khar 'khor nas/ slar spyi bo nas mar zhugs nas rang rang gi gnas su 'jam dbyangs rigs lngar gyur par bsgom nas rlung 'dzin cing sbyang ngo*/ /

Visualize yourself as Mañjushrī. In the five centers, visualize the Mañjushrīs of the five families, emanating and reabsorbing rays of light. After that, the Mañjushrī in the secret center melts into a green sphere, which then dissolves into the Mañjushrī in the navel center. That becomes a yellow sphere and dissolves into the Mañjushrī in the heart center. That one becomes a blue sphere and dissolves into the Mañjushrī in the throat center, who in turn becomes a red sphere and dissolves into the Mañjushrī in the crown center. {395} He becomes a white sphere, which is expelled through the aperture of Brahmā as if through an open skylight. There, in the sky above, on top of a precious throne, lotus, and moon disk, one above the other, is Mañjushrī, around whose heart center the white sphere turns. After that, it comes back down through your crown center and, one by one, becomes the five Mañjushrīs in the respective centers. Train in this visualization, holding the breath.
gnyis pa las la sbyar ba ni
b. Putting Transference into Practice

'chi rtags tshang ba'i tshe 'jig rten gyi zhen chags thams cad spang la/ 'jam dbyangs rigs lnga thig le ljang ser sngon po dkar po lngar gyur pa gsang gnas nas yar rim pa ltar/ lte ba snying kha mgrin pa spyi bo'i thig le la thim/ de tshangs bug nas thon nas nam mkhar yal te/ nam mkha'i thams cad 'ja' tshon gyis khrigs kyis khengs par bsam la/ mi dmigs pa'i ngang la bzhag go / de ni 'pho ba 'ja' tshon ma zhes bya'o/ /

When the signs of approaching death are all present, abandon all mundane clinging and attachment. Then visualize the five Mañjushrīs of the buddha families transforming in turn into a green, yellow, blue, red, and white sphere, from the secret center up, and dissolving into spheres in the navel, heart, throat, and crown centers. Expel this last sphere through the aperture of Brahmā and consider that it dissolves into space: the whole of space is filled with dense rainbow-colored light. Settle there in the nonconceptual state. This is what is known as the rainbow transference.
bzhi pa
4. Instructions on the Intermediate State
bar do'i khrid la don gsum ste/
The instructions on the intermediate state (bardo) comprise three parts.
dang po sbyang ba ni/
a. Training

bskyed rdzogs gnyis kyi sgo nas sbyang ba'o/ / de yang 'dun pa ni/ bdag shi ba yin/ 'di bar do yin/ bar do'i lus la bden pa med snyam du nges par byas la/ phyi snod thams cad 'jam dbyangs kyi zhing gi bkod par bsgom/ rang dang sems can thams cad 'jam dbyangs su bsgom/ gnas lngar rigs lnga bskyed la 'od zer spro bsdu'i khrid ltar bsgom/ mthar de dag sgyu ma dang rmi lam chu zla ltar gsal stong skye med blo 'das yid la mi byed pa'i ngang la mnyam par bzhag pa ni rdzogs rim gyi sgo nas sbyang ba'o/ /

Train by means of the generation stage and perfection stage. For this, you should imagine with conviction: “I am dead. This is the bardo. The bardo body has no true existence.” And meditate that the whole world around you is set out as the buddha field of Mañjushrī, and that you yourself and all sentient beings are Mañjushrī. Visualize the five Mañjushrīs in the five centers and practice the instructions on the emanation and reabsorption of light rays. At the end, train in the perfection stage, settling in the state without mental activity, where all is like a magical illusion, a dream, or the reflection of the moon in water—inconceivable, unborn clarity-emptiness. {396}
gnyis pa ni/
b. The Moment of Death

'chi ba'i tshe sa chu la thim pa'i rtags su lus lci/ chu me la thim pa'i rtags su kha sna skam/ me rlung la thim pa'i rtags su drod mtha' nas sdud/ rlung nam mkhar thim pa'i rtags su phyi dbugs chad/ nam mkhar rnam par shes pa la thim pa'i rtags su dar gcig brgyal/ de dag gi skabs su rim pa ltar nang rtags 'char ba ni/ du ba/ smig rgyu/ me khyer/ mar me/ sprin med nam mkha' la sogs 'char bar 'gyur ro/ / de nas pha las thob pa'i byang sems thur du lhung bas dkar lam 'byung*/ ma las thob pa'i rak+ta gyen du 'dril bas dmar lam 'byung*/ snying khar dbu ma'i nang du byang sems dkar dmar nor rgyal gyi rlung dang bcas pa dbu mar zhag gcig bar du bde gsal mi rtog pa'i ngang du gnas par 'gyur te/ de nyid rang ngo shes na skad cig gcig gis rdzogs sangs rgyas par 'gyur ro/ /

During the dying process, the sign that the earth element is dissolving into the water element is that the body feels heavy. The sign that water is dissolving into fire is that one’s mouth and nose dry up. The sign that fire is dissolving into wind is that one’s bodily heat draws in from the extremities. The sign that wind is dissolving into space is that the outer breath ceases. The sign that space is dissolving into consciousness is that one loses consciousness for a while. The inner signs that occur during these stages are respectively the appearance of smoke, a mirage, fireflies, a lamp, and a cloudless sky. After that, the seminal essence obtained from one’s father descends and the white experience occurs. The red essence obtained from the mother is gathered upward and the red experience occurs. The white and red essences together with the dhanaṃjaya wind [are gathered] at the level of the heart within the central channel, and one will remain in a state of bliss, clarity, and no-thought for a day. If one recognizes this as one’s own nature, one will in a single instant attain perfect buddhahood.
gsum pa
c. The Bardo of Becoming

srid pa bar do la 'phos na/ snang ba thams cad 'jam dbyangs kyi zhing gi bkod par bsgom/ bdag dang sems thams cad 'jam dbyangs su bsgom/ bdag gi gnas lngar rigs lnga bkod la 'od zer spro bsdu bya/ sgra thams cad sngags sgrar bsgom/ dran rtog thams cad chos sku skye med du rang ngo shes par bya/ / 'og min nam/ bde ba can du rdzu 'phrul gyis 'gro ba'i 'dun pa yang yang gtad/ der bar dor 'jam dbyangs longs rdzogs pa'i sku 'grub nas/ longs spyod rdzogs pa'i zhing khams 'dzin par 'gyur ro/ /

When you transmigrate into the bardo of becoming, you should meditate that everything you perceive is the display of the buddha field of Mañjushrī. Meditate that you yourself and all sentient beings are Mañjushrī. Emanate and gather back rays of light from the buddhas of the five families in your five centers. Consider that all sounds are the sound of mantra. Recognize all thoughts as the unborn body of truth. Make the repeated aspiration[9] to travel miraculously to the Unexcelled realm, Akaniṣhṭha, or to the Blissful realm, Sukhāvatī. There, in the bardo, you will accomplish Mañjushrī in the body of perfect enjoyment and seize the buddha field of the body of perfect enjoyment. {397}
[III. Conclusion][10]
dge ba'i nor 'dzin rab tu rgyas pa'i mthus/ ut+pal rnam rol sa bcu rab rdzogs nas/ / mtshungs med bcom ldan 'jam dpal dbyangs lta bur/ / bdag kyang 'gro ba'i mgon du 'gyur bar shog /

By the power of increasing in virtue, as if extending the earth, May I complete the tenth level—[rare as the] manifestation of the utpala— And, like the peerless lord Mañjushrī, May I too become a protector of beings.

bcom ldan 'das 'jam dpal dbyangs sku'i khrid kyi rim pa/ shes rab 'phel bar byed pa/ ye shes snang ba rgyan gyi 'khor lo zhes bya ba/ man ngag snyan brgyud du gnas pa la shin tu brjed par phongs pa'i phyir rnal 'byor pa 'od dpag rdo rje yi ger bkod pa rdzogs so// //

This completes the graded instructions of Mañjushrī, the deity related to the enlightened body aspect, entitled The Wheel of Ornaments of the Light of Gnosis That Makes Wisdom Grow.[11] They were maintained in the aural lineage, but the yogi Öpak Dorje wrote them down so that they are not completely forgotten and lost.
dge'o/ /
Virtue!
@#/ /bcom ldan 'das phyag na rdo rje thugs kyi khrid bdud dpung 'joms byed 'od zer rgyas pa bzhugs so/ /
19. THE SPREADING RAYS OF LIGHT THAT VANQUISH THE HORDES OF DEMONS. The Instructions of Lord Vajrapāṇi, the Deity Related to Enlightened Mind[1]

@#/ /mi g.yo gzhan gyis bskyed pa'i yul las 'das/ / dus gsum rgyal ba'i mthu stobs gcig bsdus pa/ / 'gro ba'i 'khrul pa kun 'joms rdo rje 'dzin/ / bla ma gsang 'dzin dang bcas zhabs la 'dud/ / gang du bskyed rdzogs khrid kyi rim pa ni/ / rgyal ba'i bka' dang bla ma'i man ngag rnams/ / brjed pas 'jigs phyir yi ger bkod pa la/ / rdo rje gtum pos bdag rgyud byin gyis rlobs/ /

{400} Immutable, beyond the realm of others’ imagination, Embodiment of the power of past, present, and future conquerors, Vajra holder who destroys all of beings’ confusion—To the teacher together with the Holder of Secrets I bow. The graded instructions on his generation and perfection stages— The words of the Buddha and the teachers’ pith instructions— I will set down in writing, for fear of forgetting them. For this, Vajra Ferocity, please bless my stream of being.

'dir dus gsum sangs rgyas thams cad kyi gsang ba'i snying po bsdus shing mthu stobs kyi pha rol tu phyin pa/ bcom ldan 'das phyag na rdo rje thugs kyi khrid bdud dpung 'joms byed 'od zer rgyas pa 'di la don gsum ste/ sngon 'gro dngos gzhi rjes so/ /

Here are the Spreading Rays of Light That Vanquish the Hordes of Demons, the instructions of Vajrapāṇi, the deity related to enlightened mind, who embodies the essence of the secrets of all the buddhas of the three times and who is the transcendent perfection of their power. These instructions comprise three topics: (1) preliminaries; (2) main practice; and (3) conclusion.
dang po
I. Preliminaries
sngon 'gro la yang gsum ste/ brgyud pa'i byung tshul dang*/ thum mong dang khyad par gyi sngon 'gro'o/ /
The preliminaries are divided into three parts: (1) the history of the lineage of teachers; (2) the common preliminaries; and (3) the specific preliminaries.
dang po ni/
A. History of the Lineage of Teachers

rnal 'byor gyi dbang phyug mi tra dzo ki de nyid kyis/ dur khrod chen po so sa gling du thugs dam lha lnga bsgrub pa ni 'od dpag med/ 'jam dbyangs/ thugs rje chen po/ phyag na rdo rje/ sgrol ma dang lnga'o/ / lha de dag bsgrubs pas/ so so'i zhal bstan nas ting nge 'dzin gyis dbang bskur/ bskyed rdzogs gnyis kyi gdams pa bstan nas rjes su gnang ba ni/ khrid 'di dag gcig brgyud du ston pa dang*/ mi rabs bdun gyi bar bdag cag rnams kyis byin gyis brlabs pa'i gang zag sha stags 'byung ba yin gsungs so/ / dzam b+ha la dang brag lha mgon pos ni mthun rkyen bsgrub pa dang bka' srung yin gsungs so/ / rnal 'byor dbang phyug des phyag na rdo rje la dngos su gsan nas/ slar paN+Di ta shrI pu tra la gnang*/ des rtogs ldan gIrti rat+na la gnang*/ de bdag la'o/ / de dag rnams ni brgyud pa'i byung tshul rnams song ngo*/ /

The lord of yogis Mitrayogin practiced five yidam deities {401} in the great charnel ground of Sosaling: Amitābha, Mañjushrī, the Great Compassionate One, Vajrapāṇi, and Tārā. As result of his accomplishing them, these deities each revealed themselves to him and, through concentration, bestowed empowerment. They taught him the instructions of the generation and perfection stages and authorized him to teach them to a single lineage holder, saying that for seven generations they would all be individuals whom they had blessed. They also said that Jambhala and the protector Draklha would bring about favorable conditions and protect the teachings. The lord of yogis heard these instructions from Vajrapāṇi in person and then bestowed them on paṇḍita Shrīputra. He in turn gave them to Tokden Girti Ratna, who gave them to me. This is how these instructions came down through the lineage.
gnyis pa
B. Common Preliminaries
thun mong gi sngon 'gro la yang don rnam pa bzhi ste/ dal 'byor rnyed par dka' ba/ 'chi ba mi rtag pa/ las rgyu 'bras/ 'khor ba'i nyes dmigs bsgom pa rnams ni gzhan dang mthun no/ /

The common preliminaries consist of four parts: namely, {402} meditation on the difficulty of finding the freedoms and advantages; on death and impermanence; on action, cause and effect; and on the defects of cyclic existence. These are the same as found in other teachings.
gsum pa
C. Specific Preliminaries
khyad par gyi sngon 'gro la'ang bzhi ste/
These specific preliminaries are divided into four.
dang po ci byas byang chub kyi lam du 'gro ba la skyabs 'gro sems skyed kyi khrid ni/
1. Instructions on Going for Refuge and Arousing Bodhichitta, Which Is What Makes Everything One Does Become the Path of Enlightenment

rang gi mdun gyi nam mkhar rin po che du ma las grub pa'i khri mchog tu yangs shing rgya che ba/ lha'i dar sna tshogs kyis khri dag pa can gyi steng du/ pad+ma 'dab ma 'bum ldan gyi lte bar nya rgyas pa'i gdan la/ rang gi rtsa ba'i bla ma rdo rje 'chang gi cha lugs su bzhugs pa la phyogs bcu'i rgyal ba rgya mtshos bskor ba/ mdun du yi dam phyag na rdo rje la yi dam rgyud sde bzhi'i tshogs kyis bskor ba/ g.yas su sangs rgyas shAkya thub pa la sangs rgyas stong rtsa gnyis la sogs sangs rgyas rgya mtshos bskor ba/ rgyab tu yum chen mo la po ti glegs bam gyis bskor ba/ g.yon du byams pa mgon po la theg pa mchog dman gyi dge 'dun rgya mtshos bskor ba/ phyogs mtshams thams cad dpa' po mkha' 'gro sprin 'thibs pa bzhin bzhugs pa/ 'og chos skyong rgya mtsho rnams bzhugs pa/ de dag gi skyabs zhabs na bdag dang mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad tshud par bsam la/ nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad kyi don du phyag na rdo rje'i go 'phang thob par bya snyam du sems bskyed nas/ ma nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad bla ma sangs rgyas rin po che la skyabs su mchi'o/ / zhes sogs skyabs 'gro sems bskyed spyan ras gzigs kyi khrid dang mthun par brjod do/ / mthar skyabs yul de dag 'od du zhu nas rang la thim nas/ de dag gi sku gsung thugs dang rang gi lus ngag yid gsum dbyer med par chu la chu bzhag pa ltar ma bcos pa'i ngang la mnyam par bzhag go /
gnyis pa sdig sgrib myur du dag par byed pa rdo rje sems dpa'i bsgom bzlas kyi khrid ni/
2. Instructions on the Meditation and Recitation of Vajrasattva, Which Enables One to Swiftly Purify One’s Negative Deeds and Obscurations

rang gi spyo bor paM las sna tshogs pad+ma/ a las zla ba'i dkyil 'khor gyi steng du hU~M las rdo rje dkar po rtse lnga pa lte ba hU~M gis mtshan pa/ de las 'od zer 'phros 'phags pa'i tshogs mchod/ sems can gyi don byas tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ bcom ldan 'das rdo rje sems dpa' sku mdog dkar po zhal gcig phyag gnyis pa/ zhabs gnyis rdo rje skyil krung gis bzhugs pa/ phyag g.yas gser gyi rdo rje rtse lnga pa thugs khar gtod de 'dzin pa/ g.yon pa des yu ba byas pa'i dril bu dku la brten pa/ zhal 'dzum pa spyan dkyus ring zhing dbu skra ral pa'i zur phud lnga phyed bcings shing*/ lhag ma'i zar bu rked par sleb pa/ rin po che lngas rtse phran dang snyan cha/ mgul rgyan dag do shal/ dpung rgyan dang phyag gdub dang 'og pags la sogs dar gyi cod pan gyis brgyan pa'i spyo bor oM dkar po/ / mgrin par A dmar po/ snying gar hU~M sngon po las 'od zer 'phros pas/ rang lta bu'i ye shes pa spyan drangs la/ dam tshig pa la dbyer med du thim par bsam pa dzaHhU~M baM hoH zhes brjod/ bcom ldan 'das bdag dang mtha' yas pa'i sems can thams cad la byin gyis brlabs nas sdig sgrib mtha' dag dag par mdzad du gsol lo/ / zhes gsol ba btab pas/ bdud rtsi'i rgyun them bu rdol ba lta bu zhabs kyi mthe bong las babs/ rang gi spyi bo'i tshangs bug nas zhugs/ nad gdon sdig sgrib thams cad dud khu dang sol khu'i rnam par deng nas rkang zhabs rtsa sgo chu sgo nas bud cing*/ sa rim pa dgu'i 'og tu thim zhing*/ lus kyi nang thams cad ye shes kyi bdud rtsis dkar mer gyis gang ba la shes pa gtad nas/ yi ge brgya pa 'don pa'i mthar/ rdo rje sems dpa' 'od du zhu nas rang la thim pas/ rdo rje sems dpa'i sku gsung thugs dang rang gi lus ngag yid gsum chu la chu bzhag gi tshul du/ lus ngag yid gsum ma bcos par bzhag go / de ltar nad gnod sdig sgrib dag pa'i ltas ma byung gi bar du bsgom par bya'o/ /

On the crown of your head visualize a letter paṃ, from which there appears a multicolored lotus, and a letter A, from which a full-moon disk appears. On top of it is the syllable hūṁ, from which appears a white five-pronged vajra marked with the syllable hūṁ. It emanates rays of light, making offerings to the noble ones and benefiting sentient beings. The lights are gathered back, and it transforms into Lord Vajrasattva. He is white, with one face and two arms, and seated with his two legs crossed in the vajra posture. In his right hand he holds a golden five-pronged vajra, pointing toward his heart center. His left hand is resting on his hip, holding a vajra-handled bell. He has a smiling face, with almond eyes. Half of his hair is tied up in five hair knots, and the remaining locks reach down to his waist. He is adorned with a jeweled head ornament, earrings, short necklace, long necklace, armlets, bracelets, belt, and so on, and a silken crown. In his crown center is a white oṁ, in his throat center a red āḥ, and in his heart center a blue hūṁ. From these, rays of light emanate inviting the wisdom deity, who is identical to himself. As you say jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ, consider that the wisdom deity dissolves inseparably into the meditational deity. Then pray: “Lord, bless me and the whole infinity of sentient beings and purify all our negative deeds and obscurations.” {404} As a result of this prayer, a stream of nectar descends from his big toe, gushing out as if unplugged. It enters you through the aperture of Brahmā on the crown of your head. All illnesses, negative forces, negative deeds, and obscurations are forthwith expelled through the soles of your feet and through your anus and urethra, in the form of liquid smoke and liquid charcoal. They dissolve nine levels below the surface of the earth. The whole of your body is completely filled with white wisdom nectar. As you concentrate on this, recite the hundred-syllable mantra. At the end, Vajrasattva melts into light and dissolves into you. With Vajrasattva’s enlightened body, speech, and mind [mingled] with your body, speech, and mind like water poured into water, rest with no contrivance regarding your body, speech, and mind. Train in this way until signs occur that you have purified your illnesses, negative forces, negative deeds, and obscurations.
gsum pa maN+Dal kyi khrid
3. Instructions on the Mandala Practice
['di] la gnyis te/ sgrub pa'i maN+Dal dang mchod pa'i maN+Dal lo/ /
These concern (1) the accomplishment mandala and (2) the offering mandala.
dang po ni/
a. The Accomplishment Mandala

rgyu rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'i maN+Dal gyi steng du/ me tog gi tshom bu lnga bkod la/ lcags ri'i 'khor yug gi dbus su/ rgyu rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'i gling gzhi/ ri bo mchog rab kyi steng du rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'i gzhal yas khang pa gru bzhi sgo bzhi rta babs bang rim tog gi mtshan pa'i dbus su/ pad zla'i steng du bla ma/ mdun du yi dam/ g.yas su sangs rgyas/ rgyab tu dam chos/ g.yon du dge 'dun/ phyogs dang phyogs mtshams su dpa' bo mkha' 'gro chos skyong gi tshogs rnams bzhugs par bsam pa'i spyi bor oM/ mgrin par AH thugs kar hU~M las 'od zer 'phros/ ye shes sems dpa' spyan drangs la dbyer med du thim par bsams pa ni bsgrub pa'i maN+Dal lo/ /

On a mandala made of the five precious materials, set out five piles of flowers. Then visualize the outer ring of iron mountains, and in its center the four continents and Mount Meru, made of the five precious materials, and on top of that the measureless palace, made of the five precious materials. It is square, with four gates, pediments, and terraces, and decorated with a top ornament. In its center is a lotus and moon disk, on which is seated one’s teacher. In front is the yidam deity; to the right, the Buddha; at the rear, the sacred dharma; and to the left, the sangha, with, in the cardinal and intermediate directions, hosts of ḍākas, ḍākinīs, and dharma protectors. In each one’s crown center is a white syllable oṁ, in the throat center a red āḥ, and in the heart center a blue hūṁ. From these, rays of light emanate inviting the wisdom deities, {405} who dissolve inseparably into them. This constitutes the accomplishment mandala.
gnyis pa mchod pa'i maN+Dal ni/
b. The Offering Mandala

maN+Dal gnyis yod na logs su bshams/ gnyis med na sgrub pa'i maN+Dal mdun gyi nam mkhar btegs la/ slar mchod pa'i maN+Dal ni/ oM badz+ra b+hU mi AHhU~M/ dbang chen gser gyi sa gzhi/ oM badz+ra re khe AHhU~M/ phyi lcags ri 'khor yug / dbus su rin po che sna lnga las grub pa'i ri bo mchog rab/ shar lus 'phags po zla gam las shel las grub pa ma rmos pa'i lo tog gis brgyan pa/ lho 'dzam bu gling sog kha baiDUr+Ya las grub pa nor bus brgyan pa/ nub ba lang spyod zlum po pad+ma rA ga las grub pa 'dod 'jo'i bas brgyan pa/ byang sgra mi snyan gru bzhi gser las grub pa dpag bsam shing gis brgyan pa/ gling phran brgyad kyis bskor ba/ shar lho gnyis kyi nam mkhar me shel las grub pa'i nyi ma/ nub byang gnyis kyi bar na chu shel las grub pa'i zla ba/ byang shar du dus me/ lho nub tu sgra gcan/ ri rab kyi steng du 'khor lo rin po che/ nor bu rin po che/ blon po rin po che/ / btsun mo rin po che/ glang po rin po che/ rta mchog rin po che/ dmag dpon rin po che/ rgyal srid sna bdun/ rin po che'i gdugs/ phyogs las rnam par rgyal ba'i rgyal mtshan/ gser las grub pa'i nya/ rab tu mdzes pa'i pad+mo/ chos kyi sgra dbyangs sgrogs pa'i bdud/ gter chen po'i bum pa/ dgos 'dod 'byung ba'i dpal be'u/ chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba'i 'khor lo ste/ bkra shis rtags brgyad/ me tog ma/ bdug spos ma/ snang gsal ma/ dri chab ma ste phyi'i sgeg mo bzhi/ sgeg mo ma/ phreng ba ma/ glu ma/ gar ma ste/ nang gi sgeg mo bzhi/

If you have two mandala plates, arrange them separately. If not, [visualize the deities] up in the air in front of you. Then, for the offering mandala: oṁ vajra bhumi āḥ hūṁ—corresponding to the mighty golden ground. oṁ vajra rekhe āḥ hūṁ—corresponding to the outer ring of iron mountains, in the middle of which is Mount Meru, made of the five kinds of precious materials. In the east is Pūrvavideha, which is semicircular and made of crystal, embellished with uncultivated crops of grain. In the south is Jambudvīpa, which is trapezoidal and made of beryl, embellished with jewels. In the west is Godānīya, which is circular and made of ruby, embellished with bountiful cows. In the north is Uttarakuru, which is square and made of precious gold, embellished with wish-fulfilling trees. They are flanked by the eight subcontinents. In the sky to the southeast is the sun, made of fire crystal. To the northwest is the moon, made of water crystal. To the northeast is Ketū, and to the southwest is Rāhu. Above Mount Meru are the seven attributes of royalty, namely the precious wheel, the precious jewel, the precious minister, the precious queen, the precious elephant, the marvelous and precious horse, and the precious general; the eight auspicious symbols, namely the precious parasol, the banner of universal victory, the fish made of gold, the utterly beautiful lotus, the conch that proclaims the melodious sound of the dharma, the vase of great treasure, the eternal knot that fulfills all needs and desires, and the wheel that turns the wheel of the teachings; {406} the four outer offering maidens (the lady of flowers, the lady of incense, the lady of lamps, and the lady of perfume); and the four inner offering maidens—the lady of charm, the lady of garlands, the lady of song, and the lady of dance.

mdor na lha dang mi'i longs spyod ma tshang ba med pa du mas kun tu gang zhing lus longs spyod dang bcas pa 'di dag bla ma dkon mchog mchod 'os rgya mtsho'i tshogs dang bcas pa rnams la 'bul lo/ / thugs rjes 'gro ba'i don du bzhes su gsol/ / bzhes nas byin gyis brlab tu gsol/ / ces nyi shu rtsa gcig gam bdun nam bcu'i bar du maN+Dal phul la bsod nams kyi tshogs bsags pa'o/ / de dag gis tshogs gnyis rdzogs par byed pa maN+Dal gyi khrid song ngo*/ /

In short, everything is completely filled with the many riches of gods and humans, with nothing missing, and these, along with [one’s own] body and possessions, one offers to the teacher and the Three Jewels, along with infinite objects worthy of veneration. Saying, “Accept this with compassion for the sake of beings, and, accepting it, grant your blessings, I pray,” make this offering twenty-one, seven, or ten times. In this way, gather the accumulation of merit. This completes the instruction on the mandala, which enables one to complete the two accumulations.
bzhi pa byin rlabs myur du 'jug par byed pa bla ma'i rnal 'byor gyi khrid
4. Instructions on the Guru Yoga, Which Enables One to Swiftly Receive Blessings
['di] la bzhi ste/
The guru yoga is divided into four parts.
dang po bla ma spyi bor bsgom pa ni/
a. Visualizing the Teacher above the Crown of One’s Head

rang gi spyi bo'i gtsug tu rin po che du ma las kun nas grub pa'i khri yangs shing rgya che ba'i steng du sna tshogs pad+ma 'bum ldan dang*/ zla ba nya rgyas pa'i steng du/ rang gi rtsa ba'i bla ma rdo rje 'chang gi cha lugs/ de'i spyi bor rtogs ldan gIrti rat+na/ de'i spyi bor shrI pu tra/ de'i spyi bor grub thob mi tra dzo ki/ sku mdog dkar po g.yas gser gyi DA ma ru sgra dang bcas pa g.yon dngul gyi dril bu snyan pa'i sgra dbyangs dang bcas pa/ ras dkar po'i smad g.yogs can/ rus pa'i rgyan drug gsol zhing*/ spyan nam mkhar gzigs pa/ de'i spyi gtsug tu phyag na rdo rje zhal gcig phyag gnyis pad zla'i steng na skyil krung gis bzhugs pa/ g.yas rdo rje dang g.yon dril bu 'dzin pa/ dar dang rin po ches brgyan pa'i spyi bor oM dkar po/ mgrin par AHdmar po/ thugs kar hU~M sngon po las 'od zer dkar dmar mthing gsum 'phros/ phyogs bcu'i bla ma yi dam/ sangs rgyas/ chos/ dge 'dun/ mkha' 'gro chos skyong rnams 'od zer gyis bsdus nas/ bla ma rnams kyi sku lus kyi stod smad rnams la thim pas/ bla ma kun 'dus kyi bdag nyid du gyur par bsgom/

Above the crown of your head visualize a vast, spacious throne made entirely of many precious materials, and on it a multicolored lotus with a hundred thousand petals and a full-moon disk. On that is one’s root teacher appearing as Vajradhara. Above his head is Tokden Girti Ratna, above his head Shrīputra, and above his head the siddha Mitrayogin, who is white in color, playing a gold ḍāmaru in his right hand, and ringing a sweetly sounding silver bell in his left. He has a lower garment of white cotton and is wearing the six bone ornaments. His eyes are gazing into space. Above his head is Vajrapāṇi, who has one face and two arms and is seated cross-legged on a lotus and moon. {407} In his right hand he holds a vajra, in his left a bell. He is adorned with silks and jewel ornaments. In [each one’s] crown center is a white oṁ, in the throat center a red āḥ, and in the heart center a blue hūṁ. From these, white, red, and blue rays of light emanate. The light rays gather back the teachers and yidam deities of the ten directions; the Buddha, dharma, and sangha; and the ḍākinīs and protectors. They dissolve into the upper and lower bodies of the teachers, who become the embodiments of all teachers.
gnyis pa ni/
b. [Offerings...]
bstod pa dang*/ yan lag bdun pa dang*/ maN+Dal kyang 'bul lo/ /
Making the Offerings of Praise, the Seven Branches, and the Mandala
gsum pa ni/
c. Praying
'gro ba nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i sems can thams cad/ bla ma sangs rgyas rin po che la gsol ba 'debs so/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i mthar/ 'dod pa'i don la gsol ba gdab/
Recite the prayer, “All beings, as numerous as the sky is vast, pray to the Teacher, precious Buddha,” and so on. At the end, pray for the fulfillment of wishes.
bzhi pa ni/
d. [Receiving Empowerment]

bla ma'i spyi bo/ mgrin pa/ snying kha rnams su oM AHhU~M/ dkar dmar mthing gsum las 'od zer byung nas rang gi lus ngag yid gsum la phog / sgrib pa gsum dag / sku gsung thugs kyi dbang thob par bsam/ slar yang oM AHhU~M gsum las bdud rtsi'i rgyun dkar dmar mthing gsum byung bas lus kyi nang gang bas/ sku gsung thugs kyi dbang thob cing mthar yig 'bru gsum gdan dang bcas pa chad nas rang gi gnas gsum du thim pas/ dbang gsum brten par byas par bsgom/ de nas brgyud pa'i bla ma 'od du zhu nas gcig la gcig thim nas thams cad rtsa ba'i bla ma la thim/ de 'od du zhu nas rang la thim pas rang gi lus ngag yid gsum dang bla ma'i sku gsung thugs 'bral med du phrugs kyis 'dres nas/ chu la bzhag pa ltar lus ngag yid gsum ma bcos pa'i ngang du rang babs su glod la mnyam par bzhag pa ni/ bla ma'i rnal 'byor mthar thug go / de dag gis khyad par gyi sngon 'gro song nas/

From the white oṁ, red āḥ, and blue hūṁ in the teacher’s crown, throat, and heart centers, rays of light issue forth and touch your own body, speech, and mind. Consider that your obscurations are purified and that you receive the empowerments of the enlightened body, speech, and mind. Again, from the three syllables oṁ, āḥ, and hūṁ streams of white, red, and blue nectar issue forth, filling your body, so that you receive the empowerments of the enlightened body, speech, and mind. At the end, the three syllables and their associated attributes[4] shoot out and dissolve into your three centers. Consider that in this way the three empowerments are sealed. After that, the lineage teachers, one by one, melt into light and dissolve into each other, all dissolving into your root teacher. The latter melts into light and dissolves into you. Your body, speech, and mind mingle inseparably with the teacher’s enlightened body, speech, and mind, {408} like water poured into water. Rest in meditative equipoise, naturally relaxed with your body, speech, and mind in a state free of contrivance. To do so is the ultimate guru yoga. Having gone through the specific preliminaries with these [we come now to the main practice].
II. Main Practice[5]
gsum pa
A. Instructions on the Generation Stage
bskyed rim gyi khrid la gsum ste/
The generation stage comprises three sections.
dang po bskyed pa'i rim pa dngos ni/
1. Actual Generation Stage

tshad med bzhi dang ldan pas a mr-i tas bgegs bskrad/ swa b+hA was stong par sbyang*/ stong pa'i ngang las 'og gzhi sangs rgyas kyi zhing lcang lo can du gyur pa'i dbus su/ pad nyi'i steng du hU~M las 'od zer 'phros/ 'og rdo rje'i sa gzhi/ sra brtan mi 'gyur ba/ phyogs mtshams rdo rje'i ra ba/ drwa ba/ steng rdo rje'i gur dang bla bre/ phyi rol gnam lcags las grub pa'i 'khor lo rtsibs stong dang ldan pas bskor ba/ de'i phyi rol tu mtshon cha bsnol ba'i tshad dang*/ me ri 'bar ba'i srung 'khor yangs par bsgom/

Keeping the four boundless attitudes in mind, banish the obstacle makers with the amṛta mantra. Purify everything with the svabhāva mantra. From the state of emptiness the earth becomes the Willow Leaf buddha field. In its center, upon a lotus and sun, is the syllable hūṁ, radiating light. This gives rise to the ground of vajras below—hard, firm, and immutable; all around is the vajra fence and lattice; above is the vajra tent and canopy. This is surrounded by a thousand-spoked wheel made of meteoric iron. Outside that is a forest of sharp weapons and a blazing mountain of fire. This is the visualization of the protection circle.

dbus su b+h+rU~M las gzhal yas kyi khang pa gru bzhi sgo bzhi rgyan rta babs dang bcas pa'i dbus su paM las sna tshogs pad+ma 'dab ma bcu dang dbus su raM las nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor bcu gcig gi steng du hU~M las rdo rje sngon po hU~M gis mtshan pa de las 'od 'phros/ 'phags pa'i tshogs mchod/ gdug pa can thams cad tshar bcad/ sangs rgyas kyi bstan pa la bkod/ tshur 'dus yongs su gyur pa las/ rang nyid phyag na rdo rje nam mkha'i mdog ltar sngo ba zhal gcig phyag gnyis zhabs gnyis gyad kyi 'dor stabs kyis bzhugs pa/ stag lpags rlon pa'i sham thabs can/ gsus khyim che zhing sku stod rgyas pa/ phyag g.yas gser gyi rdo rje rtse dgu pa nam mkhar gdengs pa/ g.yon pas sdigs mdzub dang bcas pa'i dril bu thugs khar 'dzin pa/ zhal gdangs shing mche ba bzhi gtsigs pa/ ljags 'dril ba/ khro gnyer bsdus shing spyan gsum bskal pa'i me 'od 'phro ba/ sma ra smin ma 'khyug cing ral pa dkar ser gyen du 'khyil ba/ sku che la yan lag dang nying lag rags pa/ rgyal rigs dkar khras dbu la brgyan pa/ rje rigs ser khras snyan cha byas pa/ bram ze dmar khras mgul rgyan/ dmangs rigs ljang khras phyag gdub dang zhabs gdub/ gdol pa nag khras sku rags dang se ral khar brgyan pa/ 'od 'phro ba'i rin chen sna lngas brgyan pa/ dar gyi cod pan gyis mdzes pa/ ye shes kyi me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs pa/

In the center, visualize the syllable bhrūṃ, from which there appears the measureless palace, with its four sides, four doors, ornaments, and pediments. In the middle of that is the letter paṃ, from which appears a ten-petaled multicolored lotus, and in its center the letter raṃ, and from it eleven sun disks, on top of which, from the hūṁ syllables, appear blue vajras marked with a hūṁ. From them light radiates, making offerings to the hosts of noble ones, subjugating all harmful beings, and converting them to the Buddha’s doctrine. The lights are gathered back and transform into oneself as Vajrapāṇi, who is sky-blue in color, with one face, two arms, and two legs in the striding posture of a warrior. He is wearing a skirt of a freshly flayed tiger skin. He has an enormous belly and fully developed torso. With his right hand he brandishes in the air a golden nine-pronged vajra. {409} His left hand is making the threatening gesture and holding a bell at the level of his heart. His mouth is wide open, his four canine teeth bared, and his tongue curled back. His face is wrinkled in anger, and his three eyes blaze with light, like the fire at the end of the kalpa. His beard, mustache, and eyebrows flash, and his light-yellow hair swirls upward. He has a huge body and massive limbs and appendages. He is adorned with the variegated white head ornament of the warrior caste, the variegated yellow earrings of the merchant caste, the variegated red necklet of the brahmin caste, the variegated green bracelets and anklets of the servant caste, and the variegated black sash and shoulder belt of the lowest castes. He is adorned with the five jewel ornaments, shining with light, and beautified with the silken crown. He is standing amid a blazing mass of wisdom fire.

pad+ma'i 'dab ma'i hU~M bcu yang khro bo bcu/ rang lta bu'i cha lugs kyis zhal nang du gzigs nas bzhugs pa/ lha tshogs de rnams kyi spyi bor oM dkar po/ mgrin par AHdmar po/ snying khar hU~M mthing kha/ de las 'od 'phros/ lcang lo can nas rang 'dra ba'i ye shes pa spyan drangs nas/ dzaHhU~M baM hoHdbyer med du bstim/ slar 'od 'phros pas de bzhin gshegs pa rigs lnga spyan drangs/ dbang bskur bar gsol bas rigs lngas dbang bskur/ lus kyi nang ye shes kyi bdud rtsis gang*/ lhag ma yar lud pas mi bskyod pas dbu brgyan par bsam/

The ten hūṁ syllables on the petals of the lotus [transform into] the ten wrathful ones, who have the same attributes as oneself and are standing with their faces looking in toward the center. In the crown center of each of these deities is a white oṁ, in their throat center a red āḥ, and in their heart center a blue hūṁ. From these, light radiates, inviting from the Willow Leaf buddha field wisdom deities identical to themselves. With jaḥ hūṁ baṃ hoḥ, they dissolve inseparably into you. Again, with the emanation of light, the tathāgatas of the five families are invited, the request for empowerment is made, and you are empowered by the buddhas of the five families. Consider that the inside of your body is filled with wisdom nectar, which overflows, so that you are adorned on your crown by Akṣhobhya.
rang gi snying gar pad nyi'i steng du rdo rje sngon po'i lte bar hU~M gi mthar/ oM badz+ra pA Ni hU~M/ zhes pa baiDUr+Ya'i phreng ba lta bus 'khor bar bsgom pa ni/ zhi ba'i bsnyen po'o/ /

In your heart center visualize a lotus and sun disk, upon which there is a blue vajra, and in its hub the syllable hūṁ is surrounded by [the mantra] oṁ vajrapāṇi hūṁ, like a string of beryls. {410} To concentrate on this is the peaceful approach.

drag po'i bsnyen pa ni/ oM badz+ra tsan+Da ma hA ro Sha Na hU~M phaT/ ces pa'i yig 'bru rnams 'od dmar po tsha zhing bsreg pa'i rnam par 'khor bar bsgom pa ni drag po'i bsnyen pa'o/ / slar yang snying kha'i hU~M las 'od zer 'phros phyi snod la phog pas lcang lo can du byas/ nang bcud la phog pas phyag na rdo rjer byas nas/ thams cad zhal nas sngags kyi sgra sgrogs par bsgom la rtags rnams ma rdzogs kyi bar bsnyen pa'i khrid bya'o/ / mthar phyi snod nang bcud la thim/ nang bcud rang la thim/ rang thugs kha'i hU~M la thim/ hU~M nam mkha' la 'ja' yal ba ltar dmigs pa med kyi ngang du bzhag go / des ni bskyed rim gyi khrid song*/

For the wrathful approach, concentrate on the syllables oṁ vajra caṇḍamahāroṣaṇa hūṁ phaṭ in a circle in the form of hot, burning red light. This is the wrathful approach. Again, from the hūṁ in your heart center, rays of light emanate. Consider that they touch the world outside so that it becomes the Willow Leaf buddha field. They touch the beings inhabiting it, so that they become Vajrapāṇi, all intoning the sound of the mantra. This is the instruction on the approach, which should be practiced until the signs [of accomplishment] are complete. At the end, the outer world dissolves into its inhabitants. The inhabitants dissolve into you, and you dissolve into the hūṁ in your heart center. The hūṁ vanishes like a rainbow dissolving in the sky. Rest in the state without concepts. All this is the instruction on the generation stage.
gnyis pa rigs lnga la brten nas/ 'od zer spro bsdu'i khrid
2. Instructions on the Emanation and Reabsorption of Light Rays, Related to the Five Families
['di] la gnyis te/
These instructions comprise two parts.
dang po phyag na rdo rje rigs lnga'i 'od zer spro bsdu ni/
a. The Emanation and Reabsorption of Light Rays of the Five Families of Vajrapāṇi

rang nyid sngar ltar phyag na rdo rje gsal bar bsgom pa'i spyi mgrin snying kha lte ba gsang gnas lngar/ pad+ma dang nyi ma'i steng du hU~M yig dkar dmar mthing ser ljang khu lnga las byung ba'i bcom ldan 'das/ spyi bor rnam snang phyag na rdo rje dkar po/ mgrin par pad+ma'i phyag na rdo rje dmar po/ snying gar rdo rje'i phyag na rdo rje sngon po/ lte bar rin 'byung phyag rdor ser po/ gsang gnas su las kyi phyag rdor ljang khu/ rnam snang lta bu'i cha lugs kyis me dpung gi dbus na bzhugs pa/ 'od zer dkar po/ dmar po/ sngon po/ ser po/ ljang khu lnga 'phros nas/ phyogs bcu'i rgyal ba sras bcas la mchod pa'i sprin bsam gyis mi khyab pas mchod par bsam pa ni rlung phar 'gro ba'i dmigs pa'o/ / rlung tshur 'dzin pa'i tshe/ phyogs bcu'i rgyal ba sras bcas kyi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las/ mthu stobs nus pa ye shes dang mdzad pa byin rlabs gzi brjid thams cad phyag na rdo rje rigs lnga'i sku'i rnam par bsdus nas spyi bo/ mgrin pa/ snying kha/ lte ba/ gsang gnas lngar thim par bsam la/ rlung thebs re re bzung*/ yang rlung phar 'gro ba dang sbyar la 'od zer lnga 'phros/ rigs drug gi sems can lha dang lha ma yin dang*/ mi dang dud 'gro yi dwags dang dmyal ba rnams la phog pas de dag gi sgrib pa dug lnga sbyangs/ phyag na rdo rje rigs lnga'i go 'phang la bkod par bsam mo/ / rlung 'dzin pa'i tshe/ de dag gi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi mthu stobs nus pa/ ye shes yon tan mdzad pa phrin las gzi brjid byin rlabs thams cad dang*/ phyag na rdo rje'i rigs lnga'i rnam pa/ 'od zer dkar dmar mthing ser ljang khu'i dbyibs su bsdus nas/ spyi bo/ mgrin pa/ snying kha/ lte ba/ gsang gnas kyi phyag rdor lnga la thim pas/ rang nyid sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi nus stobs ye shes mdzad pa gzi brjid byin rlabs mtha' yas pa dang ldan par bsam la/ rlung bum pa can gnas lngar bzung*/ mthar snod 'od du zhu nas sems can la thim/ sems can thams cad sangs rgyas la thim/ sangs rgyas sras bcas rang la thim/ rang snying kha'i hU~M la thim/ hU~M nam mkha' la 'ja' yal ba ltar dmigs med kyi ngang la mnyam par bzhag go / de dag ni rdzogs rim mo/ /

Visualize yourself clearly as Vajrapāṇi, as before, and in the five centers (crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret center) upon a lotus and sun, five hūṁ syllables (white, red, blue, yellow, and green) from which there appear [the five] bhagavāns: in the crown, white Vairochana Vajrapāṇi, in the throat, red Padma Vajrapāṇi, in the heart, blue Vajra Vajrapāṇi, in the navel, yellow Ratnasambhava Vajrapāṇi, and in the secret center, green Karma Vajrapāṇi. They are attired like Vairochana and present in the middle of a mass of fire. As you visualize them emanating white, red, blue, yellow, and green rays of light, making inconceivable clouds of offerings to the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions, {411} concentrate on breathing out. As you breathe in, consider that the body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities of the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the ten directions, and their power, ability, wisdom, deeds, blessings, and splendor are all gathered in the form of the five Vajrapāṇis and dissolve into your crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret centers, and hold the breath for a short while. Again, as you breathe out, emanate five-colored rays of light. Consider that they touch the beings of the six realms—gods, demigods, humans, animals, hungry spirits, and hell beings—purifying their obscurations and five poisons and bringing them to the level of the five Vajrapāṇis. When you breathe in, consider that all the power, wisdom, qualities, deeds, activities, splendor, and blessings of their body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities are gathered in the form of the five Vajrapāṇis as white, red, blue, yellow, and green rays of light, which dissolve into the five Vajrapāṇis in your crown, throat, heart, navel, and secret centers, so that you yourself acquire the infinite power, wisdom, deeds, splendor, and blessings of their enlightened body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities. With this visualization, hold the vase breath in the five centers. At the end, the world melts into light and dissolves into the sentient beings. All the sentient beings dissolve into the buddhas, the buddhas and bodhisattvas dissolve into you, and you dissolve into the hūṁ in your heart center. The hūṁ vanishes like a rainbow in the sky. Rest in meditative equipoise in the nonconceptual state. {412} This is the perfection stage.
gnyis pa khyung rigs lnga'i 'od zer spro bsdu
b. The Emanation and Reabsorption of Light Rays of the Five Families of Garuḍas
['di] la gsum ste/
This is section is divided into three.
dang por
i. Visualizing the Garuḍas Crowning One’s Head

spyi bor dbu rgyan gyi tshul du bsgom pa ni/ spyi bor sangs rgyas rigs kyi khyung dkar po/ dpral bar rdo rje rigs kyi khyung sngon po/ rna ltag g.yas par rin chen rigs kyi khyung ser po/ ltag par pad+ma rigs kyi khyung dmar po/ rna ltag g.yon par las kyi rigs kyi khyung ljang khu rnams/ gnam lcags las grub pa'i mchu sder can/ rdo rje'i gshogs pa brkyangs pa/ rwa rnon po gnyis kyi bar nor bus brgyan pa/ phyag gnyis kyi dug sbrul bzung nas zhal du gsol ba/ me 'bar ba'i dbus na bzhugs pa'i khyung rnams las 'od zer kha dog lnga 'phros nas rgyal ba sras bcas mchod/ sems can rigs drug la phog pas dug lnga sbyangs nas khyung rigs lnga'i go 'phang la bkod nas/ slar de dag gi sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi mthu stobs nus pa/ ye shes gzi brjid byin rlabs thams cad 'od zer dkar dmar mthing ser ljang khu'i dbyibs sam/ khyung rigs lnga'i rnam par bsdus nas dbu rgyan gyi khyung rigs lnga la thim pas rang nyid sku gsung thugs yon tan phrin las kyi mthu stobs nus pa ye shes gzi brjid byin rlabs mtha' dag thob par bsam la/ rlung bum pa can bzung ngo*/ /

On the crown of your head is the white garuḍa of the buddha family. On the forehead is the blue vajra garuḍa. Behind the right ear is the yellow ratna garuḍa. On the back of the head is the red padma garuḍa. And behind the left ear is the green karma garuḍa. They all have beaks made of meteoric iron, outstretched vajra wings, and two sharp horns, between which they are adorned with a jewel. In their two hands they hold a venomous snake, which they are devouring. They are present in the midst of a blazing mass of fire. From these garuḍas, five-colored rays of light emanate, making offerings to the buddhas and bodhisattvas and touching the beings of the six realms, purifying their five poisons and bringing them to the level of the five families of garuḍas. After that, all the power, ability, wisdom, splendor, and blessings of their enlightened body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities are gathered back in the form of white, red, blue, yellow, and green rays of light, or in the form of the five garuḍas, and dissolve into the five garuḍas crowning your head. Consider that you obtain all the power, ability, wisdom, splendor, and blessings of their enlightened body, speech, mind, qualities, and activities, and hold the vase breath.
gnyis pa gnas lngar bkod pa ni/
ii. Manifesting the Garuḍas in the Five Centers
