In particular, the lord himself received directly from noble Avalokiteshvarathe twenty-five verses of pith instruction Resting in the Nature of One’s Own Mind, {531} on the basis of which, over a long period, he explained the experiential instructions to the lotsawa, and in a summerhouse in the Ambara forest at the golden pagoda of Shrī Pashupati, they translated it. The great lotsawa in turn conferred it on his own heart son, Tropu Sempa Chenpo, and others. After that, the supreme scholar of Tropu, Tsemai Kyebu Sönam Gön, transmitted it to the teacher Yang Tsewa Rinchen Senge, from whom Omniscient Butön Rinchen Drup, [appearing in this] Age of Strife, received it and practiced it. It is a most extraordinary instruction, which the most accomplished disciples have assiduously upheld in the form of heart advice, and the lineage of experiential instructions has continued unbroken to the present day. The great siddha himself subsequently returned to India and displayed all kinds of illusion-like manifestations, benefiting countless beings. He attained the immortal wisdom body and continues to be present.

mdor na bod du byon pa'i rgya gar gyi grub thob zhig la/ grub pa'i rtags mngon gyur du ston pa'i tshul bstan pa sngar dar gyi dus su slob dpon chen po pad+ma saM b+ha ba dang*/ phyi dar gyi skabs chen 'di la 'gran zla 'os pa ni 'ga' 'ang ma byung zhes mkhas pa chen po dag gsungs pa don la'ang gnas pa nyid do/ /

In short, [Mitrayogin] was an Indian siddha who came to Tibet and displayed the true signs of accomplishment, appearing as the great master Padmasambhava during the earlier period when the Buddhist teachings were introduced and as this great siddha during the later period of their propagation. Truly, no one can match him, as the great scholars have stated.
gnyis pa
II. Explanation of the Main Body of the Text
gzhung don dngos bshad pa la gsum/ klad kyi don/ gzhung gi don/ mjug gi don to/ /
The main explanation has three parts: (1) introduction; (2) main body of the text; and (3) conclusion.
dang po
A. Introduction
['di] la gnyis/ mtshan bstan pa dang*/ 'gyur gyi phyag go /
The introduction comprises (1) the title and (2) the translator’s homage.
dang po ni/
1. Title
rgya gar skad du/ swa tsit+ta sogs
The Sanskrit title is Svacittaviśrāmopadeśapañcaviṃśatikāgāthā.
bod skad du bsgyur na/ rang gi sems ngal gso ba'i man ngag tshigs su bcad pa nyi shu rtsa lnga pa zhes bya ba ste/

When translated into Tibetan, it is Rang gi sems ngal gso ba’i man ngag tshigs su bcad pa nyi shu rtsa lnga pa, [which in English means] A Pith Instruction in Twenty-Five Verses on Resting in the Nature of One’s Own Mind.

don ni/ rang gi sems nyid lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes gdod ma nas rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag kyang de ltar ma rtogs pas bzung 'dzin gyi gzhan dbang la brten nas 'khor ba'i rgya 'tsho yun ring du dub par gyur pa gnyug ma phyag rgya chen po rin po che'i gling du ngal gso bar byed pa'i gzhung*/ tshig chung ngus don chen po dpag par dka' bar bde blag tu ston pa'i man ngag / gzhung gi tshad tshigs su bcad pa nyi shu rtsa lnga yod pas na de skad ces btags pa'o/ /

The import of this is as follows. The nature of one’s mind is innate gnosis, naturally pure from the very beginning. However, we have not realized that, {532} and as a result, we have long been exhausting ourselves in the ocean of samsara because of the dependent nature—the duality of an apprehending subject and apprehended object. This is a text that enables us to find rest on the precious island of the natural state, the Great Seal. It is a pith instruction that, in a few verses, reveals an almost unfathomable great meaning in a way that is easy to understand. As for the size of the text, it consists of twenty-five verses. That is why it bears this title.
gnyis pa ni/
2. Translator’s Homage
dpal rdo rje sems dpa' la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes pa ste go sla'o/ /
Homage to Glorious Vajrasattva. This is easy to understand.
gnyis pa
B. Main Body of the Text
['di] la gzhung gi don la gnyis/ gzhi gnyug ma ngo sprad pa dang*/ lam rnam rtog lam du khyer ba'o/ /
The main body of the text consists of (1) the ground, an introduction to the natural state, and (2) the path, incorporating conceptual thoughts on the path.
dang po
1. The Ground, an Introduction to the Natural State
['di] la gnyis/ spyi'i don dang*/ yan lag gi don to/ /
The first of these comprises (1) general points and (2) subsidiary points.
dang po ni/
a. General Points

spyir gdams pa zab mo nyams su blang zhing ngo sprod pa'i tshul snying por dril ba lo tsA ba chen po nyid kyi zhal snga nas 'di ltar gsungs te/ 'di'i don ngo sprod pa la re zhig sngon 'gro dang*/ dngos gzhi dang*/ rjes kyi bya ba gsum mo/ /

The Great Lotsawa[5] said that in general the condensed essence of how to practice and introduce the profound instructions can be introduced with three topics: (1) preliminaries; (2) main practice; and (3) conclusion.
dang po
i. Preliminaries

['di la] gsum las/ thung mong gi sngon 'gro rgyud sbyong ba yan lag bdun pa la sogs pa dang*/ thun mong ma yin pa'i sngon 'gros byin gyis rlobs pa rdo rje sems dpa' yi ge brgya pa'i sgom bzlas la sogs pa dang/ khyad par gyis sngon 'gros shes rgyud dbang du bya ba ni ye ge lnga bcu pas gsol ba gdab pa'o/ /

There are three preliminaries. The common preliminaries consist of purifying one’s mind stream through such practices as the seven branches. The uncommon preliminaries for blessing one’s being consist of such practices as meditating on Vajrasattva and reciting the hundred-syllable mantra. The extraordinary preliminaries consist of mastering one’s mind stream by praying with the fifty syllables.
gnyis pa dngos gzhi la/
ii. Main Practice

lus kyi phyag rgya gnas dben par stan bde ba la 'dug nas bsam gtan gyi yan lag dang ldan par bca'/ ngag gi phyag rgya ni dbugs 'gyu ba sor bzhag / yid kyi phyag rgya dang po lhod kyis glod/ bar du hrig ge bzhag / mtha' ma phyam tser btang ngo*/ /

The seal of the body consists of sitting on a comfortable seat in an isolated location and adopting the prerequisites for concentration. The seal of speech consists of letting one’s breath flow naturally. The seal of the mind is at first to relax, then to settle, vividly awake, and finally to let go completely.
dang po klod pa
For the first of these, relaxing,
['di] la gsum ste/ klod pa'i yon tan dang*/ ma klod pa'i skyon dang*/ ji ltar klod pa'i tshul lo/ /
there are three points: (1) the advantages of relaxing; (2) the disadvantages of not relaxing; and (3) how to relax.
klod pa'i yon tan ni
A) Advantages of Relaxing
sems kyi gnas lugs kyi 'dug tshul ni ma bcos pa nyid yin pas glod na 'dug tshul de'i steng du gro bas gnas lugs ji ltar yin pa rtogs pa'i dgos pa yod do/ /
The mode of being of the mind’s natural state is something unfabricated, so if one’s mind is relaxed, one will necessarily approach that mode of being and thus realize how the natural state is. {533}
ma klod pa'i skyon ni
B) Disadvantages of Not Relaxing
de las bzlog pa ste/ yin tshul las rang gi nan tan gyis ma glod pas phyin ci log gi snang ba 'byams nas rang la rang dbang med par 'khor zhing 'khrul pa la longs spyod par 'gyur ba'o/ /
These are the opposite of that. If one applies oneself forcefully and fails to relax, one’s perception of how things are will become distorted, and one cannot but experience confusion and delusion.
ji ltar klod pa'i tshul
C) How to Relax
['di] la gnyis te/ klod nas gzhag thabs dang*/ zhar la gegs bsal ba'o/ /
This has two aspects: (1) the method for relaxing and settling and, connected to that, (2) how to dispel obstacles.
dang po ni/
1) Method for Relaxing and Settling

'jig rten gyi bya ba brgyab tu dor/ ting nge 'dzin 'ong du re ba dang*/ ma byung gis dogs pa ye mi bya/ blos rtog dpyod gang yang mi btang*/ dga' mi dga' mtshan rtags ci yang mi bzung*/ rtog dpyod re ma yang rnam rtog nyid 'khrul yin pas sems nyid rang gi thog tu rang klod do/ / rang la rang klod de bzhag pas kho na nyid la 'char lugs gcig yod/ 'char lugs de gang yin na bca' bcos phyar med pa nyid yin/ ma bcos pa rtog pa la ma bcos par klod pa thabs zab pa'i rgyu mtshan yang de yin no/ / bcos su med pa la klod pas kyang ci phan zhes ni mi bsam ste/ mda' 'ben du phog pa la mda' tsha bar brjod pa ltar ma bcos pa'i thog tu klod pa la 'bab pa zhes bya'o/ / de ltar yang*/ ma bcos chos rnams kun gyi gzhi/ / de nyid mnyam par rtogs 'dod na/ / yul la yid ni mi spro bar/ / lhod kyis klod la lhan gyis zhog / ces 'byung ba lta bu'o/ /

Abandon all worldly pursuits. Never have any expectations concerning the development of concentration or misgivings about its not developing. Do not have any intellectual concepts or analytical thoughts. Do not grasp at characteristics—likes and dislikes. The very thought “I must not conceptualize or analyze” compounds delusion, so let the mind relax in its own state. When one leaves that relaxation in its own state, there is a particular way in which it manifests. What is that way of manifesting? It is a state where there is no correcting and nothing to be done.[6] Relaxing without contriving the thought of not contriving is the very principle of the profound method. Do not think, “What is the use of relaxing in a state without contrivance?” Just as one refers to someone who hits the target as a marksman, relaxing into that uncontrived state is called the “flow.” Indeed, not contriving is the basis of all the teachings. If you wish to realize that state, sameness, you should rest quietly in loose relaxation without any mental involvement with an object. This is how it has been taught.
gnyis pa gegs bsal ba ni/
2) Dispelling Obstacles

de ltar klod nas bzhag pas rnam rtog gi 'gyu 'phro chad nas lhan cham gyis mi rtog pa rkyang par 'gro ste/ de ni gnyis 'dzoms bkag pa'i glen sgom yin no/ / des na de la mi bzhag par de'i gnyen por rig pa hur gdon te rig ge yer re seng nge dpang gtod la bzhag go /

Having settled in a relaxed state, when the movement and proliferation of thoughts ceases, one arrives at a complete absence of thoughts. If one tries to stop both, this is dumb meditation. Therefore, rather than settling in that, remedy it by arousing wakeful awareness and settling in a lofty state—aware, pure, limpid.

de'i tshe yang rig pa'i rang gdangs shar bas gsal cha skyes pa la 'bral mi phod par 'gyur te/ de ni gsal ba mtshan mar 'dzin pa'i gnyis chos yin no/ / des na de la mi bzhag par de'i gnyen por shes pa 'phangs smad la spu ris gang dang yang ma 'dres par bzhag go /

At that time, the manifestations of awareness arise, and one is unable to part with the clarity aspect that has arisen. This is the dualistic phenomenon of grasping at the characteristic of clarity. {534} So rather than resting in that state, remedy it by settling without even a hair’s breadth of mixing with the lowly consciousness [that distinguishes this and that].

de'i tshe yang rig pa shes snyoms pa cir yang mi rtog pa'i ngang na bde song nge 'char te/ de ni blos byas rang byung gi bde nyams bya ba yin no/ / des na de la yang mi bzhag par blo nyams ci bder rang yan du byams tser btang ngo*/ / de yang bde nyams skyes pa la ma zhen snyams yang bde ba'i cha la 'bral mi phod pa'i zhen pas bcings rgyu gcig byung la/ zhen na zhen chos phra mo khong du zhen cing 'dod pa las srid pa'i nyon mongs pa rgyas par 'gyur te/ bde la zhen pas 'dod pa'i khams su lhung zhes bya'o/ /

Then again, in the state of balanced awareness with no thoughts whatsoever, there arises a state of limpid bliss. This is called a spontaneous experience of bliss created by the mind. In that case, you should not rest in that either, but instead let the mind relax freely. Even if you think you are not clinging to the experience of bliss that has occurred, it can act as a cause for being caught by the clinging of being unable to part with the bliss aspect. And when there is clinging, from subtle inner clinging and desire, the defilements of existence will grow. For it is said that by clinging to bliss, one will fall into the world of desire.

gsal ba'i nyams skyes pa la ma zhen yang gsal ba'i cha la 'bral mi phod pa'i zhen pas bcings rgyu gcig byung la/ zhen na zhen chos phra mo khong du song bas zhen pa dang bcas pa'i las las gzugs khams kyi srid pa 'grub ste/ gsal ba la zhen pas gzugs khams dag tu gol zhes bya'o/ /

Even if you think you are not clinging to the experience of clarity that has occurred, it can act as a cause for being caught by the clinging of being unable to part with the clarity aspect. And when there is clinging, subtle inner clinging leads to karmic deeds with clinging, which produce existence in the world of form. For it is said that by clinging to clarity, one will err in the worlds of form.

mi rtog pa'i nyams skyes pa la ma zhen snyam yang mi rtog pa'i cha la 'bral mi phod pa'i zhen rgyu gcig byung bas zhen chos phra mo khong du ma song ba'i mi srid pas/ zhen bcas kyi las phra bas kyang gzugs med kyi srid pa 'grub ste/ mi rtog bsgom pa la zhen pas gzugs med du 'gro zhes bya'o/ /

Even if you think you are not clinging to the experience of no-thought that has occurred, it can act as a cause for being caught by the clinging of being unable to part with the no-thought aspect. And it is impossible for it not to become subtle inner clinging, as a result of which there are subtle karmic deeds with clinging, which again produce existence in the formless world. For it is said that by clinging to meditation on no-thought, one will migrate to the formless world.

de ltar bde gsal mi rtogs pa gsum la zhen pa dang bcas na srid pa gsum las thar pa'i dus mi srid pas/ zhag la 'char yang 'char bar ma zhen pas rig pa ma bcos par lhod kyis 'jog pa gal che'o/ / bzhag pas bzhag rgyu med de ma bzhag pa'i gnas pa chen po/ gnas kyang gnas pa med de mi gnas pa'i sgom pa dam pa/ bsgom kyang bsgom mkhan med de ma bsgom pa'i ting nge 'dzin bla na med pa'o/ / de'i rjes gar du hrig ge bzhag pa dang*/ tha mar phyams tser btang ba ni snga ma'i 'gros kyis shes par bya'o/ /

Thus, if one has clinging to bliss, clarity, or no-thought, one will never attain liberation from the three worlds of existence. So it is very important, whatever manifests when you settle, not to cling to that manifestation, and to rest loosely in uncontrived awareness. Settling without anything to settle on is the great dwelling without settling. Dwelling without anywhere to dwell is the sublime meditation of not dwelling. Meditating without anyone meditating is the unsurpassable concentration of meditation. {535} After that, in the middle resting vividly aware and at the end letting go completely are to be known from the procedure described above.

de ltar las dang po pas mnyam par 'jog pa la skyes bu kha la gnyer byed pas kha la bcos pa ltar mtho dman khad kyis mnyam zhing*/ gser 'jal ba legs par byas pa'i srang ltar/ mnyam khad de gnas pa la rang sems rang bzhin ma bcos pa'i gnyug ma ngos zin par 'gyur te/ de yang bla ma dam pa'i byin rlabs gsung gi bdud rtsi dang bcas pas rjes su bzung ba dang yun ring po nas rang gis legs par bsgrub pa'i bsod nams bsags pa las ngo 'phrod par gsungs so/ /

For beginners to meditate like this, as a result of following a great being, they will gradually equalize the highs and lows in a contrived way, and when they are on the verge of achieving evenness, like a balance that is properly calibrated for weighing gold, they will recognize the uncontrived innate state that is the nature of their own mind. It has been taught that this is introduced through one’s being cared for with the blessings of a holy teacher, along with the nectar of their teachings, and through one’s having accumulated merit by practicing properly over a long period.
gsum pa
iii. Conclusion

rjes kyi bya ba gsum ni/ ngo 'phrod pa'i rjes yun ring du mi 'bral ba'i thabs dang*/ snang ba lam du slong ba'i thabs dang*/ ci byas gzhan don du 'gyur ba'i thabs dang gsum ldan dgos pa las/ / dang po ni/ dngos gzhi ngo sprad nyams kyi rtsis bzung la snang ba sna tshogs gang shar shar la sbyar te nyams su blang ngo*/ / gnyis pa ni/ rang ngo 'phrod pas rang ngo shes pa'i ngang la bde sdug las sog pa ci byung tshad de nyid kyi rtsal sbyong zhing mi 'gog pa'o/ / gsum pa ni/ rang ngo shes pas rang grol ba ni sems can nam mkha' dag mnyam pa thams cad kyang rang grol du gyur cig ces bsngos la/ lus ngag yid gsum gyi bya ba thams cad zhen med kyi ngang las 'bral med kyi snying rjes gzhan don dang du len pa'o/ / zhes gsungs te/ rgyas par khrid yig tu shes par bya'o/ /

The three things to be done in conclusion are (1) after being introduced, not separating from that for a long time; (2) incorporating appearances into the path; and (3) making everything one does beneficial for others. All three are necessary. A) Recognizing the experience you have been introduced to in the main practice, you should practice applying it to whatever various appearances arise as soon as they arise. B) In the state of recognition of your own nature as a result of being introduced to it, train in whatever arises—happiness or suffering—as being the display of thatness, without blocking it. C) Dedicate the spontaneous freedom that results from recognizing your own nature, thinking, “May all sentient beings, numerous as the sky is vast, also be spontaneously free.” And apply everything you do physically, verbally, and mentally to the welfare of others, with compassion inseparable from the state free of clinging. So it has been taught. Greater detail on all this can be found in the practice manual.[7]
gnyis pa la/
b. Subsidiary Points
spyir dbang po rab 'bring tha ma'i bye brag gis ngo sprod pa'i tshul so sor gsungs pa las/ dbang por ba la sor bzhag gsum gyi ngo sprod pa'i

As a general rule, the introductions for the different kinds of beings—those with the highest, middling, or least faculties—were taught separately. Of these, for those with the highest faculties, there is the introduction to the three ways of resting naturally,
dang po ni 'di yin te/ e ma ho/ rang sems sogs tshigs bcad gcig go /

the first of which is given in one verse: Wonder! One’s own mind is, from the beginning, unborn. Nowhere else is there the cause for creating samsara and nirvana. Present in the center of one’s own heart, It will be known through the teacher’s instructions.

don ni/ 'di ltar sems kyi gnas lugs ma rtogs pas 'khor bar 'ching zhing*/ rtogs na grol bar byed pas na ngo mtshar ba'i phyir e ma ho zhes thog mar gsungs so/ / ngo mtshar ba de gang zhe na/ rang gi sems kyi gnas lugs 'dod ma nas ma skyes shing*/ ci'i ngo bor yang ma grub pa ste/ dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas rnams byon rung*/ ma byon rung*/ bla ma rnams kyis ngo sprod rung*/ ma sprod rung*/ gang zag rnams kyis rtogs rung ma rtogs rung de ltar du gnas pa gang zhig / ma rtogs na 'khor ba dang*/ rtogs na mya ngan las 'das par byed pa'i rgyu'am sa bon can de ni/ ngo bo rang las gzhan na btsal du yod pa min te/ yul rang gi snying gi dbus su/ dus rig pa gang dang gang shar ba'i tshe/ thabs bla ma dam pa'i zhal gyis gdams pa la brten nas nyams su blangs pa las shes par 'gyur ro/ / zhes pa'o/ /

The meaning of this verse as follows. It is because one fails to realize the mind’s true mode of being that one is bound in samsara. Realizing it makes one free. This is something to be marveled at, which is why {536} the text begins by saying “Wonder!” What is it that is so marvelous? The mode of being of one’s mind. From the very beginning, it is unborn; it does not exist as the essence of anything at all. It remains like that whether or not the buddhas of the three times have come, whether or not the teachers have introduced it, and whether or not people have realized it. If one does not realize it, one possesses the cause or seed that creates samsara. If one does realize it, one has the cause or seed that leads to nirvana. Its essence is not to be sought anywhere else than oneself. Its location is in the middle of one’s own heart. There, whenever awareness arises, it can be known through the skillful means, the practice based on a holy teacher’s instructions.
gnyis pa
2. Incorporating Conceptual Thoughts on the Path
['di] la gnyis/ lam rim gyis pa brda'i sgo nas grol ba'i man ngag dang*/ gcig car ba byin rlabs dbang gis grol ba'i man ngag go /

This is divided into two parts: (1) pith instructions for practitioners who progress gradually on the path, who are freed by means of symbols, and (2) pith instructions for those who gain accomplishment at a single stroke, who are freed by the power of blessings.
dang po
a. Pith Instructions for Practitioners Who Progress Gradually on the Path
['di] la gnyis/ dbang po rab 'gyu ba rang sar sad par byed pa dang*/ dbang po 'bring dang tha ma 'gyu ba gzhan gyi thabs kyis grol bar byed pa'o/ /

These comprise (1) those of the highest faculties, for whom thought movements cause them to awaken to their own state, and (2) those of middling and basic faculties, for whom thoughts are liberated by other means.
dang po ni/
i. Those of the Highest Faculties
sor bzhag gsum gyi ngo sprad gnyis te/
For beings of the highest faculties, there are two of the introductions to the three ways of resting naturally.
dang po gang skyes gang shar dran pa'i ngo sprod ni/
A) First, an Introduction to Being Mindful of Whatever Is Born and Whatever Arises

gang skyes sogs te/ rtog pa gang skyes kyang rlabs nyid rgya mtsho las ma 'das pa bzhin du/ gnyug ma 'gro 'ong dang bral ba nyid ma 'das pa yin pa'i phyir/ gang shar thams cad rang ngo shes pa'i dran pas ma brjed na/ rnam pa de dang der shar yang*/ ngo bo stong pa nyid kyi bdag nyid can du 'gyur te/ rnal 'byor gyi rgyal por gdon mi za ba ste the tshom med par nges so/ / dran pas mi brjed pa'i tshul ni gsum ste/ dang po snang mkhan ma brjed pa dang*/ bar du 'dzin mkhan ma brjed pa dang*/ tha ma zhen mkhan ma brjed pa'o/ /

Whatever is born is the natural state, So if one remembers this, mindful of whatever arises, It arises as emptiness. This, there is no doubt, is the king of yogas. Just as the waves are not anything other than the ocean, whatever thoughts arise, they are not anything other than the natural state, the state that is free from coming and going. Therefore, if one remains mindful in recognizing everything that arises as one’s own nature and does not forget this, even though those things appear in their different forms, they will appear as the essential essence, emptiness. There is no doubt that this is the king of yogas. As for how one remains unforgettingly mindful, there are three aspects: first, to not forget the perceiver; in the middle, to not forget the apprehender; and finally, to not forget the agent who is attached. {537}
gnyis pa ni/
B) The Second Introduction

gang shar thams cad sogs te/ rnam par rtog pa gang shar thams cad de kho na nyid gnyug ma'i don las ma g.yos pa yin te/ rang sems gnyug ma de ni ngo bo gang du'ang ma shar bzhin/ rnam pa cir yang 'char ba chu zla lta bu'o/ / de'i phyir na 'khrul ngor gang skyes pa ltar snang ba'i gsal snang de ni/ rig ngor ma skyes kyang ma skyes pa de nyid skye ba'i tshul ltar snang ba'ang mi 'gal te/ rmi lam du bu mo skyes par bden kyang*/ gnyid kyis bslad pa'i ngor skye ba ltar snang ba'ang mi 'gal ba bzhin no/ / 'di yan gyi tshigs bcad gsum la rim par gnyug ma skye med kyi ngo sprod/ glo bur rnam dag gi ngo sprod/ dbyer med zung 'jug gi ngo sprod ces kyang gsungs so/ /

All that arises is thatness, And that does not arise as anything. So, whatever is born is itself unborn; While unborn, it appears to be born. All the thoughts that arise never move from thatness, the true natural state. That natural state, one’s own mind, while not arising as anything that exists intrinsically, appears in every kind of way, like the reflection of the moon in water. So, from the point of view of delusion, whatever is born appears clearly as if it were born. From the point of view of awareness, it is unborn. But the fact of its being unborn does not contradict its apparently being born, just as, while it is true that in a dream no child is born, this does not contradict the fact that from the point of view of the distortion that sleep brings, it may seem as if a child has been born. It has also been taught that the above three verses correspond to the introduction to the unborn natural state in stages, the introduction to perfect purity instantaneously, and the introduction to their inseparable union.
gnyis pa
ii. Those of Middling and Basic Faculties
['di] la gnyis/ dbang po 'bring gi ngo sprod dang*/ dbang po tha ma'i ngo sprod do/ /
This is divided into two: (1) introduction for beings with middling faculties and (2) introduction for beings with the most basic faculties.
dang po
A) Beings with Middling Faculties
['di] la gsum/ dbang po 'bring gi rab las gsum gyi dpes ngo sprod pa/ 'bring gi 'bring la phyi nang bar gsum gyi dpes ngo sprod pa/ 'bring gi tha ma la thog bab gsum gyis ngo sprod pa'o/ /

The introduction for beings with middling faculties is divided into three: (1) introduction for the best beings with middling faculties by means of analogies of the three worlds; (2) introduction for the middling beings with middling faculties by means of outer, inner, and in-between analogies; and (3) introduction for the lowliest beings with middling faculties by means of the three direct approaches.
dang po
1) The Best Beings with Middling Faculties
['di] la gsum las/
There are three analogies.
dang po sa bla khro bo'i rnam 'gyur gyi dpe ni/
a) Analogy of a Wrathful Deity’s Demeanor above the Earth

g.yas brkyang sogs te/ de la g.yas brkyang ba ni thabs snying rje chen po'i blo rgya bskyed pa/ g.yon bskum pa ni shes rab stong pa nyid kyis blo nang du dgug pa/ sdig mdzub gtad pa ni stong nyid snying rje gnyis sgom mkhan ngos bzung ba/ rdo rje'i lta ba ni blta bya blta byed gnyis su med pa'i don la dmigs pa med pa'i tshul gyis bltas nas ni/ rnam rtog gi bzhon par gyur pa rlung gi rta mchog phyi nang du dal bus 'gro ba dang 'ong ba'i tshul la bslab cing*/ rdo rje'i bzlas pa zab mo la gnas nas glo bur gyi rnam rtog du ma sems nyid gnyug ma'i ngang du ro gcig tu nyams su len par bya'o/ /

Right leg stretched out, left leg bent, he makes the threatening gesture, And looking with the vajra view, He keeps the supreme horse gently coming and going, Experiencing the many as one. His right leg stretched out signifies his skillful means, arousing the vast attitude of great compassion. His left leg drawn in signifies that his mind is turned inward by wisdom—emptiness. Holding his hand in the threatening gesture signifies recognizing the meditator, meditating on both emptiness and compassion. The vajra view is that of looking nonconceptually at the absence of duality—of something to be looked at and someone looking. Looking in that way, he trains in the gentle coming and going, in and out, of the supreme horse of the breath, on which thoughts are mounted, and dwells in the profound vajra recitation. By this means, the many suddenly arising thoughts are to be experienced as one taste in the natural state of the mind. {538}
gnyis pa sa 'og klu rgyal rol pa'i dpe ni/
b) Analogy of the Nāga Kings Playing under the Earth

rkang pa rgya mtsho sogs te/ 'di ltar klu'i rgyal po dag dus bzang po la rol zhing rtse ba na/ rkang pa rgya mtshor brkyangs/ lag pas sa steng kun nyul/ mig nam mkhar bltas kyang*/ sems rang gi gnas las mi g.yo ba bzhin du/ rkang pa rgya mtsho che la bzhag pa ni/ sems ma bcos pa'i ngang la rtse gcig tu gnas pa'i zhi gnas bsgom pa'o/ / lag pas sa steng kun tu nyal ba ni/ rtsal snang ma 'gags pa'i rol pa sna tshogs snang ba la snang stong dbyer med du rtogs pas longs spyod pa'i lhag mthong bsgom pa'o/ / mig ni nam mkhar blta bya zhes zhi lhag zung 'brel gyi ngang nas bya byed kyi dmigs pa ci'ang med pa la/ cir yang spyod pa'i tshul gyis ma yengs par blta ba ste/ de ltar nyams su blangs nas/ yid ni dus dang rnam pa thams cad du blo 'das byar med kyi rang mal las gang du'ang mi g.yo bar bya'o/ /

The feet rest in the great ocean. The hands wander all over the earth. The two eyes gaze into space. The mind does not move anywhere. When the nāga kings are playing on festive occasions, although their lower bodies are stretched out in the ocean, their upper bodies roam all over the earth.[8] Their eyes gaze at the sky, yet their minds do not move from their own abode. By analogy, their lower bodies placed in the great ocean signifies meditating on sustained calm with the mind remaining one-pointed in the uncontrived state. Their upper bodies roaming all over the earth signifies meditating on profound insight, enjoying the unobstructed display of manifestations appearing in multifarious ways while realizing them as the inseparability of appearance and emptiness. Their eyes gazing into space signifies looking undistractedly from the state of sustained calm and profound insight combined, enjoying everything while having no concepts whatsoever of doer or deed. Practicing in this way, at all times and in all situations, the mind should never move from its natural repose, free from activity, beyond concepts.
gsum pa sa steng rgyal po'i mdun na 'don rnams kyi dpe ni/
c) Analogy of the King’s Courtiers on the Earth

sgeg mo'i me long sogs te/ 'di la sbyor ba'i dpe gnyis/ dngos gzhi'i dpe gnyis/ rjes kyi dpe gnyis te drug gi sgo nas ston pa'i tshul/ rang rig dri ma med pa'i me long la yang dang yang du lta ba sgeg mos me long la blta ba lta bu/ mtshan 'dzin gyi rnam par rtog pa thams cad rang grol du 'joms pa'i stobs dang ldan pas gyad lta bu dang*/ nyon mongs pa rnam rtog gi 'ching ba thams cad las thar bar 'dod pa'i bsam pa dang nyin mtshan dus kun tu mi 'bral bas khrims btson lta bu dang*/ lus ngag yid gsum gyi spyod pa thams cad sems nyid ye shes kyi rgyal po nyams len gyis mnyes par 'gyur ba'i thabs su byed pa yin gyi/ phal pa'i chos spyod 'bangs phal pa dang 'dra ba'i nyan bshad la sogs pa dag gi ngo srung pa ci yang med pa rgyal po'i btsun mo la bu dang*/ dge sdig la sogs pa'i rnam par rtog pa thams cad bzang ngan bye brag med par rang grol du phyags pa la brtson pa phyags dar lta bu dang*/ snang ba thug phrad gang shar la rtogs pa'i rtsal sbyong bar byed kyi/ chos che che dang bzang bzang sogs lhag par don du mi gnyer bas smad 'tshong ma bzhin te drug go / gcig pu'i grogs dang 'grogs pa ni/ dran pa gcig su snang ba sna tshogs kyi grogs dang 'grogs nas/ ting nge 'dzin gyi rtsal sbyong bar byos shig ces gdam pa'o/ /

Like a beautiful woman’s mirror, a powerful athlete, A prisoner, a queen, A sweeper, or a courtesan— Keep the company of a single companion. Here the analogy is divided into six: two analogies indicating the preparation, two indicating the main practice, and two indicating the conclusion. Like a beautiful woman looking in a mirror, look again and again in the spotless mirror of awareness. Like a powerful athlete, destroy, through their self-liberation, all conceptual thoughts that apprehend attributes. Like a convicted prisoner, never part, day or night, from the wish to be free from all the bonds of thoughts related to defilements. Like a king’s queen, make all your physical, verbal, and mental activities a means by which your practice delights the king of gnosis, the nature of mind, {539} but without the slightest pretense in listening, explaining, and so on, like a common subject doing ordinary activities. Like a sweeper, be diligent in clearing away, through their self-liberation, all thoughts related to virtue and nonvirtue, without any distinction between good and bad. Like a courtesan, develop the power of realization with regard to whatever arises, whatever appearances are encountered, but without being more interested in the great or the good. This makes six analogies in all. “Keeping the company of a single companion” is an instruction to keep the company of the whole variety of appearances within a single mindfulness and develop the power of concentration.
gnyis pa
2) Middling Beings with Middling Faculties
dbang po 'bring gi 'bring po'i ngo sprod pa la gsum las/
Middling beings with middling faculties are introduced by means of outer, inner, and in-between analogies, comprising three sections.
dang po phyi'i dpe dgu ni/
a) Nine Outer Analogies

rtag dang sogs te/ de yang ting nge 'dzin ma skyes pa skye bar byed pa'i thabs gsum/ skye ba lam du 'gyur ba'i yan lag gsum/ lam mthar phyin par byed pa'i gnad gsum ste/ dpe dgus bstan pa yin no/ / de la dang po rtog pa dang nyon mongs pa thams cad 'joms pa la dpa' zhing ma zhum pas stag lta bu dang*/ bar du phyi nang gi bar chad dang nye bar 'chi ba ci byung yang nyams nga bag tsha med pa seng ge lta bu dang*/ tha mar byings rgod la sogs pa'i 'gal rkyen sna tshogs gang gis kyang lam las mi ldog pa glang po che chur zhugs lta bu dang gsum ni ting nge 'dzin skye bar byed pa'i thabs gsum yin no/ / skyes pa de yang theg pa chen po'i lam du 'gyur ba la/ gzhan phan thabs la mkhas pa'i khyad par dgos shing*/ de yang gzhan la phan 'dogs pa'i mthu lha dang bla ma la rag las pas/ mos gus kyi gdung ba drag po rnga mo lta bu/ gzhan la phan pa'i bsam pas snying rje dang*/ gis 'byung ba ri dwags khri snyan lta bu/ gzhan la phan pa'i thabs gang la gang 'dul gyis spros pa sna tshogs lam du khyer ba spre'u lta bu ste gsum dang*/ lam mthar phyin par byed pa'i gnad gsum ni/ zhe 'dod kyi gdung ba bsil ba dang*/ nyon mongs pa'i tshad nad sel ba dang*/ chos chen po rnam kyi rnams kyi nang nas mchog tu gyur pa ste/ chos gsum ldan pa tsan+dan lta bu/ 'gal rkyen gyis rtsa ba mi g.yo ba dang*/ mthun rkyen gyis rtse mo mi 'khyog pa dang*/ shes rgyud phal mo che thams cad las mtho bar 'phags pa ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas ljon shing gi sdong po lta bu/ mtshan 'dzin gyi dbang po 'gags pa dang*/ zhen pa'i srog dang bral ba dang*/ blang dor gyi rtsis gang ba med pa ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas mi ro lta bu ste de ltar dpe dgus mtshon nas/ des don zab mo la spyod pa'i mkhas pa rnams kyis stong ba nyid rnal 'byor du bya'o/ /

Like a tiger, lion, or elephant, A camel, deer, or monkey, Sandalwood, a tree, or human corpse— Adept, do the practice of emptiness. These nine analogies indicate three ways to give rise to concentration where it has not yet been developed; three branches that transform the development of concentration into the path; and three crucial points that enable one to travel the path to its end. (1) In the beginning, by being courageous and not losing heart in overcoming all one’s thoughts and defilements, one is like a tiger. (2) Later, one has no dread or fear whatever happens, regardless of outer and inner obstacles or imminent death, so one is like a lion. (3) In the end, in spite of all sorts of adverse circumstances such as sinking or wildness, one never turns back from the path, and one is like an elephant plunging into a river. These three analogies refer to the three methods that enable one to develop concentration. (4) For the development [of concentration] to become the path of the Great Vehicle, one has to be particularly skilled in the methods for benefiting others, and the ability to benefit others depends on the deity and teacher, so in the intense longing of one’s devotion, one is like a camel. (5) Because of one’s wish to help others, compassion comes naturally, {540} and one is like a gentle deer. (6) By means of the methods for benefiting others, training whoever needs training, the various conceptual elaborations are carried on the path, and one is like a monkey. The three crucial points that enable one to travel the path to its end are as follows: (7) Because [one’s practice] possesses the three qualities of cooling the scorching fires of desire, dissipating the fever of the defilements, and being the best of all great teachings, it is like sandalwood. (8) Because the root is never shaken by adverse circumstances, the top does not bend with favorable circumstances, and it rises higher than all the majority of mind streams—with these three qualities, one’s [mind] is like the trunk of a tree. (9) Because the faculty of grasping at attributes is blocked, attachment is dead, and one is not colored by acceptance and rejection—with these three qualities, one is like a human corpse. Those who are adept at practicing the profound meaning, as indicated by these nine analogies, should do the practice of emptiness.
gnyis pa bar gyi dpe drug ni/
b) Six In-Between Analogies

ri gzar chu dang sogs te/ 'di ltar rnam rtog rigs mi 'dra ba du ma shugs drag tu bskyed pa dang*/ rtog med dang btang snyoms kyis bar ma chod pa dang*/ shin tu myur ba glog 'gyu ba lta bu ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas ri gzar gyi 'bab chu lta bu dang*/ rnam rtog 'gyus tshad thams cad chos nyid kyi ngang la ro mnyam pa dang*/ rnam par rtog pa'i ngang la g.yo ba med bzhin du gnas pa dang*/ phyi'i 'gyu ba sna tshogs ci byung yang ma bcos pa'i ngang du zhi bar 'gyur ba ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas rgya 'tsho chen po lta bu ste/ dpe don gnyis pa de ni sems gnas par byed pa'i thabs yin no/ / yang dag pa'i rtogs pa la rang gi snying las lhag par 'dzin pa dang*/ rtogs pa de dang nam yang 'bral mi phod pa dang*/ rtogs pa'i rtsal gyis ci byung skyon du mi bzung ba ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas bu gcig pa'i ma lta bu dang*/ khongs grim pa dang*/ 'phral lhod pa dang*/ 'gro ldog gi mtshan nyid la mkhas pa ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas glang po che skyod pa lta bu gnyis ni gnas pa brtan par byed pa'i yan lag go / lta ba dman pa la ma zhen pas 'phang mtho ba dang*/ gzung 'dzin gyi gdung ba bral bas bsil ba dang*/ gegs skyon ci byung yang 'gyur ba med pa'i so tshugs pa ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas gangs ri lta bu dang*/ mngon par zhen pa'i dri ma dang bral bas gtsang ba dang*/ phyi'i yul snang dang nang gi rig chos gang yang ma bsgribs par gsal ba dang*/ dad pa dang snying rje thabs lam la sogs pa'i rkyen gyis gang du'ang bsgyur du rung ba ste/ chos gsum dang ldan pas shel sgong dag pa bzhin te de gnyis ni brtan pa mthar phyin par byed pa'i gnad yin no/ / de ltar goms pas ched 'dzin gyi dmigs gtad dang bral bar sems ngang gis gnas gyur na ting nge 'dzin gyi gzhi tshugs pa zhes bya'o/ /

Like a mountain torrent or a great lake, The mother of an only child, an elephant keeper, A snow mountain, or a pure crystal— If you are free of reference, the foundation has been laid. (1) Three characteristics make one’s [mind] like a rushing mountain torrent: the forceful production of many different thoughts, the lack of interruption of thoughts by no-thought or equanimity, and the mind’s moving as fast as lightning. (2) Three qualities make one’s mind like a great lake: all thought movements are of even taste in ultimate reality; one rests motionless in the state free of conceptual thoughts; and whatever thoughts concerning things outside may occur, they are pacified in the uncontrived state. These two analogies refer to the method that enables the mind to stay still. (3) Three qualities make one like a mother with an only child: one cherishes genuine realization more than one’s own heart; one can never bear to part from such realization; and {541} whatever arises through the manifesting power of realization, one does not regard it as a fault. (4) Three qualities make one like an elephant keeper: skill in reining in, relaxing, and alternating. These two analogies refer to branches that enable one to bring stability in meditation. (5) On account of three qualities one is like a snow mountain: height, for one is not attached to lower views; coolness, as one is free from the scorching torments of dualistic apprehension; and immutability in the face of whatever misfortunes occur. (6) On account of three qualities one is like a pure crystal: purity, for one is free of the impurities of gross clinging; clarity, since one is not obscured by any outer objects or inner cognitive phenomena; and adaptability in being ready for transformation by such conditions as faith, compassion, and the path of skillful means. These two analogies are crucial points that enable one to perfect stability. Through training in this way, one’s mind will naturally become still without deliberately focusing on an object, and it is said that when this happens, the foundation of concentration has been laid.
gsum pa nang gi dpe gcig ni/
c) One Inner Analogy

thog mar song ste/ 'di ltar 'byung ba'i rnam par rtog pa ji snyed pa rnams ni/ thog ma dang bar dang*/ mtha' mar rim bzhin du/ dmigs pa dang*/ bdag po dang*/ rgyu dang*/ de ma thag pa'i rkyen bzhi'i rtsa ba dang bral bas sgyu ma'i rta glang lta bu/ rang gi ngo bo de de bzhin du ma grub pas ming gis btag pa tsam las don gyis stong pa mo gsham gyi bu lta bu byed las dang bral ba rmi lam gyi sta res rmi lam gyi ljon shing gcod pa lta bu ste/ mdor na 'di ltar snang zhing rtog pa'i chos thams cad ni rmi lam gyi snang ba dang mtshungs te/ mtshungs chos ni rmi lam gyi skabs su mar me gsal bar snang na'ang*/ de'i rgyu'am rtsa ba kong bu dang*/ sdong bu dang*/ snum dang*/ me ste bzhi dang*/ mar me rang gi ngo bo dmar lam lam 'bar ba dang*/ mar me'i phyed las sel byed kyi 'od dang*/ bsal bya'i mun pa ste de thams cad rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa bzhin du 'di ltar snang zhing rtog pa'i chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa'i stong par shes pa'i ngang nas dmigs pa med pa'i snying brtse chen po mi g.yo bar goms pas mtshan ma thams cad rang sar grol zhing*/ dag pa'i phrin las lhun gyis grub par 'gyur ro/ /

In the beginning, middle, and end, respectively, Phenomena have no root, essential nature, or function, Like a lamp in a dream. Through training in compassion, without moving, all is accomplished. Every one of the thoughts that arise is, to begin with, devoid of the root of the four conditions—namely, the objective, dominant, causal, and immediatelypreceding conditions—and it is therefore like a horse or elephant in a magical illusion. Then, its essential nature is similarly nonexistent, and apart from merely being labeled with a name, it is ultimately empty, like the child of a barren woman. Finally, it is devoid of function, like an ax in one’s dream that is used to fell a tree in the dream. In short, all the phenomena that appear or are thought are similar to the appearances in a dream. In what way are they similar? Although a lamp in a dream {542} appears to shine, the four causal factors or roots of the lamp (namely, the oil reservoir, wick, oil, and flame) are all devoid of intrinsic existence. The same is true of its essential nature (the shining red light) and its function (the dispersing of light), and the darkness that is dispelled. Likewise, all phenomena that appear or are thought like this are devoid of intrinsic existence: they are empty. If one trains in great compassion without moving from the knowledge of that, all concepts will be naturally undone and the pure activities will be spontaneously accomplished.
gsum pa
3) The Lowliest Beings with Middling Faculties
dbang po 'bring gi tha ma'i ngo sprod la gsum las/
For the lowliest beings with middling faculties, who are introduced by means of three direct approaches, there are three introductions.
dang po nyams myong thog babs gsum gyis bsgrub bya blo gros dri ma med par sad pa'i ngo sprod ni/
a) Introduction to Awakening the Uncontaminated Mind That Is to Be Accomplished by Means of Three Ways of Dealing Directly with Experiences

'gro 'ong sogs te/ 'di ltar bsgrub bya'i chos bde gsal mi rtog pa gsum dang*/ chos gsum gyi mtshan nyid 'gro 'ong gnas gsum dang bral ba gsum dang*/ de'i gnas lugs stong pa nyid dang*/ mtshan ma med pa dang*/ smon pa med pa ste rnam thar sgo gsum mo/ / de yang rnam par rtog pa 'gro ba dang*/ 'ong ba dang*/ gnas pa gsum ni dang por skye ba'i rgyu/ bar du gnas pa'i ngo bo/ tha mar 'gags pa'i 'bras bu'i rnam rtog thams cad kyis stong pa'i stong pa nyid rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum du dag pa la/ zag med kyi bde ba chen po dang*/ rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba dang*/ gang du'ang rnam par mi rtog pa ste/ de lta bu'i bde gsal mi rtog pa'i 'bras bu mngon du gyur pa'i ngang du/ zab mo don la blo gros kyi mig rnam par dag pa'i rnal 'byor pa bzang po rnams kyis rtag tu mnyam par bzhag par bya'o/ /

The three aspects of purity and emptiness Regarding arising, remaining, and ceasing in going, coming, and staying Are great bliss, luminosity, and absence of thought. Thus do the wise settle in equipoise. The aspects that have to be accomplished are bliss, clarity, and no-thought; the three freedoms from going, coming, and staying, which are the nature of the three aspects; and their mode of being, the three doors of perfect liberation—emptiness, absence of attributes, and absence of expectancy. In that regard they are devoid of thoughts that go, come, and stay—they are emptiness, devoid of any thoughts for which there is, in the first place, a cause for their arising; in the middle, an essence that stays; and in the end, a result that ceases. They are pure as the three doors of perfect liberation. These correspond to untainted great bliss, intrinsic luminosity, and total absence of thought. Good practitioners with the pure eye of intelligence regarding the profound meaning should always settle in meditative equipoise in the state of realization of this resultant bliss, clarity, and absence of thought.
gnyis pa sbyor ba thog babs gsum gyis sgrub byed sgom pa phun sum tshogs par ngo sprod pa ni/
b) Introduction to the Perfect Meditation That Enables One to Attain Accomplishment by Means of Three Direct Applications

snying rje chen po sogs te/ dang po thabs kyi sbyor ba ni/ nam mkha' dang mnyam pa'i 'gro ba la/ rgya mtsho dang mnyam pa'i bsam pa snying rje chen po mdun du bzhag pa ste sngon du 'gro bas/ ri rab dang mnyam pa'i byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa rlabs po che rjes su bsgrub par dam bca'/ gnyis pa shes rab kyi sbyor ba ni/ bsam sbyor de nyid kyi ngo bo la so sor rtog pa'i shes rab kyi dpyad cing dmigs par shes pa la ma yengs par rtag tu blta zhing*/ gsum pa byin rlabs kyi sbyor ba ni/ yid dam gyi lha bsgom pa dang*/ bla ma'i rnal 'byor gyi sgo nas gsol ba gdab pa'o/ / de lta bu'i sbyor ba yis sgrub pa po rnams rang gi sems spros pas dub pa bde chen gyi ngang du ngal gso bar bya'o/ /

By settling, first, with great compassion, Looking continuously at that state without distraction, And meditating on the deity and the teacher, Practitioners will find rest. First, the application of skillful means. Beginning with the thought, as boundless as the ocean, {543} of great compassion for beings as numerous as space is vast, one should promise to accomplish the limitless activities of the bodhisattvas’ practice, which is as immense as Mount Meru. Second, the application of wisdom. Recognizing, by observation and analysis with discerning wisdom, the nature of that same attitude and practice, watch constantly without distraction. Third, the application of blessings. Meditate on the yidam deity and pray with the guru yoga. By means of these applications, practitioners will tire of their mental elaborations and find rest in the state of great bliss.
gsum pa rnam rtog thog babs gsum gyis sgrub pa'i 'gal rkyen lam du slong ba ni
c) Incorporating Conditions That Hinder Accomplishment into the Path by Means of Three Ways of Dealing Directly with Thoughts

bu nyon sogs te/ bu zhes rang gi sras la nye ba'i mtshan nas bos te khyod nyon cig ces gzhan du ma yengs par gdams nas gang mnyan par bya ba/ dang po lam du bslang bya ni/ khyod kyi rgyud la gang dang gang shar ba'i rnam par rtog pa thams cad do/ / gnyis pa de lam du bslang na nus pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/ rnam par rtog pa des 'khor ba'i rgya mtsho chen po 'dir thog mar bdag ma bcings/ mthar bdag ma grol ba'i phyir te/ dper na chu snod du zla ba'i gzugs brnyan shar ba na chu snod kyis gzugs brnyan bcings pa'ang med/ snod chags nas chu bo ba na zla ba'i gzugs brnyan grol ba'ang med de nam mkha'i zla ba rang bzhin las ma g.yos pa bzhin/ rnam rtog shar tsam nas chos nyid rang mal las g.yo ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / gsum pa ji ltar slong ba'i nyams len ni/ dang po ma yengs par bzhag pa ral bskor mkhan g.yul du zhugs pa lta bu/ bar du ma bcos par btsa' ba la mkhas pa glang rdzi mkhas pas glang po che skyong ba lta bu/ tha mar rang dgar btang ba la mkhas pa rdzing thog nas bya 'phur ba lta bu ste/ de rnams ni rgyas par khrid yig las 'byung ba ltar ro/ / gdams pa 'di ni gzhung 'di nyid kyi snying po'i snying po/ rnam rtog lam du slong ba'i thabs khyad par can yin pas na/ kye ho zhes ngo mtshar ba'i tshig gis mtshams sbyar nas/ sems can thams cad thog ma med pa nas rang gi sems 'khor ba sdug bsngal kyi rgya mtshor dub par gyur pa thabs 'di lta bu la brten nas gnyug ma rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba'i dbyings su ngal gsol bar gyis shig ces gdams pa'o/ /

Listen, child: whatever thoughts you have, Because they neither bind nor free you here, Do not be distracted, do not fabricate, leave things as they are— Behold, find rest from weariness! “Child” refers to [the author’s] own spiritual heir, whom he is addressing familiarly, instructing them to listen without getting distracted. What they should listen to is as follows. First, what has to be incorporated into the path is all the various thoughts that arise in your mind stream. Second, the reason that it is possible to incorporate them into the path is that in the beginning those thoughts have not bound one here in the ocean of samsara, and in the end they do not free one. To make an analogy, when the reflection of the moon appears in a bowl of water, there is no binding of the reflection in the water bowl. And when the bowl is broken and the water flows away, there is no releasing of the moon’s reflection. The moon in the sky has not changed in nature. Similarly, thoughts merely appear and there is no moving from their original state, ultimate reality. Third [is] how to practice taking thoughts as the path. First, settle without distraction, like a swordsman entering the fray. In the middle, be skilled in simply watching,[9] like an elephant keeper looking after an elephant. {544} In the end, be skilled in leaving things as they are, like a bird flying from the top of a ship.[10] These are as they appear in detail in the instruction manual.[11] This instruction is the very essence of this source text. It is an extraordinary means for making thoughts the path. This is why [the last line] begins with “Behold,” an expression implying a sense of wonder, and instructs sentient beings, who from the very beginning have worn out their minds in the ocean of suffering that is samsara, to rely on this method for resting in the natural state, the intrinsically radiant expanse of reality.
gnyis pa
B) Beings with the Most Basic Faculties

dbang po tha ma'i ngo sprod la gsum/ dbang po tha ma'i rab la rig dri ma med par bstan pa sbyor ba gsum ngo sprod/ / tha ma'i 'bring la gzung ba dang 'dzin pa'i rtsa ba bcad pa sgo mo gsum gyi ngo sprod/ tha ma'i tha ma la mtshan ma dbyings su bstim pa/ dgag sgrub gsum gyi ngo sprod do/ /

For beings with the most basic faculties, there are three introductions. For the best of those with the most basic faculties, there is the introduction to three trainings that show that one’s own awareness is free of contaminants. For middling beings with the most basic faculties, there is the introduction to cutting the root of dualistic grasping in relation to the three doors. For the lowliest of beings with the most basic faculties, there is the introduction to three affirmations and negations that dissolve concepts into the expanse of reality.
dang po
1) The Best Beings with the Most Basic Faculties
['di] la'ang gsum las/
The introduction for the best of those with the most basic faculties is given in three verses.
dang po dpe don gsum ro snyoms zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung 'brel du ston pa ni/
a) Three Analogies That Show Same Taste in the Union of Sustained Calm and Profound Insight

gzugs brnyan sogs te/ gzugs brnyan dang gzugs dngos dang*/ brag ca dang sgra dngos/ dbang pos dngos su mthong ba dang*/ rmi lam gyi skabs su nyams su myong ba rnams rjes su dran pa'i yid la legs par dpyad pas/ rnam pa ni gzugs brnyan sogs snang zhing*/ ngo bo ni gzugs dngos sogs kyang rang bzhin gyis ma grub pa chos thams cad snang tsam nas bden pa med par shes par byas te/ chags sdang skye ba'i yul thams cad rang bzhin gyis ma grub pas yul can shes pas bden med du shes pa na gzung 'dzin thams cad rang sar grol bar 'gyur ba yin no/ / de la brten nas ting nge 'dzin rtse gcig tu gnas pa'i zhi gnas 'grub pas na de dang de byung gi 'brel bar grub pa dang*/ mtshan ma spong byed kyi thabs zad par lhag mthong bsgom pa'i sbyor ba nyams su blang par bya ste/ dang po bsgom bya'i dngos po rtse gcig pas mdun du bya/ bar du rtse gcig pa nyid rang ngo shes pa'i sgo nas sor bzhag / mthar de nyid kyi dmigs pas blo'i spu ris zad par bya'o/ /

Reflections and forms, echoes and sounds, Real events and dreams—for the mind that thinks of these Combine concentration and the meditation Of connection and exhaustion. If one carefully examines the mind that thinks of reflections and actual forms, echoes and actual sounds, direct perceptions with the sense organs and experiences in a dream, one will understand that while the appearance aspects such as reflections appear, the entities such as actual forms do not exist intrinsically: all phenomena, apart from merely appearing, have no true existence. Since all the objects that give rise to attachment and aversion do not exist intrinsically, the subjective consciousness does not have any true existence,[12] and if one recognizes this, all dualistic subject-object apprehension will naturally dissolve. On this basis one should practice the combined meditation of sustained calm, remaining one-pointed in concentration, {545} and of profound insight, by which causal relationships are established and the methods for eliminating conceptual attributes are exhausted. First, one begins with one-pointed concentration on the object of meditation. Then, by recognizing that one-pointedness as one’s own nature, one leaves it as it is. Finally, by not conceptualizing even that, one should put an end to the mind’s fine distinctions.
gnyis pa shes rab gsum gyi sgron me spar bas sgrib g.yogs kyi mun pa bsal ba ni/
b) Dispelling the Darkness of Obscurations by Lighting the Lamp of the Three Kinds of Superior Understanding

so sor rtog dang sogs te/ 'gyu ba gang shes thams cad la so sor rtog pa'i shes rab kyis dpyad pas rang bzhin med par shes pa dang*/ mthar so sor rtog pa'i shes rab nyid kyang rten dang bral bar shes pa dang*/ shes bya dang shes byed kyi blo'i 'dzin pa zhi ba'i ngang rtag tu rgyun mi 'chad par bsgoms byung gi shes rab rgyud la bsten pa ste/ de lta bu'i shes rab gsum gyis rim pa bzhin du/ bsregs bcad brdar ba'i gser bzhin dang*/ bud shing zad pa'i me bzhin dang*/ sprin dang khug rna la sogs pas 'gyur ba med pa'i nam mkha' bzhin du spang bya gzung ba'i gnas lugs ji lta ba bzhin du shes par byed pa dang*/ gnyen po'i 'dzin med pa'i rtog pa ngang gis zhi bar byed pa dang*/ glo bur sgrib gnyis bag chags dang bcas pa dag par byed pa yin no/ /

Discernment, absence of basis, And constant, unbroken meditation Are like gold, like fire, like space, Understanding, dissolving, and purifying. By using discerning wisdom to examine all the thought movements that one recognizes, one comes to understand that they are devoid of intrinsic existence. In the end, one understands that that discerning wisdom too is without any basis. And there is the superior understanding that comes from constant, unbroken meditation on the state in which the mental apprehensionof a knower and something to be known is stilled. These three kinds of superior understanding that one should develop in one’s mind stream are respectively like gold that has been flamed, cut, and polished; like fire that burns up fuel; and like the sky, which is unaltered by clouds, mist, and so forth. They enable one respectively to understand the exact mode of being of an apprehended object or something to be eliminated, to naturally dissolve the concepts of an apprehending subject or a remedy, and to purify the two adventitious obscurations along with habitual tendencies.
gsum pa snang ba gsum gyi ye shes sad pas yon tan rin po che'i sgo dbye ba ni/
c) Opening the Door of Precious Qualities by Awakening the Gnosis of the Three Aspects of Appearance

snang med de snang sogs te/ gzhi rang bzhin gyis sdang ba med kyang lam de'i stobs kyis snang*/ 'bras bu rkyen gyis bsgyur pas sna tshogs su snang ba gsum gyi dpe ni rim par/ nam mkha' rang bzhin med pa dang*/ me long la gzugs brnyan 'char ba dang*/ shel gong dag par yul gyi rkyen gyis kha dog sna tshogs su snang ba bzhin no/ / de lta bus tshul nyams 'og tu tshud pas mnyam par bzhag pa'i stobs kyis yon tan rin po che'i gter sgo byed pa yin te/ snang med ma bcos pa'i ngang du sad par byed pas de'i ngang la rtse gcig tu tu gnas pa'i ting nge 'dzin dang*/ de snang rang snang du sad par byas pas rang snang rang sar grol ba'i yi ge dang*/ rkyen snang rten 'brel gyi snang ba sad par byas pas rten 'bral dag pa gzungs kyi sgo 'byed par byed cing*/ de ltar na ting nge 'dzin gyi gzhi las ye shes kyi ngo bo grub ste gzungs kyis mi 'bral bar 'dzin la de mthus mthar thug rim pa bzhin du/ chos sku dang*/ longs sku dang*/ sprul pa'i sku ste de rnams kyi rtogs pa rgyud la 'char bar byed pa yin no/ /

Nonappearance, appearance, and circumstantial appearance Are like space, a mirror, and a pure crystal. This is realized by means of concentration, Gnosis, and the power of memory. The ground is naturally devoid of appearance;[13] yet, because of the path, there is appearance; and the result, brought about through transformation by conditions, is appearance in all kinds of different ways. These three aspects of appearance are illustrated by the following analogies, respectively: the sky, which is devoid of intrinsic nature; a mirror, in which reflections appear, and a pure crystal, in which, because of conditions, all sorts of colors appear. {546} Through one’s making an experience of this and meditating on it, a treasury of precious qualities is opened. As a result of one’s being awakened into the uncontrived state of nonappearance, one dwells one-pointedly in that state and the door of concentration is opened. From one’s being awakened to appearances being one’s own self-experience, self-experience dissolves into itself and the door of gnosis is opened. And from one’s being awakened to circumstantial appearances—the appearances of dependent origination—interdependent connections are purified and the door of the power of memory is opened. Thus, from the ground of concentration, the essence of gnosis is accomplished. And through the power of memory, one holds these inseparably. Because of that, ultimately there arises in one’s mind stream the realization, respectively, of the body of truth, the body of perfect enjoyment, and the body of manifestation.
gnyis pa
2) Middling Beings with the Most Basic Faculties
dbang po tha ma'i 'bring gi ngo sprod la gsum las/
The introduction for middling beings with the most basic faculties is given in three verses.
dang po lus kyi sgo mo dbang po lnga la brten nas bzung ba dang g.yeng ba rdul spong ba ni/
a) Getting Rid of the Grasped Object and the Dust of Distraction in Relation to the Door of the Body’s Five Senses

mthong ba mnyam bzhag sogs te/ sgo lnga'i dbang po la brten nas yul lnga mthong ba na/ mthong mkhan rang gi ngang du lhod kyis glod la had de mnyam par bzhag pas/ snang yul ma 'gags la der 'dzin dang bral ba'i 'od gsal 'char ba yin te/ de tshe mthong ba gang yin pa dang de don gyis ma mthong ba yin pa'i rgyu mtshan/ de la gzung 'dzin gyi zhen pa ma skyes pa'i phyir/ de ltar shin tu rnam par mi rtog pa'i 'od gsal la rtse gcig tu gnas pas/ mtshan ma'i rnam par g.yeng ba'i rdul dang bral ba nyid do/ /

Perception, in equipoise, is luminosity, At which time perception has not arisen. Remaining one-pointed, utterly free of concepts, One is freed of the dust of distraction. When one perceives the five sense objects through the door of the five sense organs, if one settles in a loosely relaxed and blank equipoise, in the natural state of the perceiver, the appearing object is not blocked and there arises a luminosity in which there is no grasping at the object. At that time, whatever one perceives is, in truth, not perceived, and the reason is that dualistic clinging to it has not arisen. By resting one-pointedly in that utterly nonconceptual luminosity, one is freed of the dust of distraction by conceptual attributes.
gnyis pa gang gi sgo mo rlung la brten nas 'dzin pa yid kyi skyes bu bsad pa ni/
b) Killing the Grasping Mind in Relation to the Door of Speech, the Subtle Winds

rlung ni gar 'gro sogs te/ sems ni rlung gi bzhon pa can yin pas rlung ni gar 'gro ba der sems 'gro zhing gnas pas/ de nyid lus kyi khyim dbu ma'i nang du bum can gyi sbyor bas btson du bzung nas/ yid kyi skyes bu rang ngo shes pa'i mtshon gyis bsnun nas byed rtsol dang bral ba'i dbyings su bsad par byas pas/ rlung gi bzhon pa de med na/ sems ni gang du 'gro ste mi 'phye bo bzhin du rang sar gnas par 'gyur ro/ /

Wherever the wind goes, the mind goes too. But if you hold it prisoner inside the body’s house, You’ll put to death the ordinary mind; Without a mount, where can the mind go? The mind[14] is the rider of the subtle wind, so wherever the subtle wind goes, the mind goes and stays. By applying the vase exercise in the central channel of the dwelling place that is one’s body, one holds the subtle wind prisoner, {547} and one [can] stab the ordinary mind[15] with the weapon of recognition of one’s own nature, putting it to death in the expanse free of deliberate activity. Thus, without the subtle wind to ride on, where can the mind go? It will be like a cripple and remain where it is.
gsum pa yid kyi sgo mo kun rtog gi rang bzhin rtogs pas gzung 'dzin gnyis ka'i bag chags gzhom pa ni/
c) Destroying the Habitual Tendencies of Both an Apprehending Subject and Apprehended Object by Realizing the Nature of Conceptual Thought in Relation to the Door of the Mind

thams cad rang bzhin sogs ste/ kun rtog thams cad kyi rang bzhin ni ma bcos pa'i gnyug ma'i ngo bo las mi 'da' bas/ / rnam pa'i kun rtog thams cad ni rkyen gyi gzhan dbang las byung ba yin no/ / des na rang bzhin gsum gyi de kho na legs par shes na/ kun rtog shar tsam na kun rtog nyid rang bzhin med par byed do/ / de la rang bzhin gsum ni ngo bo'i rang bzhin bcos su med pa/ rkyen gyi rang bzhin du mar 'char ba/ gnyis su med pa'i rang bzhin ro gcig pa'o/ /

The nature of all is uncontrived: All thoughts depend on conditions. If one knows the three natures, Thoughts make thoughts themselves disappear. The nature of all conceptual thoughts is nothing other than the essence that is the uncontrived natural state. All conceptual thoughts arise in dependence on conditions. If one properly understands the true state of the three natures, as soon as thoughts arise, they make the thoughts themselves intrinsically nonexistent. What are the three natures? The uncontrived state, the nature of the essence; appearance in multiple forms, the nature of conditions; and the single taste, the nature of nonduality.
gsum pa
3) The Lowliest of Beings with the Most Basic Faculties
dbang po tha ma'i tha ma la ngo sprod pa'i tshul gsum las/
The introduction for the lowliest of beings with the most basic faculties is made in three ways.
dang po nam mkha' bsgom pa'i rnal 'byor la brten nas grub bsal gyi mtshan ma dbyings su bstim pa ni/
a) Dissolving the Concepts of Establishment and Refutation into the Expanse of Reality through the Practice of Meditation on Space

mthong bas grub dang sogs te/ shes bya'i yul 'di rnams mthong bas grub par 'jog pa dang*/ shes rab kyis gzhig pa na med ces 'jog pa ni rnam rtog gis kun tu brtags par zad kyi/ sems nyid kyi gshis 'di la 'dod nas cir yang grub pa med pas/ bu kye zhes nye ba'i tshig gis bos nas nam mkha' bsgom par byos shig ces gdams pa'o/ / nam mkha' sgom pa'i tshul ni gsum ste/ phyi'i nam mkha' sgrib pa med pa la mig che re gtad pa dang*/ nang gi nam mkha' sems ma bcos pa la blo bzhag pa dang gsang ba'i nam mkha' phyi nang cir yang mi dmigs pas rang dgar bsgom pa'o/ /

Existence when we perceive And nonexistence when we scrutinize are just concepts. Nothing whatsoever here exists. O child, meditate on space! When one perceives knowable objects, one postulates that they exist. And when one scrutinizes them with wisdom, one establishes their nonexistence. These are nothing other than conceptual imputations. But here in the fundamental nature of the mind itself, from the beginning, there is nothing whatsoever that exists. Therefore, O child, instructs the author, addressing us familiarly, meditate on space. There are three ways to meditate on space. The outer way is to stare at the sky, unobscured by anything. The inner way is to settle the rational mind on the uncontrived, spacelike state of mind. And the secret way is to meditate on space without any outer or inner references, as it is. {548}
gnyis pa rang dgar bsgom pa'i rnal 'byor la brten nas rkyen bral gyi mtshan ma dbyings su bstim pa ni/
b) Dissolving the Concepts of Absence of Conditions into the Expanse of Reality through the Practice of Leaving-As-It-Is

ga bur dang ni sogs te/ 'di ltar ga bur dang ni de yi dri gnyis po/ phan tshun gcig la gcig brten pas ldog pa so sor phye 'ang*/ ngo bo dbyer med pa yin te/ ga bur de med na de'i dri 'ang med la/ dri med na ga bur de yang med cing mi dmigs pa bzhin/ sems kyi rang bzhin la rkyen snang glo bur gyi 'khrul pa dang*/ rkyen dang bral ba rang byung so ma'i ye shes gnyis kyang phan tshun so sor ma yin cing tha mi dad pas rang dgar sgoms shig ces gdams pa'o/ / rang dgar ji ltar sgom pa'i tshul ni gsum ste/ gshis gnyug ma rang dga' ma bcos so mar 'jog pa dang*/ rtsal rnam rtog rang dga' ci skyes skyer gtong ba dang*/ ngo bo skye med rang dga' skyes tsam nas skye rgyu ma dmigs pas ma skyes par ro snyoms pa'o/ /

Camphor and its smell are interrelated: One cannot have one without the other. Likewise, conditions and absence of conditions Are not separate, so meditate leaving things as they are. Camphor and its smell both depend on each other: they can be separated as aspects, but their nature is inseparable. Without camphor, there cannot be the smell of camphor. And if the smell of camphor is absent, camphor too must be absent, nor would one ever think that it is present. In the same way, with regard to the nature of the mind, there are two aspects: delusion, with its adventitious conditioned perceptions, and gnosis, which is unconditioned, spontaneous, fresh. But these two aspects are not distinct and separate; they are indistinguishable. So, instructs the author, meditate leaving things just as they are. There are three ways in which one meditates leaving things as they are. Settle in the fundamental, uncontrived, fresh state, as it is. Whatever thoughts arise as its display, leave them as they are; let them go as they arise. And when they have just arisen, as they are, the unborn nature, experience it as the same taste in being unborn, without having any concept of there being anything to arise.
gsum pa rnam rtog gsod pa'i rnal 'byor la brten nas mnyam pa dang mi mnyam pa'i mtshan ma dbyings su bstim pa ni/
c) Dissolving Concepts of Sameness and Not Sameness in the Expanse [of Reality] through the Practice of Killing Conceptual Thoughts

mnyam pa'i sems kyis sogs te/ de la nang mnyam nyid khyab brdal chen po'i sems kyis g.yo ba'i yid blo bur ba 'gog / phyi mi mnyam pa du ma dang*/ smig rgyu la sogs pa'i snang nyams sna tshogs kyang mnyam nyid chen po'i gdams pa dran pa'i thag pas 'ching bar byed de ltar nyams su blangs pas nam zhig gi tshe mnyam pa dang mi mnyam pa gnyis kar 'dzin pa dang bral ba ni mnyam bzhag chen po ste/ des rnam par rtog pa thams cad gsod par byed do/ / rnam rtog gsod pa'i tshul la'ang gsum ste/ tha mal pa'i rnam rtog dran pas gsod/ dran pa'i rnam rtog rang ngo shes pas gsod/ rang ngo shes pa'i rnam rtog mnyam pa'i nyid kyis gsod pa'o/ /
rtsa ba'i sa bcad gnyis pa gcig car ba byin rlabs dbang gis grol ba'i ngo sprod kyi man ngag
b. Pith Instructions for Those Who Gain Accomplishment at a Single Stroke, Who Are Freed by the Power of Blessings
['di] la bzhi las/
These pith instructions are given in four verses.
dang po dag byed bum dbang gis dran rtog dpyis phyin par sbyang ba ni/
i. Training in Bringing Thoughts to an End by Means of the Purifying Vase Empowerment

khrus byas sogs te/ phyi bum pa'i chus bkru ba dang*/ nang swa b+ha ba sogs sngags sbyang ba dang*/ gsang ba chos thams cad kyi de kho na nyid la ma dag pa til 'bru tsam yang med par shes pa'i khrus byas nas/ rig pa gcer bu'i ngang du sbyangs pas dag par 'dzin pa'i dri na 'ang bral ba nam mkha'i gos gyon la/ rnam par rtogs pa brten med du bsgoms pas rang grol du bsregs pa'i sbyin sreg bya zhing*/ bags chags phra mo dran pa'i thal ba'ang bde ba nyams su myong gi 'jug ngogs/ gsal ba ye shes kyi 'jug ngogs mi rtog pa ting nge 'dzin gyi 'jug ngogs su/ bsam gtan gyi chu dang*/ ye shes kyi rlung gis lhan cig tu sbyang bar byos shig ces gdams pa'o/ /
gnyis pa pho nya gsang ba'i dbang gis dam tshig gi phyag rgya dbang du bya ba ni/
ii. Mastering the Samaya Mudrā by Means of the Secret Consort Empowerment

snod bcud sogs te/ snod bcud dang 'dra ba ni lus dang rlung ste rlung lus la brten nas gnas pas so/ / rlung de dang 'grogs pa ni sems kyi rgyun te/ de ltar na snga ma lus ni brtan pa dang*/ phyi ma rlung sems gnyis ni g.yo ba/ nam mkha' ni rang bzhin gyis 'od gsal ba'i dbyings/ nyi ma gtum mo'i me/ zla ba kun+da/ sgra gcan 'dzin ni rlung sems kha sbyor/ de las skyes pa'i nyams 'od gsal ni me khyer te/ de la sogs pa'i rtags snang 'char ba'o/ / char ni mi rtog pa ste sprin las char chen po thogs med du 'bebs pa ltar bde ba dang 'od gsal 'dres pa'i rtsal las byung ba'o/ / bde ba ni bung ba ste/ bung bas sbrang rtsi'i bcud len pa ltar 'od gsal dang mi rtog pa zung du 'jug pa'i don nyams su myongs pa las byung ba'o/ / des mtshon pa'i gsang ba'i dbang gi ye shes kyis dam tshig gi phyag rgya rtsa rlung thig le dbang du 'gyur ba yin no/ /
gsum pa shes rab ye shes kyi dbang gis lhan cig skyes pa'i ro myong ba ni/
iii. Tasting the Flavor of Coemergent [Wisdom] by Means of the Empowerment of Wisdom and Gnosis

sna tshogs yid kyi sogs te/ sna tshogs pa'i yid kyi me tog ni phyi nang gsang ba de kho na nyid kyi phyag rgya'o/ / de la tshul bzhin du bsten pas dga' ba/ mchod dga'/ khyad dga'/ lhan skyes kyi dga' ba rnam pa bzhi'i bcud blangs te/ zhu bde lhan cig skyes pa'i ro myang ba la brten nas/ sgrub pa po'i yid kyis skyes bu dpes mtshon pa'i ye shes kyis tshim par byed do/ /

In the multicolored flower of the mind One takes the essence of the four joys: When one experiences the innate, The mind, like a person, is satiated. The multicolored flower of the mind refers to the outer, inner, secret, and thatness mudrās. By making use of these correctly, one takes the essence of the four joys—joy, supreme joy, extraordinary joy, and innate joy. Based on the experience of the coemergent melting bliss, the practitioner’s mind, illustrated here by analogy with a person, is satiated with gnosis.
bzhi pa phyag rgya rnam par rol pa'i dbang gis kun spyod rgyu yan du spyod pa ni/
iv. Observing the Spontaneous Conduct of a Wanderer by Means of the Empowerment of the Manifestation of Mudrā

lus rlung sogs te/ de la lus ni dag pa'i lus lha'i skur bsgom pa dang*/ mchog gi lus sgyu mar mos pa dang*/ phun sum tshogs pa'i lus 'od gsal du dag pa'o/ / rlung ni g.yo ba'i rlung la las sbyor nus pas phyi nang 'gugs 'dren sogs grub pa dang*/ brtan pa'i rlung rdo rjer ltar 'dzin nus pas 'byung ba'i gnod pas mi tshugs pa dang*/ mi phyed pa'i rlung nam 'dzin pa'i tshe bde stong zung 'jug gi ye shes 'dren nus pa'o/ / rtsa ni sgyu ma'i rtsa chen a ba d+hu ti sbyangs pa dang*/ nam mkha'i rtsa chen po chos thams cad kyi de kho na nyid bsgom pa dang*/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i rtsa chen po chos kyi dbyings mngon du gyur pa'o/ / de lta bu'i phyag rgya de yis lus ngag yid la rgyas gdab cing bcing par byas pas drod thob pa la thogs pa med pa 'byung ba yin no/ / drod ni bzhi ste/ bde ba dang*/ gsal ba dang*/ mi rtog pa dang*/ ro snyoms pa'i drod de/ drod thob nas kun spyod mtha' gcig tu nges par mi bya ste/ gza' gtad med pa'i spyod pas phyogs ris med pa'i phrin las mkha' khyab tu bskyang bar bya'o/ / zhes pa'i don to/ /

Bind the body, speech, and mind With the mudrās of body, wind, and the great channel. There will be no impediment to attaining warmth. Do not be fixed in conduct. “Body” refers to the pure body, the visualization of the deity’s body; the sublime body considered as an illusion; and the perfect body purified as clear light. “Wind” [is of three kinds]: Through the ability to apply the activities to the moving wind, one accomplishes the outer and inner summoning and drawing, and so on. Through the ability to hold the stable wind like a vajra, one is immune to harm from spirits. And when one holds the indestructible wind, one is able to develop the gnosis of the union of bliss and emptiness. “Channel” [is again of three kinds]: The great illusory channel is the trained central channel. The great space channel refers to meditation on the ultimate state of all phenomena. And the great inconceivable channel is the realization of the expanse of reality. If one seals and binds one’s body, speech, and mind with these mudrās, there will be no impediment to one’s attaining “warmth,” the signs of progress. There are four such signs: bliss, clarity, no-thought, and equal taste. Having attained these, one should not be one-sided and fixed in one’s conduct, meaning that {551} one should maintain the limitless and impartial activities pervading all space by conducting oneself without concepts.
gsum pa
C. Conclusion
mjug gi don la gnyis/ gzhung gi rdzogs byang dang*/ lo tsA ba'i 'gyur byang ngo*/ /
The conclusion is divided into two: (1) a statement marking the completion of the text and (2) the translator’s colophon.
dang po ni/
1. Statement Marking the Completion of the Text

rnal 'byor pa sogs te/ thabs dang shes rab zung du 'jug pa'i zab mo'i don la blo sbyor bar byed pa'i rnal 'byor pa rnams kyi rang gi sems gzung 'dzin gyi spros pa sna tshogs pas dub pa ngal gso bar byed pa'i man ngag tshigs su bcad pa nyi shu rtsa lnga pa zhes bya ba/ brjod bya chos thams cad kyi gnas lugs de kho na nyid ji bzhin pa rnal du mtshon pa byed pa'i thabs/ rjod byed ma bcos pa'am/ lhug par brjod pas na do ha ste/ de lta bu'i rdo rje'i tshig gi gzhung lhag ma ma lus par bstan zin pas na rdzogs so zhes gsungs so/ /

This completes the song of realization pointing out the authentic state of thatness, called A Pith Instruction in Twenty-Five Verses That Enables Practitioners to Find Rest in Their Own Minds. This text is called “a pith instruction in twenty-five verses that enables practitioners” who apply their minds to the profound meaning of the union of skillful means and wisdom “to find rest in own their minds,” wearied by the multifarious elaborations of dualistic apprehension. Its subject is the method for pointing out the authentic state of thatness, the actual condition of all phenomena. And what conveys this is a dohā—a song of realization—for it does so in an uncontrived or effortless manner. This source text of vajra verses has been taught in full, with no omissions, so it is now completed.
gnyis pa ni/
2. Translator’s Colophon

jo bo spyan ras gzigs sogs te/ jo bo ni Ar+Ya zhes pa'i sgra las drangs na 'phags pa'i rje btsun ste rang gi lhag pa'i lha zhes pa'i sgra sbyar ba'o/ / de gang zhen/ snying rje chen po'i spyan ras gzigs kyis 'gro ba kun la dus rtag tu gzigs pa'i rgyal ba'i sras po rnams kyi gtso bor gyur pas na spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug ces yongs su grags pa des/ shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa'i brjod bya thams cad chos 'phags kyi le'ur ting nge 'dzin gyi sgo nyi shu rtsa lngar bsdus pa dang rjes su mthun par/ do ha rdo rje'i tshigs su bcad pa'i nyi shu rtsa lnga 'di nyid dngos su gnang ba'i mod nas phyag rgya chen po mchog gi grub pa brnyes pa'i skyes bu/ zung 'jug gi don la blo sbyor bas rnal 'byor/ de rnams kyi gtso bor gyur pas dbang phyug / de yang 'phags pa'i sa brnyes pas chen po/ shrI dza ga ta mi tra A nan+da ste dpal 'gro ba'i bshes gnyen kun dga' zhes/ rgyal po'i sras su sku 'khrungs pa'i tshe khrom chen po'i dbus su yab sras mjal bas lha mi'i 'gro ba thams cad rab tu dga' bas mtshan de skad du btags pa dang*/ gnub nam mkha'i snying po'i dpon brgyud lo tsA ba ste 'jig rten gyi mig mtshan byams pa'i dpal zhes grags pa des/ bal po'i yul gyi bye brag dpal gu lang gser khang gi nags khrod am b+ha ri zhes grags pa'i sa'i mthong*/ mthong*/ par+pa ta'i bsil khang du legs sbyar gyi gzhung las bod kyi skad du bsgyur ba'o/ / zhes pa'i don to/ /

These verses that Lord Avalokiteshvara gave in person to the great master of yogis who had attained accomplishment, Shrī Jagatamitrānanda, were translated by him and the translator Jampa Pal in a summerhouse in the Ambara forest at the golden pagoda of Shrī Pashupati. “Lord” signifies the Sanskrit word ārya, meaning “noble and exalted,” a term applied to one’s yidam deity. Who is this referring to? To him who is universally known as Avalokiteshvara, so called because he is foremost among the bodhisattvas, the buddhas’ heirs, constantly watching over all beings with the eye of great compassion.[18] This dohā in twenty-five vajra verses is consistent with the summary of the whole content of the Perfection of Wisdom into twenty-five doors of concentration in the Dharmodgata chapter.[19] Avalokiteshvara gave it in person to someone who had attained the supreme accomplishment, the Great Seal, namely the great master of yogis Shrī Jagatamitrānanda (Glorious Joyful Teacher of Beings), [who is described] as a “yogi” because he applied his mind to the meaning of union, as a “master” because he was the chief of such yogis, and as “great” because he attained the noble levels. {552} Mitrayogin was given the name Glorious Joyful Teacher of Beings because during his birth as a prince, when father and son met in the midst of a great crowd, he delighted all beings, divine and human. The translator, [who came from] the aristocratic lineage of Nup Namkhai Nyingpo, was commonly known as Jampa Pal. He and Mitrayogin translated the original Sanskrit text into Tibetan in the summerhouse of Parpati in the sacred focal point known as the forest of Ambara at the golden pagoda of Shrī Pashupati in Nepal.

de ltar gzhung 'di la khro phu lo tsA ba chen po'i rnam bshad rgyas bsdus dang kun mkhyen bu ston rin po che'i mdo rgyud kyi lung sbyor dang*/ bar skabs kyi rnam bshad 'ga' zhig kyang snang ba las/ khro lo'i gsung rab dag gi don gyi snying po'i bcud bsdus te 'bru 'grel gtso bor bton pa'i tshul gyis bris pa yin la/ 'gran zla dang bral ba'i grub pa'i khyu mchog chen po'i bka' srol las byung ba'i gdams ngag khyad par du 'phags pa 'di nyid thos bsam gyis gtan la phab cing bsgom pas nyams su blang ba ni dal 'byor gyi rten la snying po len pa'i thabs mchog tu shes par bya'o/ /

For this source text there have appeared the detailed and concise commentaries by the great Tropu Lotsawa, a text by the omniscient Butön Rinpoche correlating it with the sutras and tantras, and a few incidental explanations. Of these, I have summarized the essential meaning of Tropu Lotsawa’s writings, mainly drawing on the word-by-word commentary. These extraordinary instructions have come through the oral tradition of the incomparable leader of accomplished beings. You should understand that to ascertain their meaning by hearing them and reflecting on them and to put them into practice by meditating on them is the very best way to make full use of one’s precious human body with its unique freedoms and advantages.
phyag chen gdams pa kun gyi phul/ / sems nyid ngal gso'i gzhung 'grel las/ / snying po bsdus pa'i legs byas kyis/ / 'gro kun zung 'jug mchog brnyes shog/ /
